Mishap: An Accidental Haunting is truly one of the most enjoyable, lushly animated, and atmospheric hidden object games out there.  Graphics-wise, it's the best game of this type I've seen or played - in terms of the puzzles, the comic book style introduction to each chapter, and the full-blown animation present at the beginning and end of the game as a whole.  Basically, you're helping a young couple - and the strange little ghost hunter who mysteriously turns up at their door - to find and trap the myriad of ghosts haunting their home.  Among all of the hidden objects you have to find across 30 unique rooms are the components the weird ghost hunter will use to trap the main spirits haunting each section.  You are also called upon to discover a number of lesser (and much more comical) spirits along the way.  The music and ambient sounds actually add to the experience, especially the dark ghostly chuckle you hear when you've found objects that will be used to trap a particular ghost.  Mishap also comes with as diverse a set of mini-games as you're likely to find in a game such as this - some are more enjoyable and challenging than others, but they are all optional for the player.  The game also comes with some extra features to make the whole experience a little more amusing - for every one of the pesky ghosts you're trapping, there's a funny story behind his/her demise.  Heck, the storyline of the game even throws in a surprise twist at the very end.I must admit, however, that I experienced some annoying technical problems that had a definite negative impact on my game experience.  After I completed the first two chapters, I was forced to endure a horrible and constant roar coming out of my speakers.  I could still make out the words and music on top of the sound, but it was a really annoying problem.  Sometimes it would clear itself up for a chapter ending or maybe even an entire chapter, but it always came back with a vengeance at some point.  I could find no problem with my sound settings, and reinstalling the game accomplished nothing in this regard.  That being the case, I have to lower my rating a little bit - but I still consider this a must-have item for hidden object game enthusiasts.
summary: A fantastic game marred, at least in my case, by some technical problems

reviewText: Overall, this is fun to play, but it's a bit short - it took me about five hours to complete.  One difference about this game is the lack of returns to the same room - each main room has three smaller rooms to explore, and you never go back to the same scene to find more objects.  I expected a longer game considering the size of the download, but a lot of that turned out to be animation.What I liked:- There's no time limit- The hidden objects aren't *too* difficult to find, but they take a bit of searching.- The storyline is well-written - it's funny, a bit sad, and charming in places.- The riddles are fun and relatively easy to solve.- The penalty for too many mis-clicks is rather high ::g:: (you'll see what I mean).- In addition to the usual objects and mini-games, there are some 'minor' ghosts to be captured, and they have some fun stories behind them.What I didn't like:- The mini-games are mostly hand-eye coordination/speed games, and I'm no good at those, but after an initial try, you can skip them.- Some objects are difficult to find because the graphics are a bit *too* cartoonish.- I expected some sort of interactive play at the end, but the characters wrap it up without any help.Overall, this game is a little different from the usual HOG formula, and I'd recommend it to anyone looking for something new.

reviewText: I have to take into consideration the cost of the game when I review it.  Did I get my three and a half dollars worth -- absolutely!  Would I recommend it at twenty dollars?  No, probably not.  It is a typical search and find game.  Some of the items in the inventory are combined for use in another scene.  However, unlike many games that make you figure out which objects go together in order to move ahead in the game, this one does that aspect for you.  Therefore, the search and find component is just that -- simple object searches.  There are mini games as well, some are quite fun.  They do, however, quickly become repititious.  The story line is okay and there is a feature that allows you to skip it if it is too boring.  A couple things that would have improved this game: 1) the developers should have made the player how to combine and use objects, 2) the story parts that were like movies should have either moved along faster or had options to forward to the next scene (similar to the dialog boxes), and 3) a greater variety of mini-games would have been nice.  All in all, a fun game to play.  It isn't too hard, but still enjoyable.  The hint system is good and you can skip any mini-game after a small amount of time.  It took about four hours to complete.
summary: Great for the price, but just misses the mark -- would still recommend

I have been hunting around for a suitable Wii remote charger. This is it. I found it.It is not perfect, but its about 90% of what I am asking for. Let me explain...First, a bit of description. The package includes a leaflet with instructions, a power wire attachment, the charging cradle, and 2 battery packs. Everything's in white. The power wire attachment taps power from the Wii adapter, you cannot plug it directly to the mains (more on that later).It is the induction type charger, which means its wireless, you just need to pop the controller onto the cradle to charge. No need to worry about any metal contact points being in contact, or inserting something into the hole, or insert a USB port into wherever, you get the idea.To assemble, attach the cradle to the Wii power adapter with the attachment, and replace your AA batteries in the Wii controllers with the provided battery packs. That's it.There is a switch at the back where you flip to turn it on. It will glow blue. Place an uncharged controller on it. It will then glow red on the side of the uncharged controller. Nice. It then turns blue again when it is fully charged.As you well know, the Wii's controllers have so many possible configurations now... Wiimote, Wiimote Plus, Wiimote with additional motion add on, with silicon skin, with nunchuks plugged in, etc.I had these problems to solve:1. I am sick of changing the AA batteries. You need to peel out the silicon skin.2. I hate rechargeable AA batteries because that means I have to keep removing the batteries (see problem 1).3. I am sick of unplugging all the parts (Motion plus, silicon skin, nunchuk....) every time I want to charge the remote so that it fits in the charger.4. I need a charger that doesn't take up much space, as I have so many chargers... PS3, PS3 Move, DSi XL, handphone, PSP, other controllers etc.On a whim, I bought this product.How did it solve my problems?1. and 2. It provides a pair of battery packs which you never have to remove. You can cover your controller with the silicon skin and never have to peel it off to change batteries.3. This charges by induction/contactless. You just place the controller on the cradle, without the need to remove any parts of the Wiimote. Yes, it doesn't matter if you have the silicon skin, or whatever fancy straps, nunchuks, or add-ons you have. Well of course, you gotta take it out of the Zapper or light sabre or cookie cutter.4. This thing is flat and small. Looks great on my entertainment setup.Now for the bad points.You NEED TO PLUG IT TO THE BACK OF THE WII. How it gets its power is that it taps onto power from the Wii adapter before it reaches the console (plug it in between the power adapter and the console, they provide a little attachment for you to do that.) Hence it is powered by 12V DC. This is also written at the back of the cradle (12V 1 Amp).Well, that means it could only function when the Wii is turned on. What if you want to charge the controllers when you are not playing/Wii turned off? (obviously!)I tried to forgo the attachment thingy and connected the charger to a 12V DC adapter directly. Tried it for 2 days, the lights do glow, but the controllers did not charge, and thereafter there was a smell of burning electronics in the room. Yes, I fried my charger in 2 days. I DON'T KNOW WHY!I took it apart (it's easy, just remove 5 screws) and I smell fried electronics. A couple of solenoids and a couple of ICs inside. Can't fix it, so I tossed it, but kept the battery packs.So I bought a new one cos this thing is so convenient and pleasurable to use. Now I have 4 battery packs, which is great as I have 4 controllers anyway. I tried it with a different 12V DC adapter, and it started flashing like a madman, so I turned it off immediately. Seems like it works ONLY with the Wii power adapter and nothing else. I tried connecting the charger to the Wii adapter, with the Wii console totally disconnected, and it continues to charge. Bingo! So if you want to charge the controllers with the Wii off, you can do so with the Wii unplugged. But this is annoying, having to plug and unplug the power cord every time, so I decided to buy another Wii power adapter, so one power adapter powers the Wii, the other powers the charger. Problem solved.Thus this is the only complaint I have for this charger. Although I understand they are trying to minimise the number of wires coming out of your setup, I still hope they provide an option to charge from the mains directly in a future version maybe.I know this also comes in a 4 controller version right here at Amazon as well.It is quite a luxury item, being more costly than many other chargers in the market, but in the long run, it's really amazing.

Even then the wire is long enough to take care of most setups.  The lack of Six Axis is no big deal because almost no one develops for it.The L2 and R2 buttons were revamped and for the better. reviewText: I bought this product as an additional remote controller (I already have two Sony Dual Shock 3) for a FPS game (COD: Black Ops) and was very pleased at how nice it felt.  The handles are slightly bulkier and heavier than the Sony DS3 but the L2 and R2 trigger design was a nice surprise.  The L3 and R3 buttons make a cheap clicking sound when you press on them.  Because they are a little stiffer than the standard DS3, they require a little extra effort to operate.The unit came in an unopen package similar to the Sony DS3.  The construction of the unit looks solid, perhaps even more than the Sony DS3.  The only strikes on this controller are: 1) the lack of sixaxis support; 2) it's wired and 3) the "home" button doesn't function like the PS3 button (it only functions when the console is already turned on so you cannot use it to turn the console on) - thus, the four-star rating.  The velcro strap for the cable was a nice added feature for people who like to keep things organized.  Overall, this product was a bargain ($15 versus $55 for the Sony DS3).  It's a functional unit and serves its purpose really well.I would recommend this product only as a spare controller to have around or for children or friends who have a knack for spiking down one (controller) on the ground after losing a game or when getting excited.
But the x button started sticking after a week. Have to smack the bottom of it pretty hard to get it unstuck.

This controller worked great - at first.  Now it keeps turning itself off every 2 seconds.  It's been rendered unusable.  And before anyone asks, no I didn't drop it, throw it, slam it, get it wet, or expose it to harsh conditions.I'm now forced to go back to the default Sony controller, which is what I was trying to get away from in the first place.  The Nyko controller worked fine for about six months, and now it's "bricked" itself.  I know this controller was an aftermarket, "budget" product, but was I wrong to expect more from a manufacturer in the year 2012?My original review is as follows:The primary features on this controller are the L2/R2 buttons which give you just enough resistance to feel "right" when being pressed.  And they're in a concave shape (like the 360's controller) which prevent your fingers from accidentally slipping off.  If you're anything like me, you probably can't stand the mushy, imprecise, slippage-prone L2 and R2 buttons of the default Sony controller.The "rightness" also applies to the face buttons and select/start buttons, which feel springy and deliver a nice popping feel, giving good feedback with every press.  The body of the controller itself is ever so slightly bigger than Sony's, which allows for a more comfortable, natural-feeling grip.However, the L1 and R1 buttons by contrast feel flimsy.  The R1 button in particular has a tendency to get stuck in the "pressed" position, which actually does NOT affect performance: even when the button is stuck, my onscreen character doesn't actually fire his gun.  When I actually tap the button (in its stuck position), the added pressure on the button actually makes my guy fire.  This took a little time to get used to, but now I hardly notice it.Clicking the thumbsticks (the L3 and R3 functions) takes a lot more effort than on Sony's controller; you have to really, REALLY press hard to make them click.  After using the thumbsticks for a few days, though, it's become somewhat easier.  Same with the D-pad; you have to press down hard for the movement to register.  Tilting the sticks to move my character/pan the camera also takes some adjustment; in testing out this controller on Saints Row 3, I had to turn my camera sensitivity way down because it was simply too fast.  Most games allow you to adjust camera sensitivity, so this isn't too big of an issue.The fact this controller is wired may be a negative to some, but for me it's a positive because I don't have to keep buying batteries.  Another big drawback is that you can't use the "home" button on the controller to turn on your PS3; you have to hit the physical power button on your PS3, then hit the home button on the controller to sync it to the system.  Yes, you have to do this EVERY time you turn on your PS3.  It's a very minor step, but if your couch is very far away from your PS3, this could get annoying.  The controller has a nine-foot cable, with a Velcro strap to keep the cable rolled up if you don't need the entire nine feet (and let's face it, who would actually need all NINE feet?).Perhaps the biggest drawback is that this controller does NOT have SixAxis controls.  You read that right: if you want to play Heavy Rain or Flower, break out the default controller.I hope this review is useful (if a bit long!), with both the pros and the cons.  Overall I'm very happy with this controller, especially for only 13 dollars, as what was only supposed to be a second controller has now become my primary one.
It's not as advanced as the stock ones since those have some kind of gyroscopes or something, but these get the job done for almost 95% of the games that don't need those fancy sensors.

reviewText: Conduit 2 was awesome. Bit different from other wii games. This is the best shooter game I have come across. Their are plenty of different types of weapons, sometimes game seems a little bit slow though, but combat is completely unaffected. Lots of hidden items.

The first Conduit was by no means a great game but it accomplished several things. It was a more unique experience than most modern shooters (even if it borrowed a lot from perfect dark), it had excellent weapon design, basic but fun online play, and most importantly a groundbreaking control scheme that raised the standard for pointer controls. High Voltage promised that the sequel would build on the good elements of the original while fixing the poor art direction, level design, and glitched multiplayer, and for the most part they succeeded in doing this. Unfortunately, even with these improvements the game still feels like an amateurish effort next to games from larger companies.The first problem with Conduit 2 is the control scheme. While the controls in the Conduit were excellent for the time, almost all wii shooters since from red steel 2 to goldeneye to numerous call of duty ports have surpassed it with more customization options and better physics. Rather than pushing remote customization further and raising the standard for customization again, High Voltage opted not to screw with the one thing they nailed the first time around and kept the scheme from the first game untouched. The option to use motion+ is there, but it hardly makes a difference unless you aim off screen constantly.There are no separate options for aiming down sights (making the addition of sights useless), no maximum turn zones, and even a few options from the first game, such as vertical view, are missing. The cursor is at least a little more steady this time around, but it is still more jittery than in other wii titles and the game still requires a lock on to keep the view stable. The controls are still workable, but they are not at all competitive with other recent wii games.The art direction has been majorly improved, and while it obviously doesn't reach the level of a first party Nintendo game the growth is still impressive. The scenery is usually interesting and varied enough to keep you from getting bored as often as in the original. However, so much of the visual design is lifted from other games that it's hard to give High Voltage too much credit for the work.  The Washington D.C. level features pulsing tentacles on the floors and walls that look cool for a moment until you realize that you saw the exact same pulsing tentacles four years ago in Metroid Corruption. So much of the visual design is stolen from elsewhere that the game still looks generic and uninspired, even if it is a lot prettier than last time.Level designs are improved greatly and offer much more freedom and choice than before. There is much more variety and the pacing is broken up by frequent real time events or boss fights. The bosses are not particularly memorable, but the inclusion of any boss fights at all feels like a godsend after the anticlimactic campaign of the first game. Some of the levels still stretch on for too long and there are dull spots that strongly resemble the low points of the first game (they make you play through the D.C. subway system... again... for the third time), but the level designs are much better overall this time around.For the single player levels the non-linearity is an absolute good, but for multiplayer the maps feel as if they've been forced to be as open as possible at the expense of gameplay. Most online maps are formless spaces with no real logic to their design. Paths travel aimlessly through the level, directing you nowhere in particular; the contrast is extremely clear when compared to goldeneye's brilliantly flowing and interlocking maps. Almost every map features constantly differing levels of height, forcing you to climb ladders and staircases over and over when you'd rather be fighting. Speaking of ladders, the game requires you to climb them by pointing the wii remote up or down, which is so awkward and unintuitive that you'll come to hate the mechanic within the first level. Ladders aside, the new maps are marginally better than the old ones, but even the best of them are just "alright".The weapons from the first game were a joy to use, and while all of them return this time, most of them have been balanced in ways that ruin what originally made them fun. The Deatomizer, for instance, was a semi auto laser in the first game that could be charged on the fly for a one hit kill. This time around it's a clumsy and weak machine gun, and charging it requires you to spend a second to switch to a different mode where you can't fire the weapon normally. Almost all of the new weapons, such as a black hole generator or District 9's magnet gun, are so gimmicky that they can't be practically used in battle. The weapons are at least more balanced with one another, but none of them are quite as solid in their feel as before.The leveling system is also a disappointment- it takes all of an hour or two to unlock whatever you want from the online "store". There is very little satisfaction or challenge in earning your new weapons because it takes almost no work to get there. The good news about the multiplayer is that splitscreen is included and even has a wave attack mode that's reasonably fun. It's not quite as engaging as the games that inspired it (nazi zombies, horde mode), but it's a nice small scale approximation for people who don't have those games.The story is another one of the few things the first game got right; it had surprisingly good acting, decent dialog, and it kept out of your way. This time around, high voltage takes a monumental step backwards by increasing the role of story in the game while simultaneously decreasing the quality of it. The voice acting and animation are terrible, with none of the original actors returning, and the dialog is just stupid. Sometimes the corniness of the story is deliberate and a lot of the in game banter is amusing, but the amount of forehead-slappingly bad scenes in the game makes you feel sorry for High Voltage. If watching the story unfold is like watching a fat girl losing her balance and flailing, the ending of the game is equivalent seeing her face plant firmly into the ground with a thunderous smack. You will laugh and remember the final scene for a good long while, but not for the reasons High Voltage intended.Conduit 2 is definitely a stronger game than the original, but it's not competing with the original game alone in a vacuum- there are plenty of other Wii shooters out there, and Conduit 2 feels very weak compared to almost any of them. Unlike the first Conduit, C2 borrows nearly all of its gameplay concepts from other games, such as call of duty, Metroid, and Halo, and the result is a game that feels generic, watered down and amateurish compared to its sources. High Voltage HAS to get credit for trying; it's clear that they poured their heart and soul into this game, and they continue to diligently support the players with patches and tweaks to the online play while other big name titles leave their playing communities high and dry. Unfortunately, for the second time High Voltage has proven that good intentions alone don't make a good game. They just don't have the resources to pull a good FPS off yet.I find it hard to recommend this game to anyone- if you hate call of duty and are looking for an alternative with fresh mechanics, you won't find it here. If you want a good science fiction themed shooter, choose Halo (or break out your n64 and go back to perfect dark). If you just want a straightforward, all around high quality FPS for your wii, choose Goldeneye. Any of these options are a better use of your time. Conduit 2 isn't such a bad game, but it simply isn't as good as anything else out there.

The NINTENDO Wii is not the most powerful console, quite the opposite in fact. No matter, it enjoys most of the best designed games, games that, above anything else, offer great fun. And CONDUIT 2 is an excellent example of this.WHAT YOU SEE IS NOT WHAT YOU GETAs expected, although impressive for a Wii game, the graphics are not the game's strong point. The backgrounds are very artfully done whereas a lot of work seems to have gone into the graphics as well - however, the overall visual result is nothing to impress a gamer with some PC experience. Nevertheless, only a novice would allow this to prevent him from enjoying the game.THINK WHILE YOU SHOOT (NOBODY ELSE WILL)The creative level design more than makes up for what the graphics lack. More often than not there are multiple possible routes to your objective. Pair that with enemies driven by an AI with the IQ of Forest Gump, and you have an FPS where it is fun to explore the expansive map and try new approaches.FIRING ALIEN ...BUGS & POULTRYThe game offers a selection of weapons, from the futuristic shotguns and sniper rifles to alien...creatures (which are the most interesting by the way). Controlling your character will take some tweaking of the Wii-Remote sensitivity but once you get the hang of it the fun begins. Just make sure to master the controls by the time you reach the first boss because boss fights offer a much greater challenge.WHY SO SERIOUS?Contrary to most FPS games which strike serious tones and dwell in gloomy environments, CONDUIT 2 is a much more playful game. If it were somewhat longer (expect 8-10 hours of gameplay) and it sported a more challenging AI it would had been very good. Having said that, I have to make it clear that rarely had I had more fun playing an FPS game on the Wii.RECOMMENDED!
summary: A GOOD FPS, CUT & MEASURED FOR THE Wii

It's early in my ownership of the game, but this is what I have so far.  The dialogue in the standalone game has fallen greatly.  They went from having pretty good voice acting to some rather uninspired interchange.The graphics have a good deal of improvement, however, the game doesn't feel as smooth as the original.Multi-player is really changed up with how stages and rules are set.  You can choose from a free-for-all (no radar or lock-on) to a pair of team setups.  The goals have expanded as well.  The arenas are pretty good, some old, some new.  And hopefully with the updates, the cheating will be minimal, ie no rapid fire rocket launchers.  Speaking of which, in multiplayer, you need to earn a certain number of experience points in order to upgrade to better weapons (the rocket launcher is really up there), and now there is an option for improved body armor.  Based on my experience last night, some people have already picked up some serious armor.The play is very fun, the visuals are improved, but perhaps not as smooth, the music is good, the voice overs in the standalone game are dreadfully terrible and I don't particularly care for the calling cries of downed players either. Don't let the negativity of that make it sound like the game isn't great because overall, I really like this game so far.

Conduit 2 is a fantastic sequel. It surpasses the first in every way, adding in some fantastic new features. But does it live up to the absurd amount of hype it was given?Yes it does.STORY - Conduit 2 has taken the story up a notch. Even though you may not have any idea of what's going on, this game will keep you interested and curious as to how all the pieces fit together. There are a lot of fun, exciting locations to visit as well. The ending is also really cool.The voice acting is completely different. The first one had some excellent voice acting, with a serious tone, while this one takes a comical approach. At first, I didn't like the cheesy, B-Movie feel to it, but as the game went on, I really started to like it. There were some parts that were pretty funny, too.Easter eggs are also all over in this game, and I was surprised to see some really neat references to movies and other games.CONTROLS - This is where the game gave me some trouble. The controls in this game aren't bad, but they do take some tweaking and some getting used to. The classic controller is really sensitive in this game and the wiimote and nunchuk has a different feel than the first game had. Not a game breaker, but definitely a game changer.GAMEPLAY - The gameplay is fantastic in Conduit 2. Enemy A.I. is challenging, enemy types are varied, every gun feels like a different animal, boss battles are epic, puzzles will keep you thinking, collectibles will keep you searching and the level designs are fresh, colorful and give you multiple ways to play through.The In-game Store - The store is very cool. It allows you to purchase weapons, upgrades, characters and pieces of armor that you can take with you into either the singleplayer campaign or the online multiplayer. It adds a lot of replayability to this game.GUN DESIGN - The BEST part of Conduit 2! The guns make this game something incredible. Every gun has a different feel to it, but all are very well balanced. And this is made sometimes painfully clear in multiplayer.MULTIPLAYER - Just when you thought the warp pistol was useless, or that heavy armor just slows you down too much, somebody else does amazingly well with it. Online multiplayer is done extremely well. The level designs are well balanced (unlike black ops), the guns are well balanced (unlike black ops), and the upgrades are so good, it makes you want to equip them all. The game modes are all fun. I couldn't find a single one I didn't like.Splitscreen multiplayer has all the competitive online game types, but throws in a coop mode called invasion. Invasion is a horde mode similar to firefight from Halo where you fight wave after wave of enemies. But, unlike Halo, you can beat invasion mode. It does take a while, though.This game may be my pick for the best first person shooter on the wii, but it does have some flaws. Even though this game plays incredibly smooth, the framerate does drop at times. The single player feels like it could be just a little bit longer. However, it is a satisfying experience. The game did freeze on me once, but only once. The biggest complaint I have is that invasion mode is splitscreen only. No online invasion. I don't know if they can add that later with downloadable content, but if they can, then I would gladly pay for it.Overall, Conduit 2 is a fantastic game that actually does compete with Xbox 360 and PS3 games (believe it or not). A 5 star game all the way, regardless of what other reviewers say about it. For some reason, IGN gave this game a lower score than its predecessor. Are they stupid? Don't ask me. Decide for yourself. After all, everyone's different.
summary: Does it live up to the hype?

reviewText: Conduit 2 is a really fun game with very good graphics and beautiful levels. It has both split screen and online multiplayer game play. You can customize your character (avatar) with various suits, colors, equipment, weapons, and specials. You can play as soldiers, destroyers (armor seen on box art), female destroyers, alien warriors, stone statues, and more. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a great shooter for the Wii. It works with the Headbanger headset, classic controller, nunchuck, and motion controls. A must get!

The Conduit was a rather solid FPS at the time of its release on the Nintendo Wii, but it's been a few years and things are a little bit different now. However, in the time since the release of The Conduit, the Wii really hasn't had much to compete with the original game. Now it's time for High Voltage Software to blow the doors off of their Wii FPS franchise. Needless to say, they don't just blow the doors off, they blow the entire building down.Positives:- An Epic Sci-Fi Adventure - The sci-fi feel, the level design, some of the enemies, etc., actually reminded me of Perfect Dark for the Nintendo 64. Conduit 2 melds classic FPS design with some of the newest mechanics, which creates a very cohesive feel.- Voice Acting - While I did enjoy the more serious conspiratorial tone of the prior game, Conduit 2 deploys Jon St. John to voice main character Michael Ford this time around. Adding an almost Duke Nukem-lite tone to the game, it's a welcomed addition. Sure, it may be cheesy, but it's also fun, and that's what gaming is all about. Get ready for the one-liners.- Boss Battles - Unlike The Conduit, Conduit 2 features a number of big boss battles that are exciting to play. They're not super frustrating, but just challenging enough to keep you on your toes.- Story - The story is fun and campy, but the hidden goodies are back to flesh out the narrative even more if you're willing to use your All-Seeing Eye device and find them.- Graphics - We all know that the Wii isn't a graphical power house, and you're not going to see HD resolutions here, however High Voltage Software has continued to improve their tech in Conduit 2. There are some pretty decent textures, reflective surfaces, decent lighting, etc. It won't amaze you, but it's well done considering the hardware it's running on.- Multiplayer - Deep, fun, engaging. Downloadable updates/patches from High Voltage Software. Splitscreen (Up to 4 players), Online (Up to 12 players). Voice Chat via the Headbanger headset. Free For All Modes: Deathmatch, Ballon Battle, ASE Ball, Bounty Hunter, Free For All CTF. Team Deathmatch Modes: Team Deathmatch, Shared Stock. Team Objective Modes: Capture the Flag, Killing Override, Single Flag CTF, VIP, ASE Basketball, Annexation, Power Surge. This is the Wii's premier online FPS.Negatives:- Minor Technical Issues - The framerate will sometimes dip, there are some bugs here and there, and there's some other unpolished aspects such as some poor lip sync for some characters.Conduit 2 is a huge step up from The Conduit. It may change the tone to a more silly and over-the-top nature, but it's fun in its own way. I can't say if I prefer the serious tone of The Conduit or the campy tone of Conduit 2, as they both do their own thing. I think it's nice that Conduit 2 is a bit different than The Conduit, so it feels somewhat fresh, yet it still keeps the things intact that made the first game solid, but just improves upon those things in nearly every single way.
summary: An Excellent Addition to the Wii Library

reviewText: Yes!  Conduit 2!  This game's got a lot going against it.  Why? (You may or may not ask.) Well, firstly it's on the Wii...which isn't exactly the bastion of FPS games.  Secondly, Portal 2 and Crysis 2 were released within the same timeframe as this game and loom over the horizon with better hardware and bigger budgets.Does this prevent Conduit 2 from not being fun and extremely entertaining?  NO WAY!  Allow me to explain why....When The Conduit was released it was preceded with a nice media following due to the impressive screenshots and big claims in terms of gameplay.  It was to be the Wii's FPS killer app.  While it fell short of such promises due to High Voltage Software's emphasis on the game's engine development instead of level design, you could tell there was a lot of potential.  The Conduit had a robust online community and LOTS of customization aspects.  Conduit 2 carries over the insane amount of options for customization and control schemes to include the normal Wii Remote/Nunchuk duo, or Wii Motion Plus/Remote Plus, or the Classic Controller.  It also has, what seemed to me during my limited time online, a pretty good online community thus far.The graphics are more impressive than its predecessor and really stand out for a Wii title striving for realism.  What is of special note is the amount of locales in the game.  Rather than being stuck solely in the DC Metro area as in The Conduit, Conduit 2 runs the gamut of transporting the protaganist, Michael Ford, to great looking locations such as oil rigs, to Atlantis, jungles areas and various urban areas to name a few.  Additionally, enemy AI is more dynamic, although not perfect, compared to the first title.The story's just as campy and B-movie'ish as the original.  You gotta love it!  It, along with the goofy dialog and quips Ford makes during the game make it stand out from other FPS titles.  I think High Voltage Software realizes this game is an underdog in the FPS world and really made an attempt to make it unique with the dialog in the script.  The goofy sense of humor is awesome and really adds some charm to the game that really has no chance against the technical achievements of, oh say, Rage, Killzone 3, Crysis 2, et cetera.  I really stands out made the game pretty memorable for me.In the end, while the game doesn't stand out for its technical achievements the dialog and campiness more than makes up for it and makes the Conduit 2 quite a memorable game.

It's summer- my daughter is out of school, camp doesn't start for a few weeks, and it rains every day here in Southwest Florida. To keep my daughter from turning into a TV zombie, I thought I would get her a few active games for the Wii. She enjoyedNickelodeon Dancefor a long time but there aren't many songs on there and she's sort of into more popular music now, so she grew bored of it.So I ordered both Kidz Bop Dance Party andJust Dance Kids 2- she played both for a while and she *clearly* prefers Kidz Bop over Just Dance. While Just Dance is sort of videos of kids dancing in different costumes, Kidz Bop is fully animated, and you can "dress up" the character you choose, which is a *big* draw for my daughter. Also, the game seems a little more structured, as opposed to "pick a song and dance to it" which Just Dance seems to be.We haven't played the games long enough to be able to give a good report on the responsiveness of one over the other, but my daughter is definitely more interested in Kidz Bop. There's just more for her to do in that game, and the points system (earning points by dancing which you can use to buy accessories and things) really motivates her. Plus, the songs are a little better and the dances are a little more modern.I guess it's really up to the individual kids. But for my daughter, anything that has to do with personalization on the Wii is a huge draw for her.
summary: my six year old prefers this over "Just Dance"...

I don't know, frankly this just seems like a rip off of the Just Dance series. It looks like a couple others agree with me, and that's probably because that's exactly what it is. I mean, the Just Dance series is pretty decent, so therefore this game is pretty decent too, but there aren't any significant differences between this and those games. It's really kind of insulting. I guess that's just what game developers are doing these days, ripping each other off, but I would like to see something original! There's so much potential for creativity in the video game world!

If, like me, you love the We Cheer games and are yearning for a third game in the series, you might find Kidz Bop Dance Party surprisingly fun.  After all, it and We Cheer fell off the same Namco family tree: this is just an American version ofHappy Dance Collection [Japan Import], a Namco game that was only released in Japan.  You could even call this "We Cheer Junior".Gameplay is the same: pick a tune and dance along with the avatar while moving your remote along the tracks of arrows.  This game only uses one remote, and the dancing isn't as complex as We Cheer's, but I still work up a sweat.  The 24 songs are mainly pop tunes by the Kidz Bop singers; as cover versions go, you could do a lot worse (e.g. DDR Hottest Party) and kid tunes like Chicken Noodle Soup and Ice Cream & Guacamole, are catchy and fun for all ages.This is a better party game than We Cheer because it offers a guest mode, so guests can jump right in without having to create a file.  In Free Play mode, all the songs are unlocked from the beginning.  The Challenge mode is nice and simple, as challenge modes in dance games ought to be.  No epic battles or puzzle-solving, just progress along a trail of stars.  You win points to spend on clothes and accessories in a virtual shop, again like We Cheer.I thought it was overpriced when it came out, but for $20 or less it's a great deal.  I'm spending as much time playing Kidz Bop as on Zumba, We Cheer, Michael Jackson or Just Dance 2, and more than on Dance on Broadway (that was a waste of money) or Wii DDR.
summary: Not We Cheer 3, but close enough!

reviewText: My kids generally have little interest in the Wii. They will try a game play for a short period of time then return to a game of Barbie or coloring!However, as they both like music and dancing, and are fans of some of the artists whose songs are featured in this game, I decided to sell my Disney Dance revolution which they could not care less about and replace it with this! It was a good move!I noticed a lot of reviews noted that it was similar to the just Dance series - I have not tried this so cannot compare, however my main goal was to get a fun game that my kids would like and this particular format resonated with them in terms of tracks and ease of play.The first thing that struck me was the fact that is was easier for younger children - granted we started with some of the easier dances, but some other games on the market which require kids to follow along may be too fast or complex for younger kids and kids will get frustrated when they cannot follow along or see some success. My 7 year old was able to dance along and readily score points as she mastered some of the moves. It was simple to understand and the graphics provides a good guide as to what move to do!Also, another important factor - the game and the Wii remote pair well together and the game picks up on the remote action. Nothing is more annoying when you are moving correctly but there is a disconnect between the game and the remote - this was not a factor at all in this game.The songs are fun and mostly contemporary - Thriller of course is a little more dated, but has the fun theme dance and is such a classic that even my toddler recognized it and played along. The songs have been adapted to make them age appropriate. The version we had also came with a bonus CD which was perhaps the weakest part as I did not recognize a lot of the songs and neither did my kids!The game has plenty of different modes, we have only tried solo play to date my there is an option to play against a friend, plus little girls will love the dress up, customize and shop sections which are added benefits!Of all the kids dance games for the Wii, this is my favorite  - simply because the ease of play and remote responsiveness, combined with a fun and modern sound track help keep younger kids engaged and it is a game in which they can have fun without the frustration of complex moves or rules. Great game!
summary: Fun game for younger kids, responds well to remote and recent tracks!

reviewText: The F.E.A.R. series has been different enough from the saturated FPS market to warrant four titles.(Thats including Files) But has it over stayed its welcome?Originally developed by Monolith, F.E.A.R. became a rare gem in todays industry. An FPS that goes forward with a huge emphasis on story and atmosphere. The first three games made this evidently clear and thankfully Day 1 studios continues this tradition, for the most part.F.E.A.R. 3 is easily the best looking and performing of this franchise. It sports a revamped engine, improved enemy A.I., an array of unique co-op and multiplayer modes([...] run is awesome), and the return of the everyones favorite homicidal cannibal in gaming, Fettle. Also the gameplay has been tweaked to near perfection and is easily the best improvement made to the trilogy. However, despite the myriad improvements Day 1 has made to F.E.A.R. 3 , the game is uneven. The creepy atmosphere the game creates is marvelous but is completely under used, instead the majority of the game is spent moving from decimated cities, an erie neighborhood, military checkpoints, etc. Even with the unique gameplay and atmosphere, F.E.A.R. 3 falls short due to much of an emphasis on shooting and not enough on story/atmosphere.Basically, you(the player) spend less than 1/5 of the game in its madness.While F.E.A.R. 3 stands apart from the rest of the FPS market, it ain't no call of duty clone, it could have done more in terms of story and that is my biggest complaint. Mainly because this was suppose to be the end to a trilogy and the ending leaves you asking yourself "Dude ...... wtf?" (Much like F.E.A.R. 2)I would recommend this game if you and a friend want to play co-op because that is the best way to play the game, and definitely try "[...] run" its the best.overall 8.25 out of ten (I use gameinformers rating system)PROS:1. It offers a unique approach to the current FPS market2. Co-op modes are unique, only one multiplayer mode but its good3. Satisfying gun mechanicsCONS:1. The silent protagonist really needs to go away, this isn't the 90's2. Lack of atmosphere3. Unsatisfying conclusion to trilogy
summary: Too little horror and too much "pew pew"

reviewText: I'm writing this review of the ENTIRE FEAR storyline. If you have not played the first ones start there before picking up this title. The action and 'fear factor' that everyone says is missing probably were playing with other people and having loud music in the background. next time try playing with the lights low and with headphones. On to the review:Graphics are not the best but not the worse either.sound and music are what sets the stage for any FEAR game. if you hear crteppy music something bad is about to happen but that is to be expected when you have hollywood directors helping out a video game.Storyline is about wrapping up ALL of the previous titles in one fast and albeit loose fashion assuming that you have played all of the previous titles.Overall opinion of the game is that I have been waiting for this title for a while and knowing everything from the beginning to the end is like watching a kid grow up. This would be like the adult version of the series cause there are less things that scare but there is alot more things done right. From the first title you saw the weak game engine, the firefights were intense but are less and less as the game progressed. The second titles extraction point and persus mandate (FEAR FILES FOR THE REST OF YOU) were short filler games that were suppose to lead up to FEAR 2 but somehow lost there way. And FEAR 2 was the turning point in the series cause it showed how to do it right. Just enough scare to keep you wondering what's around the next corner. And last FEAR 3 the RACE to stop mommy from giving birth. So this game is fast and quick paced to reach the end of the story. And what a story if you play from FEAR 1- FEAR 3 with all the titles in between and you will see the growth of this series. And why the dev's went with this 'style' of gameplay. COD and MOH are good titles in there own right but when you get tired of those titles pop this in for a quick change of pace. And one last thing, to any game studio that is thinking about making another game based off a movie this is how its done.
summary: Nice ending to a great story.

Graphics/Design:The graphics in F.3.A.R are not spectacular, but they get the job done. The level designs are linear for the most part and player's won't have much trouble navigating the levels and finding where to go. Though the levels are linear, each level has it's own distinct look to it, so environments are not repeated which is pleasing to the eye.Campaign:When playing solo, the game will operate as a normal shooter since you will playing as Pointman. However, the game shines when it comes to the co-op mode. In co-op the game allows the second player to be Paxton Fettel, he plays very differently from the Pointman, using his psychic abilities and mind control techniques against his enemies. He brings in a more dynamic strategy to the combat, he can restrain enemies in the air allowing the Pointman to get an easy shot, he can take control of soldiers allowing him access to their artillery providing fire support for Pointman, and finally he has the ability to give Pointman a shield barrier that makes him more damage resistant in combat. In other words, Paxton is the perfect wingman in combat, his abilities allow for many combat options for the player, whether they want to assist the Pointman from afar with the shielding and levitation powers or possessing a soldier and fighting alongside the Pointman on the frontlines. Whatever character the player chooses to be, the campaign is very fun with two people. The story is hazey at first, but begins to clear up the further you get. The campaign is filled with intense firefights and awesome cut scenes that will leave you saying, "Holy $#&%!" The downside is that the campaign is very short, it will not take you very long at all to beat it. Also, and regretfully it is not as terrifying as the last two games, which is a little disappointing.Multiplayer:The game offers two competetive and two co-op modes which offer hours of fun. Every game mode is unique in their own way giving a new experience

I don't play multiplayer or co-op so this has no bearing on those. I am strictly a solo campaign player.FEAR has never been one of my top priorities. I was fairly excited for the first one, because about a year or so prior to its release there was a very long demo video that showcased some incredible combat and enemy AI. Those have always been the series' strong suit. Likewise, the FEAR franchise has always seemed to go out of its way to have very dull and mundane level design. The first FEAR took place almost exclusively in office buildings and industrial concrete basements. FEAR 2 "really shook things up" by adding a couple of ruined city streets and an elementary school. And now F3AR (ugh) has made the wonderful contribution of a megastore (a la Costco) and some suburban homes. Be still, my foolish heart. All in all I thought it was a step down from FEAR 2's level design.The combat, for the most part, remains as fun as ever. But it was the same 'ol same ol'. 90% of the time you're up against wily commandos intent on taking you down, or insane civilians who might as well have been zombies lifted straight out of Left 4 Dead. Occasionally you'll have to face a mech walker or a helicopter or two. The worst sequences of the game were those in which you had to face a swarm of leaping feral monsters, I was never really clear on where they came from or what they had to do with anything. It's possible the story explained it, but if so I missed it. Not that I mind. The story and the "horror factor" in FEAR have always been very minimal and completely beside the point as far as I'm concerned.All in all, I was ready for this game to be over before I actually reached the end. One of the few games I will never, ever replay. I mean, as tepid and mediocre as FEAR 2 was, at least it was good enough that I played it twice.
summary: Sub par entry in an already mediocre franchise

reviewerName: Dwayne Hicks - 3/22/14 till Gears 3 on Xbox One
reviewText: This is a good game in a saturated genre. It is not a very scary game but as a shooter action game it succeeds in being fun and challenging. They do a good job in mixing up enemy types, which keeps the action fresh. The enemy soldiers flank and lay cover fire and press you if you stay in cover too long. Most of the other enemy types just rush at you but sheer numbers make these enemies challenging.Story wise I have been entertained I did not play either the 1st or 2nd game so not sure if the story meshes with what was already laid out but on its own the story is above average for a FPS these days.I was pleasantly surprised by the graphics in this game. Seeing some vids online made the graphics look pretty bad. The graphics are not the best out there but the gameplay makes up for any lack of visuals and that's really what matters. The settings are fairly detailed and varied.  There are no epic set pieces but good settings and level design are present at every part of this game.The multiplayer in this game is awesome and there are some fresh modes with two small problems. I have played Soul King, F'N Run, and Contractions modes. I have not yet played Soul Survivor. Soul King is my favorite of these modes Basically 4 players start as specters and than the map populates with AI controlled bots as a specter you possess one of the bots and kill other bots once they die you collect the dead bots soul the other players do this too and to really win you have to kill the other players than they drop their collected souls. If you are the "soul king" the person with the most souls all the other players can see where you are on the map at all times. The game is fast frenetic fresh and very fun. F'N Run is fun as well a wall of death smoke is coming up behind you as you and a team of up to four players plow through enemy bots. It is awesome to turn around and see this smoke coming up fast behind you that will kill you but some maps require jumping over obstacles which is unfairly too hard and not always responsive. Contractions is basically a Fear 3 take on Nazi zombies from COD but you have to go out and get supplies between or at the end of rounds.Now for the problems with multiplayer, The lobby system and matchmaking leave a lot to be desired. You can host a match but unless you have a party of people set to go you can sit there for a while, before your game populates. You can join already hosted match but the host has to launch the game so sometimes you'll join a match and there will not be enough people for the host to launch the game and also sometimes it is a full lobby but the host has fallen asleep at the wheel and doesn't launch the game than you go back to square one. Also as I mentioned earlier Soul King is my fav mode so far but I have yet to have a full party complete a game. Usually 2 people quit by the end of round one, leaving me with one other person. Than if the host quits game ends. Needless to say the way this is set up I spend more time trying to get into a multiplayer game than actually playing the multiplayer.The multiplayer and graphics were good surprises after purchasing this game. Also the campaign co-op makes this game a package well worth a purchase. If you have a lot of friends who bought this game you wont have any of the issues I had with matchmaking but that is a small issue overall for me. A solid fun shooter with good co-op/multiplayer  and an above average story, definitely worth a purchase

Well, FEAR was decent, FEAR 2 was an improvement and pretty fun.  FEAR 3 seems like it was thrown together with little effort to improve on its predecessor. The story line is strange and a little messy.  Enemies start to become repetitive.  And this game is certainly not "scary" by any means.  My assessment is that this title is a mediocre shooter at best.  Score out of 1-10: 6.5.  Typically, when it takes me a long time to get through a game it's due to the difficulty level and resulting frustration that makes me put it down for a while.  However, this game took me a while to get through because I kept putting it down out of boredom.  If you are a crazy FPS fan, and are in dire need of something new, this may satisfy you.  But probably not.  If you are looking for a good story, fun battles, and a game that you can't put down, PASS.PROS- Control scheme works well- Some gunfights can be fun- Voice acting is not badCONS- Poor graphics for a next gen game- Enemies are repetitive and actually more annoying than anything else- No real thrills or "scares"- Just not really that fun overall

The first FEAR title became known as one of the quintessential scary titles for the XBOX 360 when it came out back in 2006 a year after similarly freaky game Condemned: Criminal Origins.  With the flashlight being the only source of light for the vast majority of the game and the eerie backdrop, FEAR became one hell of a freaky title that ranked VERY high on my scare-the-crap-o'-meter.  FEAR 2 and FEAR Files were equally freaky with the ending in the second installment forcing me to wake up every night screaming for two weeks for fear I unwittingly made Alma pregnant with her next 'child.'With all that in mind I expected FEAR 3, the alleged ending to the franchise, to answer all questions, finish well, and scare the excrement out of me in the process.  After having beaten the game in under five hours and playing a little bit of the co-op and multiplayer I find myself shaking my head in disbelief that I paid full price for this severe letdown.Let us begin.Yes, you read correctly; I beat the game under five hours.  I thought the end-boss on the end-level was a lead-up to one final showdown with Alma, the main protagonist of the series, given how the story was finally beginning to progress.*in best Bill Lumberg impression*Yeaaaaaaaaaaaah... about that memo.When I got the achievement after beating a VERY easy final boss I was in complete disbelief that I had already completed the campaign mode (bleep bloop?).  The campaign felt like a long campaign from Left 4 Dead 2 than the usual 6-12 hours that first-person shooters typically run.  I was then treated to a very brief ending that was closer to a cut-scene where your score is put against your partner in order to determine what very short ending you would be treated to.  If you scored more points as the "Point Man" protagonist you get his ending whereas, concurrently, if you score more points as the other 'hero' Paxton Fettel you get his ending.  How cute.It wasn't as though the ending solved all the questions of the overall story arc either, even with both endings.  The ending made me raise my eyebrow and simply give off a four-worded response: "No way in hell."  Two years of waiting for the conclusion and I get another non-ending that more-or-less opens it for a sequel.  It is this kind of BS that makes us gamers less inclined to get new titles opening night.  And the BS didn't end there.As mentioned earlier, FEAR 3 was not scary at all.  Perhaps I am desensitized by the exploding babies from Dead Space 2, an equally disappointing game, but there were no moments that were genuinely scary since most of the game took place during the daytime with lots of lighting.  In fact, the second mission took place in a VERY lit favella in a place that looked strikingly like a particular game mission in Rio di Janeiro (I bumped into "Soap" BTW, he says, "Hi").  I used the flashlight attachment less during FEAR 3 than I used ambient lighting in the first FEAR.Truth be told, FEAR 3 felt like an arcade shooter and, like Dead Space 2, a dramatic deviation from the previous installments.  This is not necessarily a bad thing as there were some redeeming aspects to FEAR 3.  The melee attack system proved very entertaining as, like Mortal Kombat, the foot sweep proved to be the bane of the existence of many an enemy in the game.  No BS, when I played through the game again as Fettel, I beat the first level on the "fearless" difficulty setting and only got hit five times as I spent literally the entire level utilizing foot sweeps.  They were virtually one-hit kills on most enemies.  I even had a blast with jump kicks (the jerks removed the roundhouse kicks from FEAR 2: Project Origins).  All the while I was whistling "Kung Fu Fighting" by Carl Douglas.  Yeah, the game was THAT easy.Another nice aspect was the utilizing of power armor, which made a small cameo in Project Origins.  You not only get one more chance to pilot the amazing piece of machinery but FOUR chances that are relatively long.  To make this nicer, the control schemes were virtually identical to the previous installments so it was pretty simple to get acclimated to playing the game.Lastly among my favorites was the co-op features.  This was what everyone got excited for and it's obvious that is where the vast majority of the emphasis went into.  It was well executed and balanced as the abilities of both Point Man and Fettel compliment each other (which only do so in co-op) as the latter can suspend enemies while the former guns them down.  My partners-in-crime online enjoyed this feature, and we tried doing the other multiplayer features that closely resembled Nazi Zombies and Left 4 Dead, but that didn't last very long.  We were hoping for a scary game, not an arcade shooter.In short, the game play was as solid as FEAR 2: Project Origins, but completely without the scary features.  Worthy of a rental or if the game seriously goes down in price.  I akin this game to Dead Space 2 albeit with the exploding infants.All in all, a 75%.

The NPC AI of the original FEAR had some of the greatest ever seen in modern FPS. This has strangely been forgotten about over the years. In 2011, FEAR 3 teases a fraction of that AI and actually surprises gamers. We’re still not at 100%, and this raises the issue of why us gamers are more fascinated with fancy bump-mapping than playing with enemies who will out-do you by flanking and working together to cave your skull in.If you’re a fan of horror and FPS, FEAR 3 is a must-buy. It does not reach the high standard of 2005’s product however, but is probably better paced and executed than FEAR 2. Visuals range from great to poor; high-res to blotchy and watered down textures. There are lots of things happening all the time in FEAR 3, so when you’re not being attacked and engaged in battle, the supernatural is at work. It’s a very “busy” campaign.Score and ranking up plays a subtle importance. More points are awarded for using different weapons and methods. Even well-hidden dolls of Amy can be sought out for bonus points. It all feels very strange , even in a game which relies on strangeness; but feels oddly compelling. It encourages a repeat play with a second character, Fettel. Fettel is a psychic who has only melee weapons but can possess other NPC’s to progress through the same campaign, this gives the player around 12 hours of gameplay in total. Fortunately, it doesn’t seem overly long or tiring.Sound plays an important role here, even more so than the visuals. The score dictates the mood, and keeps you on the edge - or calms you right down, before jump-scaring you out of your comfort zone once again.Two missions make the player believe he's playing Left 4 Dead 2 - yes really. We’ve gone from the dark, weird and elaborate atmospheric setting to a silly, over-the-top black comedic one with (yes!) zombies who charge you with suicide vests. This experience feels disjointed and not part of FEAR. Thankfully, this is short lived - the game returns to its dark roots before long.There’s moments of frantic action which become tough and frustrating, more notably a few sections on the rooftops. Soldiers come in thick and fast, swearing like dockers as they become annihilated by the player in slow motion. There’s a solid boss battle or two to be had, and a section where you’re attacked by infinitely respawning demon dogs as you panic to close a shutter down (which, supposedly protects you from the fierce power of the dogs pounces).I admire FEAR 3 because it’s a title many people avoided, but I actually really enjoyed it for what it was. It is dark, grim, depressing and soul-sucking title which horror buffs will love.

reviewText: I think at this point, the mythology of the F.E.A.R. games has collapsed in on itself. The story has evolved into something nonsensical and this third chapter has lost any, if not all of the frights that the first one managed to gather. Does this make F.E.A.R. 3 a bad game? No, in fact it's far from being a bad game. I'd actually say that this is one of the best two-player co-op games you can currently get your hands on and it shouldn't be missed for those who enjoy progressing through a solid campaign experience with a buddy.If you've played the expansion pack for F.E.A.R. 2, then you will be familiar with Point Man, who is one of the two characters you can play as. The other is Paxton Fettel, cannibal psycho psychic dude who has been a series staple from the very beginning. Between the two of you, assuming that you're playing with someone else of course, you will team up to dish out some serious harm to your enemies. So much in fact that you're certain to attain a certain euphoria as you zip through levels decimating your enemies. And decimate them you do. There's something inherently satisfying about psychically suspending some dude in the air while your partner unloads a clip into him at close range, making him jiggle like some marionette. Or you can just make them explode outright in a fine mist of blood and gore. Point Man plays like a standard run and gun super soldier but Paxton adds a certain flair to the proceedings that makes things that much more fun. In the end, the game trades in it's well worn scare tactics for some solid co-op gameplay and it's a worthwhile trade.The game also offers some online multiplayer modes, the best of which in my humble opinion being the "F***ing Run" mode that puts you and three others in front of a wall of smoke that kills anyone who can't manage to stay ahead of it. It's incredibly intense and a lot of fun if you can find people online to play along with you.I like this game very much and it offers a significant amount of replay value for your dollar, which is one of the best compliments you can pay a game of this type. I would recommend this to fans of the series looking for a change of pace and to those looking for some good two man gameplay. Look elsewhere for scares or you'll be sorely disappointed.

Fear 3 is a very capable fps with slow motion mechanism. I can't say it really stands out from the prior 2, because they all use the same formula.  If you'd played the others, you'll be right at home.  If not, you can play this one without playing the predecessors, because the story doesn't really carry over and this game is pretty polished with some pretty cool settings.  My main complaint with this series is that there is not much variety to the enemies so it gets rather repetitive after awhile.  Fortunately, this game isn't too long and it has some online modes you can play which I've read are decent as well.  I still for the life of me can't figure out why they have mechs in this game.  The game is hardly scary as it is, so let's give the gamer a nearly invincible suit to lessen any tension that might be there.

Let's get down to brass tacks; this is a fantastic Co-op game. Online is cool, but splitscreen is a blast. You play as pointman ( the silent protagonist of the first game, who can slow down time) and his deceased brother, whom he killed Fettel ( a morbidly amusing spectre that can use his ghostly abilities to levitate his enemies, setting them up to be shot by pointman, exploded in a cloud of gory awesome if you walk up to them and melee, or posessed and used as meat suits, giving Fettel all of pointmans abilities, sans time slow, until the meat suit dies, you run out of ghost juice, or you blow it up yourself, tee hee). You are trying to find your mother, a terrifyingly powerful psychic, who looks like a little girl, a naked woman, or a creepy pregnant woman after she raped the second games protagonist; don't ask, it doesn't matter.The story is superfluous. What does matter is the pitch perfect, lightning fast, gameplay that you and a friend will have a blast playing. Pointman and Fettel's individual abilities complement each other perfectly. When pointman slows down time, Fettel's melee becomes much more powerful. When Fettel levitates an enemy, they become a sitting duck for pointman to fill with holes. Fettel can also put a shield around pointman when things get hairy.While playing through the game, you will notice that you gain levels by performing in game challenges, like levitating ten enemies for your brother to shoot, getting fifteen melee kills, and shooting enemies from cover. Whoever plays better in the level is the "favorite son", and if they are the better player, the character they play as will get the ending.Now, take everything I have said, and cut the fun in half if you don't have anyone to play with. I'm not saying there is no fun to be had if you play this game solo, but it will not be the same experience. Only play this if you definitely have someone to play with. The online modes are all enjoyable, depending on how many people are online. All in all, if you have a partner, I highly recommend this game.
summary: Single player is fun, Co-Op is better

reviewText: I haven't played any other Fear games and so this might explain why the plot was completely lost on me. Two brothers brought up in a sterile experimental facility observed at play, at sleep and at war. Okay got that. For some reason though one of them doesn't talk and both boys really don't look alike at all. I'd like to see the milkman as I'm pretty sure we're looking at two different dads here. But regardless of the confusing fable presented in Fear 3, no good game's success should fall on the shoulders of the story being told however lackluster it may be. I mean, did we really care who the Space Invaders were? Nahh.So what you have is a solid FPS. Not really much variety of weaponry, and since you can only carry two weapons at a time it makes sense to have a long range and a short range with you and the shotgun and three-burst semi do the job thorough out the game nicely. There's slow-mo bullet time fodder which isn't nearly as satisfying as I expected as most bad guys take loads of rounds and in some cases many reloads to fall and often don't drop before bullet time has drained. For example there's a particular type of glowing blue bad guy that even in the game's easiest setting, Recruit, takes an inordinate amount of lead to drop. It does get kind of old at times.The atmosphere is obviously something worked on long on hard by the devs and there's at least a couple of truly spine-tingling moments in Fear. Usually these scares weren't so much from the 'BOO!' gotchas but more from some naturally creepy surroundings and audio that have been nicely constructed to induce suitable 'wet my pants' moments.Each chapter, or interval, usually is based around a particular location; supermarket, airport, broken bridge etc although later chapters are much shorter than earlier ones and this resulted in a quick wrap-up feel to the game especially the final boss battle.One factor I do like is once done, you can begin the game from the point of view of Fettel the more vocal of the two brothers. Without spoiling things, Fettel's abilities are more supernatural than Point Man's and add a really refreshing slant to a subsequent play through. The single player campaign also has an RPG element with rewards such as extra health or new abilities being awarded based on your performance and those stats are carried through from one play through to the next. Anything that gives more replayability should be applauded.Obviously the game has been also heavily tuned for co-op which unfortunately along with MP I did not play. No matter though as I felt I got more than enough game out of the single player mode and despite there being little new here I enjoyed the game for what it is.

I've seen a lot of reviews totally lambasting this title, but I have to say that I'm really enjoying the game.  I seem to remember the same thing happening with Fear 2, but I think I actually liked that game better than Fear 1.  I'm not sure what it is, but Fear 2 and Fear 3 just seem to resonate with me more than Fear 1 did.  The graphics and gunplay of Fear 3 are both very good, and the story works for me (However, I did have a lot of questions at the beginning.  Be patient.  Your questions will be answered as the game progresses).Just as in Fear 1, you play as the point man.  Armacham has imprisoned you in a far off country, presumably to isolate you and prevent any further disruption of their fiendish plot.  I won't give away any spoilers, but all three games' stories come together gradually.  Wes Craven and Steve Niles were both hired to assist with the writing and story progression.  Whether or not their involvement had any real impact on the story is anyone's guess, but like I said, I'm enjoying the story.  It's not really that scary.  In fact, the entire Fear series has never really been that scary (Half-life 2 and Turok: Dinosaur Hunter actually made me jump more than these games did).As in Fear 2 I find the gunplay to be excellent.  Hit detection and animations are very good.  I like the look and feel of the weapons (although there really isn't a huge selection).  Finding ammo is sometimes an issue during large fire fights.  The cover system works very well and is a welcome addition.  We get to run around in mechs again!  Overall, the gunplay is the meat and potatoes of the game, and it works.Graphics remind me quite a bit of Fear 2.  The color palette is once again varied.  Fear 1 looked really drab and monochromatic.  Fear 2 introduced a lot of brighter colors, and Fear 3 looks very similar.  The game is supposed to support DX11, but I don't think it looks quite that detailed.  I've got everything turned up to max settings (I have a GTX 580, getting 60 fps).  At any rate, it still looks pretty good.  Again, I think it's comparable to Fear 2.If you're a Fear 1 purist, you might not like Fear 3.  Many complain that the game is consolized, and they may be right.  Regardless, if you enjoyed Fear 2, then you will most likely enjoy Fear 3.  I can't really find too many shortcomings other than the graphics don't really seam to be DX11 and the story can get a little convoluted at times.  If you want a good shoot-em-up, you could do a lot worse.
