This game is awesome. Far exceeded my expectations. It looked like a decent shooter that was reminiscent of most FPS games. I thought it might be a lot like Borderlands (which would not be a bad thing...Borderlands was awesome!), based on the "points" received for well-executed shots, along with the ability to upgrade equipment and/or abilities along the way. In that sense, it really is like Borderlands. But it's really a very different game overall...and not in a bad way. It's got its own identity, and a very high fun factor.The good:+The skillshot system is awesome. You can play the game like any other shooter, if you want, and ignore the skillshots altogether. But it's so much more fun if you embrace the skillshots and pursue them. Note that not all of these are actually "skill" based, so that's a bit of a misnomer. For example, one of them is to get a kill by shooting or kicking someone into a high voltage fence. This doesn't really require any skill...just taking advantage of the right timing and use of the environment. Some of them ARE skill-based, though, and even the ones that aren't don't make them any less fun to pursue. Watching a guy get frizzled on an electric fence is pretty cool, even if it doesn't really require me doing anything specific to make it happen.+Along with the skillshot system is the upgrade system. You can upgrade your equipment and (to a lesser extent) abilities (things like health and so forth). This is very cool, and gives the game a bit more depth than most shooters. It also give you a little bit more incentive to pursue the various skillshots.+The graphics are actually pretty good. Colorful, detailed environments, many of which can be used with the skillshot system, and the effects are quite well-done.+The story is actually pretty good. It's completely absurd and over the top, but not necessarily in a bad way. If you don't go in expecting a riveting story, it's actually a pretty good premise. I won't spoil any of it, but it's got a decent antagonist who you really love to hate.+The length of the single player campaign is awesome for a FPS, especially compared to other recent shooters (COD games, for example, which are offensively short for the single player campaign). The SPC should take at least 8 hours for most players, and if you try to go for the skillshots, it will take even longer. The combat doesn't get repetitive because of the skillshot system.+The sound design is excellent. Effects on shots and environmental takedowns is great, the music is very cool. The only downside of the sound is the laughable voice acting, which can get grating after a while, but it does go along with the over the top story.+The "fun" factor. This game is just plain fun. It's frantic, hectic, and loud. Lots of energy and a fast pace throughout. Sometimes I wished that it would slow down a little bit for some contrast, and while that happened a slight bit, it didn't seem like enough. That said, though, this is also in line with the over-the-top nature of the whole game. The skillshots are loads of fun, and I just had a blast with this one. Very well done.The bad:-The game is very linear. Definitely an "on rails" kind of game. And by that, I mean it's VERY linear. When linear is done really well, it's not noticeable at all (like the Uncharted games - very linear, but I never felt like I was being pushed along a particular path in those). Here the linear nature of the game didn't really bother me much, because the skillshot system kept things fresh throughout, but I was definitely aware that it was linear throughout most of the game. You are pushed along singular corridors...and pushed, and pushed. There is almost no variation in approach to different areas, enemies, etc.-The user interface is somewhat confusing and unhelpful. It lists the various skillshots, but without any seeming purpose. It doesn't tell you how to accomplish those skillshots, nor does it clearly identify which ones you've successfully achieved and which you have yet to go. Many of the skillshots are only unlocked as you progress through the game, or as you perform other skillshots, but it's not clear which ones are new. Fortunately, this didn't seem to hamper the game or the skillshot system, but it could have added something to the game that wasn't, and it seems like a missed opportunity.-Language. SO MUCH CURSING. Why is this kind of language necessary? Some of the quips were funny, once. But they repeat the same jokes and foul language, over and over and over. It does go with the over the top story, but it's just not necessary, and would have been a much better game without it.Overall:This game is loads of fun. A more open-world format, a better UI, and FAR less foul language would have made it near perfect. Here's hoping for a sequel that addresses some of these issues, but the game is definitely recommended for FPS fans.Gameplay - 8/10Plot/Story - 6/10Graphics - 7/10Sound - 6/10Length - 8/10Fun - 9/10Overall - 8.5/10 (not an average)NOTE: I didn't include anything about the coop or multiplayer aspects of the game, because I never play multiplayer at all...ever...so I couldn't care less about it, and can't speak to it. Sorry. But apparently the coop is somewhat limited but pretty cool, and the multiplayer is pretty neat in itself. Others can speak to this.

Shooters are my favorite games.  What makes Bulletstorm so fun is not only the gameplay, but the bawdy and rambunctious characters and tone of the story.  If you like games that are dour and realistic, Bulletstorm is not for you.  If you enjoy a bit of witty repartee between eviscerations and bludgeonings, make Bulletstorm you next purchase.The point system that rewards for audacious killing is somewhat similar to the game, Madworld (a terrific game).  There is a lot of fun to be had trying out new and inventive ways to slaughter the villains and mutants who seem to be constantly on the attack.  The LEASH is a fun device for hurling enenies about, and the SLIDE feature is similar to the slide mechanic in VANQUISH (another terrific game).  The point is, there are lots of ways to kill enemies that don't involve shooting.A must for run-and-gunners.

First of all, I will not say that this game is better or worse than Black Ops considering how different they are.  From a campaign perspective, I think Bulletstorm is hands-down a better game than Black Ops.  BTW, I play a lot of Black Ops and, for the most part, I think it's a better game than reviews indicate.Anyway, Bulletstorm is tons of fun to play.  I'm not much of a sci-fi guy but the story is good and the action is a blast.  Kicking guys into cacti, leashing an enemy to pull him into a metal gate and impale him on a piece of rebar...awesome!  The variety of ways you can kill never gets old.  I adapted very easily to the controls and the physics of the game and am easily able to switch between this and other shooters without any problem.  If I were judging strictly on campaign, I would give this game 5 stars without question.Unfortunately, the multiplayer is quite lacking.  If the Treyarch guys put too much into multiplayer and not enough campaign, the developers of Bulletstorm are guilty of the opposite.  It's fun to play but there is only one mode (Anarchy) and no way you can actually battle other players.  It's just a team of players going against AI enemies.  Like I said, it's fun but pretty weak considering the competition out there in the FPS genre and it gets boring pretty quickly.  I bought Black Ops in November of last year and I still play the online multiplayer.  I still play games that are 2 or 3 years old because of multiplayer but I don't suspect the case will be the same with Bulletstorm.  I will probably play the campaign through one more time on a harder than normal difficulty and shelve it.I disagree with the reviewer who claimed that this game is all about shock value because of some coarse language.  There are about 5 R-rated movies released in any given week with more coarse language than this game.  Even if you are offended by foul language, it's incorrect to say that this game is about shock value, there is some definite substance here from a gamer's perspective, I'd just like to see them take the multiplayer further.
summary: This game is ALL ABOUT FUN...but multiplayer sucks

reviewText: I played through the story line, and I enjoyed playing the game,  Some people have complained about the language and story,  but I thought that the way they integrated the experience aspect with the story line was good, it makes sense to the story that your gaining skill points which is different then other games.  The story is not fine literature,  but then again it's a FPS.  If you want a story driven game this is not the right place to look for it,  I am aware other games have story and action but this game is not trying to do that,  It is not like they shot for something and missed,  they aimed at a specific goal and made it.The graphics and good,  and the game play is engaging as well,  the skill points aspect of the game is fun, and not as repetitive as I thought when I looked at the reviews,  it is all based on how you play the game,  if you change up the weapons frequently then it is not that big of an issue,  if you use the same three guns the entire game it will be an issue.I am extremely disappointed in the multiplayer function,  I have a good internet connection at my house, and this game kept saying some odd message about something or other not being properly set so I would have trouble hosting a game,  I have not had this issue with any other game I have played or owned, so I am a little confused,  also I have gone back to older games that I enjoyed playing online,  Resistance two is one of my all time favorites,  it came out a while back and has a lot of features,  Games are supposed to progress and develop new features,  all games have lets say a death match or team death match,  one of the recent halo games has something called Horde which is basically the only multiplayer function in Bulletstorm.  Resistance Two has all those other multiplayer plus team based missions that change up every time you play a map, so that no two times are the same really,  the objectives in each mission and they change up so that you have a unique experience.  None of that in this game,  it is the same thing every time,  you have to play with a certain number of people, and you have to gain skill points by killing enemies,  but the maps I have played on were so small that the other people kept killing people right before I tried to,  We were fighting over enemies to kill... Lame.I am giving this game three stars for that reason,  EA is going to charge people who buy the game used ten dollars to use the online features,  or just to play the story mode,  not sure if you can just play offline.  But that is really unfair to consumers,  first to charge them, but also because the content is not working as well as it should,  the one multiplayer match I got into was glitchy, and they decided that the best place to put a warning about internet connection was in the center of the screen,  I was playing and right in the middle of the screen was "internet connection bad" or something like that in big black letters,  not cool.  So The only thing that you really get is a single type of multiplayer game, where you work with other players to fight a bunch of bad guys,  to get points and your ranked when you play echos,  that does not seem worth charging people who want to buy a used copy ten dollars.  They should have put in the other standard multiplayer games,  Death Match, Capture the Flag, and so on, as well as team based for the same thing.  They could have been more creative, then using something that is basically a multiplayer version of the game in a smaller level, Resident Evil 5 added Versus, but they charged players,  if games are going to be adding multiplayer DLC that seems really wrong,  I will bet anyone that they release DLC and the download will be super small because like some other games,  it will just release content on the game disc.Also people who have complained about the language should know that you can turn it off in the main menu,  you can also turn off blood and gore.This game should have been better in terms of the multiplayer,  because that is how most people get hours out of a game,  but this games multiplayer functions are super lame,  and non creative,  I mean just off the top of my head they could have used the gravity boots from the first five seconds of the game to do a sky scrapper death match, where your running around a building,  they could have had a death match where not only do you have to survive but you have to make your way through a collapsing building a very popular theme in the game,  expanding on that they could have a team based version where one team has to keep you from escaping and destroying the building.  That took me two minutes,  the game developers had a lot more time to give players a really fun multiplayer experience, and instead they gave us one lousy mode that hardly works,  and they expect people who buy used games to pay ten dollars to be able to play it, as well as not being able to play on multiple platforms,  the days of games making it easier to go play at a friends house or lend games is being destroyed by EA.

The game follows Grayson Hunt voiced by  Steve Blum (who is most well known for his voice as Spike Speigle in the cowboy bebop anime series) and Ishi Sato as they are on another mission given by their general Serrano, lets just say things go wrong and they end up on a ex resort planet now populated by mutants. reviewText: I'm a big sci-fi shooter fan, so when I read reviews that Bulletstorm wasn't outright terrible it was a no-brainer to try it out.From the product description I was expecting a stupid-fun, uncomplicated shoot-em-up that didn't draw you in with story or complexity but just gave you something to enjoy for your money.  I have to say that even given those constraints, I was pleasantly surprised.For a start, it IS stupid fun.  The dialogue is b-movie rogue hero stuff and progress is linear and direct, with no bother with an open world/roam anywhere playing field.Simple, yes, but the first surprise came with the highly polished gameplay.  Controls are fluid and instantly familiar.  Character movement is smooth and aiming is easy.  Fun and combat variety come from the "leash," "thumper," kicking, and sliding mechanics.  Leash an enemy and yank them toward you, and they float in slow motion for a few moments while you kick or shoot them to pieces.  The skill-based kill system is fun, encouraging you to be creative.  What they also got right is they don't make it impossible to do this by overrunning you with hoards of enemies.  While combat is well paced, you still have time to try out those various kills.  The more creative you are, the more points you earn.  Some of the skills are comical too (kill a burner by shooting his butt), and the whole game has a carefree, lighthearted feel to it.But the biggest surprise is the graphics.  Some reviews here say they are so-so, but with a mere 720p HD LCD the environments are, gasp, really beautiful.  I didn't expect this at all, but the vistas are just gorgeous.  The environments are non-repetitive, very well detailed, and varied.  You won't see pieces of wall design repeated all over the place.  They are also accurate, in the sense that what you see from a given vantage point is what you played through earlier, not just a generic canvas.  For example, standing on a huge dam, in the distance you can see the collapsed railroad bridge that you fell from earlier, and the ground way down on your right looks like what you played through to get where you are now.You get the usual doses of variety.  There's the mounted-gun-on-a-train section (with the truly awesome sight of a huge turbine rolling along behind you), and a great section where you get to control a big mechanical dinosaur - laser beam eyes! - to mow down enemies.  How many games let you control a big dinosaur in a future amusement park?  Hilarious fun and every little boys' dream.It's definitely not a little boy's game, though.  Language and violence are very adult.Although I haven't quite finished it yet (I'm close to the end of the single-player campaign), I'm pleasantly surprised.  The game may not take itself too seriously, which is part of what makes it so fun, but the developers definitely DID take it seriously.  They may have set out to make a stupid-fun shooter with an ingrown silliness (like drinking the booze bottles you find and getting drunk for a few seconds), but that didn't stop them from taking their jobs very seriously.  Solid controls, beautiful graphics, no glitches to speak of, and the combat system all more than make up for the lack of story.  Who cares when you're having this much fun just kicking *ss and taking names?
summary: Surprisingly more than just dumb fun

This may be one the greatest bargain bin games ever!  I spent much more on the gameback in late winter, and I'll still get my $'s worth.  Don't even worry about getting a new copyor paying for an online pass, because the multiplayer has two forms of effective combat, kickingand leashing (electric whip).  There is an echoes mode, in which you replay campaign levels (i'm not convincedthat it's a different form of gameplay); echoes is like a condensed campaign.  While playing Bulletstorm,I occassionally felt the title of the game pertains to the action, but in the final level, in which you get to mantwo consecutive gattling guns, the title of Bulletstorm rings true.  There's alot of color in the game, and a good varietyof gameplay.  The outdoor environments look great, but the indoor levels make you wish the entire gamewas played out in the open, where you can see all of the alien planet.  The nature of the gameplay lends better to spacioussettings than cramped spaces.  Some games produce a feeling of suspense in tight, dark places, but Bulletstormjust oozes a claustraphobic feeling.  You can choose to play the game either from a distance or up close and personal.There's a decent array of weapons at your disposal, which are unlocked as the game progresses.  My favorite toolsof destruction are the sniper rifle and bombastic lasso gun.  The gameplay's usually brainless, but occassionally,you have to use your noggin to solve puzzles to open pathways.  I didn't have a use for all of the points I collected,because you're supplied with ammo, and once you unlock charge shots, your equipment isn't upgradable.  I can seehow this would be a "point freak's" game, because there are alot of ways to score big.  If you're like me, and just wantto stay alive while causing as much destruction as possible enroute to the closing credits, Bulletstorm will entertain you,but not thrill.  I did feel a sense of accomplishment after intense fire fights in some of the later levels.This is an innovative, solid FPS.  Don't waste much time on the multiplayer unless you really enjoykicking baddies into sharp things.
summary: Great for what it's worth; Shooter McGavin reigns.

reviewText: This game was fun and I just enjoy the the kill with skills idea. Making want to kill everyone a different way. Story isn't epic or anything, it's okay, but very predictable. After playing mostly Call of Duty games, it just reminded me of when I first started playing Unreal Tournament. I like using all the guns and the leash. Controlling the sniper rifle was new since I suck with sniper rifles and this made it interesting. Same with using the leash. I did find it hard to buy ammo for all the weapons, I stuck to just a few weapons I like. But the game was still not that hard at all and I was able to beat it in 6 hours. Problem is there's really nothing to do after you beat it. Unlike other games were you can go into multiplayer and just start blasting other people. The multiplayer here is just you in a party of 4 fighting waves of enemies. The issue here is I really don't know anyone else with the game so you got to partner with random people who might not care about team work. Plus I had a hard time connecting just to start a game so I just didn't bother trying. The "Echoes" mode is just you going through the single player game again trying to get the most skill points as possible. So nothing really new there. The leashed might have been the issue for a deathmatch multiplayer game mode, but couldn't they disable that for multiplayer?  Anyways this was a fun game for the 6 hours I played it, but there is no lasting appeal and I probably should have rented this instead. In face I recommend everyone else to just rent it, don't waste your $60. My friends were asking me if they should get it, I told them I'm done and they can just borrow it. There's an online code like all EA games, but single player is all they need. Based on the ending, there will definitely be a sequel, I hope they add a better multiplayer mode.

Got Bulletstorm the day after it came out and played the demo before I got it just to know what I was getting into. Bulletstorm starts out with you, Grayson, drunk off your a** trying to get information out of a prisoner. Then you start going through the basic movement mechanics of the game to get a feel for it. The witty remarks that are made by Grayson are off the wall and very hilarious. This game flows very well is graphically decent looking...but its gameplay and story are what set it apart.Grayson and his team of Dead Ops were sent out to perform hit missions coming to find out the people they were killing were actually innocent civilians trying to expose the Confederation of heinous crimes. Grayson decides to rebel against them and become a pirate destroying any and all Confederate ships he runs into. Then, one day, drunk off his a** he finds, the main ship with the general who betrayed him on it. So being completely smashed he does the logical thing, starts attacking it wildly with a turret. He succeeds in bringing it down along with his ship on a semi-deserted planet. That is where the story begins...and I am not giving up anymore than that.When it comes to gameplay and combat...this game does it well. A decent variety of weapons with a regular attack and a charge attack. You can upgrade the ammo clips and charged attacks as well. The fun part of this game is doing the different skills. Everynight I am sitting there thinking of new ways to lay these idiots out. Favorite has to be the flail gun (explosive attachment) then kick them into a group of enemies...AWESOME!!! You are going to have a lot of fun doing the different things in this game, I guarantee it.This game is worth its price tag, have not been online with it yet but it has a variety of play modes and kind of a beat the score mode as well. As a huge fan of Epic Games and the Gears franchise, I was very excited about this game. But after playing it I am very dissappointed overall.The Pros...Anarchy Mode (Although it was poorly implemented, see below)Pretty good visualsNice weaponsSolid enough campaignYou can actually customize your characters, which was something that was absent in Gears and Gears 2. A nice addition.ConsNo co-op campaign. I realize this may not work with the whole "kill with skill" gimmick, but its not a good excuse to not have it, in my opinion.Poorly implemented Anarchy Mode. Although the concept is great, and I still play horde mode a couple of times a week, they really dropped the ball here. They rush you between rounds when you have to purchase your weapons, upgrades and ammo. They give you 30 seconds and then that's it, you have to wait until the next round. Why put a time limit on this?Many times the combinations don't execute properly or you aren't awarded the points even when you do exactly what you were supposed to.Only a handful of maps doesn't help any at all. I know that its probably difficult to make maps for a game like this because of all the interactive elements on each level, but they should have had a few more.I enjoyed the campaign and the anarchy mode will provide you with a few hours of enjoyment, but you'll soon tire of the kill with skill gimmick. I'll probably trade the game in next week; its not worth holding onto even for the Gears 3 Beta.

I got this as a Xmas gift from a coworker and Love it and truly have enjoyed it to the point that having finished on easy found that jumping to normal really became tough and just learning to work on skill kills since easy kills = very little reward to put towards real weaponry/upgrades.Be forwarned that this thing is truly "M" with it's non-stop potty language/gore as they must have had a committee appointed to determine the most outlandish crude language so you definitely want to go into the menu settings to turn it off and the gore if you have kids, however, I'm not a prude at 61 and no kids in the house and found the language and the techniques for kills actually adding tremendous humor as you work through the levels as I normally don't like slasher gore games but it became quite humorous using the leash and thumper to smash or skeet shoot them in midair or use the environment around you to creatively destroy them.  Even the sniper rifle was cool as I kept missing not realizing they move after you shoot and you get to aim the slomo bullet in flight and it's not as easy as it seems to get a hit - whats cooler is if you hit an explosive target to burn the enemies instead as body shots get you a paltry 10 points.Also, be forewarned that there are periods where the game has some glitches where you may be suspended in a region that you cannot escape or get locked into the scenery and your left with no choice but to restart a checkpoint or chapter unfortunately.  I would guess during each playthrough twice it occurred about 2-3 times but during about 8-10 hours gamelay simply meant some do over killing.Been playing FPS since Doom was a shareware piece, and a big fan of Serious Sam Series and EDF and love the simplicity and while you can do the easy level fairly quick it offers up the Echo challenges and the game much more difficult.  This is no Borderlands where an addiction factor with collecting weapons and DLC's that can keep you busy for months and months through two tiers and 69 levels but it can be intense, challenging, and IMO humorous as can be the way it's presented.  You'll finish it quickly on easy and just getting used to the skill kills and want to play again since you may be just getting used to how to use many of the weapons since you have to earn money to buy up and ordinary kills equal very little to buy the real kick-butt weapons and charges.Got my copy for free and love these type $20-$30 budget games but realize this title is truly an "M" rated title folks and it's strictly kill as quickly and creatively as you can and proceed forward - this is not Borderlands GOY edition addiction but in some cases it's more intense in quick spurts versus wandering a massive map of Borderlands and honing your addiction to the weapons collection and crazy time spent surviving all the Underdome challenges and just one of those 20 levels of five in three arenas takes far longer and harder than this entire game - the Underdome DLC took me months to survive them all at Tier 2 whereas this game will be done in a day or two at easy.  Different beast altogether but well worth the money IMO.  Enjoy but turn off the potty mouth in the settings if you desire or you have kids or spouses sensitive to that because the dialogue and four letter words are unrelenting as ones bullets!

First off, this game is very fun, but there's no need for anyone to buy this game; people should just rent it. The main story is pretty short (I'd guess around 6-8 hours though I'm not sure) and there's really no other modes to sink your teeth into. There's a challenge mode where you can join your friends and essentially play small portions of levels. However, with no competitive aspect and little variety it quickly becomes boring.The story is a relatively generic jock sci-fi throwaway which ends up taking place solely in a blown up theme park. The game is very vulgar, but in a childish way where it's so stupid it's kind of funny. However other times it comes back around and you're left just shaking your head. The leash is an interesting gaming weapon, but it is very simplistic, allowing for very limited attacks and experimentation. Most effective attacks boil down to leash a guy to you (unless they're "too fast" which was annoyingly ridiculous) kick them away and blow of their head. The guns you get are pretty cool, but with very limited ammo most of the time and only two weapon spots the fun is limited. Also, the coolest part of the weapons, getting a new one and trying it out on a bunch of baddies, ends around 3/4 of the way through.The whole point system is very interesting, with how the leash gives him the hud and points for effective play resulting in ammo and weapon upgrades, but at the same time it gives points for things that break the idea. For example groin shots (dude, you just don't shoot another guy in the d*ck), getting drunk, and killing insects. Why not just get rid of all the pretense and make a wicked awesome game, who cares if it does or doesn't make sense.Finally, I had a multitude of glitches, the worst being a game breaking glitch where I had to restart the whole level. Along with that large glitch (of which I've heard there are many other gamebreaking glitches, mostly involving your AI partner getting stuck) there are many other smaller ones, for example some of the animations/challenges not activating when they should (especially for nut shots).In the end, this game is essentially a placeholder for Gears of War 3. If they didn't have to release it when they did, I think Epic could have had an absolutely amazing game on their hands.

The title of this piece refers to an interview I once saw with the developers of Halo: Combat Evolved. This was Bungie's big goal, to create 30 seconds of fun for the gamer, and then let him do it again and again. And it worked - Halo is arguably one of the greatest FPS franchises in the business!However, without fail, the same thing could be said for just about EVERY shooter out there. Point, shoot, reload, point, shoot, reload... Still fun though, right?People Can Fly and Epic Studios have done just that with their new opus, Bulletstorm. Only, this time, they added a couple new wrinkles to that 30 seconds; a nifty new tool, the tether; and a carnival house devoted to pain! Just about everywhere one looks in Bulletstorm, one sees something they wouldn't want to get too close to in real life - cactus covered in deadly spikes, exposed electrical wiring, man-eating plants, etc. Each of these things are designed to be used by the player to rack up crazy combinations of over the top violence visited upon the bodies of maniacal (and most probably cannibalistic) muties out to kill you. The more you manage to wring out of a combo, the more points you get. However, since points in Bulletstorm equate to cash, and cash is what you need to buy more ammo and upgrades for your fabulously twisted weapons arsenal, it behooves the player to be as creative in his kills as he possibly can. This "skillshot system" is what changes everything - People Can Fly obviously love video-games, and it shows in a perfectly balanced system designed to reward player creativity with bigger and better toys...One example is the flailgun, a weapon you find early on that shoots spiked grenades connected by a chain like a sadistic bolo, perfect for tying up a foe which you can then use to fling into a group of his buddies before remotely setting off the explosives, multiplying your skillshot count by the overall amount of enemies. If any of them end up stuck to a cactus, or slamming up against an explosive barrel, you get credit for those things, too! All these seemingly disparate mini-atrocities add up to one big score, which the player can then use to buy themselves something nice from the store. And since every item in the store is a weapon or something weapon-related, that "something nice" is definitely gonna be something you like. This, of course, is just one small example - not only does each weapon have a secondary mode, they also have their own specific skillshots to unlock inspiring the player to use each weapon in ways he may never have thought about before!As for re-playability, Bulletstorm has that in spades. Playing thru the campaign opens up challenge areas you can take on separately by yourself, or with a couple of friends (the main campaign has co-op as well!). Your scores are kept track of and placed on the gamerboards for everyone else to see. The better you get at manipulating each one of these spaces, squeezing out more and more skillshot points, the better you end up being in the campaign upon every consecutive play-thru. In the end, the experience is akin to billiards - the better you get at it, the more satisfying the experience. And with graphics this good, and characters this fun to hang out with, you're gonna want to get better...On the subject of multi-player, results can be mixed. If you're playing with friends with a common goal, you're gonna have a lot of fun. If you're playing with strangers, you're probably not gonna have any fun at all as most of the gameplay relies on mutual cooperation and good communication. But with a single-player experience this good, who cares?
summary: 30 seconds of sheer, unadulterated fun. Rinse. Repeat.

I got the chance to play this game's demo and felt completely overwhelmed by all the stuff that I felt you needed to do, but I decided to give the full game a chance just to see if I would have the same experience. Thankfully I did not have the same experience and I actual got into the game. In the game you will be playing as the character, Gray, a super soldier who goes rogue with the rest of his group. Several years after going rogue he sees the chance to take down the man who sent them on all those missions and decides to basically kamikaze the other's ship. Amazingly enough some people survived, you (of course), the man you want to kill, and a couple of others, but you have crashed on this planet. The planet is in disarray and there are gangs that roam the streets looking for control of all that is there. You'll have to fight your way through them if you want to have a chance at getting back at Saranno, the main who sent you on all the missions that you hate yourself for.Graphically this game looks pretty good, there's a couple of locales that you'll get to see through the game, and the character design for the different factions definitely give them a unique look, but then to fill the screen with bad guys its all cut and paste. There are a couple graphical hiccups in the cut scenes where certain things don't completely render, but overall the graphics stand up for this fact paced game.I couldn't tell you one thing about the music in the game, it just didn't stand out. What did stand out was the voice acting, there were quite a few voices in there that left me feeling like I had heard them before. The dialog was above and beyond cheesy, but I think for the most part I was able to forgive the game for it.The controls for the game definitely took a couple scenes before I really got a handle on them. Once I got the controls down, though, man I had a lot of fun quickly attacking, switching weapons, using the electronic tether, and kicking enemies into highly fatal situations. There was also the sliding mechanic of double tapping 'A' that definitely created some interesting scenarios.Overall this game, in my opinion, was made to rack up a high score. Its basically a game in which you want to be inventive on how you dispose of your opponent, and the game definitely gives you some environmental help in that area with large cactus, steep drops, foot carts, highly explosive containers, spinning blades, electric-charged cables, and more. Shooting the crap out of your enemy, then pulling them to you with the tether, then kicking them away, shooting them some more, and then watching them impale yourself can definitely have its moments of utter bliss, and also cause lots of points to pile up. Now there is a reason for the points, they will be used to upgrade your weapons, possibly unlock new ones, and reload your ammo reserves. You can also change what three guns you currently have equiped. For me personally I had the machine gun, the sniper rifle, and the shotgun, and I was hell on wheels with that combo. The game does try to get you to use all the weapons so that you can unlock all the special combos that will bring in the big bucks the first time you successfully do the required action, but after a while I kind of just stuck with what felt comfortable. Fighting your way through all those enemies can at times be really enjoyable, and sometimes frustrating because you will have cleared a section of a room or area, and then as you're trying to spot up to take on some enemies on the other side of the room all of a sudden more enemies appear at your back. So make sure you're protected when using the sniper rifle. That reminds me the sniper rifle is a very unique experience not only do you sight your target but you also control the bullet, apparently everyone in the game, minus you, has beyond human reaction time, so you're going to have to steer the bullet into the opponent if you actually want to hit them, otherwise you're going to miss almost every time unless you're trying to take on one of the bigger characters who can take a couple of rounds without falling. I did have one huge glitch happen to me in one of the levels where I somehow got so far ahead of my CPU companions that I couldn't progress any further, so my advice to you is that whenever you're taking an elevator make sure they are with you, if they are not you might have to replay an entire level all over again.With all the cheesiness and the arcady feeling I still really like the game. Yes it set itself up for a sequel, yes there's probably areas that could be improved, but at the end of the day if you're just looking to blow off steam and destroy enemies Rambo style, with some added flair, this is the game for you. This game gets an 8.3 out of 10.

I have been waiting for this game since I heard about it over a year ago. At that time I put it on my wishlist. Then a little over a month ago the demo hit Xbox Live. I downloaded the demo and was blown away. I came out of my room and hit the pre-order button in wishlist. I wanted to leave a review based on the demo and update when I got the game, but I waited.Fast forward to today. I have been counting the last few days down till release day and then I had to wait till after dinner to play because I had to help my kids do some stuff after school. Needless to say I was chomping at the bit. I put the game in and downloaded it to my hard drive as I ate dinner, so it would be ready when I was.This game is so amazing! Take the graphics and Unreal software engine ofGears of War 3, the post apocalyptic terrain ofBorderlands Game of the Year Editionand add the smart alec comments of ne'er-do-well and you have the building blocks to this game. Now make the game move at a pace faster than makes you comfortable and send the bad guys running at you headlong to rip you to shreds while their comrades are laying down covering fire for them. All this is just a set up for the games real feature... KILL WITH SOME SKILL!!Every weapon you you possess gives you a new way to kill the enemy. Every weapon combines with every other weapon to give you ways to kill the enemy. Now for the truely genius thing about KILL WITH SKILL, you earn points for each type of skilled kill that allow you to upgrade your weapons, buy new weapons and buy ammo to allow you to get new ways to KILL WITH SKILL. You even get environment skill kills depending on where you are in the story, plus you get skill points for being quick to look at the story elements the game wants you to see by pressing the left trigger quick. I am having a blast hustling thru the game at an advanced pace and getting my points for KILLING WITH SKILL. I laugh at the names of the kills and try for the harder ones continually (harder skill kills earn bigger points). The coolest part about the skill kills is that when they are unlocked, they tell you how to achieve them. No guessing, just more KILLS WITH SKILLS.I have not played the multi-player yet, but I am glad that it has both co-op and multi-player. When I do play some multi-player I will edit my review with the new info. A little side note about the game, I like that for no more cost, I got the Epic Edition by pre-ordering which gave me some cool multi-player bonuses (couple of skins, new leash color and 25,000 bonus experience to start muli-player with). I am actually glad they they didn't give me some over powered weapon that took the challenge out of the campaign portion of the game. Oh yea, I get access to theGears of War 3beta when it starts with, my epic edition purchase.In short this game offers great graphics, gameplay and fun. If you are wondering if you should get the game you should. Don't hesitate, because the longer you wait the longer it takes to KILL WITH SKILL!!!!!!
summary: OMG I love to KILL WITH SKILL!!!!!!

reviewText: I personally didn't get much out of this game.  My thoughts below.Pros:-The world was beautiful artistically.Cons:-I found the leash way too gimmicky.  It was fun at first throwing guys into walls of spikes etc., but then it just got repetitive and boring.-At one point in the final couple levels I got 'stuck' and literally had to reset the console and the game 5-6 times before the map would register that I killed all the enemies and let me open a door up. What a waste of time.-The NPCs were often no fun for me to fight and instead felt like a chore.-I found several of the boss battles incredibly annoying and often had to replay a lot of them too many times for it to be fun anymore. Perhaps I've just gotten old and bad at first person shooters.-Although unrelated to the actual gameplay for a shooter, the story was stupid and the primary villain was an idiot.Personally. I won't be buying into the next round.

I'd like to compare Bullet Storm with Duke Nukem mostly because it's over the top and attempt to take seriousness out of the game and put in intense violent action with funny colorful dialogs.Storyline ~I like to think that the developers were aiming for a 1980s style B-rated film plot line. For those of you who don't know, 1980's b-rated movies were generally gems where funny one liner dialogs and corny plots occur while trying to be serious but being extremely funny.The story of Bullet Storm puts you in the role of character who is trying to seek revenge. The character is part of a team who had orders from a general who told them to assassinate people they thought were terrorists but it turned out that the general only wanted to kill people trying to expose the truth about their government. The point is the story is ridiculous and silly.The game has it where you shoot down the general's warship, but your ship was badly damaged as well. You land on a planet that happens to be a resort planet, but somehow it was overrun by violent gangs and mutants. The entire game has it where you're to try and exact a revenge on the general.Many funny dialogs and plot are exchanged as you advance the story. I won't give away much but then there isn't really that much to say other than it's corny and silly and very unrealistic but it has its share of funny moments.Graphics ~The graphics of Bullet Storm is beautiful. As I said earlier, you're in a resort planet so you're going to see many wonderful tropical places as well as inner city surrounding a beautiful place. However, I've noticed sometimes when you think a place is beautiful, if you zoom in, you can see that they're not actually objects, but pictures that the developer trick you into thinking that it's a far off scenery. That isn't really distracting unless you take the time to really pay close attention.As far as your character graphics, there are so problems. While the graphics is wonderful, from time to time, the gun on your characters back may "bounce" or "distort" for a second. It doesn't happen often, but it does happen from time to time.Gameplay ~The game is set as a 1st person shooter. You do get one scene where you actually get to shoot from a space ship, but otherwise you're stuck in the 1st person view. The cut scenes tend to have it where you're viewing the characters in 3rd person, but sometimes you see scenes unfold in 1st person. Doesn't totally matter.The environment in this game is sort of confusing from time to time. You don't have "free roam" in areas. What I mean is, for example, you can't jump off a rail. Even more so, you can't freely move. While the environment may appear to be open and unlimited, you can't actually move around. You have to follow a set area and sometimes and invisible wall may block you from doing something. I recall one part near the end, you have a lot of "free roaming" but yet when you think you can go into an area, an invisible wall sort of blocks you from going to that area even though you can see an opening.You don't get that much of a weapon selection. You get guns and all of them has a primary fire mode and something called a "charge" shot which is basically like a secondary fire mode that cost you a "charge" that you can upgrade. You also get this thing called a whip, which is used to pull enemies out on the open. You can also you a charge shot on the whip which causes a lot of people to fly into the air at an radius. I found that most of the weapons are boring to use. They have some good ones like a grenade launcher, but it isn't fun at all. I found the best weapons are the standard machine rifle, pistol and the sniper rifle. The sniper rifle is probably the funniest weapon to use as you can navigate the round to the target. It's quite fun but again the AI behavior is the same. Like for example, if you use a sniper rifle, start steering it towards the enemy, he'll slow motion dodge it but once you figure out the pattern it's very easy because the enemy always does the same exact pattern.To get upgrades and ammo/charge shot purchases, you have to have point. Each time you kill an enemy, you get this thing called "skill shots" points. For example, if you just plainly shoot someone, you'll get really low points. But if you kick someone to a spiked fence, you get more points. You can compound it like for example, you can whip someout out in the open, kick them to a spiked fence then you get bonus points. It's fun at first, but sort of gets boring at the end when you realize every option is pretty much exhausted. In some cases you can kick these funny looking hats on people, or even shoot a plant that causes mass hysteria. You can even drink booze or inhale the mass hysteria plant and get bonus points by being in an intoxicated state. It's quite fun.There are problems executing the skill shots. For example, some places have decent barrels laying around. So if you "aim down the sight" sometimes the auto aim follows someone running off in the distance. So you miss the skill shot chance and now you're stuck having to find another way. It's rather annoying to have the auto aim lock onto something you don't intend to shoot. This can be bypassed though. I've learned that if you want to do this, don't aim down the sight. Instead hip fire and perhaps waste some rounds trying to do something that should have been done easily by aiming down the sights.Also, you get two AI partners in this game. While they appear hardcore in cut scenes, they don't really help out in game. They run around and from time to time may just run past enemies. I don't recall any AI saving me in the game. Matter of fact, they just randomly run around and take cover and so fort. Personally I like it where they don't help, but sometimes it's a wonder why they're so "dumb" yet in scenes they appear so different.Some of the boss battles in the game are excellent. I recall this one plant boss, and I never had so much fun fighting a boss. It's fun and exciting. However, that is pretty rare. I think that is the only large boss of the game. Plus one train level, you had to dodge a giant tire while escaping which was extremely fun and exciting times. The game has few great moments but near the end they degrade to simple story line. There isn't even a final battle except a button mashing one which made it about as exciting as pong in 2011.Overall I was happy with the game. The ending to it is horrible. Just horrible. It opens up for Bullet Storm 2, but I don't think I'm getting that title due to some of the issues with this game. Overall it's funny, but I don't think I want to make it a habit buying sequels to this game. It's fun but the story is non-existence and having one large, continuous b-rated storyline would not be very fun. Plus the gun play, which exciting at first, gets boring at the end when you figured out the patterns. Overall fun, but don't want a sequel.

I had fun with this game but it relies on one premise to make it fun and that's the skill-shots.  If you don't feel like doing them then this game is going to get overly repetitive and boring quickly.Story - You're the leader of a band of space pirates who were formerly a special ops group.  Your boss has had you killing innocent civilians while telling you they're bad/dangerous people.  You find out and now you want revenge.  Fast forward a little and you and the bad guy have crash landed on a planet full of criminals and some other things.  The rest of the game is you and your partner hunting down the bad guy to get your revenge.  Nothing really new or interesting here but it's a shooter so not a huge deal.Characters - There are 4 main characters.  You, your partner Ishi, a female spec ops soldier named Trishka and the main bad guy General Sarrano.  There are some minor characters but they die 2 seconds into the game.  There's nothing really great about any of them and you're very unlikely to get attached to any of them.  It's also unlikely that you'll end up hating any of them either.  They all serve their purposes so once again not a big deal.Dialogue - The game starts off on a bad note with every character swearing, and not just a little but a lot.  I don't mind swearing but it was like listening to a bunch of 8 year olds who just found out some "bad words".  It's fairly annoying at first and I thought I was going to dislike the game pretty quickly.  With that said, as the game goes on, it's clear that all this excess swearing is part of what they were going for to make the characters over the top for humorous effect.  Eventually, while I didn't enjoy the dialogue that much, I found that it grew on me somewhat and laughed at a joke here or there.Gameplay - Like I said, this is a skilless shooter.  You'll attack enemies until you get shot enough that your screen will turn red and you'll hide behind some object for about 4-5 seconds before your screen clears up and you're good to go again.  Repeat over and over.  You'll get a leash early on that allows you to grab an enemy and fling them towards you in the air, normally in slow motion.  You can use this infinitely and it'll work on nearly every enemy.  You also have the ability to kick enemies which suspends most of them in slow motion for about 3 seconds.The main premise of the game is to use your weapons, leash, and kick abilities to do special moves which get you points that you can spend to upgrade your weapons.  You'll get points for just killing enemies but not very much.  There are objects littered all over the board like explosive barrels, explosive hot dog carts, cactus, spiked bars, electric wires, etc.  By kicking enemies or leashing enemies into these objects you'll get extra points.  Each weapon will also have a list of special ways to use them to get unique kills that will get bonus points.  One of the nice things about the game is that the special moves list is sorted by each weapon and non-weapon.  It'll place a check mark next to any you've completed so that you know you've done it.  It'll also let you hit a button to hide any special moves you've done so that you'll only see the incomplete ones.  There are also a lot of quick time events that will pop up to give you more points.  Part of the problem is eventually you'll do most of the skill-shots once just to do them and get the bonus points they give and then you'll just be repeating the same boring easy ones over and over.The game is also extremely linear.  You aren't going to be exploring anything during the course of this game.  You'll be on a path the whole time and the game will even point out things you need to kick or leash in order to continue along this linear path.Weapons/Upgrades - Including the leash, I think there are 9 weapons.  There's a standard revolver, assault rifle, and shotgun but there are a couple unique weapons.  Some of these are useful and some are not really useful at all.  The sniper rifle is powerful but can get annoying.Every weapon has the same upgrades.  You'll spend an initial amount of points just to unlock the ability to upgrade it and access it's special moves list.  You can then spend points you've earned to buy ammo, get more total ammo, unlock it's special charge attack, buy charge attacks and buy more total charge attacks.  That's it.Enemies - There's really not a whole lot of variety.  You've got weak melee attackers, some suicide bombers and then everything else has guns and blasts at you.  None of them are challenging in the least.Challenge - If you're looking for a game that requires some semblance of skill than look elsewhere.  This game is just way too easy.  I wasn't sure what to expect coming in so I played it on hard and still found it to be a cakewalk.  You could beat this game never doing any of the special moves and just using the assault rifle the whole time.  Heck, outside of bosses/mini bosses/air units, you could probably just use the kick move the whole time and beat the game.  I'm not exagerating here.  There were parts where I simply just stood in one spot and kept hitting the kick button while melee enemies would run up to me and I would send them flying into some spikes, killing them without ever getting hit.  The mini-bosses aren't hard.  They're really just toughened enemies that will appear every once and a while with the other normal enemies.  They can be killed really quickly and with ease just using the assault rifle charge shot and the leash.  I think there are only 2 actual bosses in the game and both are incredibly easy.  The final boss is just fought in a quick-time event.  The only times you'll really die during this game is if you go out of your way to try and do a skill-shot.  Other than this, you'll almost never die.  It's also impossible to fall to your death as every ledge has an invisible wall to keep you up.Length - The game is maybe 8 hours if you spend time trying to do a lot of the trick shots.  If you ignore these or just don't care though, I could see people beating the game in 6-7 hours, maybe less.Minor problems - I don't know why but they don't have a jump button in the game.  You'll press the A button to vault over obstacles in your path.  The game also relies on a single auto save for your game.  I had the game glitch twice.  Once an enemy somehow pushed me on top of a car.  Because the game has invisible walls, I wasn't able to walk off.  Fortunately, I was smart enough to try using the slide button which got me off of it.  Another time some enemies or explosions pushed me into a pile of tables or something that I couldn't get out of no matter what I did.  I quickly reloaded the previous checkpoint before the game had time to auto save me in there and force me to restart the board.  The Echoes mode is simply parts of the campaign that you can play as a timed challenge to get points on a leaderboard.  Way to go the extra mile on that mode.  The entire campaign you have at least one AI partner with you yet there is no included co-op play.Overall - The game is alright and it has it's fun moments.  If you're doing the skill shots you'll have fun with the game.  If you don't bother with them then I hope you enjoy kicking enemy after enemy into a pit or some spikes since that's all you'll be doing.  The game is simply too easy and it's not satisfying killing these dumb enemies over and over again the same way.  This game is better than some skilless shooters but in the end this is simply another overrated skilless shooter.  I'd say the game is about a 6/10.

Looking at its trailers and hearing its reviews, I had little to no expectations for this game. But then I liked Gears of War and Shadow Complex games and since this was also being released by Epic, I thought why not give it a shot. After finishing the campaign mode and trying Ecos and Anarchy modes, I have to say I am quite surprised.***********PROS.***************-AWESOME COMBAT SYSTEM: This is the best aspect of this game. You can slide, leash to pull enemies, kick them and use variety of weapons with primary and second fire and pull a huge variety of combination off of them. At first you may feel like it may get redundant, but thanks to variety in levels, there are a huge variety of things you can do. Thanks to that you won't get bored till the end of the campaign.-VARIETY IN LEVELS: Other than awesome combat, there is plenty of variety in levels. Throughout the campaign you experience a variety of environments including the space, woody greenery filled areas, abandoned factories, building high in the sky that is about to fall apart and list goes on.-SURPRISES: There parts during the campaign where you will be surprised by certain events and the gameplay that will follow it. I really don't want to spoil it for you, but trust me you will like it.-GREAT GRAPHICS AND DECENT ART WORK: The first time I saw the trailer for this game, it really looked unpolished to me. But now that I have finished the campaign, I can say that since then they seem to have refined it quite a bit. Certain levels just look gorgeous. I guess never doubt the power of unreal engine.-VARIETY IN WEAPONS: There are 8 different types of weapons and that is not including the leash. Each weapons (including leash) has devastating alternate fire mode. There is just plethora of combos you can do if you mix and match these weapons. I personally enjoyed each and every one of them. Also, while some weapons may look and sound familiar from other games, they will play very differently in this game. For example with sniper rifle in this game you can change the direction of bullet after you fire it. I personally have enjoyed the variety very much.-UPGRADABLES: To top of each weapon is upgradeable with the skill point you earn by killing enemies in creative ways. This rpg element will truly encourage you to creatively kill enemies and get as many skill points as possible. While this rpg element is not as well thought of as other games, it still adds incentive to do your best.-ONLINE PLAY AND ECOS MODE: While not my favorites (see cons.), after you finish the game, you can stay busy by playing online multiplayer (anarchy mode) or Ecos mode which has the same levels as campaign but gives you stars on your performance.************CONS************-RELATIVELY SHORT CAMPAIGN: Hate how games these days have such short single player campaigns. Unfortunately bulletstorm is one of them. While I enjoyed each and every moment of the campaign I found it to be very short (~7-8 h max and that is because I explore a lot).-MINOR GLITCHES: I had my character stuck while jumping over objects at least 3-4 times. Unacceptable. All the games have glitches, but under no circumstances your character should be stuck like this. I mean you can't even kill yourself. Restarting the level is the only option.-MEH MULTIPLAYER AND ECOS MODE: Compare to some other games these days, I didn't enjoy the multiplayer so much. I got tired of it rather quickly. Also the Ecos mode felt the exact same as the campaign. I wish they had added more varieties.-LACK OF NEW GAME+ MODE: This is a game that can really use a new game+ mode (i.e. start with all the weapons you collected etc.). Unfortunately, it doesn't have it. So there are some really cool weapons and upgrades you get towards the end of the game. Unfortunately, if you want to use them again, you will have to play the game again and you will only get to use them for last few levels. Just very unfortunate.**********CONCLUSION****************Simply speaking I am looking forward to Bulletstorm 2. Partly because I enjoyed this game and partly I have faith in the developers that they will improve the weak aspects of this game. All and all I enjoyed pulling off crazy combos in beautiful, but destructible environments, but I wish they had longer campaign and had fixed some of the things described in the con section. I give this game 8.5/10.
While some things are rough around the edges, this game is a blast to play.  Give it a shot if you have the cash.

So, in bulletstorm you shoot weird monsters with big guns.  You shoot progressively bigger monsters with progressively bigger guns until you find the bad guy and shoot him for while (sorry, spoiler alert, you fight a bad guy at the end)...  Okay, so Bulletstorm doesn't bring much new to the table, but I promise you, you're not gonna care.  It takes the tried and true formula for a first person shooter, moves it forward at a double time and lets you try your best to keep up.  It's an old school roller coaster of a game, linear and almost totally on rails, that is well worth the price of admission.It doesn't start off so hot, though...  actually, it's starts off BRILLIANTLY, with your character drunk off his ass and interrogating a bound and bloody bounty hunter who was hunting a price on your head.  But it doesn't take long to devolve from there, as we get into some of the worst dialogue and story-telling I've heard in years.  There's an awkward flashback, then a jump in time, some terrible voice acting and me left wondering just what the hell is going on.  Not that it matters - it's pretty clear from the get-go who the bad guy is and his untimely betrayal comes as zero suprise.  Then I'm on some... resort?  Like, an entire planet that's a resort?  Is that what it is?  With tough chick side-kick and cyborg side-kick.  And there's gangs of guys and then gangs of... zombies?  I don't know, a bunch of things that look like Gollum with a gun.  Nothing is set up, things are kind of explained after the fact but not really; it's a narrative mess is what I'm getting at.  Early on I was having some dangerous and upsetting flashbacks toCall Of Juarez: The Cartel, which is an ugly path I didn't want to walk down again.  Bulletstorm, of course, doesn't take itself nearly as seriously as and Call of Juarez game; it knows it's borderline retarded and doesn't hesitate to wallow in that.  It's a brave and bold game, even if it does eat its own glue-stick.But where Cartell failed miserably, Bulletstorm exceeds.  The gameplay is frantic and addictive, putting a couple of new spins on space marine FPS.  There are a couple of gimmicks in this one that work out pretty nice, first among them being the 'leash'.  It's a beam of blue... energy?  Mind powers?  Who cares, you grab bad guys with it and fling them around.  Once flung (by anything, actually, not just the leash) the baddies spin through the air in a sort of slow motion, letting you plan some sort of grizzly demise for them.  You've also got a dedicated 'kick-in-the-face' button, which you'll use as much as any gun.  You see, bulletstorm is littered with environmental hazards (spikes, frayed wires, lava pits, cliffs) and you're rewarded with points for finding clever ways to kill. In fact, there's an in game list of well over a hundred different ways to explode (or what-have-you) a monster using your weapons, the environment, or some wacky combination of the two.  Harder combos yield more points and, since you need those points to buy bullets and upgrade your weapons, you spend most of your time not thinking about surviving but about how to most creatively dispatch.  It's a strong point for the game as well as a weakness: bullets are hard to come by, so you better get creative if you want to get heated at the next drop-box.  Constantly having to link up to dropboxes to resupply and monitoring your point intake gives the game a needlessly choppy feel and pulls you out of the action time and time again as you're constantly trading out weapons to ones you have bullets for or just ones that might fit the fight better.  In the end, though, that's a small hiccup and the swift and often brutal ways of maiming your opponents (maybe I'll light him on fire, shoot his leg off and kick him into the electrical wire?  It's been that kind of day, why not?) remain the highlight of the game.  And the more efficient you can become with it, the more satistying it is - leading to a healthy amount of replay value.Which is welcome, because the game is rather short (8 hours?  something like that?).  That, and the ending is incredibly unsatisfying, with the ending fight completely failing in comparison to some of the games more awesome and cinematic moments throughout.  Listen, I know you want to set up a sequel, but COME ON, give me SOME kind of final fight!  With a game this insane and a story as weak as this one, it would not be hard to BS your way into the plot for a second chapter once you've wrapped up this one.  Seriously, give me a satisfying final fight; I'm not in this for the plot at this point (looking square at you Halo 2).Even with its failings, I have to recommend Bulletstorm.  It's a lovely take on a FPS and a juicy dose of the old ultra-violence.  There are even some pretty gorgeous landscapes and truly cinematic moments scattered here and there that would be worth checking out all on their own.  All in all, it's an excellent title to keep on the shelf for a rainy day... or just any day you feel the need to light someone fire, fling them through the air and then impale them screaming onto a giant cactus.  You know, one of THOSE days.

I should first point out that I am not a fan of FPS games, until now. The FPS genre, to me was boring and not fun at all. I don't know what compelled me to download the demo way back when, but I did. I didn't play the demo until just about two weeks ago and I must have played through the demo 10 times. It was just fun. the gameplay was fresh, the idea was fresh, and the concept doesn't feel like a clone of another game. FPS's seem to be a dime a dozen these days, cloning one after another, but throw in a leash, some kicking and sliding, ultra vio-lence, about 999 ways to kill a baddie and a breath of fresh air is breathed into a genre I thought to be very stale. I haven't played any online modes just yet as I like to complete the campaign before I delve into any competitive play, but from the standpoint of being about 3 hours into the campaign I can absolutely say that this is the most fun I have had with a game in the FPS genre. Without taking itself too seriously and just throwing a ridiculous plot together with with cohesive gameplay this game is just pure win.

I'll be honest, I only bought this game because I was getting bored of CoD: Black Ops and wanted something to tide me over until Dragon Age 2 came out.  So I figured, why not get the game and also get the GoW 3 Beta as well?  Surprise surprise, turns out this game is one hell of a fun ride!As someone else mentioned, this game is essentially Gears of War meets FPS.  The graphics are phenomenal and the Unreal Engine still kicks butt.  It literally feels like a faster, looser, and even more violent version of Gears from a 1st person vantage point.  I gotta say, I really got into this game the second I started playing it.The story is pretty disposable - which is totally fine because I didn't really care about the plot because all I was thinking about was how to do as many different skill-based kills as I could with the awesomely fun arsenal of weapons that I had.  Even something as simple as using the whip was hilariously fun.  It's awesome when you can just do all sorts of different combo kills - even the simple ones such as whipping a person into the air, shooting them, then whipping them back again so you can kick the body back away and shoot a few more rounds for posterity comes off as insane and fun.  I also like how there is a very detailed list of kill types that you need to hit if you want to add bonus skill points.I started out playing only a little bit, but suddenly I found that several hours had passed by.  That's how this game works.  It just sucks you in because of the easy to pick up controls, solid gameplay, and addictive kill kill kill action that really never gets old.  Definitely worth picking up!ADD: I forgot to note the multiplayer aspect.  I had a decent time with it, as it reminds me of the horde gametype in GoW.  Had a blast playing with 3 other players to wipe out tons of NPCs, though in this case, it's the STYLE kills that really matter.  In the later rounds, it gets hard to level up unless you and your teammates meet the skill challenge kill.  Teamwork for killing is important, which is a nice twist from the usual point shoot kill move on aspects of some FPS games.  It did take me awhile to get into a game, but once you're in things were pretty smooth for me.

Having seen a video demo of this game before it came out, I was very excited. The gameplay seemed fluid and innovative. It seemed like gears of war combined with something that I've never seen before.However, from the very beginning of the game, it becomes evident that whoever wrote the dialogue was trying to make it as offensive and hard to listen to as possible. Don't get me wrong, I don't mind swearing at all. I'll gladly listen to a game that throws around R-rated language. That's not what bothers me. The thing that does bother me, however, is that there's a line between language being relevant and language just being annoying and childish. This game gets a running start and long-jumps over that line. The language of this game is reminiscent of the beginning of middle school when kids were just learning all the naughty words and had no idea how to use them. The characters throw around swear words that not only are not needed in a situation, but often don't even make any sense in the context in which they are used.And not only is the language bad, but the dialogue is just pathetic in some places. Most characters seem to have believable lines, however there are some (particularly the robot version of one of your allies who follows you throughout the game) who just spout poorly-written line after poorly-written line.Aside from that, though, the game is actually a fun and creative shooter. The gameplay is really smooth and fun. The game is a little over-the-top gory, but not much more than other games of the genre. I especially enjoyed sliding, for some reason.I really feel like this game could've earned a four or five star rating if not for the abysmal dialogue.Bottomline: fun game, terrible dialogue. I would recommend renting this game instead of buying it.

Before I start this review, let me ask you a few questions.  Are you an "experienced" gamer that has been playing FPSs for years?  Are you bored to tears with military style shooters that are so similar to one another that they all kind of just blend together?  Did this last iteration of killzone feel more like a chore than a good time?If you answered yes to any or all of these questions then bulletstorm might be the fresh take on the FPS genre that you need.PLOT:  I've read a few reviews bashing the plot of this game, and I honestly don't understand why.  Okay, nobody is mistaking Bulletstorm for Mass Effect.  But you know what?  It's not trying to be Mass Effect.  Bulletstorm does not take itself seriously, and neither should you.  The language and jokes are supposed to be over-the-top ridiculous, and if you can get into the spirit of what it's trying to do, you'll get some good laughs out of it.  And let's be real, if you think other FPSs like CoDMW/BO or BFBC2 have well constructed narratives, then you are sadly mistaken.Graphics:  I personally loved the graphics on this game.  It's probably not as technically impressive as KZ3, but the environments, colors and art direction put it above KZ in my book.  Some of the outdoor vistas are jaw dropping, and the set pieces in this game are absolute top notch.  The only time it got a bit "blah" was in a few of the underground levels later on.  These are few and far between though, and overall this is an extremely pretty game.Gameplay:  This is where Bulletsorm shines.  The leash mechanics work beautifully once you get the hang of it.  The shooting is tight and accurate.  Your character feels fast and agile, with a slide/kick function that provides you with several options for how to dispatch enemies.  But the best thing about Bulletstorm is that the "kill with skill" mantra is actually fun (really fun) to work at.  When I bought the game I thought that some of the kills I saw on the trailer would simply be too difficult to pull off, but the game is great about picking up what you are trying to do, and providing some assistance to help you get it done.  You'll want to play this game again just to go back through and find all of the neat ways to massacre your enemies.  I almost never repeat a game, and I'm already on my second playthrough of Bulletstorm.NOTE: for the people saying that these mechanics don't add anything to the game, they simply aren't trying to get anything out of the skillshot system.  If you go through BS like it's MW, then it will feel pretty familiar, but you'd be doing yourself a disservice.  There is so much to explore gameplay-wise, that it is an absolute fail not to experiment with the unique selection of guns and skills.Online:  I've only dabbled online, but this seems to be the only failing in the game.  I would have really like to seen some competitive online MP, but the closest we get to that in BS is the Echoes online play, which is essentially just an online leaderboard that keeps track of your scores for certain levels.  There is also some coop type games that are someone amusing.  Overall, these are all pretty lackluster.Verdict:  If you want to experience something new in the FPS genre, get this game.  Outstanding gameplay and gorgeous graphics highlight a fun, but simple romp on an alien world.

Bulletstorm, put simply, is a non-stop action-shooter that won't let up until the credits roll. Once I picked up the controller I could not put it back down. The result was a game I finished quickly but find unquestionable replayable whenever I'm in the mood for insane FPS action!While the story is fairly generic, the voice acting and "crude" or "vulgar" dialogue (hilarious stuff, by the way) make the cut scenes a joy to witness. Characterizations are good, too, so you will care what happens to these people, you just might not be surprised.Gameplay is king here. Nothing feels more rewarding that rushing into the next battle zone, pulling an enemy towards you in slow-mo, then using your gun or mighty boot to send the poor fellow into a bed of spikes, pitfall, or giant cactus. Combat is generally fast and fluid. You'll also be rewarded for embracing the "kill with skill" mentality. Get creative and you'll receive points that allow you to purchase weapon upgrades and ammo. You won't get bored!Graphics are mostly good. Close-ups of characters tend to reveal some weakness (especially with hair detail and animation) but everything else looks great, especially the stunning backgrounds. During a brief moment of peace between firefights you'll eventually find yourself on a gorgeous seashore surrounded by mountains, waterfalls, and giant gears, all framed by a beautifully rendered sky and sunlight. The inclusion of such beauty amid the horrors of constant fighting is wonderfully effective.The game gets a strong five stars for presentation, insane levels of fun, and creative use of vulgar language. However there is one MAJOR issue that comes up at the VERY end of the game.SEMI-SPOILER ALERT!!!The ending sequence sets up a sequel that will likely never see the light of day due to lack of sales. I understand that the folks who made the game are a smaller group with the enormously successful Epic Games, makers of the Gears of War franchise, but they should have known better than to put a cliffhanger at the end of a brand new intellectual property. As someone who absolutely adored Bulletstorm from the opening seconds, it pains me to know that there is no true closure to the events.That said, I suggest starting a petition for a the developer (People Can Fly) to create a DLC package containing the final mission, so that everyone who loved the adventure of Grayson Hunt can finally get the closure they deserve.SEMI-SPOILER ALERT OVER!Conclusion: if you like over-the-top action shooters, and maybe hilariously off-color dialogue, this is a game you absolutely MUST play! Recommended for Xbox 360, but the PC version should be just as awesome if the demo is any indication. Get it now!

Bulletstorm is a fun game for the short time it lasts, but it really doesn't bring anything new or inspiring to the table.  The combat is fluid, the graphics are beautiful, and the sound is really well done.  The story is your typical betrayal/revenge deal, but the main point of the game is to massacre everything from point A to point B for about 8 hours.  Stringing together combos and using the environment to kill your enemies is fun for a while, and there are a wide variety of ways to do this, but I eventually just kept using the same simple combos over and over.  Those who are offended by harsh language and exploding/maimed/dismembered bodies need not apply, as the game contains a lot of both.  I didn't get a chance to play the multiplayer/co-op so those modes did not hurt or help my score of the game.  People that live and breathe FPS should check the game out, everyone else should get the game on the cheap if they're on the fence.  All in all, a fairly good game that I would like to see more from in the future.
