reviewText: This game starts out pretty slow and I almost quick.  But after playing for a while I really started to get into it.  Oddly, it is almost a DIRECT ripoff of Borderlands, but the graphics and scenery are great.I was a little disappointed with the ending because there is no boss and the enemies are the easier in the game, but they are obviously setting up the sequel.Buy it on sale and you will no be disappointed.

I haven't beaten the game yet, but insofar, I've definitely enjoyed the hours I've spent playing this game and don't regret buying it at all.  The A.I is awesome in Rage, and enemies react to your attacks by dodging, ducking, hiding behind cover, fleeing etc, so good eye hand coordination is a must.Also, when an enemy is down, it doesn't necessarily mean he's dead.  He'll be dying yes, but he can still pull out a weapon and try to kill you :D  The animations are great as well, much better than other lauded titles *cough* Mass Effect 2 *cough*As for the graphics, it's a mixed bag.  On one hand, the megatexture technology allows for incredible variation and detail in the game's textures which makes for a more convincing World.  Basically, Rage is the best post apocalyptic rendition ever seen in a video game..  Although I haven't admittedly progressed very far yet, I can still see and appreciate the variety found in the various locations that I've been to.On the other hand, the megatexture itself is still rather low resolution in a number of areas (mostly interior) due to heavy compression for the consoles.  Supposedly the game engine constantly and dynamically adjusts texture detail on the fly to maintain both visual fidelity and  performance; a great thing to have when playing on machines with low memory ie consoles.But for modern gaming PCs, it's not really necessary....which is why there is a CFG hack out already which overrides the game's dynamic adjustments, so you can enjoy Rage at full quality settings.  If you have a mid range GTX 400 or 500 series card with at least 1GB of VRAM, I HIGHLY SUGGEST generating a CFG file override by following the directions in this guide:[...]The game will look noticeably better.  If you want to take it further, you can try using this CFG file which tweaks the settings even further for enhanced visual detail:seta image_usecompression "0"seta image_anisotropy "4"seta image_filter "GL_LINEAR_MIPMAP_LINEAR"seta image_preload "1"seta image_lodbias "-2"seta image_ignoreHighQuality "0"seta image_ignoreLowQuality "1"seta image_useCache "1"seta image_cacheMegs "1024"seta image_cacheMinK "128"seta r_renderer "best"seta r_multiSamples "4"seta r_useRenderThread "1"seta r_skipBump "0"seta r_skipSpecular "0"seta r_cgFragmentProfile "best"seta r_cgVertexProfile "best"seta vt_pageimagesizeuniquediffuseonly2 "8192"seta vt_pageimagesizeuniquediffuseonly "8192"seta vt_pageimagesizeunique "8192"seta vt_pageimagesizevmtr "8192"seta vt_useCudaTranscode "2"seta vt_maxppf "24"seta vt_maxlockedpages "256"seta vt_minlod "-2"seta vt_lodBias "-2"seta vt_maxaniso "4"seta vt_qualityhdplossless "1"seta vt_qualityhdppower "0"seta vt_qualityhdpspecular "0"seta vt_qualityhdpnormal "0"seta vt_qualityhdpdiffuse "0"seta vt_qualitydctpower "100"seta vt_qualitydctspecular "100"seta vt_qualitydctnormal "100"seta vt_qualitydctchroma "100"seta vt_qualitydctluma "100"seta vt_restartIf you play at 2560x1600 like I do, then you don't need to set multisampling above 4.  But if you play at a lower resolution, you can set the MS up to 32x I believe..  But with these settings, the game looks absolutely beautiful!As for texture streaming problems, I believe most of these problems have been fixed by both AMD and Nvidia with the latest drivers.  I'm using 285.38 myself, and I haven't had any issues at all.  Make sure you use the update function immediately after installing the drivers though, as there was a profile update released by Nvidia on October 4.GPU transcoding must also be turned on, as it helps reduce the texture streaming time significantly!PC specs:Core i7 @ 4.3ghz12GB DDR3 2000GTX 580 SC SLi

reviewText: For $59.99 you'd think id software would have tested this game before shipping it. 7 years in development and it crashes to desktop for those of us with ATI graphics cards. I'm uninstalling this and sending it back. I have no time to rollback drivers or fiddle around with settings through a developer console.It might be a great game but I'll never know. Do yourself a favor and DO NOT BUY the PC version of this game until they release the GOTY edition - maybe by then they'll have fixed the atrocious problems that plague this game.

First off, these are my specs so you don't think I'm running some outdated piece of garbage:i7 2600k @ 4.6ghz8gb of DDR3 @ 1800mhz2 GB HD 6950Brand new Windows 7 Pro install with the game on a separate hard drive from the operating system and everything fully defragmented.The rumors about the textures are definitely not rumors. Unfortunately, the game really does not look very good. If you are someone that keeps up with all the latest first person shooters, then I will try to describe what it looks like at it's absolute best:Homefront with better animations and character models.I hate to say it but there is a serious amount of detail missing, and on top of that when you turn quickly you will see texture pop-in....I assume this is because it was designed to be played with a controller, and controllers cant move around as quickly as a mouse, thus eliminating the problem.....for console players at least.So for a game that took so long to make and was being promoted largely around it's graphics alone, it can be pretty disappointing. If you are a hardcore PC gamer, I can pretty much say for sure skip this one simply because it is missing all those features that people want like being able to change the FOV and not having a frame rate locked at 60fps (people with 3d setups are screwed), you can't even do SLI or Crossfire with the game...not that it would matter considering it really is not very taxing due to the lackluster textures. Even John Carmack released a statement saying that concentrating on the console version ended up hurting the PC version so there isn't even any denying it.So is there anything good about the game? Well...yea, but I seriously doubt you will find anything that you haven't seen before and don't buy it expecting to test out a new system because it's not that kind of game, the only graphical options are AA, resolution and gamma...no joke.I enjoyed the gun play aspect of the game, if there is one thing ID won't get wrong, its shooting at stuff although the difficulty is way, way, too easy. I even found myself enjoying the driving parts of the game (possibly more than the main portion). The driving parts play like the old Twisted Metal games from PS2 and I found that to be entertaining overall.I just can't in good conscience give this game a high score after paying $60 for it and basically not getting what we were promised. The porting issues with PC games only seems to get worse and worse and the only time we can hope for a short reprieve is when the current generation of consoles starts to become stagnant and people start coming back to PC gaming.I say yes, play this game and enjoy yourself. But please, do not pay $60 for it. If you are getting the PC version, I can almost guarantee that you will not be getting your moneys worth.
summary: RAGE is not a terrible game, but definitely not a great one either

reviewText: I have to start by saying that feedback about Steam really has nothing to do with the product.  You do have to use Steam for the game, but in the Steam engine it is possible to set it to play offline.  Plus I personally like Steam because I can play the game from either of my computers without the disk in the drive, and each computer can play the same save files.  It's also a great way to have a digital backup copy of the game in case the DVD gets damaged.As for the game itself I feel that I can't give any stars, and I really can't even talk about the gameplay.  I had purchased this game a while ago and still have no luck in trying to get it to work.  After hours of chatting with support from steam and Bethesda no one can figure out why it won't even start properly for me.  My computer meets and exceeds all requirements for play, and there are no conflicting hardware issues. I did speak to one person who was a little "candid" about the issue and explained that iD was a big reason this game has so many issues, and Bethesda is trying to fix the issues as fast as possible.  I personally do believe that because from personal experience I feel that Bethesda makes amazing games. Their games do usually have some minor issues, but the issues get worked out pretty fast with updates. I have a lot of Bethesda games and this is the only one that I have ever had serious issues with.It seems like this game might be fun and interesting if it worked.  If you do buy the game and get it to work I hope you enjoy it, but be warned that there are major bugs which prevent some people from even playing the game properly.Update - 9/1/2012So it's about 9 months since I purchased this game.  Until this week I could never get it to work.  As stated before; Bethesda said they were working on many common issues, but none of the updates corrected the problem.  My old video card was compaitble with the game,but apparently that was the issue.  I recently upgraded the memory card to one that the game says is "unsupported", but for some reason it actually works now.  I am not sure why a supported video card wouldn't work and an unsupported card actually works, but hey I'm happy that I can play now and it wasn't a total waste of money.I started playing the game and found it to be pretty interesting right from the start.  I amost feel as if the game is somewhat like Fallout 3 or new vegas, but with a lot less extra stuff.  By this I mean that while you can drive cars with weapons, shoot bandits, and play as a FPS it still lacks depth.  You get missions which are pretty much straight forward.  You do get some quests randomly or by looking at the jobs board in town, but they aren't anything too special.  In games like Fallout you were given missions but allowed to do whatever you wanted because it was an open ended sandbox RPG/FPS, but this game you get missions and most times if you don't want to do one of them right away theres really nothing else you can do.  I don't want to give any story away but the first town sends you to a second town after the first few missions.  You meet the people in the second town and get about 2-3 missions from them.  Then you go back to the first town and get a few more missions, but going back to the second town the gate is closed and the guard says the people have decided to pack up and move on.  After you get sent to the third town you can go back and visit the first town, but really there is nothing to do and no one really worth speaking to other than the shop owner.  The guy in the first town which gave you the missions goes to another town for "a few days" which really means hes pretty much not coming back anytime soon.  Not to mention the fact that the map you can drive around on is basically a big closed area that allows you to go to about 5-6 places that have no reason unless a mission is telling you to go there.  Most of the time these areas are actually restricted until you get the mission.I think this is a great game concept.  Somewhat similar to Fallout but less of an RPG and more of a FPS, but I honestly feel more like the character is an errand boy as opposed to a "hero."  I've been playing a lot since it started working this week but I'm already getting tired of playing.  If you like linear games that give missions and are mainly a FPS you might enjoy this game, but as a fan of most FPS and RPG games I'm not that crazy about this game.
summary: Waited 5 months to write thisreview and it still won't work. - Updated 9 months after buying

reviewText: I picked this up on sale for about $5.00, and for a $5.00 game it's decent so far.  The game looks pretty good on my two-year old Radeon 5850, though there are some mip-mapping artifacts at far distances.So far I have no technical issues.  The game comes with it's own utility to set the optimal settings for your system.  The game did not recommend the highest settings, so the engine must have some feature improvements typical of the older id software titles, designed to run for the latest video cards.Gameplay-wise Rage is like how other reviewers have stated: somewhat repetitive.  But there is a progression of weapons and inventory and equipment, like your cars, so that gives me something to look forward to in upcoming missions.I'm playing on the Hard difficulty and it's just about right in terms of a challenge, so far.  I've played a lot of id software games and found their Hard difficulty to be too easy, while Nightmare mode to be too tough.  I like the fact the game will let you carry all sorts of weapons, since I'm used to that style of play.  Compared with Duke Nukem Forever, it was a pain to be limited on the weapons, even though they upped the carry maximum to four guns.I never played Borderlands so can't say how it compares.  But I have played the STALKER series and this game somewhat reminds me of that, except in STALKER there are no vehicles.  In STALKER you would meet up with NPCs would could give you optional quests to take, and you could build up a list of quests to do in any order.  Rage appears to have a similar quest-gathering system.In Rage there seems to be lots of areas to explore as you run back and forth between the quests given to you by the settlements.  I remember Doom 3 had a quest-like system with the recordings you would find around the base, but in Rage the quest system is handled better.I'll update my review later after I have gone through more of the game.  So far it's a good buy if at a cheap price.

Quad core i7 3.4ghz, 8gig DDR3, AMD HD 6970m 2gig GDDR5, 256gig SSD.This game still doesn't function. The AMD driver update makes the game playable, but you'll still encounter tons of graphical glitches, problems etc. Some of this makes it less fun to play and a little less pretty, other glitches make it a complete waste of time. If you're running and gunning maybe low texture quality won't be that big of a deal, but don't stop to admire an outdoor vista! You'll think you were playing a game from 1997.The glitches that really suck are when characters don't draw correctly and turn into a mess of geometry and ghosts of that character being drawn in and out of different positions, with different weapons. It certainly makes the cities seem... alive, if not seizure inducing. You can also see enemies drawn through walls in weird ways, and shadows can go across walls/floors when the enemies are actually a floor above you. I've experienced this all, with a top of the line system and the most up-to date drivers.You cannot change most of this - it's a console port so there's no way to adjust any graphics settings aside from AA and screen dimensions. Nothing else. Now, if you follow some community hacks to try and get the game to work there are config files and console commands that can attempt to force the game to work at your systems capability level, but this is rather technical and a real waste of time since it doesn't really fix anything, just slightly improves the badness.Now - once the game is fixed up it'll be much prettier and the fun potential is all over the place. Bu there's no multiplayer, the RPG elements are wholly without any interaction, any choice, and since all you do is click "E" when facing a character that can talk to you, any sort of replay ability is going to be reserved for those that enjoy driving between cities, doing menial tasks and not being able to skip through cut scenes, character dialogue and any other part of the time wasting that's marketed as RPG.Finally, just a couple more indications of what this game is about - the bar in the second city has a man smoking a cigarette in it... well it's random when you load, but he's either got the cigarette in his hand, or it's floating mid-air about 2 feet away from his hand. It at least follows the movement to take a drag, but again, kind of a near miss when the guy is 2ft away with his smoke.In terms of AI, stare at some enemies that see you, fire at you, watch you step into a doorway and you'll be met with a near continual loop of "where'd he go?" coming from them. Apparently the AI doesn't know how to move, and doesn't understand anything beyond Peek-a-boo.There's some fun elements, there's a lot that could have been fun, and if they ever fix the game the graphics will probably be great... if they fix it. Just don't buy this for PC, if you want to play it, it's really not as great as all the pay-for-review sites say, but it is fun. It'd even be a great $30 console when that time comes. But until then, save yourself the headache (literally with the graphics bugs!) and spend your money elsewhere.

The game itself is pretty solid.  It has the feel of DOOM 3 when you're doing missions, and a pretty decent adventure feel outside of mission areas.  It is basically completely linear though, so if you are looking for an expansive adventure this probably isn't for you.  Don't expect Fallout.The graphics are great, when they aren't getting jacked up.  And there lies the problem, I don't know if the problem lies with video drivers or is really an Id Tech 5 engine screw up, but it seems that this game wasn't tested at all on PC because the graphics are very screwy.The texture popping is very prominent, the only things that are fully rendered are those that you are looking at, an area is never fully represented so any time you turn your head, there will be a texture pop.  Fairly often (about once a minute) a wild shape will jut into the screen, which is sometimes bright enough to make you physically uncomfortable.The vehicle portion of this game has been given WAY too much credit by it's makers.  The buggies handle pretty awfully, and nothing like a real buggy, or any kind of car.  Vehicle combat is something you will quickly realize is no more than an annoying gimmick.  Enemies have insane maneuvering abilities and can annoy the hell out of you.The sound is one thing I have really had a problem with.  This is the one game I own that has messed up sound placement.  I have fully updated drivers but I still have problems.  The big thing is that an enemy thirty feet away from you and to your far right can sound like it is directly in front of you, inches away.  In a game where sneaking has its benefits, this really ruins the experience.If they fix the tech problems, I'll give this game a 4 or 5, but until then I can't do better than a 3.  It deserves some praise, and I wish the raging 1-star reviewers could look past the errors to give the game a proper representation.

reviewText: It appears to be an unfinished game that needed a follow up and DLC that it never got.This is obviously a great attempt at a game that has graphics issues that as of Nov 2012, still are not fixed. The game would be great if it wasn't plagued with flashes of random jagged images that ruin your view on a regular basis. I am able to play games like Batman Gotham City, Skyrim, Fallout NV and other games on high detail with no problems.Also, the way the game renders is aweful. If you are looking forward and remain still, it is clear as day and is very detailed. As soon as you look right or left, it must re-render the terrain that you are looking at from scratch. If you look back to the front, it must re-render it all over again. It's very annoying.Another reason that I dropped my score is that when you are driving vehicles, you can't look around at all. So if you are taking fire, the only way to know where it's coming from is to get out or off the vehicle and look around. This will play into the linear style of gameplay and the unnecessary reasons for free roaming exploration. What I mean is, when you are driving around, if you think you saw something off to the right, there is no point to get out and explore since you can't look left or right unless you stop and get out. Also, if there is a building, they are all locked until you are specifically sent there. There is zero reason to get out and enjoy the scenery.There isn't a lot of reason to roam the map and look for many items. They are all on the way to your next destination (Linear gameplay). Just look around the immediate area that you are already required to go to. If you decide to go off on the map and explore, it's pretty pointless.If you ever decide to take on the armed buggies outside town, they will just respawn and take all your ammo. Ignore them. Trust me.If I want to play a racing game, I will buy a racing game. Make it an option to race and not a requirement in order to continue the game. 4-5 hours into gameplay you are told you can't have the supplies unless you arm your buggy. You must go to some jerk at a garage to arm your vehicle. You have $$ but that is useless. He says that you MUST take part in races to earn credits that will be used later to arm your buggy with guns. Then and ony then will the sheriff give you medical supplies. (What does a sheriff care if I race my buggy and arm it with guns and what does that have to do with medical supplies?) Also, why is a sheriff giving out medical supplies? Isn't there a supply store? Yes there is but you can't buy the supplies.Serious loopholes and requirements drag the game out and bore the player. I will finish it since I paid for it but I will most likely uninstall it once I am done. Very little replay value here.

reviewText: ID has always been known for the cutting edge in 3d gaming technology, and RAGE is the showcase for that. Even though Unreal Engine has seemingly become much more ubiquitous than id tech.And RAGE is definitely impressive. The detail is sharp, but the draw distances and levels are truly grand. I'm not sure how it stacks up with like the Frostbite engine, but it does a pretty good job.This is basically two games. One is a shooter component. The other is a demolition derby car component. Both are done well enough. The enemies are standard fare, but they have some tricks. Like, melee enemies will juke and dive like Emmitt Smith while they run towards you. range enemies use cover well and so on.The enemies also seem to have an inordinate amount of HP. Which results in rattling your rifle and running out of ammo trying to kill them. This is a little frustrating, since one of the joys of shooters is seeing the enemy go splat with a quick shot. Here, you shoot and shoot and they keep on coming at you. When you finally kill one, it's like an eventuality.The game world has some neat art stylings, but it was also very linear. Yes, it is open-world, but you really can't do much with it other than go to quests. And the quests basically go like, enter area. Shoot up stuff. Get to to end of area. Door to outside magically appears. step out door. go back to base.There are some areas of creativity in manufacturing stuff, but mostly it's just shoot everything in a room till it's dead and then move on to next area. And shooting everything in room till dead takes some time since the enemies have a lot of HP.The interface is truly bad in this game. ID is supposed to be a PC company, right? So why is everything consolized? The worst offender to me was weapon switching. You can only switch 4 weapons at a time, despite carrying 9. This is for the d-pad obviously, but with a mouse I should be able to go through all of the weapons using the scroll wheel. Unless it's not the emphasis.I beat the game and it ended. I wasn't left with a feeling of awe, more like relief that it was over.hopefully we'll see impressive use of this tech in future games. hopefully those games will be better than this game.Oh, and one last point, make sure to defrag your hard drive before playing this game. The game apparently needs a good hard disk subsystem due to some streaming tech. If your hard drive is fragmented, get ready for periodic hanging of the game while it searches for the bits of data. For me, it was like 2-3 seconds every 2-3 minutes. Pretty bad.Defrag solves that.

reviewText: A post-apocalyptic FPS / vehicle combat game, "RAGE" attempts to deliver fast-paced gameplay but bogs itself down with unnecessary RPG elements."RAGE" is the product of Id Software, better known for games like Doom and Quake.  RAGE attempts to incorporate both on-foot shooting and third-person buggy-driving combat as part of an "open-world" concept. Its setting is heavily based on Mad Max and other post-apocalyptic standards; following a comet strike on the Earth, the surviving humans basically turned into the cliche division of honest settlers and evil raiders in football gear. Really, there's not much more of an explanation beyond that: you play an individual with special technology who was locked into a survival pod before the comet hit, and when you emerge there's "raiders and stuff".A low-story game isn't a bad thing - that allows it to focus on gameplay, after all. However, despite their barely developed setting, the game insists on trying to shove story in where it doesn't belong. The game advances primarily through doing quests, and doing quests basically means going to talk to someone before going to the next "shoot everyone on this linear path" dungeon. The story is incredibly lackluster (the good guys are named the "resistance" and the bad guys are named the "authority", and there's no real explanation why one's good and the other's evil), and really it just serves as an obstacle to shooting things. In one case I was doing a quest so that I could do a quest so that I could do a quest - three nested quests for one routine mission. They're the usual fetch-quests and "go kill everyone in this building" quests, but they seem ultimately pointless.To be fair, when the game does get to the shooting, it's pretty decent. There's two main kinds of enemies: humans and mutants. Humans mostly use guns and grenades, meaning that fighting them involves using cover and tactics. Mutants rush headlong with claws and occasionally slow-moving projectiles, which means that fighting mutants is much more fast-paced. Human enemies have a lot of variety in design terms (different gangs and so on), but not so much in actual combat terms. The game's occasional bosses are more gimmicky than reflexive; the one that stands out the most clearly is a giant mutant who targets you with highly visible attacks while you shoot at him with an infinite-ammo rocket launcher.There's a decent, if standard, collection of guns in the game, including pistols, shotguns, machine guns, rocket launchers, and so on. Each weapon also has three types of ammo, which provides some diversity. None of the guns were really worth getting excited about; the crossbow's mind-control bolts are the only vaguely unique thing, and all they let you do is blow up one guy. The rest of the ammo types are either "does more damage to x enemy" or something simple like exploding ammo or lightning ammo. One element that mixes it up a bit is the presence of support items. These items include basic things like medkits and grenades, but also encompass more advanced tech like radio-controlled explosive cars, sentry guns, and deployable robots. One such item, the "wingstick", is a razor-sharp boomerang that serves as the game's main logo. These items are relatively interesting and add some variety to the run-and-gun process.The other main part of the game is the driving segments. Over the course of the game you will obtain buggies of various kinds which can be used to drive from area to area (you can also walk, but naturally it takes longer). Buggies can be upgraded with better engines, armor, weapons, and so on by winning races. The vehicle combat is fairly solid, although it's more of an obstacle than anything - you're trying to get somewhere, there's some enemy buggies in your way, kill them. It might be more interesting if the world was actually open, but it's not. RAGE's world is a winding set of paths with a few branches; there's no real exploration because every interesting place is eventually a mandatory quest point. At one point I found a mortar outside an enemy base and was curious about it; it turned out to be a quest item like five minutes later. Everything interesting is something pre-planned, and there's not a lot of "hey I found something pretty cool" moments. The game has crafting based on ingredients you can find around the world, but the linear maps means that "finding ingredients" means progressing forward and grabbing everything you see.RAGE has multiplayer of several kinds, including shooting deathmatches, driving deathmatches, and co-op missions. It seems strange that the main campaign doesn't have cooperative play, only isolated challenges do. The game's graphics are decent but uninspired, drawing upon a tired array of post-apocalyptic concepts with the occasional steampunk or Wild West imagery thrown in for good measure. The music, however, was definitely a letdown. The game actually becomes way more enjoyable if you throw on some rock-and-roll or anything fast-paced, because the game's shooting action doesn't exactly match up with the slow, meandering soundtrack.Overall, RAGE wasn't a good game. It was a chore to push through, and the decent shooting doesn't make up for what a bore it is. If it had JUST been shooting, maybe it would have been okay, but the incredibly forced questing and the laughable world bog down the core gameplay by a huge amount. 5/10.

I'm not sure what all the negative reviews I've seen on the Internet are all about?  From my world, this game was a blast.  Then again, I didn't come into it with any preconceived notions or expectations other than to have fun.  I was totally open to whatever type of Gameplay id was going to throw at me this time and so I was not disappointed like so many others when this game wasn't an improved version of past glory.  It is simply a mission/task based game and provides hours of mindless (better catch that) entertainment.  I use video games these days to relax so I'm not looking to work too hard anymore.  For me, the fun parts outweighed the negative aspects which are there so with that said:Pros:-Lots of fun shooting stuff that needs killin...-Enough story to make it more than just a mindless shooter.-Really good graphic detail.-Fairly long so that it can be played a little every now and then and last a while before you have finished it.-Very cool old school weapons and a few techno geeky ones thrown in.-Cool side-show type games to play within the game to earn money with and lot of required racing which was a new twist for a FPS.Cons:Most of what you've heard is true...-It can be dry and a bit stupid the way you interact with the people.-No real choices to make, just follow the story line and complete the game.-No way to turn off the vulgar language.-Racing elements are arcade only with no option to go first person and actually get inside your vehicle like a real racing game gives you.-The game's save system is weak and the saves are interruptive.-The game is not difficult enough to provide a real challenge even on the hard settings.-No real free roam.  You are bound in at places that you could clearly just walk over and should be allowed to.  Let me walk down there and get stuck if I want to, I don't need virtual guide rails.-I don't talk!  I want to speak!  LOL!-Rips up a large chunk of drive space after installing this 3 DVD monster.All the cons aside I still enjoyed the game and am going to play it over again a few more times in the future.  So if you are a little more laid back like I am now you may find you really enjoy this game especially for the price that all the bad reviews have beat it down to  ;)
Though short, this game still offers far more than any other FPS title.  Excellent enemy AI, beutifully rendered scenery with no redundancy whatsoever.

reviewText: I avoided this game when it first came out because of all the horror stories I'd read about how it runs on PC. I recently picked this up super discounted from a certain service that rhymes with 'cream'. So how does it run nearly a year later?  Well, flawlessly for me. I running a decent PC - GTX 570 and overclocked i2500k with 16 GB of memory - Runs Rage maxed out (only using 4x AA but I think it goes up to 16) at 1080p with nary a frame rate drop or stutter. Hasn't crashed or frozen, and no issues with texture streaming/loading. It's a beautiful game too, though some of the textures look bad up close - nothing I've never seen before.When you're not driving upgradable buggies and off-road trucks in the desert, you're in various settlements talking to people, gathering up quests, upgrading your arsenal of weapons, crafting stuff (auto turrets, exploding remote control cars, temporary buffs, etc), competing in races and buying and selling ammo and supplies. And when you're not doing that the game will occasionally tell you to go somewhere and shoot stuff in the face. The thing is, you spend a lot of time in Rage NOT shooting which is unfortunate because the shooting in this game is classic id software crazyness: lots of circle strafing avoiding slowish moving projectiles, bashing enemies that get close to you and blowing stuff apart with shotguns (among other weapons). Fans of Doom will feel right at home with the shooting. And just like Doom, you'll go in a room, throw a switch, and enemies will overwhelm you. Often.The game is too long for its own good unfortunately. The formula of go to X settlement, talk to X person, deliver X goods, return to questgiver or go to X enemy camp, kill X guy or gather X part, return to town gets old a few hours in and the game is rather lengthy for how repetitive it becomes. However for $10 or whatever I paid for it, it's a steal. It's part Borderlands, part Fallout 3 and part Doom. All great games. Try it, you might like it.

Maybe all the good ideas have already been done, I don't know.  Or maybe it simply easier to copy ideas that came before, but Rage is so unbelievably derivative and boring, it's embarrasing.Like many others here, I'm a veteran gamer, and will try almost anything.  Most "professional" reviews are garbage, and are paid for by the developer or the studio, so they are never to be believed.  I usually make my own decisions on these things, and Rage is no different.  I was more interested in the actual customer reviews, than the paid for "professional" reviews, and as they were overwhelmigly negative as well as consistent as far as criticism, I figured I'd wait until the price was dirt cheap to buy it, which I did this past holiday season.After playing through a good portion of Rage, I am appalled.  This game is simply not even worth the space it takes up on my computer.  It is simply awful, boring, derivative, and has zero personality.  I am truly stunned at how bad this gigantic piece of software is.  An EPIC disaster in gaming development.  All this is even more amplified by the unbelievable HYPE and PR, as well as the uber expensive pricing when it was released.  Just a disaster...1) There is ZERO story.  It is Borderlands, yet much much worse, and far more pretentious.  The graphics and artwork are pretty sophisticated, but they are hollow and meaningless because you simply don't care about any of what you're seeing.  The dialogue and characters are painfully slow and tedious.  There's no personality.  Its dreadful2)  The gameplay is weak and boring. As far as shooters go, it is not even worth playing it to shoot things.  The console themed shooting and damage are just as tedious, and I personally never connected with the action.  The weapons are not interesting, very conventional, and the action is well.... not really that exciting.3) Driving... oh good grief, the driving.  It appears that the driving was put in in order to extend the amount of time you spend in the game.  There is NO reason to drive anywhere, other than the fact that there is really little else to do of value.  Its a collosal time wasting part of the game, boring as anything, and the vehicles are wholly uninteresting and derivative.  Dumb, just dumb.4) Linearity...  not much else to say, but you are on rails.  There is zero movement outside of the predetermined tracks the game is played on.  You drive past these ambitiously designed and drawn structures and scenes, but they are stage props.  There's nothing there.  You can't go anywhere, except the occasional sewer, which is also hyper linear.  No surprises here.5) The Stuff you pick up has no rhyme or reason.  Its wierd stuff, and some of it has value, while some of it doesn't.  If you like shooters with stuff (Borderlands, Fallout, Stalker, etc) you'll want to scoop out your eyes after a few hours playing Rage.Conclusion:  If I paid more than the few dollars I actually paid for this mess of pretentious poppycock, it would have haunted me for the rest of my life.  This game is one the most severe examples of OVERHYPED/UNDERDELIVERED products in human history.

reviewText: ((INTRO))While Bethesda has developed one critically-acclaimed CRPG after another CRPG since 1994, their publishing records have been mediocre at best.  Games like Rogue Warrior, WET, Brink and many Star Trek games have enraged gamers who blindly purchased those games on the strength of their prestigious name alone.  Only FONV was spared of such fate.But just as they were once reinvigorated by a 'hands-off' media mogul, ZeniMax, 'id Software' headed by the Godfather of FPS, John Carmack, has joined the ZeniMax family.  Carmack, wanting to gain financial muscle without giving up his creative control and integrity, turned down EA and agreed to join Bethesda.With a new arsenal under their belts, Bethesda finally published a game that can live up to their TES and Fallout prestige, albeit not without some flaws.  It's Rage, developed by the renowned id Software.((id TECH 5))Carmack, the creator of Wolfenstein 3D, Doom and Quake series, is notorious for spending too much time on the engine and focusing only on the tech side of the game development.  So it's a no surprise that Rage is one heck of a great-looking game on PC thanks to his 'id Tech 5' engine.Colors, graphical fidelity, textures, details and draw distance are nothing short of breath-taking and framerate is rock-solid on nVidia-equipped PC.  The art design is focused on style rather than photo-realism, character animations are highly stylized and vibrant.The game is over 25 GB when fully installed on your PC.((FPS FOR NON-MODERN WARFARE CROWDS))FPS has evolved significantly since Doom 3, the last game developed by id Software back in 2004.So gamers who loves multiplayer-focused FPSs like Modern Warfare, Halo and Battlefield series must be aware that Rage is a single player-focused FPS with one single player portion, one seperate co-op portion and vehicular multiplayer portion.  There is no FPS multiplayer; no deathmatch, no CTF, no onslaught.Also gamers who expect another Fallout or Borderlands must be aware that Rage is neither CRPG like Fallout 3 nor Action slash RPG hybrid like Borderlands.Rage is a FPS first and foremost with a long campaign (about 12 hours main quest alone and many sidequests and minigames to take on and racings to join); I finished the single campaign around 20 hours doing everything and I finished seperate co-op portion in about 5 hours.  Think of Doom 3 with handful of hub towns set in large open outdoor environment in wasteland and MotorStorm thrown in the mix, you have a good idea what Rage will be like.((GAMEPLAY))You take quest, you drive through the wasteland, fight off the enemy vehicles, enter the indoor environment, kill everything that moves, head back to the quest-giver, upgrade your weapons and vehicles.  Take some rest and play some minigames, take some sidequests.  Rinse and repeat.There is no character buildup to worry about and there is no interaction with NPCs or environment.  Conversations with NPCs are one-way.  They either give you quests, barter with you or engage in minigames with you.  Story is bare minimum and an excuse for the action.  You cannot pick up weapons from the dead foes and items you pick up are solely used for your weapon and vehicle upgrades.  It's this rather simplistic and cumbersome gameplay mechanics and lack of FPS multiplayer portion that will disappoint many hardcore Modern Warfare crowds.Outstanding gunplay mechanics, sound effects and awesome graphics with smooth framerate Rage offers on PC are not just for show but a requirement in order for you to fend off endless waves of hyperactive mobs with excellent A.I.  I've never experienced such relentless, methodical and unpredictable foes in FPS genre and you are in for a fight for your life every inch of your way.  Your enemies will coordinate the attack plans to corner you, flank you, flush you, trap you in packs.  And because you are pretty much ineffective in melee combat, you have to use things like sentry-bot, turret, RC-mini car, wingstick and crossbow to keep them at bay and figure out which types of ammo to use and up to 4 different types of ammos can be slotted in any given weapon.While Rage is not a RPG, it packs surprising amount of depths in customization and menu layouts.  Your weapons must be purchased or given but can be crafted, customized and upgraded to your hearts contents by picking up various items and components scattered throughout the world.  Every weapon packs a violent punch and each hit ends with satisfying gore.Vehicular action and controls are very well implemented and speedy racing action (both combat and non-combat) and mayhem are thoroughly satisfying and a nice change of pace.((DOWNSIDES))The game is definitely one of the longest FPS out there but feels so brief and short in part due to its excellency but also because you get sucked into this gorgeous world that gives you the illusion of endless possibilities but gives you very limited amount of freedom.I guess I've been spoiled by Fallout 3 and FONV (even Borderlands to some extent) but it's impossible to look at Rage and not thinking about some what-ifs; filling out this gorgeous open-world with more NPCs, more quests and more meaningful interaction with such a detailed world, but as I said earlier, Rage is a FPS.  But I have to keep telling myself it's FPS, FPS, FPS,...but what if...It's almost a crime not to fill this gorgeous open-world up with enough contents to rival TES and Fallout series.It would have been nice if they put mobs on foot in the wasteland also but as it stands the open-world outside corridor and hubs are a playground solely for vehicular action, and the world, that will take forever to walk, feels so small when you drive around.id Software is no Shakespear when it comes to storytelling department from Wolfenstein 3D to Doom 3, but I can't shake the feeling that the story is inevitable setup for franchise or more DLCs to come.  The story is rather disappointing and the ending might even enrage some of you.Last, but not least, Rage on PC is not for the average rigs.  While not as system resource hog as the first Crysis or Crysis 2 with high-texture pack and DX11, its system requirements are not low.  Remember that meeting the recommended system requirements doesn't mean you can play the game at the max setting.Considering the size of the installed game and incredible graphics, the game is bug-free and stable with smooth and solid framerate.My PC is equipped with Intel i7 950 3.1 Ghz, Corsair 6 GB tri-channel DDR3 Dominator GT and EVGA GTX 460 1024 MB Superclocked; certainly a high-end but not a top-notch system but the game runs at solid 60 plus fps with no texture pop-ups, no screen tearing, no slowdown and loading time about 5 seconds.((STEAMED))Yes, it's steamed.((OUTRO))If you enjoy unique FPS like Crysis, Far Cry, Deus Ex but not fans of mainstream FPS behemoths like Modern Warfare, Halo and Battlefield, try Rage.  It doesn't revolutionize anything new at all for the genre but it feels fresh and unique precisely because it does everything different from more mainstream approaches.However, even if you are fans of Modern Warfare, Halo and Battlefield series, you will find it enjoyable if you keep open-minded.  It offers long main quest (in FPS standard) and many sidequests and minigames to take on.  It does offers vehicular multiplayer portion and story-driven seperate co-op portion.  With the graphic to melt your face and awesome gunplay mechanics, it's one of the best game of the year.((Addendum))It seems Rage is much more inclined to nVidia than ATI and so many ATI owners have more problems than nVidia owners but not every ATI owner have problems and not all nVidia owners can run the game problem free.I am not taking id Software's side but it is indeed impossible for any developers to QA for gazillion cases of various PC peripherals combination possibilities, and no developers ever test for any video cards out there; it's just not their jobs outside creating and developing the game itself.  They simply program for the respective graphic card architectures, not toward any specific video card.First update your respective video card driver and optimize your HDD before installing the game.Make sure you keep your drivers for DirectX, C++ Redistributable and sound card up to date and open up your control panel on your Windows and adjust your nVidia / ATI control panel.  These updates are important not just for Rage but for all PC games all the time.If you have broken quests, character stuck in environment, objects disappears, etc, they are in-game programming bugs.  If you cannot start the game, black screen, no sound, scratching noise, etc, they are usually related to your PC settings and hardwares / drivers.  It doesn't matter if your PC is an uber-powerful top of the line machine or brand new.I can appreciate the frustration for those who cannot play the game while I've never had any single problem.  Unfortunately, you just have to wait for the new updates for your graphic card.New patch from the developers also adds new options for graphical settings.  They also plan to release multiple PC exclusive patches, like 'The Witcher' series, that will give additional modding tools, DX11 options and even higher texture packs that were originally cut from 125 GB size.
summary: It has all the great tools to be a tremendous game but falls a little short

reviewText: Wargames. Wargames never change.Welcome to the new post-apocalyptia. Our hero emerges into the world after been cocooned into the underground shelter known as the Vault - no, strike that: the Ark, the Ark! The year is 2029 and, following a near-extinction event (namely, the asteroid Apophis spiraling down Earth's gravity well) humanity has pealed back the last vestiges of our civilized facade. Small surviving communities fight to the death for the small pockets of land, shelter and water. They fight off brutal bandits, persistent mutants and each other.SHOOT. LOOT. BARTER. UPGRADE. REPEAT UNTIL SATISFIED.RAGE is a RolePlaying Shooter (RPS), although it plays much more like an FPS than an RPG. There is no leveling up and you have no real inventory. On the other hand, you get missions (apparently no one strained any creativity muscle to think those up), you keep what you kill, you sell the junk you do not need and upgrade whenever you can. There are schematics (buy them whenever you find them) that allow you to MacGyver gadgets and customized weapons out of found components.The characters you meet are quirky and interesting whereas your enemies will react to your killing shot (strangely though, not to all the previous ones!).All in all, the game is fun to play and although its replayability is not that high, it is a game well worth of your attention.AS NEO HAS REPEATEDLY EXPLAINED, WE WILL NEED GUNSAnd by "guns" I doubt he meant...WingSticks. These are what you'd get if you were to cross a boomerang with a Ninja-star: they may look good in action but I found them to be far less satisfying than a good shotgun. Do not be disheartened though. Every weapon is extremely beautifully designed and they come with up to four different type of ammo.InBioshockone could complete the entire game by first zapping the enemies and then finishing them off with the wrench. In RAGE you can do the same with electric ammo followed by some WingSticks. And, unlike BioShock, ammo is plentiful in RAGE.IT'S A BEAUTIFUL WASTELAND OUT THERE (IF YOU CAN SEE IT)I was one of the lucky ones because my gaming PC has a single nVidia video card and I am running in a 32bit WinXP environment. ATI cards, SLi stacks and 64bit systems are out of luck: the developer did not care enough to optimize the game for them! Hence the number of gamers complaining about this.So, when they work, the graphics are gorgeous. More artistic than realistic and with great light/shadow transitions. Ever since the originalUnrealI always notice the skies of a game and RAGE has beautiful cumulus and stratus clouds, through which the Sun scorches the Wastelands.So, crack open a cold bottle of Kola-Kong, sit back and enjoy. (No, you do not need to keep the cap. Do I need to keep reminding you that this is notFallout 3!).HAVE BUGGY WILL TRAVEL. THE SLOW SHALL DIE.After so many hours raking Pandora for that perfect Chimera pistol, it was inevitable that once I slipped into yet another sand buggy and start roaming desert vistas I would think ofBorderlands. Buggies here are not only a means to travel but they can also be raced around tracks.They are a good addition, the are fun to handle and they offer a nicely done racing component to a shooter game.CAN YOU STOMACH THIS NEW WORLD?The game comes with surprisingly modest hardware requirements for the eye candy it is. The biggest problem is the HDD space - it will hog ...25GB! For a game that is far from being...100-hours long that is on the excessive side. I had to uninstall no less than 4 games in order to fit this on my primary HDD.Now, the rig I am running RAGE is a two years old Intel Core i7, with 3GB of RAM, nVidia 480GTX (updated to driver 280.26) on a MSI Eclipse running WinXP (SP3) - and it plays at a decent framerate but not free of frequent rendering and the occasional tearing. And this is where the game looses its first star: it is not finished.Consoles are sold at cost and the companies make a profit by pricing console games higher. PC games are different. No one...subsidies our PC systems. So, if you are going to ask for 60$(!) for a PC game, it better be PC-optimized and polished to a shine. And when you think you are done, polish it some more.Otherwise what exactly are you selling, the...promise of someday been able to play the game I pay at such a price?FAST! SHOOT THE VALVE THAT CONTROLS THE STEAM.Yes, RAGE comes with mandatory STEAM tie-in. This means two things. First, for the love of God, if you bought the game retail, activate, then kill the STEAM download, delete the local content that managed to slip through and finally reinstall from your disks. Do you really want to wait for 21.6GB to download?Secondly, this means the $60-game is not yours to keep. You can play with it but you have to leave it in STEAM's playroom when done. You cannot resell it if you so decide and you cannot gift it if you get bored with it. I take a full star off for such DRM schemes; however, if this is not important to you, feel free to adjust my rating accordingly.A FINAL BULLET.Although not that original, RAGE incorporates a number of RPS ideas with gusto and style. Unfortunately, the game has not been polished yet, a number of graphical glitches persist even for nVidia systems. Game publishers should learn the value of respecting both their product and their paying customers.My advice is to wait until the price matches the product.

PROS:First Off, Highly recommended especially with the super LOW Price Tag.I really like this game. I like the story line, the game play, the fact you drive around blowing/shooting other vehicles. The FPS aspect of the game is great, movement was smooth, and shooting was precise. The variety of weapons and ammo along with building sentry bots, remote control cars, and many other things that you build was a huge plus IMO. Personally this game was very fun for me, it kept pulling me in over and over again. ID did a great job IMO. But not everything about this game is rosy. Please see my CONS.CONS:Overall graphics could have been much better. Personally I am getting sick and tired of Console Ports. Companies "NEED" to design games based on PC technology then port them over onto Consoles. This ensures best possible graphics for the PC. Porting a high quality PC game onto the console ensures better Picture Quality vs. if it was designed for consoles. FACT.This game suffered from massive graphics glitches, primarily with AMD/ATI graphics cards, though Nvidia based cards had their fare share of issues.Anyhow after several weeks of its release, most if not all glitches have been resolved, all thanks to game patches and driver modifications and updates.What really pissed me off was this game is way too short. It took me about 25hrs on HARD. This game should have been double the length IMO.OTHER THOUGHTS:Hopefully they release an expansion pack that is 2x the length of the original.
summary: Great Game but Too Short......We need an Expansion Pack FAST.....

reviewText: I will start this by stating that I very much enjoyed RAGE from a fun to play perspective.  However, the technical issues in and out of the game do lead to some issues that can't be overlooked.For starters, out of the box I found out that I couldn't immediately play the game because I couldn't install it.  This isn't a bash against Steam or autoupdating by I literally couldn't install it.  It turns out a number of DVD copies of RAGE shipped with incomplete product keys.  Rather than the 15 character keys that Steam requires, I got 14.  After dredging through Steam's user forums for a while I found out what the problem was.  Unfortunately, the only way to figure out the rest of my key was to plug in every letter and numerical character on the keyboard until Steam accepted my key.  I started with 0-10 and went through the alphabet until "O" before finding the final letter.  Annoying.  Granted, it could have been worse "Z", but annoying none the less.After getting through the product key debacle, I finally was able to install and play.  Immediately after exiting the Ark, you are treated to some of the most beautiful graphics you have ever seen.  After, that the game strips this away and you are left with graphics that are far less impressive.  This is the constant and uneven balance of RAGE.  There are times when RAGE, idTech5 and MegaTexture absolutely live up to all of the hype.  There are moments when the game is simply unrivaled in graphical quality.  Then, there are times when textures are so low resolution that you cannot make out text on in-game sings.  During one mission, there is a picture on a desk to id Software's Tim Willits that it took me a long minute of staring to figure out that was who I was looking at.  While id has talked about a high-res texture pack that will help alleviate this, it is currently absent.The other big issue with idTech5 is texture popping.  Think early Unreal Engine 3, but rather than occurring once at the beginning of every level, it is every time you move through one area and turn around to the other.  While this had been improved with RAGE's first patch, it still is a persistent issue that is simply a flaw (or not depending on your perspective) in idTech5.  John Carmack admitted to this during his keynote at QuakeCon where he described the ideal way to break his new engine.  Back into an area and spin around quickly and everything will be a mess until it loads.  idTech5 lives up to this description and simply cannot be "fixed" regardless of patching since it is simply a characteristic of the engine.After the technical issues, the question becomes is RAGE fun?  I believe that it is so long as you go into the game with the right expectations.  If you are looking for a true open-world RPGFPS, you will probably come away $60 poorer, 25gigs of hard drive space lighter and holding a lot of contempt for RAGE.  If you are expecting an id Software shooter set in a more open world than they have ever made, you will come away pleased if the technical issues don't drive you off.  The weapon set is impressive.  The different ammo types and upgrade ability do provide a measure of depth id has never had before, though it does fail to hold up to the level it is provided in other games.  The enemies are fairly varied with the different bandits, mutants and the authority.  The level design is more open and less of a corridor shooter than id's previous games, though still very much on rails.  I almost hesitate to say I won't spoil the ending because it doesn't really end.  Basically, RAGE suffers from the John Grisham ending.  It feels like the campaign stopped just when it was going from great to spectacular and it goes from 60 to 0 in about half a second.  It is a real shame id chose to end the game this way.  If it had continued, I probably would have enjoyed it even more than I did despite the technical issues.Overall, RAGE isn't a genre redefining FPS.  It borrows heavily from other games and is fairly shameless about it.  It doesn't however take the depth of the games it copies from.  At it's core, RAGE is very much a superficial id Software shooter. Everything is deeper than they have ever been with id, but the depth still doesn't compare to other games in the genre.  With the right expectations of what RAGE is, you can enjoy it warts and all.  If you are expecting other games with an id veneer, you probably should reinstall any one of the games RAGE is constantly being compared to and skip id's new offering until you can catch it on sale.
summary: Good game marred by technical issues

reviewText: The Good: Solid shooting, great weapons design, different ammo types is a blast to use, strong atmosphere and enemy design, car combat works wellThe Bad: False sense of freedom, buggy and glitchy technical nightmare, ending is really lame, enemy variety is low, overall feeling of repetitivenessI have to come right out of the gate and say Rage is probably one of the most disappointing games I have played all year. With all the hype about the amazing and revolutionary graphics engine and weapon system that id Software (the inventors of first person shooters) has made, you would think they would fall through. The game completely is a 180 of what id said the game would be like. The first thing you will notice are the enormous amount of bugs and game breaking glitches especially for ATI card users. The graphics will literally be completely distorted, or the entire game will be blue. How do you fix this? Extract a file from the graphics driver update and put it in the Rage folder. Or you can fiddle around with Catalyst Control Center, or how about the game not even running right unless you have it open? This is completely absurd and should not be like this upon release. I spend a total of four hours fixing this damn game so I could just play it. So you're probably asking is it worth it?Well the shooting is solid and that's a fact. id knows what they are doing and the guns are great and super fun to use. You can upgrade them at stores in towns, and use various ammo types because the enemies do need different approaches. This is by no means a straight up stand in one area and shoot everything. You will die quickly so use what you have available to your advantage. Guns like the assault rifle use regular steel rounds and feltrite rounds which are more expensive but more powerful. The shotgun can use buckshot, but also pulse rounds and pop rockets which act like explosive shells. You get a rocket launcher, sniper rifle, and a pistol that shoots four different types of ammo. There's a decent amount of guns in the game and you slowly unlock them as the game goes on.Shooting enemies is fun because each weapon packs a punch and feels good to shoot. Enemies have great animations and fight worth a damn so the game isn't too easy. There are even some pretty fun boss fights as well. The enemy variety is pretty low, however, you get maybe five different kinds through the whole game with some just swapping out outfits such as different bandit groups. The whole point of Rage is to run around in the world and explore dungeons to complete various mission types. The dungeons are varied and have a lot of loot in them to engineer items such as bandages, wingstick (boomerangs that are instant kills!), sentry bots, RC cars that explode, ammo, grenades, and a whole slew of things you can build in your menu while your on the field. This can be really fun and encourage exploring every corner for junk to sell or use.Now you're probably wondering how the game is like an open world? While the game has a great art style and feels a lot like Fallout that it is trying to copy it isn't in any way. The game has a nice post-apocalyptic art style and has some great designs and pulls of atmosphere, but it falls short because the game has a false sense of freedom. The outdoor areas must be driven (more on car combat later) and can not be traversed by foot because for one it will take forever, and two the other cars will kill you instantly almost. The world has a lot of "hallways" that you can drive in that lead to each dungeon, but by no means is it a free open world like Fallout at all.This tends to be very depressing because you can see all this great open land, but it's barren and closed off by cliffs and walls around you. I mean there are only three towns in the whole game, and they are spread out in two different areas that you have to load between. There is a nice amount of side missions as well as races which involves the over hyped car combat. You drive around your car, which controls very well, and do various races to earn certificates to upgrade your vehicle so you can survive out in the "wasteland". The combat is fine and all, but mainly serves as just a way to get to your missions in the "open world" because car combat out here is far and few between.I also had a problem connecting to characters because you don't talk to them much and they really just give you missions. I also had a problem connecting to the story because while it has potential, it falls short with a terrible and lame ending, plus it just ends abruptly with a poor final mission with no boss fight. Some of the side missions are probably more interesting than the main missions. Overall you're looking at a 15 hour campaign even if you complete every side mission.  I also have to mention that the graphics look good, but there are better looking games out there thanks to Rage's weird low resolution texture problem, but there are some really nice lighting effects throughout.Overall Rage is a buggy, broken technical mess that most people will just give up on. However, the game has solid shooting, excellent weapon design, and engineering stuff is really fun. The false sense of freedom and so-so car combat really bring the game down to just a mediocre experience that will not leave an imprint like Doom or Quake did all those years ago. Sorry id but try, try again.
summary: Too many bugs and glitches keeps Rage down

reviewText: "Rage" is a new FPS action game that is played through 'Steam' . This downloaded version cost $59.00.Theme:After an asteroid has hit Earth all that remains is a post apocalyptic world filled with renegades and scum. It is left to you and a few isolated groups that try to restore some semblance of civilization.The Pros:1.) beautiful, smooth flowing graphics (played with 4 Gb RAM and Ge-force GTX 470 video card)2.) atmosphere for buildings, tunnels and sewers...spooky ambient lighting, shifting shadows, dripping water and goo, creaking pipes, the sound of scampering unseen feet. The opening quest in Subway Town will have the hair on your neck standing up.3.) a nice balance between FPS individual enemy fights and 3rd person vehicle battles.4.) a competitive racing game (within the game) that allows you to earn cash and credits to improve cars, weapons etc.5.) as well as the single player mode, there is co-op with friends and a random game for battle other player on-line with your cars.6.) enemies are quick and devious, often in packs...making them a challenge to take down.7.) a crafting scheme that allows you to make several important objects from scavenged items.8.) a quick access system (with the use of F1-F4) allowing you use items (weapons, bandages, grenades etc.) quickly in the heat and chaos of battles (both against personnel and vehicles)9.) game saves...anytime!  Best to save very often.The Cons:1.) the cost...$59.00. Pricey!2.) performance issues...I've been lucky to have a set-up that runs really well. After reading some  other reviews, I guess others are not so fortunate. Friends of mine with running issues; many have an ati card in their computer...something to consider before spending $59.00 on this game. Hopefully a patch will fix these problems...because, when running properly, this is a great game!3.) with the 'Steam' download...no instructions. Making the initial learning curve a little more complicated than it needed to be.4.) initial splash screens (thankfully very short) and most cut-scenes are not skippable.5.) although the driving world is very open, the quests through buildings etc, is very linear.6.) having played and finished the game, I would say it has little replay value. There would be nothing new to try except playing it on a more difficult level.Impressions:A game very reminiscent to 'Borderlands', but in my opinion, a better effort.The in-game Racing feature, open world driving that usually involves car battles and the quests for objects within building areas turned out to be a lot of fun. The game, once you get acquainted with the game play is a real adrenal rush.As mentioned above, there seemed to be that fine balance between driving and questing that fit together perfectly to provide an interesting and intriguing game.I realize some people are having performance issues, but to me, much better than I expected.  5 Stars.Ray Nicholson

Yeah, id really dropped the ball on this one. Seems like they can't do great things any more.This is basically just Borderlands and Fallout 3/New Vegas done in a slightly different way, only not as well and way too late.The game is not horrible, just kind of empty and lackluster.PROs -INVENTORY - Simple, easy inventory. No 'weight limit' baloney!ENEMIES - Some new creeps with some OK moves to dodge me.WEAPONS - A new idea called a Wing Stick. Essentially a boomerang. Kind of fun.WEAPONS - You get a sniper rifle early in the game!ROBOTS - Having turrets or bots to assist your battles was great fun and I felt this should be done again in future games.CONs -RAGE = LAME CORRIDOR SHOOTER - This is an old school gaming term that means you cannot really go where you want and have few options with how to fight the enemy. Take some cover or fight head on. Nothing creative or cutting edge about that. id/Bethesda phoned it in big time.ENVIRONMENT - It is completely non-destructible.  No breaking down walls or smashing through doors to gain an edge or explore. No shooting ceilings or large objects to make them crumble, then fall upon the enemy for a crush kill.RACES - Lots of races attempt to fill up the lack of game substance.RACES 2 - Once you have enough credits for vehicle upgrades, there is no incentive to race any more.RECYCLING - You wind up repeating a lot of levels for meager reasons!WEAPONS - The sniper rifle is ALMOST the ONLY weapon you really need. I found I could advance slowly, engaging a few enemies at a time and do head shots without even getting touched or being at risk.WEAPONS AGAIN - You don't get the best weapon (Authority Pulse Cannon)until the very end. This might be good thing though, since the enemy AI and battles were not that tough even on the hardest setting.WHIMPY WEAPONS - A few weapons and a few meager upgrades for them....YAWN!!!!!!!!!!!VISUALS - Poorly done graphics on a supposed 'cutting edge' gaming engine.VISUALS 2 - This has the identical cartoon/cell look of Borderlands.VISUALS 3 - This looks identical to Fallout 3/New Vegas.ENEMIES - Crappy AI. Easy to beat on the hardest settings.OUTER MAP - There is no map for you for the wasteland. I WANT A MAP I CAN PUT WAY POINTS ON!!!!!!!!!!!!!!INNER MAP - There is no map in the villages to show you locations or guide you.MISSION MAP - There is no indicator or guide as to who is offering missions. So, out of fear of missing everything, you have to drag yourself all over town regularly talking with every character to see if they are offering a mission, 99% of the time there is nothing. Thanks id!INCENTIVE - There is very little incentive to explore the outside world. Therefore, this makes the game linear. There are a few flowers to collect. Hoopity do!VENDORS - I find it annoying that I cannot just walk up and purchase. They have to say something first to you and when they are done, you can interact. Petty complaint but annoying nonetheless!BAD DLC - Did you play the 'sewer missions'? If not, you did not miss anything. If you did, can you even remember them? No, you can't because there was NOTHING interesting or worthwhile about them. First, you have to find them. This was not fun, it was just annoying. Once you clear them there will be jobs on the board asking you to go back (more recycling of levels...YAWN) and clean them out of all mutants. The problem is, this time there is even less challenge, fewer enemies, no extra treasure or goodies that make it worth going back and doing it!BAD ENDING - The ending is just that...an ending. It felt rushed, unplanned and you don't even have any real good battles! You fight off some teched-up muties and then it ends. No big bosses, nothing you did not fight already. The game just ends. The critics slammed the game for it's bad ending and now that I experienced it, I agree. In like a wimpy lion, out like a diseased kitten.WOLFENSTEIN 3D - Overall, I felt like I was playing a game that should have been released 10 years ago. Then it would have been impressive.I could think of another 5 or 6 more CONs, but I think I have made my point.id is what I grew up on! Wolfenstein 3D on floppy disks delivered via the mail! id is like a family member, but now Thanksgiving is coming and I am not sure if I want to invite id to the table this year!Really good DLC might just save this game if they release something with new weapons and enough substance and challenge to it to motivate you to play it some more. Though, with Borderlands 2, coming....and with Battlefield 3 and COD:MW3 and Skyrim all within 30 days of being released, I doubt most gamers will care.Mostly, this game just made me nostalgic for Borderlands. My only solace is that Borderlands 2 is coming and they will show id how it is done, because RAGE just does not deliver!

There's a great game in here somewhere, struggling to get out. Unfortunately it never quite succeeds. RAGE was hyped up enormously prior to its launch and I was one of those gamers who looked forward to getting around to playing it. Don't get me wrong,  I enjoyed the game but I was always aware that it could have been so much better. The story is standard post-apocalyptic fare and, more notably, the script lacks humour. The gameplay and combat, while good at times, are never outstanding. It tries to create the illusion of open-world play but in fact it's pretty much a corridor shooter with defined routes and little opportunity to explore. The graphics are also deceptive: the landscapes look good from a distance but close-up the textures are disappointing. It should be noted, however, that the background music is quite impressive. There are echoes of both Borderlands and Fallout 3 here, but RAGE is a subpar game when compared to either. It's a shame that the people who brought us the excellent Doom series failed, on this occasion, to match their earlier success. I've no doubt, however, that they will regain their form in the future. 3.5/5
summary: Just a bit miffed, I'd say

Here we have a side title from Id Software and it is called Rage.  Taking a break from the DOOM series it would seem, Id plays with various side concepts here.  Right off the bat, there are Final Fantasy 7 references immediately apparent.  There are attempts at RPG building, interaction and item use.  The game feels like a sci fi version of Desert Solitaire.  Nobody does desolation imagery, lonely adventure, thoughtful visuals and suggestive religious iconography like Id Software.Despite this, the game can feel hokey at times, especially in the repetitive buggy driving sequences.  It should feel Mad Max yet instead feels very .. middle school afternoon.  That or maybe it's there as some kind of Pixar "Cars" tie in.  Whatever it is it's slightly annoying, especially given the confined world in which to explore.  That said, the limited world available is graphically incredible.  Lonely, kind of sad landscapes unfold before the viewer revealing a world that feels vast and desolate.  The characters are worn, desperate types who live their unhappy lives trying to survive.  Finally strong character interaction comes into play for an Id Software title.More than anything though, this feels like a kind of "preview" for Doom 4.  It was Id Software's chance to dabble with genres using their recently made game engine.  Time will tell us how much of Rage will carry over into Doom 4.  One thing is clearly noticeable, Id is going to need a good melee system.  Resident Evil combos or FarCry knife action, something must be done for a melee system over at Id Software.

Gist: If you are limited to only 2 or 3 full priced titles this fall - rent or wait on this one.To me it felt most like playing Resistance FOM in a Fallout 3 world.Pro: Nice Desert/Post Apocalyptic Design and SceneryCon: Large Install (took 15+ min on PS3), Slow Load Times, Mostly a Platformer more than anything, In-game references to previous Bethesda games give a tired feel.Best description for you is: It is a variation of Borderlands with Fallout 3 design and graphics while giving the distinct flow and feel of Resistance FOM single player campaign with some enemies similar to those in Bioshock.  Add to that having to do rally races to progress in the story. And that gives you RAGE.  But is it as good as any of those games? I don't really think so.  To me it felt most like playing Resistance FOM in a Fallout 3 world.The desert/post apocalyptic setting is nothing new and includes tired references to Fallout 3 (yawn, zzzzz).  You must place first in some races to progress the story and if you want to restart a race it goes into a long loading screen the same as if you restored from a save. (yawn, zzzz  Despite a lengthy install, load times seemed very long (yawn, zzzz).  Too much inaction for an FPS (yawn, zzzz).If you loved Resistance FOM (linear flow platformer but no aliens), Borderlands (single player missions but less weapons), Fallout 3 (design/graphics but no RPG aspect), Bioshock (enemies coming from all sides)and some Sega Rally thrown in for good measure then it follows that you might also love this game as well.  Or, like me, you may think, "been there, done that and in much better packages already. And now with this game, despite a lot of seemingly good aspects, I'm feeling just a bit burnt out on the whole thing so when I'm hit with these long loading, loading, loading, screens my patience has run out and its time to hit the EJECT button."So that's my opinion - RAGE has some really nice aspects but it just doesn't add up to a real nice package that hooks me, reels me in and keeps me wanting to play it.
