Although its not as open of a world as I would like its pretty darn close.You play as a mute character like most games these days and you don't really care to much for his story cause there really isn't one but that isn't bad. You get vehicles which you can upgrade later on in the game and get new vehicles but unfortunately its only a few vehicles at most. The guns and gadgets you get are pretty cool and make the game a lot more fun. Once you get the ability to craft turrets that are either on the ground stationary or actually move (like a spider!) and shoot at enemies you can't help but find it fun.The enemies are a lot better then other games at the time. When you shoot them in the leg or something they actually react to that. Such as limping or jumping or crawling towards you. They even try to avoid your shots by jumping off of walls or grabbing onto the ceiling and such to avoid getting hit. It makes it much more challenging. You also get the heavy class of enemies that have bigger weapons or much more difficult to take down. You also get the ability to loot dead bodies when playing missions to allow you to buy items and materials to make the game more fun so there is also that.A lot of the time your tasked with going to ruins and such to get a specific item or such and have to watch out for bandits and all that. Unfortunately a lot of the levels are recycled so that you basically go through them again but in reverse. Such as going in through the exit you made before and leaving through a somewhat new entrance near where you entered the first time. It isn't a game breaker but iv heard a few players complain about that. I still enjoyed it even though some of those levels I already knew from playing through them once.You do drive at times from mission to mission so there is that but its not really a difficult drive. The racing missions are scattered around and you only apparently have to do like 2-3 at most in order to progress through the story so your not forced to do a bunch but you can if you want. Some of them are fun cause its kinda like mario kart in a way where you can destroy the other vehicle with weapons. Luckily there is no rubber band effect (if you play racing games you probably already know what this is if not look it up on google such as "rubber band effect racing games) so you can end up winning the race by a landslide at times.Unfortunately you don't really meet to many memorable characters and most characters you meet you only talk to a few times for a little bit before never having to talk to them again.At one point near the middle of the game you do fight this really big.. um "enemy" (again not going to spoil it for those who don't want to know just yet) and well its not the best fighting spot iv played but its still pretty fun.The end of the game though is a huge disappoint. You can almost tell that they rushed the game or were busy working on another game at the time *cough* Doom 4 *cough* which really made this game not as good as it could have been. When the ending was coming up I was thinking "no it can't be done yet.. they really aren't going to end it this soon" I could almost tell it was ending around then. It was kinda like "here is the big gun now go kill bla bla and help save us all" type of scenario.What really got me annoyed was near the end of the game you are walking around and you might catch this old guy talking to this other guy talking about a "monster" that was "at least 60 feet tall" and then when you get close and try to ask them about it they just shut their lips and tell you not to ask about it or something. Then after the game and started seeing the credits it hit me that they must have been working and planning out a lot more to happen but then either lost the funding, ran out of time, or were ordered to rush the ending and get the game out as soon as possible. You will be able to see this if you play the game and make it to the credits.The ending level was strange and felt out of place. You drive to this area and are told to take out this enemy to basically save the people or something and you get this very strange level that looks nothing like the rest of the game and go up against these enhanced "enemies" that you never fought at all before with a special gun that what iv heard most players saved and didn't use much because they though they needed it for a final boss fight and then were disappointed by a cut scene. I even heard about players rebooting the last save and playing through it again just incase they might have missed something or that there was a bug and caused them to miss the last boss fight that it clearly felt you were going to have.Ontop of all that after the cutscene and the end credits they don't allow you to go back and explore the outskirts and finish up any side missions you might have had. You basically have to start the game all over again. For those who didn't get the anarchy edition (or special edition) that has a few DLC stuff. Such as a different costume that gives you 5-10% off of stuff in shops and the double barrel shot gun I will tell you this. Your not really missing out on anything. I think it was just a ploy to get a few extra dollars out of you for a few stuff that really wasn't that great. I never tried the extra sewer missions except 1 because I heard it was just an area you go through and shoot a few waves of enemies and get an item at the end over and over again through all of them. The one I played through was basically the same as what I had heard so unless you want to waste ammo and shoot more enemies then your not missing out on much.Recently a month ago or so Bethesda released a DLC that kinda fixed the problem with not being able to go back to the outskirts after the final mission and added a bit more to the game. Unfortunately though it was a long wait for people who bought the game a year before and played through it already. And it wasn't even free it will cost you like 5-10 dollars to get it for something that fixes the game. I had just finished the game around the time they announced this and I know most players who had bought and beaten the game a year before were like "DLC that's a year late on a game I played a year ago is a little to late" so it is nice they finally release a bit extra stuff to the game but like most players felt it was a bit to late.Conclusion:I might sound a bit hard on this game near the end of this review but I really did find it to be a fun game. I heard they are making a sequel to it so I hope the sequel will be a lot longer and have a lot of the problems ironed out but since they kinda focused more on Doom 4 when they were making this I am unsure how it will work out. The ending of the game was pretty weak and bad but I think they made it in a way so that they can make a sequel to it.I would say if you are interested in this game get it. Right now for PC its not to expensive and even though there are some graphical problems at times its still a fun FPS game. If they do come out with Rage 2 I will be pretty interested in getting it but I will probably wait like I did with this one for the game to go down in price unless im quite sure they did a better job on it then this one.
summary: The ending might make you rage but its still a fun game

reviewText: Games need to have three things to make them good, good plot, good game play, good graphics, this makes them fun to play again and again.  Rage has good graphics; the plot had potential to be sure but seriously lacks substance. For me it's a way to pass the time.  The characters are neither believable nor engaging, there is a serious lack of weapon variety, it's stupid that you can't pick up enemies weapons when they drop them and over all it just does not feel very deep.On the positive side we have a post apocalyptic world that was not destroyed by nuclear war, which is a nice change, the game does not crash every five seconds and if your just looking to kill time this will do it. Without a doubt I found the mutants in the game to be the most obnoxious enemies ever, once you get used to them they cease to be scary and are just a pain.No one seems willing to put forth the effort to make a good game anymore.

Even w/3.6G QuadCore, 12G RAM and nice GPU the game detuned my graphics and when I tried to crank up it said "not enough cores"? Huh? Nonetheless it looked great to me- maybe the best looking I've ever seen. It took about 10 hours to play through, so cost me like 70 cents per hr... not bad. Wants you to use 'wingsticks' and things but I mostly stuck with an SMG and a very fun combat shotgun. Sounded and reacted like real and was a real kick in the pants. RC car bombs were fun. Overall I had a great time. If I paid 60 bucks, well... I'd be a little mad but I didn't and was worth every penny. All the sounds, voice acting and motion and AI were very realistic.Some levels were kinda obvious drop-in or shut door behind you and throw wave after wave after wave at you, but survivable. Stock up on rockets for a few times it throws you in a small area with a couple very tough beasties. Save often.FUN FUN FUN for a very nice price- you will not regret it. A great 8-10 hr diversion. Forgot to mention two negatives- I had a Vsynch or some problem where my screen had a kinda split across it, something was not working well with my GPU. Also in 8-10 hours I BSOD's like three times. And I haven't seen a BSOD in like 10 years- have a VERY stable PC, so if your PC ain't so stable, you may be experiencing some lockups! Also it ends quick, I thought I was 1/2 to 2/3 finished and boom- credits scrolling. But again, great entertainment for under a buck an hour!
summary: Great game if bought for the right price

reviewText: This game was hyped to no end prior to release only to fall flat instead of out for PC. FIRST OFF THERE WILL BE SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEW !!!The game itself was very bug filled on release. I don't know about you, but I'm tired of game producers releasing bug filled or broken games on release only to promise patches or release patches withing days of release. If you can make patches to mostly fix a game within a week of it's release push the date back for release and fix it before releasing it to the public. When we pay $60.00 for a game we expect it to be playable right out of the box.The game itself was not original, Fallout with Borderlands overtones. If you like games like Fallout, play Fallout it's a much better game. One big difference between Fallout and Rage is Rage is way shorter of a game in comparison to Fallout, if you like a game that takes a long time to beat don't play this one. The scope of the world on this game is very small, and the amount of quests to keep you interested in the game is short.This game had a lot of potential, if the game was stable on release, had a much larger world, more quests, better graphics, updated game play engine to make use of the power of today's PC'S, and a more original story this game would have been an awesome game. But it will most likely be remembered as the as the broken on release poor fallout clone with a horrible PC port.P.S. Although the game is broken even after patches and beta graphic drivers, at least Amazon stands behind their customers. I returned the game and received a full refund from Amazon for the game. My suggestion to all PC buyers that are having problems like I did, go through the refund process as long as it has been within the first 30 days since you received the game, and get your money back from Amazon, and send a message to these game creators, that if we are going to spend our hard earned money on a game we a expect a working game out of the box with the same effort put into making it as they did for the console versions.
summary: Fallout/Borderlands Clone Falls short for PC

reviewText: I had high hopes for Rage as it has been literally years since iD Software has developed a new game and this one being a new IP for them. I should start with mentioning that Rage is not a bad game at all! It is a whole lot of fun and the FPS mechanics are just as superb as they were in iD's previous games. However, it is obvious that Rage has a TON of untapped potential and is sorely lacking in many areas... I won't turn this into a huge wall of text but will give a few bullet points of things that aren't all that great about Rage:-Multiplayer is limited to car combat - I can't believe iD of all companies would opt out of FPS-based multiplayer!-Story - It tries to have a story... sort of, but it isn't really all that well fleshed out-Missions - You basically just run jobs back and forth for the various NPCs in the game... It gets really repetitive, however, the shooting and FPS mechanics are amazing when you are actually fighting enemies so the game actually held my attention quite well throughout the gameOverall, it is definitely a really fun game. I don't know think there is much replay value here seeing as the multiplayer isn't all that great, but the singleplayer alone has 20-40+ hours of gameplay time. This alone makes it worth the purchase price. If you enjoy singleplayer FPS games and are looking for: great shooting mechanics, amazing feeling/sounding guns, great graphics and animations; then you will probably want to pick up Rage. Otherwise you might want to wait until it goes down in price over the next few months...

This game is meant to be a co-op action/rpg centered around 2 characters.  There is alot of action, and most of it is good.  While there is leveling up, you do not have much choice in skills.  Each character has 3 spells and 3 combat skills to choose from.  The spells are the same 3 for both characters.  Each spell or combat ability has 3 levels, such as lower mana cost, higher damage, etc.  The game is mostly linear with a few side quests that you may discover if you check everything in every level.  Weapons are found in racks scattered throughout the levels.  The female character is an archer, although she can also use a sword, and the male character is a fighter.  He also has a crossbow, but archery is not his strong suit.  The graphics are pretty good; however in the cutscenes there is no facial animation other than the mouth. The combat is pretty fun, but nothing that hasn't been done before.  Everything else about the game including the levels and history are pretty much recycled from any other fantasy game you may have played.  If you want to play single player, the partner AI is pretty descent and you don't have to worry about babysitting your partner.  There are a few simple puzzles that are easy to figure out, a few of which require your partner.  Again the computer AI is competent, so not a lot of frustration if you choose to play single player.  The game is fairly long as well.I would say this game is worth a purchase if you can find it for $20 or less.  However, there are other action/rpg games about to come out such as Skyrim and Diablo 3 that will blow this game away, so save your money for those games if you can.  This would be a good purchase during the slow release summer months when there is nothing much else to play.
summary: Action/RPG that's heavy on the action, light on the RPG

Developed by inXile Entertainment and published in May of 2011 by Bethesda Softworks, "Hunted: The Demon's Forge" is a third person single player or co-op action game.  Set in a gritty and brutal fantasy world, the story follows two mercenaries (Caddoc, a human male warrior and E'lara, a female elven archer) as they investigate the disappearances of townsfolk after sinister creatures begin to emerge from the underground.  Armed with a magic artifact called the Deathstone which allows the wielder insight into the lives of the deceased, Caddoc and E'lara set out to the nearby town of Dyfed in search of its missing inhabitants.  Here are my thoughts on Hunted: The Demon's Forge;Pros+ Grim, dark and adult fantasy setting.+ Hidden areas are fun to discover and explore.+ Excellently detailed character and creature models.+ Humorous and witty banter between Caddoc, E'lara and the NPCs.+ Spell and action particle effects are clean and look impressive.+ Rez vials are a convenient way to revive companions.  Much easier than kneeling over them for a set amount of time while getting beat on by enemies.+ Dungeons have dark and eerie feel to them.+ Blood splatter from combat is a nice touch on characters.  Shields are also destructible.+ Very non-stereotypical main characters.  E'lara is shoot first ask questions later elf who is always more than happy to rush into battle.  Caddoc is a calculating and strategic mercenary warrior.+ Solid voice acting talent includes Lucy Lawless, Laura Bailey and Robin Atkin Downes.+ Outstanding soundtrack by Kevin Reipl (Gears of War, Unreal Tournament, Resistance - Burning Skies).+ Weapons and armor have excellent detailing and design.  Many weapons also have magical effects accompanied with simple particle effects.+ Can see many items you're carrying such as weapons, potions and rez vials.+ Gruesome looking creatures.+ A few good scares in dungeons.Cons <Contains SPOILERS>- Impossible to tell which items you can break and which ones you can't.- Caddoc's crossbow is slow and quite lackluster.- Lots of invisible barriers and places where items can fall behind which you can't reach.- Careful fighting next to "sleg" pots, it's extremely easy to drink them altering the ending of the game.- Checkpoint save system which can be really poorly spaced in some areas.- Melee combat against enemies is often extremely dangerous even for Caddoc.- Cut-scenes can often cause you to lose loot that you didn't pick up in battle.- Many areas are one-way only with no option of returning.  If you missed something, too bad!- Some really ugly and dated environmental textures.- Health and Mana potions can disappear even though they still show on the ground.- Some musical glitches where it gets caught in a loop so you can't tell when combat is over.- Finishing maneuvers while neat, lock you into the animation but not your partner which ends up looking odd.- Riddle heads tend to get a bit repetitive.- Some graphics clipping issues.- Limited number of enemy types.- No jump or crouch.- Clumsy cover system.- No inventory option.- Linear gameplay.- Some jerky character movement."Hunted: The Demon's Forge" is exactly the type of fantasy action game that I look for.  Its dark story, grim setting, brutal creatures and unique characters intrigued me from the very beginning.  The teasers hinted at Gears of War style gameplay but in a fantasy setting after which I was sold.  Unfortunately, "Hunted: The Demon's Forge" just doesn't live up to such lofty expectations.  The game felt unfinished and largely subpar in so many areas.  The game's faults really show with its broken cover system, linear gameplay, dated graphics, clumsy character/enemy combat, invisible barriers and overall bugs.  Despite these issues there are some bright spots in the game as well.  The character and enemy models look great, the combat is generally fun, the voice acting and soundtrack are quite well done and the overall setting of the game has a very dark and gritty feel to it.  That being said it's still not enough to push this game beyond the average or cause you to overlook its many flaws.  I played co-op with a friend (I played Caddoc, he played E'lara and it took roughly 10-12 hours to complete) and while we enjoyed it, we both agreed to be glad when it was finished.
summary: A fun but flawed 3rd person co-op fantasy action game

The Good: Archery is quick and fun, story starts off with potential, female characters are beautiful, lots of different environemntsThe Bad: Clunky and boring combat, lots of bugs, looks average, very linear, some times unresponsive controls, story ends up being a complete wasteMost action RPG's tend not to be too bad, but Hunted is probably one of the worst I have ever played. The game has an interesting story that falls flat due to poor storytelling and pacing. You play as a mercenary couple: The human Caddoc and the beautiful elf E'Lara. Caddoc is calm and reserved while E'Lara is all about rushing in and killing everything. The swapped stereotypes are nice, but the overall story goes nowhere until the very end. You get caught up in a mission to stop an evil man named Annuvin who is using a dangerous liquid called Sleg that can turn everything into evil. Along the way the only other part of the story is trying to find a mayor's daughter for a high reward. Not very interesting since the game is linear to a fault, and the gameplay is just yawn worthy.Throughout the game there are points where you can swap between the two and they each play differently. Caddoc is all about melee and brute force while he has a crossbow that does minor damage. I felt the crossbow completely useless since it does hardly any damage (even after you find a few upgrades) and is very slow to shoot and takes forever to reload. His melee attacks are best, but you just mash the attack button ad nauseam. If you block attacks with your shield you can charge a fury attack, but if you get hit once before it charges it depletes. What kind of thing is that? Every so often you will get super charged and do extra damage, but I could never figure out how this happens exactly since it seem to be random.E'Lara is all about using her bow and melee is just like Caddoc's crossbow; useless. You can pick up different level weapons at three levels which are fast, medium, and slow, but she doesn't have a fury meter. If either partner dies you can throw each other regeneration vials, but if you run out you're dead for good. You can also use magic, but it's clunky and doesn't fit right because some magic uses your weapon then you have to switch to just magic which involves throwing stuff. The game is just very clunky and not very responsive and it makes a lot of battles a huge pain to get through.Upgrading magic works, but it's nothing special since there are only three different types and then two upgrades on top of that. You get upgrade crystals by finding them in containers or enemies will drop fragments. On top of this you would think that being an RPG there would be side quests. Not really. You can find paths that lead to "rare" weapons, but these tend to be just as useless as the rest of the game and not worth anything. Hell, you can't even spend the gold you pick up through the game. It just increases your score on the leaderboard. You can also find death stones on fallen enemies to hear their stories, but what's the point? You'll be too busy screaming at the clunky combat and falling asleep at the derivative gameplay.Does the game at least look good? Not really. This is another game that uses the Unreal Engine 3 that doesn't use it to its full potential. The game looks average and for some reason has a lot of bugs and constant slowdown even on high-end systems. The voice acting for the characters is good, but since the game is so boring you won't really care. Why should you play through this? The archery in the game is fun at first because at least that part is done well and is pretty quick and fun. Hell, just play to stare at how gorgeous E'Lara is if you want or even Seraphin. Everyone else should just move on to better action RPG's.
summary: Terrible design choices leave this promising game in the dirt

The game play is very simple, they give you auto aim, and replenishing your health is very easy as well. I've just started through the first parts of the game, and while i'm not disappointed, i can't really say i'm very impressed either. The detailing is great, but the graphics still leave something to be desired. I don't or haven't noticed any bugs yet, but time will tell. It's pretty much like a mid evil version of Resident Evil 5, which i loved because of the co op. On PC it's not going to be like on consoles unless you play with someone online. No one will be sitting on PC with two controllers for co op mode. So your stuck with switching back and forth between characters, which is fine since i play alone anyways. The story is pretty flimsy, though effective enough. The dialogue is about as bad as i've ever heard for this genre of gaming. And everything else well, it's just there. But it does have its fun, and good moments. So as i get further into it, it's just nice to have a simple kind of dungeon adventure to play without having to think about every move you make, and stop and talk to 100 different people throughout the game. If you're looking for that, then stick with Fable and Dragon Age etc.I noticed someone called this Gears Of Sword and they are basically right, the cover system is exact, some of the walls you hide behind are exact, and even some of the scenery(which looks good on highest settings 1080p) resemble Gears as well. Just in Dungeonesque fashion. I cranked up everything and have up to 60fps no problem. So i don't know that it looks dated, maybe just a few years old. I don't think the hype this game has been giving out since last year is at all worth 60 or 50 bucks. Maybe 40 at the most. But it is a decent game, and the more i play the more i'll update. Combat is very simple, spells and magic are as well, and i get the feeling it would probably be better suited on 360 or PS3, but wouldn't look as good. But i do have the feeling also, that the co op on a large 52 inch LED/LCD would be more fun as well. So if you get it for PC expect to play alone, i may get it for 360 when the price drops, or not. So far it's far from the best looking or playing RPG(which i wouldn't call it), but far from the worst also. I'm going to try The Witcher 2 and see how much better it is, i'm sure a lot. On PC that is. Console will ruin it i'm sure.
summary: Decent Co op Hack and Slash

reviewText: This game is pretty good, but not as good as Street Fighter 4.  The control is the main complain that I have for this game.  It is not accurate or sensitive compare to Street Fighter 4, but it does help when you just do certain move several time to make sure it register. I beat this game with all the characters in the game. Strong characters are those with "blast" move as their super.  Since they are releasing another game called Ultimate MvC 3, it certainly makes you feel like getting a ripoff when buying a "full" game like this similar to Street Fighter 4 when I first bought it and then they keep releasing a few more characters and call it a "new" game (super street fighter 4, super street fighter 4 arcade) and selling this new games at bargain price at about $20 when fan of the series pay $40 to $50  for the game original "few" characters.

Marvel Vs Capcom 3 is an exercise in seizure-inducing, flashy super-moves, ridiculous combo strings, and a pretty impressive cast of characters. Unfortunately, it's mostly all flash and very little fun.Characters are pretty absurdly imbalanced, and there's an enormous focus placed on aggressive tactics. This game throws defensive play completely out the window with overpowered super moves, combos that (even when blocked) are nearly impossible to counter attack, and assists that are really easy to abuse. And the X-Factor? This just makes the game even more aggressive.The game's designers fully admitted that they had no intention of balancing the game, simply because there's too many characters. Due to this, people just pick the overpowered characters like Sentinel, Wesker, Akuma, Hulk, and Dante, to name a few (not coincidentally, highly aggressive characters). This may sound like a lot of variety, but keep in mind that this game is 3v3, and you're much more likely to run into match ups involving at least 2 of those characters.There's supposed to be balance tweaks coming for Ultimate, but I'm not holding my breath. If they had no intention of balancing in the first place, what are the odds that Ultimate is going to get it right?If you love games that focus on off-the-wall combos, then maybe you'll like this game. I don't know, I guess I just want my fighting games to be a little more involving than just memorizing and practicing combos to death. If you're a defensive-oriented fighting game player like me, pass this one up.

It was perfect for me. The entire roster has a balance of great characters. That main character I was looking forward to being Trish from DMC series, whose more than what I expected her to be in battle.There's just so much to this game, I don't want to spoil it for anyone. The only flaw I would say it has is the endings. They put little or less efforts into everyone's endings. That's all I'm going to spoil. The endings for everyone are just basically two comic slides.Other than the flaws, the gameplay/replay value/music/etc are just off the hook. This all just by my perspective because this is my kind of fighting game. I'm sure out of everyone in this fighting game there's 1 character for everyone. As for me. That 1 character is Trish ;)

With Street Fighter IV collecting dust for months, I didn't expect to enjoy Marvel vs Capcom 3 anywhere near as much as I have. It was a last minute decision to pick up and I'm glad I did. The gameplay is smooth, sophisticated, yet easy to pick up at a basic level. The "simple mode" of controls is great for a round robin game night with players who aren't normally at all competitive. It's all very smooth. I can't imagine playing it with a regular controller, though. Thankfully, I still have my SF4 fightstick and a recently-acquired Hori stick.I'm disappointed that some of my favorite characters aren't included, but that doesn't take away from the game for me. reviewText: It's been 10 years since Marvel vs Capcom 2. Finally the third game is now on store shelves. Will it live up to it's predecessor? Only time will tell. This review will talk about the different modes the game offers, the characters, and of course, the gameplay.The original Marvel games had very few modes, arcade, versus and training. This game offers these modes, online play (which I haven't touched yet), and mission mode. The gallery doesn't count...Versus mode: You fight with your friends locally. Pretty standard.Online: You can fight other people around the world in a ranked match or a exhibition. From what I've read, there is no replay or spectator system. This is a major drawback as it lessens the community experience. Basically, you end up waiting in a lobby bored to death before having an actual fight (spectator mode makes this bearable in Street Fighter 4)Training mode: Practice combos, using assists and just getting to know the characters and team strategies. You will spend a lot of time here.Arcade mode: Fight the computer until the last boss. This mode can also be used to practice before fighting online. I've that on the hardest setting the AI becomes particularly unfair with psychic blocks and throws but never shows off any real unique combos.Characters: People complain that there aren't enough characters and I think its pretty silly. You get close to 40 right off the bat with DLC along the way. Almost every single character is unique. Like keep away? Dormammu, Arthur, and Chris are really good. Like rush down? Wolverine, Dante, and Akuma are great. Marvel 2 had 56 with like 30 clones, seriously. I guarantee you will find more than a couple people you like.Gameplay: Very different from Marvel 2 and Street Fighter. Combos are usually light -- medium -- hard -- special -- jump -- repeat -- possibly super. This is the general order of attacks but there are many combos in the game. Assists are your partners that help you out for a short time. They are used to put pressure or keep away or gain more meter. You can switch between them in the middle or the match (now in an air combo). The controls are much simpler than before and this helps and hurts the game. Its easier to pull off moves but it feels like every character is doing the same thing. Combo into the air, then to the ground, bounce, more combo or super.The X-factor is new to the game and makes a character very strong temporarily. You can easily kill all 3 opponents with one guy. But you can only use this once. I'm not sure if this helps the game or hurts it. Its just something to help people come back from a beating.The biggest fault of the game is the low health for the entire cast minus Sentinel. Fights can be very fun, so it's very anti-climatic to only combo someone 3 times before they die (once for Pheonix). You can set the damage lower but that should have been the default option.Great game and tons to figure out. With DLC on the way and a huge community, it has very high replay value.

Marvel vs Capcom 3 has been a long time coming. And just like any long-awaited sequel, there will be people who love it, and people who hate it. As for me, I'm a fan, and here's why:Easy but deep: The controls in MVC3 are a bit different than what you may be used to from MVC2. In fact, I think it was harder for me to adjust than it would be for someone who had never played MVC2. I think that, on the whole, the controls are easier to learn and much easier for new players to pick up. The simple control method takes this even further and lets even non-gamers take a swing. Sure, they'll button mash, and it may not be a true competitive match, but I respect that Capcom was willing to let them in. The game controlls a lot like Tatsunoko vs Capcom on the Wii. Despite the simpler controls, it still feels like there's a good deal of strategy for each fighter.Character: I'll admit, I was a little dissapointed that MVC3 didn't live up to it's predeecessor's record of characters. That being said, not many fighting games will give you this broad a selection. And, unlike several other fighting games I've played, none of them feel the same. I wished for a few more x-men on the marvel side, and I'm missing Mega-Man on the capcom side, but there'll certainly be someone for every player on this roster.It's not a perfect game, but the only negative things I have to say about it are more about how it compares to MVC2 than about the game itself. All in all, it's still crazy over-the-top fighting. I think if you're looking for a good old-school, 2-d fighter you can't go wrong with this one.

Although rated for teens, children under the age of 10 will enjoy this game. The simple mode allows novice and young players to compete right away. One caveat for parents is the game contains language you don't want your second-grader to repeat.My sons are 8-years old and 6-years old, a bit young for the game's intended audience. "Marvel vs. Capcom 2: New Age of Heroes" released a couple years before my kids were born but that hasn't stopped them from gravitating toward used copies every time we browse a game store. The prospect of playing as Spider-Man, Iron Man, Captain America, Hulk and Wolverine is mighty tempting for a young boy so, when teaser trailers forMarvel vs. Capcom 3appeared last year, requests naturally followed.I wasn't concerned about the voluptuous female characters (my kids turn their heads in disgust when Lois Lane kisses Superman) or the animated violence which is no worse than what they watch on Cartoon Network. The stylized fighting is relatively tame (read: no where near as bloody) as you'll find inX-Men Origins: WolverineorMortal Kombat(BTW: both of those games carry an `M' rating for players 17-years old and up).The characters' dialogue inMarvel vs. Capcom 3is generally engaging and fun but once in a while you'll hear a cringe-inducing line that you hope your kids won't repeat. For example, Chris Redfield is pithy, shouting, "Eat it!"; "Suck it!" and "Eat Lead!" And Deadpool gleefully announces, "Check me out, I'm the ghost of Christmas kick your ass!" Along with barbed comments from Spencer and Taskmaster, the game earns its `T' rating for teens.The gameplay is three vs. three, tag-team fighting with loads of special attacks. The simple mode allows players of any age or skill level to jump in and have fun. In simple mode, little time is needed before battling the game's final boss, Galactus. However, I encourage parents with younger players to explore the mission mode to perfect moves, especially X-factor, which creates a glowing red power aura around your character.The game's main disappointment is the lack of an adventure mode that would allow two offline players to play together as a superhero team. I had hoped the game would include more unlockable extras and modes to extend the game life. After a couple hours of gameplay, my sons grew tired of fighting each other and the CPU and returned to playingMarvel Ultimate Alliance, where teamwork is key.In summary,Marvel vs. Capcom 3is an addictive, visual feast. The Marvel characters look and sound authentic (my sons didn't know many of the Capcom characters and, frankly, weren't that interested in them in the first place). This is a game that I see them playing in spurts but never wanting to trade or sell (probably because it will be another decade before the next installment).Rating: Four stars.
summary: Good fun, but beware the language for players under 13

reviewText: Ok - I like to keep things low verbiage and straight to the point - so here goes.  I have no experience playing Marvel vs. Capcom 2, so was not sure what to expect with this game.  The first thing I noticed is how beautiful the characters and background are.  Furthermore, the gameplay is responsive and keeps a solid framerate.  But perhaps the most important aspect of a great game is the one that is often overlooked - the fun factor! Well, that is were this game shines.  The fast paced fighting is intense and the AI never feels cheap.  Characters have a variety of moves which keeps the experience fresh, and it is very satisfying to juggle opponents and finish with a hyper move at the end.  Is this game perfect no, but it is well worth the money and may very well be the best fighting game currently available for the xbox360.  It can take a while to learn how to effectively play this game, but hang in there and you will be rewarded.

This is a great game, however Capcom decided to release a special version within months of this release with more characters which is crap Ghost Rider should have been in the original release or as DLC paying another $60 for the same game with a few more characters is bad business.

What I've played of this has been awesome so far.Cons:The roster is nowhere near as big as MVC2 with some obvious omissions. The game modes are a bit bare. I have yet to try it but I hear spectating is not an option (I really hope they fix this via a patch if this is true).Also, let's face it....Capcom is going to milk us with DLC characters and stages in the future.Pros:So far everything seems a bit negative but the fighting which is the meat and potatoes of this game is wonderful. It is going to take some time to master all of these characters. At first I thought I was going to dislike the new control scheme with just a single L, M, H action button and the special button instead of the LP HP LK HK setup we were used to in MVC2 (or the other, deeper SSFIV setup with all six buttons) but in the ensuing chaos it actually works out well. Before you know it you are pulling off air combos and super moves and you won't care that the buttons seem limited.I don't think I have to say much about the graphics. You've seen the videos. This is one flashy beautiful comic like game. I am sometimes catching myself getting beaten to a pulp because I am busy admiring the lush detailed backgrounds and the character models. So far I've only played the single player so I haven't had the chance to see others play while I watch. The super moves are sometimes so over the top that they make you chuckle. In a good way that is. (I'm looking at you Deadpool).If I tire of this game and I start seeing that it is shallow I will certainly come back here and change my review. But for a first impression....it can't get better than this.

reviewText: This is a really tough review to write because as a long-time gamer, I have to weigh my experience with their "VS" games and the other game it mimics (SF4) and balance that with the innovations (sorta) that the game offers.  Visually it is a treat for the eyes, and it's nice to see "non-standard" characters in a game as wild as this.  But spectacle is only part of it.  The gameplay is where the primary focus of contention is.This game has the highly-simplified control scheme of having only four attack buttons.  This is good in that it helps new players pick up and go, but it's bad in any number of other ways.  First, since it has changed so dramatically from MvC2, that means a number of controls have changed on a game level and on a character level.  That means a jarring transition for fans of the older games.It's also disappointing to see characters get their movelists chopped in half or more and smacks of lazy programming in the sense that they wanted to keep the moves to a minimum to rush a game out.  In more traditional VS games and in SF4, the six-button control affords one a great degree of control in responding to an opponent, where as the four-button is definitely less finesse.  While I find that disappointing, some prefer the simplicity of it.  For completeness' sake, MvC2 had a four-button control as well, but that cleaved closer to the six-button traditional, and CvT had a similar control scheme.And speaking of characters ... there's a lot of debate over the roster.  Again, it's hard to complain given that this is really ahead of MvC2 by a great deal ... but it also smacks of gold-digging when you consider the size of the MvC2 roster.  Granted a few of the "hidden characters" were merely shameless palette swaps, but quite a few were not.  Also, unlike MvC2 they didn't waste roster space on three "only appearing in this game" characters (Amingo, Son Son, and Ruby Heart) so I'm not sure I can complain about wasted roster space.  Alternate costumes are largely well done for those characters that have a large wardrobe (like Spider-Man) and there are some nice gems (such as Punisher-Cap) but to fill out the Capcom side, it might've been nice to see "cosplay" outfits such as Ryu dressing like Ken (Heck, it'd be nice to give Ryu his MvC1 transformable fighting style) As much as I'd love to discuss DLC, that does not come with this game (or at least this version) so what characters will be coming or otherwise purchasable is beyond the scope of this review for good or for ill.The storyline is actually slightly more present than in MvC2, no matter what people say.  Having a recognizable big bad like Galactus goes a long way toward explaining the storyline, as opposed to MvC2 which flashed still pictures "explaining" that everyone was recruited by a pirate to fight ... some sort of gooey chaos machine?  I don't buy the backstory too heavily (Doom and Wesker hatch a plan involving Galactus eating the world?  Uhhh ...) so I'm glad it isn't really put forth.  I like that all the characters at least have individual endings.  Disappointing, however, that in match-ups, there's no "fight your rival" (which would be hard given the random team nature of the game) and that only the lead characters address each other.Game modes are at a minimum; given it's built off SF4, you'd think they'd have a few more options.  Oh, and on a personal level: performing complex combinations isn't a "Mission," it's more like "Advanced Training."  If you want to dole out missions, maybe that would've been a good way to use a single-character fighting system, allowing for rival fights, like maybe a single-character story mode that helps flesh out the overall game's backstory!Overall this game is a good game, and if you can get it for a reduced price, I would recommend getting it.  Despite the visual flair of the game, it feels cheap.  Looking at the history of the series and the games from which it was "born," I can't feel justified at paying $60 for what feels by comparison to be an incomplete game.

reviewText: When I first bought Street Fighter 4, it disappointed me so much.  I found myself so frustrated with that game.  I was expecting Marvel vs. Capcom to disappoint me as well but it has been a great game and have provided plenty of fun for me!  Even though performing combos is a bit tricky, I like the fact that the moves are relatively easy to crank out.  The graphics are incredible and I love the constant banter from the characters, especially when Iron Man yells out "Protoooooooooon Canon!!!!!"  This game rocks!

After a decade of waiting, I am so glad MVC3 is finally out! The game interface is simple but gets to the point.  The gameplay is amazing and despite the limited controls (as opposed to MVC2) learning the new controls was a breeze and you can find yourself mastering the game in no time.  The screen shots speak for itself.  The graphics are amazing and stunningly beautiful.  For the most par,t each character has their own individuality, there aren't any repeated characters (Iron Man/War Machine; Wolverines; Ryu/Ken; etc.)  As a huge fanatic, I am quite satisfied, but not blown away by this game, which I will explain below.The one thing that I was bummed out about most was the roster.  It is no where near as big as MVC2 and the added characters were not all that exciting.  I was excited that Dante and Zero were added, but then I realized that SEVERAL characters were removed like Strider Hiryu, Hayato, Iceman, Gambit, and many more!  From a roster of 56 diluted to 38 (Two that will be DLC; Four unlockable), there's bound to be quite a few characters we will miss.  If it weren't for the roster, this game could've easily been one of the greatest fighting game created.  Although the roster was dissapointing, the gameplay and graphics make up for its shortcomings.  I highly recommend this game to anyone!
summary: It's about time!  But where are all the characters?!

reviewText: I haven't bought a fighting game in my life but I got a great deal on this after the Dead Rising 2 avatar fiasco. The single player is mediocre as there isn't much of a story, the computer is unrelenting and the payoff is substandard. The online mode seems to pair me up with people that have made it their mission in life to be the gods of this game, so that was out after a short while, but playing with friends is a ton of fun.Having a few people over to play a tournament or just goof around is what this game is all about. It reminds me of when I was teenager, going to the Jersey Shore with friends and wasting all our money in the arcade playing each other at whatever game seemed coolest. Those days are (unfortunately) long gone but this game is a good reminder of that.If it didn't have that aspect I would have rated the game lower since it's literally just a straight fighting game that plays on people's nostalgia and love of brands. reviewText: Being a huge fan of Marvel vs Capcom 2 (and really hoping to grab ahold of MvC1 on a console sometime), playing Marvel vs Capcom 3 was a no-brainer for me. Since I own a Wii, the closest thing I could get to something like this was Tatsunoko vs Capcom, so when I got the opportunity to play this, I wanted to see what I was missing out on.Apparently I didn't miss out on much, because I happened to find Tatsunoko to be the better fighter.You still get a giant roster of characters, and it's really amusing to see Phoenix Wright take on the likes of Spider-Man and Hulk, but as much as I wish to say the gameplay itself was as awesome as it was in MvC2, I just feel like something's a little off. The fighting, while still chaotic, just didn't feel as beyond over-the-top and fast-paced as the previous installments. It was ONLY over-the-top and fast-paced. Plus, while the graphics look nice and crisp/colorful, nothing beats the lush 2D sprites/3D environments mixture of MvC2. On top of that, the sound effects weren't as connected to the fighting as they were before. In the previous games, I REALLY felt Hulk punching his opponent. Here, I hear a simple smack.All that really isn't to say that this game is an utter disappointment. I was still genuinely enjoying the game all the way through, up to the usual difficult final boss. Oh, and online play is definitely exciting as well. I just simply didn't enjoy it as much as the first two games in the series.

You have to multi-task in a way I've never had to do with a game before. You have to keep track of your three fighters health and how much health can be healed. You have to keep track of your hypercombo bar so you know when and what to use to give the most damage as possible. You have to watch your timing on things. reviewText: So, I finally got a few days of gameplay with MvC3, and I don't really have too many complaints...not many that can't be fixed with a patch or two anyway. First, let's start with the game itself. Everyone will be comparing this one to Marvel vs. Capcom 2, so let's get right to it.This game launched with 36 characters, while MvC2 had a total of 56. Yes, if you haven't heard, the sequel has 20 characters less. Is this a bad thing? Depends on who you ask. The majority of the online MVC community is extremely upset that this game launched with less characters...however the biggest difference is you don't have "clones" in this game. In MvC2, you had several characters with nearly identical clones. Iron Man had War Machine...There were 2 Wolverines, Mega Man and Roll...did they play 100% identical. No, not at all, however you had a few characters that played extremely similar in MvC2...in MvC3 though, everyone is a completely different playstyle. The closest you get is Ryu and Akuma in terms of 2 characters playing similar. With that being said, 2 characters are being launched as DLC within the month (Jill and Shuma-Gorath), which will cut the deficit to 18 characters. I do expect capcom to sell DLC over the next year+, and I wouldn't doubt that by this time next year MvC3 will have tied or have surpassed the character count in MVC2.Now with the discussion of character DLC, people are arguing and complaining about how capcom is "going to rip the consumer off on DLC that should've been included at launch" etc. Remember that you're buying this game as-is, and that the DLC is something extra, and usually not-neccesary to continue playing the game online or offline. As is, we got 36 characters for a fighting games, 18 from Marvel and 18 from Capcom. I will welcome DLC, especially if it's for a character I would enjoy such as Carnage, Megaman, Ghost Rider, Daredevil etc. Just remember, you're buying the game and it comes with 36 extremely diverse characters.People who were experts at MvC2, expecting to automatically pick up a controller and make people rage quit online have something coming to them. It's as if this is a brand new game, with ideas from the first 4 games but not the same button config. One light attack, one medium attack, one Heavy attack and one "special" attack. There are two buttons for your assists. And if you hold either of those buttons, you can switch your character out for another. So basically, everyone starts off fresh, and it's a simple game to get a hold of. Think of the button controls as a 75% Street Fighter and 25% Tekken. Button mashers can do well, but obviously those who are willing to take the time to learn the controls will do a lot better.Mission mode is one of the new additions to the game. Each character has 10 missions for a total of 360 missions. These missions range from very easy (One simple Hadoken) to a complicated, very precisely timed long sequence of button presses. You can learn a lot as a player from doing these missions, and while these missions aren't exactly as hard as Street Fighter/Super Street Fighter IV's Trials, these missions are not to be taken lightly.Graphics are amazing, sound is amazing. No problems in that area. My only real real real gripe with this game is the lack of two options. First, in player lobbies, something was given to us in street fighter 4 and Marvel vs. Capcom 2 that may have spoiled most of us; Spectator Mode. Now, if I want to practice with friends, I have to wait and do absolutly nothing while my other friends play. Meaning, if I'm in a lobby with 7 other people, and I just lost my game, I now need to wait for 5 more games to complete, while i sit and do nothing. No Minigames, no training mode, and no spectator mode. Seriously? At least something to warm up with, like in Super Smash Bros. for the Wii...but no, instead I can watch the life bars deplete. Seriously bad move. While there are rumors that this may appear in the future in a patch, it's not there at launch. Another small feature that's also absent is setting infinite time in Player lobbies. Another feature that's ridiculously absent.Overall a great game, and with several patches, this could be the best in the series.
summary: Could be the best one in the series...Just needs a patch or two.

reviewText: Being a Marvel vs Capcom 2 whore of the highest order myself, I can understand why the purists would not be too crazy about this game. They've changed the formula quite a bit, to the point that it kind of loses whatever it was that made MvC2 such a classic among fighting game fans. But is that such a bad thing? It may seem so at first but believe it or not, the game is actually pretty good once you sink your teeth into it.The graphic presentation obviously makes up the biggest difference here from MvC2. The game uses the MT Framework engine used in Resident Evil 5 and no matter what you may or may not think about that game in particular, there's no denying that it had spectacular graphics. Same goes here with the characters being rendered in full 3D models that fight on a 2D plane, very much like Street Fighter 4 did. This allows for some pretty spectacular specials and a veritable light show taking place in just about every match. Some may cry foul that they've moved away from hand drawn sprites but as long as the game isn't trying to play on a 3D plane, then we're good as far as I'm concerned.The character roster takes a hit and I was pretty sad to see a lot of my favorites get left out. You're bound to find characters you will enjoy playing with and some surprising additions. I thought M.O.D.O.K. was actually an inspired inclusion, even if his character controls horribly. It does suck that we've lost something like twenty characters, give or take but if there's one thing I can freely say, it's that the game actually feels a lot more balanced than MvC2 does. MvC2 was capable of some truly one sided mismatches on many occasions and it doesn't really feel like that's a problem here. Granted, there is some cheapness with some of these characters moves and tactics but overall, they did a really good job of making sure the game is more or less balanced.The gameplay has been dumbed down a bit, with the controls being relegated to three attack buttons and the addition of a "special" button that serves as the pop-up initiator, whereas before you had to press down and hit them with a fierce attack to setup the air combo. I liked how it was initially because it felt like you had to work to pull it off. A properly executed air combo is still a thing of beauty when done right, its just been made a lot simpler to do. It feels like the game in general has been simplified quite a bit to usher in newcomers in the audience but don't let your fears get to you as the game is still quite deep. Calling in your teammates has been made simpler too and once you get used to it and how they work in terms of pulling off team specials, it becomes second nature. There are a few general additions to the gameplay that make getting ridiculous combos a lot more fun, like three tiered air combos where all the characters on your team can get involved. You also get a license card that allows you to look at your stats as well as anyone else playing over Xbox Live. Very nice touch there. In the end, yeah they've changed the gameplay but if you can get past that, you'll enjoy the game very much.It took me a bit to warm up to it but I think this game has a lot more going for it than people might suspect upon first playing it. I know some of you are upset that Guile was cut or that the graphics are all "3Dish". I say, just let the past go. You can still go back and play MvC2 whenever you want. I would definitely suggest getting your hands on this because its a hell of a lot of fun and still a blast to play with your friends and enemies.Last but not least, the music is INFINITELY better than MvC2's. And they somehow managed that while keeping the "Take You For a Ride" song in there in a remix form.
summary: The ultimate smackdown game returns with both minor and major modifications...

reviewText: Marvel vs. Capcom 3 is a fan-favorite offshoot of the long-running Street Fighter series that branched out with the well-received X-Men vs. Street Fighter back in the competitive glory days of the 2D fighter.  Over the series' evolution the character rosters would eventually expand over time to include all Marvel comics heroes and villains as well as Capcom's entire legacy of classic video game characters.  The result was, of course, insanity.  MvC is one of the flagship competitive fighting series known for it's complex game mechanics that reward player creativity, extremely hectic action, and deluges of winking fan service towards comic geeks and gamers alike.  It's been a decade since the last MvC title, but with Street Fighter 4 having brought 2D fighters back into the spotlight, the time has never been better to revisit the eternal question once again: could Ryu whup Spider-Man?So how does this crossover extravaganza match up against previous titles in the series?  Very, very well.  While a lot of fans are decrying the relatively smaller 36 playable character roster (down from a mind-shattering 56 in MvC2), the fact is that it's better this way.  The old MvC games pretty much cut-and-pasted the characters from the slew of other versus games out there and threw everyone in the mix which led to mismatched and useless characters.  Competitive play pretty much boiled down to a handful of characters that were clearly much better than the rest.  MvC3 may have trimmed the roster, but it is a phenomenally fun, deep, and balanced roster with each character being useful in their own way and full of nuance.  Both companies also have a lot of new faces representing them, with some of the more obscure characters being surprisingly interesting.  Plus, they all look marvelous.  Even with the fan complaints this is probably the best thing about MvC3.  Yes, in high-level play, there are certain characters that are overpowered, but that list is small and most of us playing this game to have fun and not to win at all costs as a pathetic attempt to boost misguided egos (which probably shouldn't be built around being "good" at video games) are not going to spam Sentinel beams ("neutralizeneutralizeneutralize"...ugh) and Dark Phoenix every match.  That would just be pathetic.  So yeah, MvC3 features one of the coolest and most balanced rosters in a 2D fighter that I`ve ever played and after a few of weeks of play, I have yet to find my favorite character and have settled mainly into a 9 character rotation.  This is the highest praise.As before, this MvC title features single 3-on-3 tag matches instead of the classic 1-on-1/best-of-3 format favored by most fighting games.  This is really what sets the series apart from other hardcore 2D fighters.  While you can only control 1 character at a time, you are able to change at will and to call in "assists" from your offscreen characters to supplement your offensive and defensive endeavors.  For example, if you are trapped in the corner by Wolverine while using a character with poor melee capabilities like Arthur (of Ghosts and Goblins fame), you can call in Haggar (from Final Fight) to come out swinging and knock Wolvie back so you have room to breathe.  This feature adds exponentially to the strategy and complexity of the game and makes forming an effective team combination both vital and fun with so many possibilities.  This brings me to the point that needs to be hammered home the most since I am about to drop some complaints: this gameplay is AMAZING.  It's fun, fast-paced (I have been sweating in the dead of winter), complex, yet very easy to pick up and play assuming you understand the basics of fighting games. The controls have also been streamlined for console play, much to the chagrin of those who spend way too much money on specialized arcade-style stick setups.  While beginners may want to polish their skills in training and arcade modes before tackling veterans online, they shouldn't be too overwhelmed.  This is the definition of easy to learn, difficult to master.  There is also a "simple mode" to the controls to level the playing field between friends with skill discrepancies in multiplayer  that allows some more complex moves to be pulled off with the push of a button at the expense of variety.  It's an alright idea, I guess, but it's not for me.  Mission Mode allows for players to challenge themselves to duplicate combos dictated by the game, which is a cool challenge, but the fact that some of the combos are so long the commands can't even fit onscreen makes it feel like you are practicing for a piano recital and not playing a game.  Not fun, but a good way for beginners to learn the art of comboing, nevertheless.Okay, folks, it's whiny time.  While I have nothing but praise for the gameplay and graphics, I have to take MvC3 to task for a stunning lack of features.  First off, as I write this there is no lobby spectator mode in multiplayer.  That is to say that when you join an online lobby, you don't get to watch the other players' matches while you wait your turn.  You pretty much get to sit and stare at a loading screen.  That is not why I play these games, and it`s unacceptable.  The fun and learning experience of watching and commentating on ongoing fights is a huge part of any fighting community and while Capcom has claimed they will patch this in later, I cannot think of a good reason to not have it there in the first place.  This STANDARD.  Frankly, I'm tempted to drop a full star off of the rating, but assuming they make good on the promise of a patch, I'll hold off on that.  Now, in one of Deadpool's 4th wall-breaking antics (a staple of the character in the comics) he occasionally addresses the player personally at the end of the match during his victory rant with "WHAT DO YOU MEAN YOU WEREN'T RECORDING THAT?!".  Good question, Wade.  Why couldn't we record that?  It's becoming pretty handy to post videos and study recordings of matches to show off to friends and learn different gameplay techniques.  Again, this should be standard.  In addition to the massive multiplayer gripes, the single player lacks a lot to see and do.  No in-game cut scenes aside from the canned match openings really hurts the production value of the arcade mode.  The endings are cool and all and usually filled with crazy crossover goodness featuring characters that we wish had made the roster but didn't, but the static comic images pale in comparison to the fully animated and voiced finales and story sections of games like Dead or Alive 4.  It's ridiculously easy to unlock the very few characters that aren't immediately available and the other unlockables are mostly things like art and character profiles.  Not super-rewarding, but better than nothing, I suppose.  Worst of all, word has it that a lot of the alternate costumes (and possibly even full characters) are already present on the disc, but are being sold as DLC.  This is not good, Capcom.  Making us pay to unlock something on the disc we already paid for is no way to do business and I WILL NOT DO IT.  The price for upcoming downloadable characters is about $5 apiece. A bit steep, if you ask me.  Also, your non-ranked online stats aren't displayed and are lumped with Arcade Mode victories instead.  Not cool.  This should have been an all-time great fighter, but as it stands, it feels half-@$zed and unfinished in a lot of areas and having Capcom charge us for things like alternate costumes after leaving so much out of the game does not help.So in conclusion, Marvel vs. Capcom 3 is a deliriously entertaining fighting game.  It's full of surprises, little obscure touches for fans, funny verbal interplay between characters, and most of all good times.  You really can't beat it for awesome gameplay.  However, I'm going a bit easy on the rating in anticipation of the patch for spectator mode and I need to point out that companies need to stop putting out unfinished games and then charging us for extra content.  It feels like Capcom held back features from this game intentionally (possibly anticipating a "Super" edition in a year or so?) and that stops this from getting a perfect score.  However, since the game itself is so damn fun I've still got to give it very high marks since that`s always the final word with me.  Comprehensive features or not, this is still an awesome game and I'm having a ball with it online and off.4  stars rounded up because I can't stay mad at you, Capcom.

In the extravagant world of Marvel vs. Capcom 3, there is rarely a dull moment. You and your opponent each have a team of three characters to battle it out in one frantic, continuous round accented by dazzling finishing moves and triple-digit combos. But beneath all its style, the game's core combat mechanics have been simplified and work harmoniously to drive you, and the action, forward. Locomotion plays a large role in this, even if the characters are slower than before. This change feels natural in the game's large arenas and affords you the time to plan out your next move without having to rely on blindly overwhelming your opponent. But even if you are slower, you never want to stop moving. There is safety in mobility when every character can clear the length of the arena in a single bound or pepper you with projectiles from a screen away. Stopping only makes things easier for your opponent.Movement keeps the battle flowing and changing as you duck in and out of your opponent's reach, each side frantically searching for that break in the other's defenses. Sometimes opportunity is easy to spot. Other times you have to make your own luck. In either case, when it's time to strike, the number of tools you have in your arsenal is intoxicating. You might unleash a fierce flurry of blows, summon another character to take a quick shot, or employ a snap back attack for a more favorable match-up. When on the defense, a well-timed advancing guard can punish a nasty rushdown player, while a crossover counter can rescue a teammate under fire. Regardless, after each encounter you take away a little something to add to your repertoire--be it practice with your favorite go-to combo or knowledge that a new assist isn't all that great. There's a constant sense of progression as you endlessly experiment with new tricks and new combinations.
Buy it used. It's not worth it to spend the bucks on a new one. After few hours of play around 4 hours my son never played it again.

reviewText: A running joke/insult for MvC3 is "THIS is what took them 10 years?!". Well, it's not like the game's been in development for that long, but I can kind of see why a lot of people are ending up disappointed with it. The lack of gameplay modes, the high price for downloadable characters, a lot of the characters here more or less being ones that no one really wanted, etc. Granted, I'm not in the same boat as those people, but Marvel vs Capcom 3 just doesn't deliver all the goods in my eyes, and I was hoping Capcom would've really given it their all considering how beloved the last game was, and how it's still frequently played in big tournaments like EVO. The bottom line is that if you're a hardcore fighting game fan, as in the kind of person who counts frames, knows the right links in combos, knows exactly how much damage x attack does to x character, and even the right spacing for moves, you're probably going to eat this up. Casual fighting game fans, stay away from this game if you have any plans of playing online.I'll start with the things I liked about MvC3. First up, I actually liked most of the cast here. In Marvel vs Capcom 2, you had a very diverse cast, with characters from popular and obscure games. The thing is, at least half of those characters rarely got used, because it was made very clear when you played with all of them, that characters like Amingo and Roll wouldn't last 10 seconds against a Magneto or Sentinel. But the cast was still there, and a lot of people were happy with who they had. In MvC3, it seems like Capcom took time in putting equal time into the characters, making things a lot more balanced than in the last game. And I really love how some less popular/known characters are here instead of the standard guys, like how we have Amaterasu from Okami and Arthur from Ghosts 'n Goblins. I had a lot of fun seeing each character's different moves and animations. The music is also MUCH better than MvC2's, as we no longer have rejected Charlie Brown tracks. Instead, every character has their own theme, and once a character is taken out, the new character who steps in has their theme playing. And for people who like getting trophies, there are a lot of pretty easy ones to get. I got nearly 40% after playing for just 2 hours. The endings for each character were also a great touch- your ending in arcade mode depends on who your main character is when you beat the final boss, and some of these things are pretty funny. 'a lot better than those in either version of Street Fighter IV.Now the not so good, which is the rest of the game/the important parts- the gameplay. If you've played Tatsunoko vs Capcom on the Wii, the controls here are very similar to that. So if you've only played Street Fighter IV over the last 2 years, this is going to be pretty different for you. You have light, medium and heavy attacks, a special launcher attack for air combos, and the other buttons are used for calling in your team mates for assists. It's not that hard to get the hang of, but here's the thing- Capcom included a Simple play mode, where square is all of your attacks, triangle is your special moves, x is still the launcher, and circle is your hyper combo attack. This is for very casual players who button mash, or don't want to spend time learning moves. This carries over to online mode, where you could face someone using these controls, and spams special moves over and over again, causing a ton of frustration. It'll get pretty annoying fast too, since the couple of times I've went online, at various times of the day, matchmaking was 50/50, and it'd take forever to get a match, even when there were tons of people available and I had a good connection. 'reminded me of the Guilty Gear X2 #Reload days...But the key problem for me is that I just plain got bored with how flashy everything was, though that might be because this just isn't my kind of game I guess. I love fighting games- 'started out with the first Street Fighter II on the SNES, moved on to the King of Fighters and Fatal Fury games, Samurai Shodown, Capcom vs SNK, Last Blade, Street Fighter III, Guilty Gear, etc. I think it's because I'm more keen on traditional 2D fighters that don't involve tagging in your partners every couple of seconds to win. But that's just me.However, the thing that ruins a lot of the fun for me is the X Factor. This is a special move you can use once per fight at any time. If you use it when all 3 of your characters are active, it gives you a small boost in power for a few seconds, and recovery on the red part of your bar is healed a little faster. If you use it when 2 members of your team are present, it gives you more power and faster healing. But if you use it with your final character, they can be a complete monster. Some characters that will completely obliterate entire teams while in X Factor mode are Hulk, Sentinel, Zero and Dante. If you're facing one of these guys with a fragile character like Phoenix, who already goes down in about 8 hits (to balance out her strong attacks), kiss your lil' lady goodbye after 2 hits. I'm really hoping a patch comes out that cuts down the boosts a bit sometime in the next couple of months, but it doesn't seem likely. And while I said the roster is pretty balanced, some characters are still a little overpowered, or too newbie friendly to the point where you can zone your opponents pretty easily with a few moves. But advanced players will know how to get around this of course.Visually, the game looks pretty good, though some character designs are downright weird looking. Chris in particular looks odd during his win pose, and the illustration of the Hulk has tons of people wondering what's wrong with his teeth. Everything has a comic book look to it, and a lot of the Capcom guys translated well to this style, even if they haven't been in a major console game for years. But gameplay is generally smooth and there's rarely any slowdown, online and offline.Like I said, there's a lot here for people who obsess over fighting games, but if you're interested in playing because of the characters or hype, you might just want to rent it for a day and see how it goes. Marvel vs Capcom 3 is vastly different from the likes of Super Street Fighter IV, a game I keep bringing up because up until now, it was -the- fighting game to play on consoles (BlazBlue being a close second, but not as well known). Casual fighting game players will be annihilated online, so if you do get this but don't plan on getting an arcade fight stick or being that serious, it'd be fun for parties or something with relatives who don't play many games. Just don't say I didn't warn you, especially when a single Sentinel wipes out your party while X Factor is active.
summary: Well, the hardcore fighting game players will at least love it.
