reviewText: First off, fighting games are my favorite Genre.  From Street Fighter to Tekken to Mortal Kombat I pretty much love them all.  The strategy involved within them is usually a quick mind game, which I enjoy.  Marvel Vs. Capcom 3 doesn't dissapoint.  The overall playstyle is very easy to pick up, but can be difficult to master depending on which characters you chose.  Alot of people ask which fighting game would you compare it to?  Obviously that would be street fighter, as far as the inputs go, however, it is not as technical and way more easier to pick up.  I'll list a few pros and cons about this game.+Presentation:  I actually love the comic book feel to the game.  The game is not meant to have realistic graphics or anything.  It works very well for what it is.  The Hyper and super combos are flashy and that's what makes the game.  It makes you go "oo and aah"+Gameplay: I actually like that pretty much every character has the same setup of Low, Medium, High then Launch button.  It makes it pretty simple to play with a vast amount of characters.  Even though that this scheme is "standard" there is still multiple ways to attack your opponent before launching them in the air for an air combo.  You don't have to rely on this button scheme all of the time.  Also, it doesn't work for every character.  Dormmamu for example, you can't connent a low, medium, high into a launch.  You have connect Low, Medium and then Launch.  His High won't connect.+Sounds and Voices: I love all of the English Voices except for Ryu. I have him set to Japenese, but the rest of them are pretty Epic, and some of them are quite Hilarious such as Deadpool and Hulk.  I love how you go into a fight and the voices seem so personalized for what's actually going on.  For example, when Deadpool goes into a match when he is fighting a street fighter character (Akuma, C. Viper, Chun Li, Ryu) he will say "I Freaking Love Street Fighter, Will you Sign my spleen for me?"  It's pretty funny and entertaining.Now for some Cons of the game:-Unlockables: There is not very much going on here.  The unlockable characters can easily be unlocked in about 20 minutes of gameplay.  It isn't that hard.  I believe as soon as you hit 8,000PP everyone is unlocked.  After that, all you have is player endings and models.  Which are not all that exciting to say the least.-Online play: This is by far the worst thing about the game.  The online play is HORRIBLE!!!  First of all, I can never find a match.  I will literally search for about 10 minutes before I can find one, and when I do it's a laggy spam fest.  All players do online is chose Zoner characters mainly Sentinal, Trish, Dormmamu, Dr. Doom, Arthur or Iron Man, and they spam beams all day long.  I am actually not complaining about this, because spamming is a viable tactic in a fighting game.  If you can't beat spammers that is your fault.  Anywho, my main complaint is the lag involved, everytime I try to get to them, I usually can't.  I am a close range fighter my Team consist of Akuma, Chun Li and Wolverine.  The only far range fighter I have is Akuma.  So it can sometimes be tough for me to get in.  Also, I have a problem with the ranking system.  I am not too sure how when I started a rank match as a beginner I got paired with a 6th lord.  That made no sense to me at all.-Sentinal:  He's over powered.  I hate him, I hated him in MVC2 and I hate him now.  I don't care what anyone says.  He's chaep.  Hands down.  May I ask why Capcom decided to give the biggest character in the game the most stamina, mega damage output, and a full screen beam move that you can do by just pressing one button?  It makes no sense at all.  To top it all off, his launch has armor properties, which means that you pretty much have to hit him twice or more if he is trying to launch you in the air for an air combo.  It's ridiculous.  Not to mention his Sentinal Force Bomb assist.  It's ridiculous.  You can't advance at all when it's coming at you.  It takes up the entire screen you have to block it.  I could go on and on all day about Sentinel.  He needs to be nerfed big time.-Unbalanced:  Every fighting game can't be perfectly balanced.  MVC3 is not as unbalanced as MVC2, but it has it's moments.  Close range characters (Hulk, Hagger) have high stamina and high damage output which is how it's supposed to be, but what about other close range characters such as Chun Li, and Wolverine.  Their damage is not very good at all, especially Chun Li.  It just seems like Close ranged righters in this game recieve the end of the stick most of the time.-X Factor: Stupid just stupid.  Sentinel in X factor = Death Sentance.  I hate it.  I hate how I can defeat two characters on one team, and then my opponent can take out my entire squad by just going into X factor and either spamming long range attacks or just keep doing super moves.  Also not to mention the least amount of characters you have the longer X Factor stays activated and the higher the damage output.  Do you want to know why so many people pick Sentinel as their third character and then X Factor?  Yea, that's why.  Highest Damage output in the game goes even Higher, and it lasts longer.  It's so ridiculous.Overall MVC3 is just an okay game.  It's fun, when you are playing with someone who is actually skilled and likes to do combos.  Otherwise it can become really frustrating and old very quick.  Do I regret my purchase?  Eh, not at the moment.  But I have a feeling that I will once everyone figures out that you pretty much have to be to an a**hole to even win a match anymore.
summary: I love the game, I hate the players

Marvel vs. Capcom 3 was definitely the most anticipated fighter this year; consequently, the expectations were through the roof. Normally when this happens, disappointment is bound to happen due to the unrealistic expectations. Luckily, I'm a reasonable person so my expectations weren't crazy..But unfortunately, this game falls pretty short regardless.First things first - the graphics are outstanding.  The characters are 2D, but are shaded in such a way that they appear 3D. The stages are beautifully made with tons of detail (such as Chun-Li being painted on the side of a building on the Daily Bugle stage, and the glass in the Resident Evil stage being broken when there's a heavy slam on the ground). The Main Menu screens contain beautifully done artwork and are nice to look at. The end match screens, which are made in the form of a comic book, are well put-together as well. Voice Acting is another plus. There's even some personal conversations between characters at the beginning and end of a match. A neat little touch.The gameplay is great. The roster is MUCH more balanced than the broken atrocity that was Marvel vs. Capcom 2. Capcom tried to make the game more accessible to newcomers and casual fighting fans, and it shows. One example is the "simple mode." When I first started to play fighting games, I was clueless on what the motions meant--Z-motions to do uppercuts were basically like quantum physics to me. While I can do it flawlessly now, there are many newcomers to this genre who are just like I was. Thus, Capcom added "simple" mode which allows people to do combos, special moves, and hyper combos by the simple touch of a button. This doesn't give an unfair advantage, though, since you'll only have access to about half of your moveset. The only way to get better is to practice, practice, practice. The purpose of simple mode is, if you don't have the time to practice consistently, you can still play and join the fun as you practice in secret when you can.One reason people tend to give this game low ratings is due to the lack of modes. Lack of story mode, survival mode, time attack mode, etc. for instance are pretty much a standard part of most fighters nowadays. This game lacks all of the mentioned modes. In fact, all there is to do is Arcade mode, Mission mode (do the indicated combos), Training Mode, and Vs. Mode against human only (no VS. CPU), and Online mode, which we will discuss later. This means that there isn't too much to do. Me personally, I'm not holding this against the game since I don't really care too much for stories in fighting games, or survival mode/time attack mode, etc. Training Mode does what it's supposed to, and Arcade is just your standard Arcade mode. Still, for a game that was marketed towards casual players, the lack of features was surprising.The online is what destroys the game. Unless you have a LOT of friends to play with in person all the time, online mode is where one spends (or should be spending, at least) the majority of their time, due to the multiplayer nature of this game. One problem I, as well as many people, seem to have is the fact that connecting to matches takes tediously long.Another severe blow to the online mode is due to the lack of a Spectator feature. When you are in a lobby with more than 2 people (such as playing with friends), rather than being able to watch the match between two other people you just sit at the menu. You see the health bars of the 2 participants, but who honestly wants to look at that? This wouldn't have been a big deal if it wasn't something that ALL OTHER fighting games had (Super Street Fighter IV, Tekken 6, even Marvel vs. Capcom 2). If it is a 3 player lobby, this can be tolerable; if there are 5 people in a lobby however, this means 15+ minutes of staring at the menu before you can play. Who wants to do that??The nail in the coffin for this game, however, is the netcode (which is what the online is based on). The netcode was poorly made. The game contains a button lag implement while online, where if you press a button, there is a brief delay between your press and the attack actually occuring (unlike offline mode, where the attack comes out instantaneously). It is also inconsistent, since this lag varies between matches. This means all the time you spend in training mode, and all the fancy combos you do on your friends in real life are difficult to impossible whilst online due to the delay.  Even blocking is tricky to do because of the delay, which means you will probably still be getting hit when you started blocking well before. As a result, most people online tend to do the same exact combos over and over with not much variety, and this tends to get boring to endure. I am not one to complain about spamming/etc, but when the game isn't doing something what I'm telling it to do, something is wrong. On top of the button lag is regular lag. From what I've seen, you can be playing against someone across the street from you and the game will still randomly slow down and turn choppy. The match will run smoothly one second and all of a sudden there will be pauses in between frames. The training mode has a lag feature where you can practice under certain lag conditions, but it is completely different from the actual lag you encounter online. It is essentially a waste of time. Capcom can do much better than this, as demonstrated by their previous fighter, Super Street Fighter IV, which had FANTASTIC online play.That being said...Marvel vs. Capcom 3 is still a decent game. It's a bare-bones game, but if you're a huge fan of the series then you'll love it regardless. If you're a casual fighter, look for a friend who has it and try it out before purchase.
summary: Good game, but online needs MAJOR work

reviewText: Marvel vs. Capcom is one of those cross over fighting franchises that make certain gamers salivate. You will have your choice of 3 characters to go up against another team of 3 characters. If you can master the moves, as well as master when to bring a different character in, you could find yourself a champion. Now as with most fighting games, there's not a whole lot to the story portion of the game. Yes, Galactus is trying to consume your world, and you're going to need to defeat all the fighters between you and him, but other than that, its basically knock out your opponent with skill.Graphically this game looks great. In my opinion there will never be anything wrong with a 2D fighting game. You're also going to have quite a few of very intense attacks that run smoothly when executed. I have to give it to them, there isn't much, if any, jittery motions or graphical issues when trying to do so much on the screen. The backgrounds will give you a sense of nostalgia for the most part. I personally really like the Ghost 'n Goblins board.The music is your standard affair fighting music. Sure there's some special flair for the characters and franchises represented, but you're probably not going to be paying any attention to it as you're going to be solely focused on your opponent.The controls for this game will basically have you utilizing every button minus the select button. You'll notice that buttons for different characters will do different things, as well as combinations of buttons. The thing about fighting games is that there's always going to be different combinations of buttons to create some very devastating attacks, and if you can master those, which I have to say most of them aren't too difficult to get down, you're going to have quite a bit of fun with this game.So as stated above this is a fighting game where you get to choose from several members from the Marvel Universe as well as the Capcom universe. Sure there were a ton of characters that I'm sure people wanted to see in the mix, but overall I think they did a pretty good job capturing some of the favorite characters from respected franchises. My personal favorite combo was Arthur (Ghost 'n Goblins), X-23 (Xmen), and Trish (Devil May Cry). Sure they aren't the heavy hitters of the bunch, but man can they deal out some punishment when you get their moves down. Personally I'm a button masher so I know that online competition is a bit out of my range, but facing off against friends is a lot of fun, and if you liking fighting games, and have a competitive streak, you'll find you've played more matches than you intended to. Take Jesse and I for example, we ended up playing 30+ matches, sadly we split them down the middle, so I couldn't show my awesome supremacy, but it was enjoyable every time.So if you're looking for a solid fighting game that gives you more than kicks and punches, and has a cast of characters from different Capcom games as well as characters from the Marvel Universe, then this is the game you've got to try. I may not be the biggest fighting game person, but I have to say that I highly enjoyed this game, and also the fact is that if you button mash there's a good chance that you'll last a bit through a match/game. This game gets an 8.8 out of 10.

**WAIT FOR THE ULTIMATE EDITION WHICH IS HERE:Ultimate Marvel Vs. Capcom 3The new heroes are here to kick butt and take names, and after a decade of wondering if this game would ever come into being, Marvel vs. Capcom 3 is finally here. If you've never played the series before, let me just inform you this is not your typical fighting game. This is more of an action fighting game, in the sense that the first few matches are going to be chaotic looking. There's characters popping in and out of the screen. There's combos popping up all over the screen. Before you know it, you're dead without even getting a hit in. But with much practice comes great benefits.Your first choices in the game will be to take it offline in arcade mode or training, or take a chance in online battles via ranked or player matches. Offline modes are limited to arcade, training, versus, and a mission mode. Arcade is just the basic story mode. You'll pick three characters to battle, all with different abilities to battle round after round until you defeat a special boss. When you beat the final boss, you'll unlock a comic strip ending for the character that you were last using. You'll also unlock some badges and titles for your win to show off online. If you're having a difficult time learning moves, training mode is there to help. However, mission mode is going to be more helpful in teaching you how to successfully complete moves. Mission mode is more reminiscent of the challenge modes in Super Street Fighter IV. You have a training dummy in front of you, and you're mission is to provide a certain attack to it.Online modes are limited to ranked and player matches. I don't really find this to be a bad thing, but it's apparent some people wanted more modes. You can party up online much like a "quarter mode", which is great, and it's also the downfall of online play. While you're the observer, you never get to watch the battle. You're treated to two player cards of the fighters with the health bars moving up and down during their match. But you'll never get to see the moves they're pulling off, making tournaments seem almost pointless. There's also no replay feature, so watching some of the cool moves you distributed to a player is long gone. Hopefully Capcom will reintroduce this in a patch in the future, without a DLC cost.Everything in a match is fast moving and player momentum is natural in a game like this. You want to keep moving, providing damage, and repeat. In Marvel vs. Capcom 3, and while the animations have been slowed down they compliment the game atmosphere nicely.One way Marvel vs. Capcom designers have tried to help remove the anxiety new gamers feel during their first match is by introducing a new mode: Simple mode, or button mashing mode if you prefer. It gives high hopes for beginners to be able to win a match. With this mode enabled, you literally can just press the same button over and over while moving the stick around to pull off sweet moves. By using simple mode, even the most novice player may have a chance at winning. While simple mode may be good for grandmas and tottlers, it is going to limit the amount of special moves a player can use. It enables easy access to simpler moves, and that's it. Now, this doesn't mean that in simple mode, you're not going to need any skill at all. You'll probably want to focus on blocks to get you ready for the real fighting of the game: the online modes.Another huge change is the inclusion of X-Factor. This mode enables to you increase your attack power and speed for a limited time, depending on how many characters are still alive in your party. It also resets your animation, giving you access to chain more moves together that would be impossible otherwise. It sounds like a gimmick move, but in the game, it's been quit helpful and I haven't experienced it being overused.Graphically, this game is well done too. The game feels much like a comic book opening up in front of you. The dark shadows look amazing, and can't simple be justified to how amazing they look in screen shots. The animations are smooth, and you'll rarely see a hick-up in the game. The backgrounds are slightly muted to bring the characters forward a little bit. It almost looks like you're playing a 2D fighting game at times, which isn't a bad thing. They just mastered how well to do the visuals in a sense that it looks old school, yet 3D at the same time.Let's talk roster for a minute. There's 36 characters to choose from, half from Marvel Comics, and the others from Capcom games. This is a lot less than the roster of Marvel vs. Capcom 2, but is that a bad thing? Marvel vs. Capcom 2, while a terrific fighting game, had some huge holes in the balancing because of so many characters. Most of the time, the balancing wasn't from over-powered fighters as much as under powered characters. So Capcom decided to keep the roster a little smaller while fine-tuning each character with pros and cons. This is obviously a good thing, but coming from Capcom, this might have been a way to milk a little more money out of the game. We can expect some DLC to come out shortly after (March has two new characters and a costume pack scheduled for release). What worries me is how much this stuff is going to cost. Capcom knows people will buy it up, so are they going to charge the extra mile because they know this?However, even though I'm not a fan of overpriced DLC, Capcom is at least listening to the fans on the DLC they want. On Capcom Utility's website, you can actually vote for characters you want to see in the game (hint: Gambit needs to come back, so vote!). I find this to be really neat and I hope they truly listen to their fans. If anything needs DLC fast in the game, I feel they need to add some more maps. The maps are awesome that are already in the game, but there's hardly any to really look at. I wouldn't even mind some recycled maps from the previous installments of the game.The only other complaint I have is the controls on a standard controller. They work, but they never feel comfortable. The game begs for a fight stick of some sort. I haven't played on the Xbox 360's D-pad yet, but I can imagine it being atrocious given that the 360's D-pad isn't exactly the most impressive on the market.If anything, the game is going to hold it's own for a while but it will probably not be in the ranks of classic like it's predecessor. It's all a matter of time to how well this game will rank in the end. With DLC coming out, one can hope that Capcom listens to their fans and keeps the community strong.+ Great character list with balance issues in check+ Outstanding graphics and sounds.- Being nerfed online by Iron Man. Over. And over. And over...- No replay modes.
Kept us busy for hours and hours. Classic characters that come back in better graphics and moves than I remember when I was a kid!

reviewText: I was hyped to see MVC back again, at first the game is super entertaining with such great graphics and the great roster. But after a while, at least for me, it gets boring. I found myself playing just for getting some points and endings.

Okay, I was REALLY excited when Marvel vs. Capcom 3 was announced. The new characters, the new graphics and a long awaited sequel of Marvel vs. Capcom 2. It was on my list of games to get and while I couldn't get it on initial release, I was foolish to sell my Okami game (that I won at a Smash Brothers tournament) to get enough money to buy this game...and what pissed me off was when I got the game, Crapcom decided to release an updated version 6 months after this game was released meaning when I bought the game THEY ANNOUNCED THEY WERE REMAKING IT. You don't know how angry I was with the announcement especially when Ultimate would have Phoenix Wright and Vergil (probably the only two new characters that I cared about because the Marvel side was crap addiction).But this was probably the game that made me realize that Crapcom has fallen from grace especially when they used the tsunami as an excuse to delay the game and as many people pointed out, Capcom of Japan wasn't even near the tsunami so there was no way they as a company would be affected (but the workers and their families are another thing but we're talking about the company).The worse part was when I got this game, I wouldn't be able to get my money back because this game won't sell for that much with Ultimate that came out and Crapcom basically said "Unless you buy Ultimate, you're stuck with this junk we're not supporting."This is a real shame because I had fun playing this game...but got bored just as easily. The game feels like a beta version with Ultimate being the complete version. The game is not balanced and it feels like the endings at the end of each character chapter was just thrown in at the last minute foreshadowing who would show up in Ultimate. I feel for the Megaman fans who were teased with the poster of Megaman in one of the background stages and then denied access to have him in game to the point that his only "appearance" was a palette swap.The worse part was because of Ultimate, there wasn't much you could do with game once you got all the endings and achievements. There weren't that many characters to unlock and there were only two DLC characters (that Crapcom would charge later in Ultimate at the same price instead of putting them in given they were in this one). I really liked playing with Dante, Chun Li and a Morrigan team but when everyone plays broken characters like Magneto or easy to use Wolverine online, there was either no challenge because they were too easy or they would constantly spam online making online play worthless. This game didn't have spectator mode either.So the main reason I'm giving this a 1 is because I feel cheated out of my money and now this game is just sitting in my room never to be played again because it got boring after a month and there's no way to get all my money back. I'll probably try to sell it later for something but it still pisses me off greatly. I give the fun rating a three because I did enjoy playing this game with my friends, but again, this doesn't do much because once they're gone, its back to being bored with it again. If I just waited and bought Ultimate, I probably wouldn't be feeling as agitated as I am now but I won't get Ultimate given I boycotted Crapcom.

reviewText: Ok I guess its time to throw in my 2 cents about this game. I have alot to say so this may come off as a rambling review, so forgive me if it goes that route. First I'll adress the title of this review. They really did not serve Phoenix well in this game. It is not that she is a bad character, she just is to weak. She looses health faster than any character maybe in the whole history of the versus games. I own all the versus games. I'm not saying that makes me an expert, but damn it is just rediculous. Just for FYI I own that Saturn version of X-Men vs Sf , MSH vs SF and the Dreamcast version of Marvel one so I got the good copies of those games not the watered down PS1 versions. But I digress that is a let down, because I really wanted to roll with that character, I swaped her out for Storm, so that completes my team that I use the most of Dante,X-23 and her. Enough of that, now on to something the public may acutually care about.There is alot of complaining when it comes to this game and I knew it would be that way. This is the kind of game that is going to generate over praise and be overly criticised because it is a popular title. You have the camp that will love this game now matter what after all ITS MAHVEL BABY!!! And in some peoples mind just for that reason alone it can do no wrong. Then there is the camp that will not like because ITS MAHVEL BABY!!!They want to oppose it and act like yeah I heard of that and I played it. It is a overated piece of _____ and I hate it. This is wrong, that is wrong, and what have you. This game is not perfect by any means. You have Tatsunoko vs Capcom that recieved praise from the public and most people said it is a very good game and you should own it if you like fighting games. I have that game is it fun, yes is it perfect no. These two games are alot alike. They have virtualy the same fighting engine with this game being easier to play than that one. Which to me is unbelivable. But this game has Marvel in the front, it is a sequal to arguably the most popular fighting game ever made, so people are inclined not to like it. Now I'm not saying if you don't like this game you are a side line hater with an agenda. But, I know human nature and I know that plays a roll in some peoples minds.If you are comparing this game to MvC2 your already looking to the wrong source to get an understanding of this game. Like I stated before this game plays like Tatsunoko. If the sequal to Marvel 2 was made in 03 it would probably have been alot like that one. But, this is 11 years later and times have changed alot. Hell, I was 21 when the Marvel 2 came out lol. Capcom in a wise business decision made this game easier to play to get more people and more importantly more money. From a business stand point that makes sense, from a gamer stand point you look like a sell out. But, by no means is this game easy. Its like I heard someone say, most of these people talking probably have no mastered anything so they should wait to see what the game holds before they write it off. I have seen some sick combos in this game. That _____ ain't easy to pull off. There is deep gameplay to be found if you look beyond the controls and actually delve into it.Next complaint did the roster is not as large as the last one. Come on people use some common sense. Did you really think it would be? The last game used character sprites dating back to 1994, X-Men Children of the Atom. That is where they got Storm, Cyclopes, and Wolverine sprites came from just to name a few. So they had a back log of characters from that series, the Alpha series and the Vs's games. So the said F it throwem all in here and see what we get. We got an unbalanced mess is what we got. Yet a fun game that is a classic. Yes there where new sprites Jill and Cable come to mind. But on the whole they where just copying and pasting them into that game.I always wish Capcom did redraw those character that would have been really cool to see, oh well that didn't happen. Maybe when its said and done will have a game that has that many characters. But you will have to pay for them. For 5 bucks a pop and you can have all the characters that Capcom makes. Ughh DLC that is whole other story I ain't gettin into today.The most important thing here is the game fun. And that it succeeds in. I'm not a kid anymore. I play games for fun in particular I play fighting games. I have overs 60 so I like that genre and I'm glad to see it make a come back. Down with the FPS!!! I'm kidding. The game is really good looking, online videos do this game no justice. The comic book look and style of this game really pop of the screen. And if you have and HD tv it is eye candy. The game is just eye catching, even if someone you know does not play video games. They will see this and ask what is that game you are playing. The characters are a little to floaty and the tag in and out is slow. Its not a fast as Tatsunoko's and especially Marvel 2. Anyone can play and enjoy it. Look I'm not with dumbing down games. Games now a days are way to easy on a whole. This game does not need a simple mode. How slow do you have to be to not be able to handle a L/M/H attack button? The game is what it is have fun with it, try not to look at what it is not and appreciate what it is. I gave this game 5 stars and it is not a 5 star game it more like 4 1/2. But and I say this every time I want to give a game half grade. Amazon does not have half scores so I gave it five, to boost its score because this game desereves a higher score than 3 1/2 stars. So people plug in your HRAP, Madcatz TE stick or even a PS3 controller and be taken for a ride, did you think I wouldn't say that atleast once. Life is far to short to be complaining about video games. Enjoy the game for what it is and put the BS to the side, because this is Marvel vs Capcom 3 sit back and enjoy the show. Peace

reviewText: MvC3 is currently one of the two monthly tournaments I run at my restaurant/bar. Initially, we found that there were a few overpowered characters (Sentinel, Phoenix), but after a few patches - that problem was smoothed out. After running a few tournaments, we generally agreed on the following:Cons:-Character Roster seemingly incomplete (No Ken, yet there is Ryu and Akuma. No Megaman, but there is Zero. Etc)-Have to pay for Downloadable Content of new characters-Depending on your level of play, it could get frustrating (especially online)Pros:-Very visually appealing comic-book style art-Easy to pick up and learn, mix-and-match combos/teams encouraged-New balanced damage system - Combo-decay prevents players from abusing infinite/100% damage combos-Progressively balanced character set (No such thing as "best character" or "best team"), For example: Amaterasu attacks fast, and has a smaller hit box. Sentinel has a larger hit box, but conversely - he has more reach. Phoenix technically has TWO lives. MODOK can lay traps on the field. Haggar's Pipe attack hits like an Ultra. Etc.Notes:-The addition of X-Factor had mixed reviews. Competitively, it was an unfair game-breaker and my tournament people wanted an option to turn it off. During casual play, it was welcomed yet seldom used. A "win" through X-Factor was considered "cheap" by both casual players and professional players.Bottom Line: Get it, it's fun. If you're casual, you'll feel like a pro. If you're pro, you'll be able to play with so many variables.
summary: All Characters Equally Unbalanced. That's Right.

I'm a huge fighter fan, especially of the 2D variety. Blazeblue, Darkstalkers and of course the SF series and all of the variaties attached to them. But after being a lifelong gamer, I quit playing fighters. Games evolved, sports and racing games became more realistic and this generation's arcades live long and prosper under the names of Battlefield and Call of Duty. And having friends over for a party game is no longer limited to fighters and sports, but singing, mini-games, etc.MvC3 does some things great. For my money's worth, this is not only the best looking fighter ever, but one of my favorite games ever from a graphics standpoint. The characters have to be seen in motion with the insane speed and fireworks exploding at all times. For some it could be overwhelming, not for me.  Visually stunning is an understatement.The controls. This is a bit of an issue. Because the game moves so fast and Capcom loostened up the controls (allowing sloppy input to still generate the desired move) the game very quickly can devolve into a button masher. It is too easy to accidentaly trigger your mega-ginormous-screen filling-finsiher when your simply trying to swap characters. After carefully building your "Maxx" gauge for that end of match push only to burn two levels while your trying to swap teamates is very frustrating. My 8yr old loves it. Talk about pick up and play. Anyone, including a 3rd grader, can take a quick peak and the moves list and light the screen on fire. For casual gamers, that's terrific. For a hardcore fighting fanatic, that it is heresy.I gave the game 5 stars for fun because it really is. But 3 stars overall for lack of depth and replayability - hence the title. The characters are eclectic, but different. As DLC has already been announced, I fully expect to see more popular characters show up over the upcoming months. No where near as revolutionary as it's predescessor but an enjoyable game non the less.
summary: Why the fighter genre almost died...and will again

reviewText: Marvel Vs. Capcom 3: The Fate of Two WorldsThe title says it all.  Marvel and Capcom battling each other and together to save the world once again.  Even though it took more than 10 years to make, the wait was well worth it!!Controls:This is where everyone will have a lot of gripe with.  If you played Tatsunoko Vs. Capcom, you'll see that it's similar to this game, but with the difference of the 4th button.  Now, MVC2 had Weak/Medium and Strong attacks that made it simple, but insanely difficult to pull off combos in the game.  In MVC3, it's totally different.  There are 4 buttons here.  Weak Attack, Medium Attack, and Strong Attack are your three basic attacks in the game.  The last one is called the "Special" button where this button launches the opponent into the air, rather than figuring out what attack makes the opponent launch up in MVC2.  The L1 and R1 buttons are used, like before, to call your allies and assist you with whatever assist you gave them.  Also, they added new features, like X-Factor that powers up your character and can cancel ANYTHING (including Super Moves).  Also, they put in Team Aerial Combo, which allows you to call your allies and continue your combos.  There are many more add-ons in this game, so try it out!!Graphics:Shinkiro's beautiful artwork has made MVC3 look even better.  All the characters are 3D now, and they all are detailed!  The backgrounds are beautiful and aren't distracting to the players at all, but are there to provide a colorful place to kick your opponent's behind in.  Also, many characters make a cameo in the stages and the endings too.  Don't believe me? Play this game already!!Story Mode:Not much of a story here, but a new feature is that each character has their own ending (in which will give you Trophies when you complete them).  Even though The Fantastic Four aren't here, all your characters will come together to try and stop Galactus from destroying the Earth.Characters:The line-up is smaller than MVC2, but hey, I'm not complaining like others.  Many new characters are in this game, like Trish, Dante, She-Hulk, Thor, Deadpool and many more.  My little gripe about this is that if you got the Limited Edition for this game, you can't get Jill or Shuma Gorath until March 15th.  Many players will already have a team by then, and Jill and Shuma Gorath will be hard to add to their teams since it's one month from now.Gameplay:It's Marvel Vs. Capcom 3. That's all I have to say. Just kidding. The game allows you to play with your friends and with other players online easier than with MVC2.  Not only that, they added a Mission Mode for this game.  If you played Super Street Fighter IV or Blazblue: Continuum Shift, then you'll recognize this part.  Creating insane combos with EVERY character is in this mode, and actually helps you learn X-Factor Cancel and Team Assist easier than just playing the game.This game is amazing, hands-down.  I recommend this game to ANYONE, even children, as the game is exciting and will make players play this game for hours and hours!!Also, to note, the DLC for this game will be coming at a later date:1.  Jill and Shuma Gorath: $5 per character, available on March 15th.2.  Shadow Mode: a Free downloadable pack that features the Capcom's creators, like Ryota Niitsuma (the creator of MVC3), and their very own CPU-controlled teams for you to fight against.3. Alternative costumes for six characters: Ryu with his Street Fighter 1 costume (Red Hair anyone?), Chris Redfield in his RE1 costume, Dante looking like his father, Sparda, Captain America in a more modern outfit, Iron Man and his American costume, and Thor, in his original costume.  This pack will cost $5 also.Hopefully, there's more to come w/ the DLC!!!!
summary: The Fate of Two Worlds rest in your hands!!!

After more than ten years of waiting, the follow-up to one of the most successful and well-known crossover gaming franchises at last arrives. Marvel VS. Capcom 3 breaks into the scene facing a great deal of expectations and anticipation, and in most aspects it delivers, but unfortunately it falls just a bit short of being the spectacular game it could have been.The gameplay and general mechanics are essentially a mishmash of those from both Marvel VS. Capcom 2 and Tatsunoko VS. Capcom. You're given three characters and a series of four core buttons to work with, those being Light, Medium, Heavy and Special attacks. This closely resembles the setup of TVC, simplifying things a bit from the punch and kick commands of MVC; a wise move, given that it generally trims the fat of the previous game's complexity.The Assists, Hyper Combos, crossovers and many other advanced tactics all return, but there are a handful of new alterations and quirks. For one, unlike TVC, there is no Mega Crash (although it is possible to break away from certain long combos) or Baroque; instead, there's the X Factor, a completely new tactic that may only be used once per match. X Factoring allows each of your characters a brief speed and power boost, along with gradual health recovery. These effects are strengthened depending on how many of your 3 characters are remaining (it is at its maximum if you only have one character left). This occasionally adds an interesting element to the gameplay, but many have argued that it's an unnecessary feature which can unfairly turn the tide of a fight, and there is definitely some validity to this complaint. Adding to the imbalance of this is the fact that different characters receive different boosts, leading to some characters gaining ridiculous power boosts while others don't really become much more of a threat.Switching out, or swapping characters, is unfortunately now a sorely obnoxious task, requiring the player to press and hold the Partner button until their other character appears; mistakenly tapping the button will cause a crossover Assist, and as many veteran players know, initiating an Assist when you're intending to switch out can cost you a character, or worse, a match. Needless to say, this can take a bit of getting used to, particularly for those accustomed to the simple back+/Partner command that came before.`Simple mode' from TVC also returns, allowing a significantly simplified control scheme in which special moves and Hyper Combos can be more easily initiated. This may sound unappealing or unfair to those more willing to adjust to the traditional controls, but simple mode also disallows certain attacks and abilities, so it's more of a tradeoff than a wholehearted handicap; it's ultimately a more accessible and user-friendly version of the control scheme.The roster has been among the most debated-over aspects of the game; MVC2 had a whopping 56 characters to choose from, while so far MVC3 only offers 36. Granted, unlike MVC2, you'll find no recycled sprites here; each and every character is brought to vivid new life and design. Many staples and favorites return, so fans of Ryu, Wolverine, Morrigan, Storm, and many others won't be complaining. Devil May Cry's Dante and X-Men's Deadpool are among some of the exciting new additions, while a surprising number of more obscure fan favorites also managed to make the cut. Some of the exclusions are rather upsetting, however, particularly the lack of Venom, certain X-Men characters and most shocking of all, Capcom's flagship character Mega Man. There's more downloadable content to come, however, so we'll have to see what the game's future has to offer.Some of the game's modes and single-player options are more disappointing than others; the online mode is overall pretty satisfying so far, allowing players to either log on for a quick match with a random player or friend, or join a lobby of several players in a sort of informal tournament system. Players can `friend' opponents they'd like to play again and even speak to one another through console-compatible microphones. Lag is generally minimal or non-existent, and thankfully you'll be forewarned of the connection strength in the lobbies before joining. There are also of course leaderboards and rankings for the best of the best, but you can only gain ranks through random Quick Matches, and sadly there's no spectator option; this is particularly frustrating when you're waiting around for your next match in the lobbies.The single-player modes aren't quite as satisfying. MVC3 has a rather standard Arcade mode which features nothing but a series of random battles followed by a boss fight and usually anticlimactic ending sequence which differs by character but is merely a brief series of still pictures and text. The end-game credits are nice the first time you watch them, but they're the same regardless of which character you win with, and therefore aren't nearly as interesting the second, third or fourth time around. Super Smash Bros. Brawl's Subspace Emissary wasn't what a lot of people were hoping for, but it was more engaging than what's offered here. Although the Arcade mode serves its generic purpose, a few more cutscenes or character-specific individuality would've made it really worthwhile.MVC3's biggest asset is it succeeds in a few of the key areas where both TVC and MVC2 failed. TVC offered an overly simplified control option which occasionally allowed for disproportionate advantages, and yet was oftentimes preferable to the needlessly complex alternative. MVC3 manages to find a healthy balance between MVC2's ice-cold complexity and TVC's desperate attempt at accessibility; both regular and simple mode in MVC3 are useable without being cheaply advantageous or impossible to understand. Although deeply advanced tactics will be reserved for deeply skilled players, as they always have been, most players will gain a deeper understanding of the control schemes offered here more quickly than they would have in MVC2.Unfortunately, as expected, opportunities to be cheap present themselves in MVC3 just as they do in most fighting games. Thankfully only a small handful of the characters seem genuinely broken or overpowered, but the ones that are can be truly frustrating to go up against; both Sentinel and Iron Man can fill the screen with enormous and heavily damaging beams and projectiles, while Phoenix becomes virtually impossible to approach, let alone defeat, once she transforms into Dark Phoenix. Ryu spammers are also expectedly back in action, but thankfully so far it doesn't seem quite as common as it was in TVC.The game has a visual style that is distinctly American and heavily influenced by comic books; as where MVC2's artwork and aesthetics felt more authentically Japanese, this game comes off as though it belongs a little more to Marvel than it does to Capcom. This works both for and against it; most of the Marvel characters look amazing, and several of the Capcom ones do as well, although the heavy Americanization of the likes of Tron Bonne and Morrigan can come off as a bit wonky at first. Aside from that, however, the visuals are vivid and gorgeous; one thing you'll never be bored with is what goes on onscreen during matches.Although the complaints may have seemed heavy, MVC3 is in fact a very entertaining and visually appealing game; the online mode is extremely fun and engaging, and some of the downloadable content to come, namely the new characters and complete costume revamps, seem very promising. Tuning up the roster and 1-player mode-adding more modes in general, for that matter-would have really made it nothing short of excellent, but here's hoping they really take popular demand into consideration for DLC.

Has it really been a decade since Marvel VS Capcom 2? It seems like only yesterday I first discovered it in an arcade and eventually played it to death on the Dreamcast all those years ago, so saying that Marvel VS Capcom 3 has big shoes to fill is saying it lightly. Featuring graphics similar to Super Street Fighter IV and Tatsunoko VS Capcom; Marvel VS Capcom 3 takes all the insane combos and crazy character team-ups and gives them a serious upgrade. There is so much chaos going on on-screen that keeping up with it is difficult at first, but the game delivers everything that fans of the Marvel VS Capcom series have been yearning for. It looks and plays spectacularly, is easy to pick up and play, and it's final boss in Arcade Mode is Galactus (!), which makes the game worth checking out regardless. The only gripes I have with Marvel VS Capcom 3 is that the character roster isn't nearly as massive as it was the last time around, but that's understandable. However, while giving both Normal and Simple control schemes before you start playing gives button mashing gamers a whole new way to inflict damage. This choice between Normal and Simple comes off as being a bit cheap, especially considering how surprisingly deep the fighting engine was in Marvel VS Capcom 2. Still though, Marvel VS Capcom 3 is a spectacular achievement, and is more than worth picking up.

I feel like a bunch of haters dislike this one because it isn't Marvel vs. Capcom 2. I'm not going to be one of the hundreds of reviewers all saying the character roster was the problem, because it wasn't. I had no issues with the character choices what-so-ever. My gripe with the game is once you finish MvC3, there isn't much left to do.I remember playing MvC2 on my Dreamcast for months, unlocking colors, characters and stages in the game. It was a total time waster, but it was addicting trying to unlock and finish everything in the fighter. MvC3 needed this concept. I earned all the PS3 trophies in moderation and platinumed MvC3 in 10 days. When I was done, I looked at it wondering, "so....what do I do now?" The combo mode is wonderful and quite challenging. Other than that and arcade mode, you're done offline. Sure this is a step up from zero number of offline features in MvC2, but it's not saying much.Online mode is great, but it's pointless and not enough thought was put into it. One of my favorite features found in most current fighters is spectator mode. This allows you to observe other player matches as you wait your turn in line to battle the winner. It's fun and gives the players something to do as they wait for their upcoming matches. This feature is in Blazblue of all games. Even in Capcom's very own Super Street Fighter IV has this, but it's missing in MvC3. So when I'm playing with friends, I have to sit in boredom in a standardized player room waiting for matches to end. What's the point of having online if you're not going to do something unique and fun with it? To collect icons and titles? I don't see the point in that either.I believe this is an unfinished product. With Shadow Mode being added every week for $0.99 cents, special costumes to be added (for cash), and the possibility of future DLC characters (more moolah)....I just feel either Capcom is getting super greedy or the game is unfinished. The gameplay is fantastic and I will not knock it, but the features are presented as an after-thought. Honestly, if I see a Super Marvel vs. Capcom 3 down the road, I'm done with Capcom. Traded this in for a better game, a.k.a. Mortal Kombat, and I suggest you do the same.
summary: Greed or Unfinished Product: Take Your Pick

Alright, I'm going to start right off by explaining how come I give this game 4 out of 5 stars. The reason is simple: character choices. It's not that there aren't enough characters to choose from, cause there are (however Capcom has had years to develop this game and easily could have included more), however its the fact that some of the characters that "made the cut" are just plain...weird. M.O.D.O.K? Seriously? Was there really a NEED to put him into the game? Taskmaster? I don't recall people lining up begging to have him as an addition to this widely anticipated release. However, despite some of the character selections currently available (omitting current and upcoming DLC characters of course), that's not what this game is all about, is it? No, it's about having FUN, and when it comes to having FUN, this game definitely delivers! The graphics are absolutely top-notch and the colors displayed on-screen are simply breath-taking. The online mode is pretty good as well, however I do have one minor complaint in that when you join a lobby (a type of mode that allows you to join with up to seven other players to fight against), you aren't allowed to watch the match that is taking place between two of the players within your lobby (if that makes sense). This is one of those cases where it would be much easier to see it than to explain it through text. However the bottom line with that is, you end up (sometimes) with a lot of idle time while waiting for a match to start (unless you enjoy staring at a dull screen until your time to fight commences). Each of the characters bring to the table their own unique fighting styles, some are more powerful, some are quicker, and some are ridiculously slow (a-hem...Arthur), however the developers at Capcom did a great job in balancing this all out (in my opinion).Having said all that, I definitely am impressed by what this game has offered so far, and I look forward to what lies ahead as far as future DLC is concerned. So if you're "on the fence" about picking this one up, I'd say at the very least, at least rent it, and if it turns out to be something you'd enjoy, buy it! I'm sure glad I did! :)

So it is really frustrating. So, so much for combos. Second the last big battle for arcade is a big let down, I don't even know who the big boss is. I really enjoyed the Konquest in Mortal Kombat- I haven't seen the story mode on this game. So I don't even know how the suppose two worlds came together and what the whole point of the game is, story wise. On the other hand Mortal kombat Deception had an incredible story mode as did MK Armaggedon their story modes were lengthy and action packed. So this game strikes me as just a bunch of Arcade mode fights, and practice/achievement modes. There are no mini games. Again the MK series Deception had Chess and"Tetris" like mini games which made the game not only great but spectacular.Overall this is a nice game with great colors, graphics and play quality. reviewText: I have been a 2k player for many years, I first started playing since 2K5 which was a great game as well. The last two years of NBA 2K have not been anything special, 2K10 felt like a minor leap over 2K9. However that is not the case this year, this game feels like a MAJOR leap over the previous games in the series, which I think most people didn't even think was possible.Graphics: Awesome, don't look at the gameplay videos, that tells a completely different story. When you actually play this game and look at it, the motions are amazing, particularly how the great the equipment on the players move when the characters run down the court. The facial expressions are also amazing, and give you an amazing feeling during highlights. Also the skin tones and the Tattoos all look good, and are placed in the right spot.The only knock on the graphics that I can say is how some of the characters have an unnatural look to them (Jermaine Oneal, Larry Bird, and even Kobe to some extents look weird). The UI and the menu system is very nice though, something 2K games have always been good at. The courts are also done in amazing detail and look good down to the last piece of hardwood floor. There is so much more to be said about the graphics, but its hard to sum it all up, the graphics all around are good I would rate them an 8 out of 10 definitely the best looking in the series.Sound: The sound is solid, the court sounds sound legit, the way the shoes sound during a quick stop and the way the ball sounds as your are dribbling and how it sounds when it goes in the net is perfect. The soundtrack for this game is very good, its definitely improving over the previous years versions and the best so far. You got Snoop, Drake, Big Boi, Cassidy, Kid Cudi, and even Ron Artest (lol). The sound is great, and the play by play is truly amazing. You really think you are watching the game, 2K has always been strong here after playing a couple of matches, I rarely heard the same things said in different games during pick up games, which is amazing. The announcers always have an amazing way in season mode/My Player mode of talking about when the season is coming to an end, and what place your current team is at in their conference which is amazing.  They certainly put a lot of time and effort in the play by play which makes the ambience much better.Controls: Not a lot to say here, in one word it's great. If you have used the 2K controls before it will be like second nature here, its very easy for even beginners to pick up and play. After one full match from the beginning to end, you will already have a strong grasp on the controllers. So just solid here, and still one of the best things about 2K basketball games.Gameplay: A game changer, everything feels like its been improved from before. They still have all the legitimate traits of older games before this one. Lebron shoots like lebron, he has his signature shot, and his signature blocks, its scarily realistic with how they made so many players play like themselves. Tons of research had to go in for it to be this accurate. The new thing for this year is the jordan challenges. Believe it or not, this pays homage to the older 2K games. If you play NFL 2K5 (Rip) they had a mode where you can go back and play legendary games and win these game and do what those teams have done. Well, its back now, and you get to use all the amazing Bulls teams from 90's with Jordan. they also recreated all the rosters so that it is the same roster as jordan was with and the teams that he played against. So the challenges are like score 63+, plays his flu game, etc. Its really an amazing thing that they created here for the greatest basketball player of all time. The My Player mode is truly amazing, you start as basically a nobody, you create your character and when you are all finished you choose what kind of player you would like to be (scoring, passing, defensive, etc.) once you do that it assigns point to your player that can be used to build different stats. You start out in the draft combine, be impressive and you get drafted once you do, you start competing in the summer league. From there, now you are fighting for a roster spot, its really amazing and actually shows you the process of what these players have to do when they are coming to the NBA, amazing. Online, I have played about 5 games, and I have to say that its been great! No lag, and there has been no server problems which have been a huge knock on 2K basketball games online, it's looking good so far however.EDIT 11/26/2010: Yep decided to edit this one, bought it since launch and I am still playing it even now, on black friday and also a month and a half after its release. The rating would not change at all this truly is an amazing game, you must try it for yourself!Overall: IGN called this game one of the greatest sports games of our generation, and they are right. Nothing really quite matches everything it offers. If you play this game online and offline, you can easily surpass over 100 hours of gameplay before you know it. Throw in Jordan challenges, My player mode, and online in general, and you have a deep game with more to come back to each time you turn it on, THIS is what 2K basketball is all about.
summary: An Evolution of something that was already great

Let's get one thing clear, the only reason people praise this game so much is because it's the first game to actually feature Jordan as a playable character. Even when he was still playing ball he never got included in the games, which is kind of weird. To be quite honest with you, his inclusion is the only really great thing about this game. The game itself is all kinds of broken, which only leaves you feeling frustrated.I don't want to see any comments on here saying "looks like someone is bitter because he lost" or "you just need to practice" because both of those are wrong. I don't mind losing in sports games, it isn't that big of a deal to me. In regards to the second point, I've had this game for a year and a half so I've practiced plenty. I keep reading reviews that say this is the most realistic basketball game ever. How? It's not realistic visually or gameplay wise. All the players look like distorted versions of themselves and the jerseys are all stiff like cardboard. Then you have the abomination that is the gameplay.There's times when an opponent will shoot a jumper from inside the perimeter, he scores, and it counts as a three. I can't even say "sometimes" because it happens a lot. There's times when you pass it to someone on the post and the opponent shoves him out of bounds as soon as he catches the ball. Then there's the god awful shooting mechanics. I mean seriously, there's no real formula as to how the mechanics work. It all comes down to luck. You can go on for days about how "there's a steep learning curve" but we all know that's bs for "it's broken." Demon's Souls has a steep learning curve, this is insanity.I can't tell you how many times I've had a wide open shot or lay-up and my player misses completely. Which brings me to the next two points: 1) You never get the luck of the roll on the rim 2) Your player becomes useless once the ball leaves your hands. The opponent? 99% he will get the luck of the roll. You? No. What I mean by useless is exactly what the Websters dictionary defines it as: not able to give service or aid. He basically becomes a statue for a full second so even if you miss the lay-up you have no real shot at getting the rebound.Finally, trying to run a play is a nightmare. First off they're all extremely long so unless you have the positions memorized there's no point in trying. Secondly, it feels like there's some sort of invisible barrier stopping you from even getting to your destination. Running plays is supposed to make it easier to get an open look, it's not suppose to make you want to throw your controller at the TV.I didn't even get into the other things like the terrible menu or the awful My Player mode, but all this negativity is bringing me down. Bottom line is this: don't get this game. Especially if you're looking for a basketball game you can just pick up and play every now and then. This isn't the game for that kind of player.

NBA 2K, from day one, has been the video game world's best representation of basketball. Amazingly, the team outdid itself this year.The inclusion of Jordan and his playable retrospective smartly opens up the game to anyone with a passing interest in basketball. It also breaks the stigma that each year's game is just a roster update. While it seems Pippen plays like crap, it's a wonderful mode that will give you several hours of play. You'll be amazed how many hoop heroes make appearances, and are thus playable.The rest of the game is as rock-solid as ever. I can play a season for simply taking a team to the championships, or use The Association to be more GM-centric. Minigames like the dunk contest and 3-point shootout provide nice diversions. My Player is still here, though I haven't played it much after not really liking it in 2K10. But basically, there is a TON of game here that will keep you occupied throughout the season.This game demands a high basketball IQ -- even on lower difficulty levels. You really have to use your head to outsmart the AI. Otherwise, it will pick off your passes and posterize you early and often. That's actually a positive, since it teaches you to be a better player.Some old issues still exist that I really wish would get cleaned up. The trade screen only displays 4 slots per team, but at times the computer will hide a fifth item off-screen. Passes are extremely imprecise unless you use Icon Passing. And I hate that there's no way to alter the speed of your pass (my friend is great at intercepting -- even inbounds passes).I've definitely gotten my money's worth out of NBA 2K11. The season may be nearing its end, but the price has gotten lower. If you've waited, now's the perfect time to snatch it up.

I've never been a huge fan of the 2K series until this one. Let me tell you why.I think 2K11 is when the game finally crossed over from "flat-out unrealistic" to "semi-realistic". Granted, a basketball video game will probably never get close to being realistic, but that's what makes them fun.Anyway, what I'm trying to say is that 2K11 got more realistic in ways that don't detract from the fun of the game.For example, passing is now much more difficult. Gone are the days of just lasering the ball to any player on the court regardless of defenders or positioning. In 2K11, if there's a defender between you and the man you're trying to pass to, the ball WILL get stolen. Sounds like a simple concept, but nobody seemed to be able to get that right until now. Speaking of passing, alley-oops are also much harder to do than in 2K10. Nowadays the dunker better have a clear lane to the hoop; he won't magically jump through a defender and hammer it home. Also, if you're trying to throw the alley-oop pass, your defender will deflect it if he's guarding you closely.All these factors force the player to make more careful decisions instead of playing a sloppy run and gun game filled with unrealistic passes and dunks.Aside from the passing, the difficulty when dribbling has also increased. If you try to bring the ball up court with one of your big men, prepare to have it picked pretty quickly. One of the things that used to bother me about the older 2K games is that when you dribbled and collided with another defender, your player would just keep running in place like there was no real contact between the two players. Now in 2K11, if you run into a defender, an actual collision will take place. Your player will recoil from the impact and it will take some time to recover before you can drive or shoot again. Either that or you will just lose control of the ball altogether.So basically, 2K11 went for a slower paced, more realistic, and more `tactical' approach this time around. But don't worry. You're still going to see plenty of high flying dunks and oops, and plenty of sweet dimes too. You're just going to have to be smarter and more careful with the way you go about things.Overall, the game plays great and there's only one thing I can complain about. Sometimes on an open dunk, your player will perform an extra and unnecessary move. I was on a breakaway with J.R. Smith the other day and I was hoping to see a crazy two-handed windmill from the free throw line. Instead, he does a spin move under the basket and goes up for a regular dunk. This has happened multiple times with other players as well. I'm not sure if it's a glitch or if I just haven't learned to play correctly yet.OK, enough with the gameplay, now onto the visuals. The graphics and interface are the best yet in the series, but they're not amazing. The animations on the other hand, are awesome. I don't want to say too much, but me and my buddy went crazy when MJ went for a baseline rock the cradle dunk in the middle of a pickup game!Well, that's all I can say for now since I've only put a couple hours into this game, playing head-to-head with my buddies. I have yet to try the single player and online modes, but for a casual player like myself, this is about all I could ask for in a bball game.

reviewText: I'm not the best console sports game player.  I can barely remember all the button combos and needing to know the X's and O's of football and basketball eventually get the best of me.  Hence my last Madden game had me googling nickel and dime and 3-3-4 defenses vs blitzes etc just to win a few games.Three things pulled me into this game:1.  No More College Basketball Games.  Wasn't overly impressed with the last EA NCAA Basketball 2010 game, and unfortunately a new version didn't come out this year (and may never again).2.  Tired of Madden.3.  Michael Jordan.  Yes, he's the best ever.  Statistically, he far surpasses Kobe and any other current player.  I actually stopped watching NBA shortly after Jordan retired (for the 2nd time) and hence haven't been all the excited to play an NBA game.Wow, I don't know if 2k Sports has always been this much better than EA Sports' basketball games, but this game will WOW you.  I've never seen anything like it.  Call of Duty will wow you with atmosphere and details.  NBA 2k11 will wow you with amazing likeness of the real NBA.  And to top it off, it actually makes me want to start watching the NBA again!Playing as Michael Jordan is priceless.  The $59.00 for that feature alone was worth it.  His dunks, fist pumps, shrugs, all make me reminisce of those glory days.  Don't know how they did it, but they sure got his likeness down.  It doesn't just look like a computer animated basketball player - it actually looks like Jordan when he dunked.Then I played some of the other classic teams.  The Sonics.  Watching Kemp dunk sure looked like I remember him.Some of the players don't look as real as Jordan, but hey, this game is all about him.  Kobe looks odd, Larry Bird just looks bad.  But I having watched a few highlight reels of Wade and LeBron, I can say that they sure nailed those two as well.If I could ask for 1 thing, it'd be to be able to get the Phoenix Suns and Charles Barkley - My other favorite team for that era.  Maybe they'll have it for DLC.Honestly, I don't know how they can top this game next year.  It's that good.  You've probably heard the drama about EA Sports NBA Live getting bad reviews from their demo, and after NBA2k11 came out, they decided to not release NBA Live this year, and focus on next year instead.  I don't want to read too much into it, you can see from the other reviews as well: NBA 2k11 is the best basketball game ever.My favorite part though, is the montage they put at the end of each game.  It shows highlight reels for your Player of the Game, with awesome music.  But it's they way they do it.  They'll change the colors, freeze players on a break-away or dunk, or make it black and white except your player (or maybe the basketball).  It looks awesome, and when playing with friends, it's one of the funnest parts of the game.  After the game ends, we'll all be:  "quiet quiet, it's time for the Player of the Game!".One final note:  The commentaries.  Fantastic.  I can't tell you how frustrating it was to play Madden and hear them tell me nonsense that either didn't make sense for the play that just happened, or was just gibberish.  The commentaries here are fantastic.  Sure, there's some repeats, but it's still fun to listen to.  We played on Thanksgiving Day, and sure enough, the commentary said, "Thanks for joining us on Thanksgiving, have we got a treat for you..."  Nice.A+++++

The AI team you play against is all NBA Defense, even if you are playing a crappy defensive team like the Phoenix Suns or the New York Knicks. Whats worse is that your AI controlled defenders on the other end suck! They often play way off of players. Basically their team is on you like white on rice. I might have had 2 or 3 fast breaks that were succesfull in the 3 weeks I've played this game(I only play on weekends). However I've seen the AI have open shots and uncontested dunks a 4-6 times a game. Their passes don't get stolen at the same frequency as your will. This game was a huge let down. I would not recommend it to anyone. I might give it another chance when summer comes.

However, the game is just not realistic for several reasons- #1- there is no way a player can be a 90% three point shooter and not make one three-pointer. #2-there is no way a guy can be drafted to the NBA as a top ten pick in the first round, and also a starter, and not make a single lay-up or a shot directly in front of the basket. #3- the directional buttons are a failure, because you can select the triangle or the circle to throw a direct pass and the computer will make you do otherwise. #4-every time you go for a fast-break or on a run, the Heat button comes up on the screen or what's happening around the league screen comes up in the middle of an awesome play or in the middle of passing the ball #5- the game is supposed to be realistic to the current teams line-ups, why did they have Steve Nash playing for the Mavericks? And Kirk Thomas playing for the Knicks? ((HELLO)) they haven't played for those teams since they first came into the league. #6-the online game playing is fun, but freezes up each time a player leaves the game. #7- it is hard for you and another person to play each other without the controllers getting mixed up- example- I end up being the Laker when I selected the Celtics and my opponent ends up being the Celtics when they selected the Lakers.  Now- the My Player- the one who gets drafted- OH MY!  First of all, you can play your heart out and the game will give you a "C". It's like they expect you to play ALL positions. If a Center is passed the ball and your Center does not block him, then it's your fault- the game will tell you that you allowed the shot. Really? I am the point guard. One game, I met all the requests it said to do during the game- make at least 3 jumpshots, limit your man to less than 40 percent shooting. I did all of that and then some and the game said "Fair". Even when I was the only player playing defense and offense. Who judges the game, hockey players?  The only reason I keep playing the game is because there are no other b-ball games out right now. I heard some company in Canada took over. Well, all I can say is that, they need to be schooled in B-ball whoever they are. I hope to see more improvements. Like, "it shouldn't be this hard." No wonder NBA Elite was pushed back (or canceled whoever you want to believe). NBA2K11 has set a standard that the EA Sports division as a whole needs to take note of. But then the 2K sports series always seems to have been doing this for awhile now and the only thing that is saving EA Sports right now is its lock on the NCAA and NFL licenses.From the moment the game starts, you know you are in for a treat as the `new gimmick' of Jordan's addition is clearly apparent. But for those of us that have been gaming for awhile aren't looking at this as a gimmick. I know for myself, the opening game from the 1991 Finals brought back memories of the first of the EA Sports games for the Genesis Bulls vs Lakers but now it's come back full circle. High res graphics, player models and and great commentary (even a YOUNG Phil Jackson!) makes me almost cry! Remembering that all those years ago, the closest we got to playing this game were sprites and numbers makes this game a dream come true!So, let me stop waxing nostalgic and talk about everything else. While the opening game is great, for those that could care less about this are going to be frustrated that they can't immediately go through to the menu. To me, that is one minor negative but once you do get through that one thing that I did like was that 2K cleaned up the mess of an interface from last year and made the menus this year a lot easier to navigate through. As always, customize as you see fit.Some may complain that this game is another roster update but I know for myself, I played 2K6 and 2K7, skipped 8 and 9 but I got last year's game and was amazed with the Living NBA feature which has made it back and the NBA Today feature.  One thing that I have always loved about this series that EA Sports needs to take notes on, is that the 2K Sports series doesn't always try to throw a gimmick every year with a `new controller feature' or something so totally lame that it breaks the game instead of enhancing it (YES EA GAMEFLOW IS BULLHOEY!!). To its core, NBA2K11 is essentially the same game that you have played for years following the philosophy of `if it ain't broke don't fix it" but the beauty of this is 2K spent more time tinkering with improving the AI and player animations and it shows. The control scheme is essentially the same but the ball animations and player reactions to the controls have improved much since last year. Playing around with NBA 2K11 shows that given time, it almost becomes a living breathing thing that, if you didn't know any better, you were watching an actual game rather than a video game.Now as much as I like Jordan, one small distraction is that the game is littered with almost any and everything Jordan throughout the game but considering what it takes to get him to endorse anything and because of those endorsements, products will sell, I can let it slide.One thing that is fun however are the Jordan challenges and if that is this year's `gimmick' which  came along with getting Jordan to endorse this game, it's a great one and I spent a lot of time trying to play through these challenges so I can unlock Jordan. I haven't done it yet but I have unlocked a few of the sneakers!I won't repeat too much of what the previous reviewers have said but getting back to the presentation as always it's slick even in between quarters, watching a pseudo commercial about upcoming matches tends to be fun, the  time show is a bit more improved this time around as I liked how the commentating crew talks about other games being played in the league now I am wondering if I started playing the Association, if there will also be game highlights. The commentary and crowd reaction is as kinetic as ever and people always tend to get on the commentators repeating things but I mean come on, we know it's going to happen, but the commentating on here is better than what you get in some EA games. It's still cool to hear them talk about your player's performance from a few nights ago and instead of making up some imaginary number, that stat was indeed true.As far as other extras, I tinkered around with the black court games and with that came some of the usual suspects of 21, 3pt Shootout and more.  Definitely always worth looking at when you aren't in the mood for a full out 5 on 5 confrontation.But there is one negative and that is the Move controller. I think any game that gets Move support needs to have a calibration/tutorial session built in before they just toss you to the wolves. It took me about 15 minutes to properly set my Move stick and I wasn't all that crazy about trying to play this with my dualshock. I also have the new Nav stick and could not figure out how to get it to work with the Move controller so if anyone has pointers on getting it to work, please let me know but the Move right now as it is, feels more like an afterthought than well thought out.Otherwise, if you are a basketball fan or sat out of the 2K phase, then this is the time to get it. As I said, EA needs to take notes and it's no surprise that their franchise has been put on hold. 2K takes your expectations and surpasses them by making a sports game that easy to get into and hard to put down once you start to play. If you are a Jordan fan and want to relive some of his past glory, then this is as close as you are going to get short of a holodeck and once you unlock him you get to use him against today's youth so forget trying to recreate him in Create a Player, YOU HAVE HIM.
