COD Black Ops Review:After witnessing some major hype for Call of Duty (COD) Black Ops (BO), I felt like the game couldn't possibly deliver on what it was built up to be.  I played and enjoyed COD Modern Warfare 2 (MW2) for months.  Not simply just multiplayer (MP) like what seems to be the focus for these games, but also for the Spec Ops and yes, the single player (SP) campaign.  I consider myself a gamer somewhere between the realm of casual, and hardcore (casu-core?).  To me, this means I like to enjoy games for their SP campaigns first before I go online to play with others.  Even though my main interest in gaming lies in being told a great story, COD Black Ops did not disappoint in this and most other areas.Gameplay: 9 / 10The gameplay in Black Ops is simply a revision of what's been tried and true from other versions of COD.  COD has become an obvious annual release date, for which some find to be a bad thing.  However, the gameplay doesn't falter.  The controls feel very tight and responsive, you're given a whole slew of options in terms of button configurations and difficulty levels.  I find that the gunplay, the firefights, and the assistance from bot team members all help me to feel immersed in the games.  As for the SP campaign, I always play through the first time on the default difficulty setting, but then go back and crank it up to super hard (Veteran for COD).  I found that the Black Ops' difficulty ramps up rather nicely.  The Normal SP campaign is very approachable even if you've been away from first person shooters (FPS) for a while, while the Veteran campaign is noticeably more difficult.  On Veteran, be expecting some excellent tactics for the most part on behalf of your enemies.  They flank, they flush you out with grenades, they corner you, they'll take side passage ways (when they exist) and if they get a bead on you, you're a 1-2 shot kill for the most part.  They don't miss much...which sometimes can feel a bit cheap and lead to a set of "die-restarts-die-restart" moments.My gripes about COD Black Ops are probably shared by many: there obvious points where the action stopped because I hadn't passed an invisible line.  I can see needing a break on Casual or Normal difficulty, but it seems that on the harder difficulties it would be in order for your team to eventually press forward even when you're not ready.  This would make it harder, but more realistic.  The enemies in this don't follow you very far, so if you're not ready to approach you can just back up into the empty wasteland of dead bodies you've left behind.  The enemies still waiting will...wait.  Additionally previous games by Treyarch (COD World at War specifically) had the issue of infinite spawning enemies until you crossed a line.  Black Ops deals with this for most levels but there are some where I can swear it still exists... In a nutshell the enemy spawning is a bit rocky.  The SP campaign is for the most part 99% linear, with minor variations of hallways that lead to the same place.  It would be nice to have a bit of exploring to do, though I have to say the cut scenes between playable sections are top notch action and have many "oh snap!" moments.  Lastly, the lack of a online and/or split screen co-op campaign mode is a bummer, though I can't really see how it would work well given the storyline.As for the MP side of things, the customization is a huge improvement.  You are no longer (compared to MW2) required to unlock perks, weapons etc. in order, instead you're allowed to pick the one you like and buy it with earned COD points.  You earn more points with kills, and also level up your profile.  There are still unlockables which really turned out to be a nice variety of game mechanics.  The perks are for the most part the same (with the exception of 1 or 2) which was rather disappointing.  In reality I anticipated there to be some noticeable differences in the MP options.  The guns, the attachments and perks were for the most part the same.  I really felt like had this been a MP-only game it would have been an extension of MW2 with a 1960's twist.The differences I can think of off the top of my head was a reflex sighting (my personal favorite), the under-barrel flamethrower, the nova gas grenade, one that emulates someone firing on your opponents' map.  On the other hand, the killstreak rewards were about half different.  I like the addition of napalm and the fact that since a 5 killstreak is about my normal max it's a nice one at an achievable level.  The tactical nuke (from MW2) is gone, which never seemed very tactical in the first place, and I being a "casu-core" gamer never had a chance at the 20+ killstreak to get it, so no loss to me.The MP is still filled with young teens with racist and/or dirty vocabulary, but that's sort of the norm on the internet it seems.  I would love for COD Black Ops to have included some method of an age check or filter that would allow those of us who wish to play competitively with people who are actually respectful to have a venue to do so.  But such is life.  Additionally, the player level matching seems to be non-existent where I'll be on a team of 3 or 4 newbies up against a team of 5-6 generals.  A graduated level system would have been a great inclusion, one that would let those who are level 10 and under play against others in their same range, and on to level 11-20 etc..  to give those getting started a chance instead of being fragged 47 times before getting to move around.  Just a thought.I actually greatly missed the inclusion of Spec Ops missions from this game.  However, my wife and I both enjoyed the Zombies mode for a short while.  The difficulty on it makes it unapproachable for us as a team beyond the 5th or 6th round.  I enjoyed playing with random folks online and the action is quite intense.  To me, however, the lasting appeal isn't there.  I can only play through the same 4-5 rounds with access to the same 4 guns so many times before it's onto something else.  Perhaps a gun randomizer (not the mystery box) for which guns are the starter weapons, or even a difficulty setting adjustment would have been nice.  Still, Zombies mode was fun for a short while, but I found Spec Ops to hold my attention better.Finally, there are a few minigames hidden as Easter eggs, one of which is very well executed "Smash TV"-style game with a top down view in the essence of Black Ops and Zombies mode called "Dead Ops Arcade.  It's a welcome yet totally unexpected addition; and worth having a go for sure.Graphics: 10 / 10I have heard people continuously gripe about how bad the graphics are; I on the other hand believe these complaints are completely unfounded.  The graphics have a grit to them, but look extremely good.  The gun models (and animations) are fantastic, the character models and facial expressions are also very realistic.  The lip-syncing is also excellent...which means it was never noticeably off.  I found the environments that you walk through in both SP and MP to be highly detailed with great high-res textures and models.  In fact I found myself thinking had I designed it I probably wouldn't have thought to put "X" there, but it looks realistic, lived-in and used.  All of this adds to the immersion which is the main goal of gaming in my books.  As previously mentioned, the cut scenes between playable sections are very high action and quite entertaining.  But fitting to this section, their graphics are crystal clear and highly detailed.Sound: 10 / 10While I'm not a huge Stones fan, I did think it fit the SP campaign well and was used sparingly enough to make it feel fresh to the game.  The little heavy metal sections were welcome and indicated "this is going to be intense"...which never seemed to fail to deliver.  The weapon sounds make the weapons feel incredibly real and certainly powerful.  The sounds for each weapon are noticeably different and gave me the impression that the sound designers had their work cut out for them.  The SP's voice acting is delivered very well by the recognizable voices of Ed Harris (Hudson) and Sam Worthington (Mason), and Ice Cube (Bowman), Gary Oldman (Reznov).  I found the cast fit very well and gave this game a very high-production value feel to it.  The writers developed a dialog that never felt clunky or out of place as well.  Finally the sound effects of the vehicles, explosions, ricochets, and even voices being muffled through water sounded dead on.  Overall the sound is incredible and really deserves to be played where the surround sound is able to work its magic.Presentation: 7 / 10Black Ops packs some major presentation value as is the norm with COD games.  The action is like being in an over the top 1980's movie, where you're somehow able to single-handedly clean out entire squads of highly trained soldiers.  But the way it's presented lets the realistic part of me agree to just enjoy.  There has to be at least 20 explosions in nearly every chapter and yet it still gains intensity up to the end.  The graphics and sound work come together to assist the story into believable that has been crafted to be woven into the history during the cold war.  While intentionally confusing at times, I found the story to be quite entertaining and well structured.Black Ops takes place in a number of vastly different and unique locales.  I particularly enjoyed the snowy levels in MW2 and was not disappointed in the similar levels in Black Ops.  The voice acting of even the unnamed soldiers is excellent to the point of making you believe the team is highly trained and legit.While the presentation for the most part was phenomenal, I couldn't help but notice some really bad errors, bugs or just sloppy work in some of the closing moments of various chapters in Black Ops.  Unfortunately, these sort of trumped the rest for me, as I couldn't believe how unfinished or rushed some parts felt.  During both of my play-throughs of the SP campaign, I felt that the concluding moments of the entire game, along with those of a few other chapters were all too abrupt.  While trying not to spoil anything, I remember noticing that after having endured some of the most incredibly hectic and intense firefighting during S.O.G (chapter 4), the end of the chapter is just "BAM!" Good guys land, bad guys are nowhere to be found and everything's alright.  It went so far as to go from a treacherous battlefield full of enemies to a deserted wasteland in a matter of seconds.  While it feels small in writing, what it takes from the experience is not to be understated.  For all the work that goes into making a gamer feel immersed in the action and letting it all of sudden wrap up in 5 seconds is just absurd and dumb.  In my opinion, all the rest of the game's polish was cheapened due to these inconsistent parts.Another gripe was when Hudson or one of the other NPCs would get stuck in a corner continuously running.  After trying to wedge myself between them and the corner to no avail, it had to kill myself to restart at the last check point.  Lame.While not exactly a presentation issue, in MP the servers were less than cooperative.  I got booted from nearly as many games as I actually got to finish.  My connection was not the issue and I believe it may have been patched within the past few days.  But still, for a game that is 5% SP and 95% MP, the MP should be absolutely shining flawless.Final Thoughts: 9 / 10Black Ops delivers in many ways.  The changes to MP were either no change to something good, or more customization and options to make it better.  I think there's still room for improvement in the area of match making, but I'm only one.  As far as the SP campaign, the story was very interesting and had some overall very high-production-value and memorable moments.  While the feeling of immersion is greedily snatched away during certain low points may have ruined some moments for me, overall the game is a good value if you enjoy MP, SP and find Zombies mode entertaining.  If you're ONLY in for SP, you may be disappointed with the length, but the replay value is there if you enjoy a challenge.
summary: Despite being broken in some areas, Black Ops still delivers plenty of bang for the buck.

Overall, I was disappointed with Modern Warfare 2 in both single player and multiplayer modes. Single player campaign was nothing more than a your typical Hollywood action flick with all action all the time. Needless to say, it got old very quick and the story was impossible to follow with your typical unbelievable ending. Multiplayer while better than single player suffered from lame perks that people abused and required no skill to use. Commando/lightweight (i.e. teleport) was possibly the cheapest perk combo in that game. The game also suffered from bullets curving around the corner a horrible spawn system that just turned this game into a camp fest. I really didn't mind the camping because I understood why people did it. I mean who wants to have someone spawn right behind and shoot them in the back every 3 seconds?Enter Call of Duty Black Ops, a game that looked good on TV but based on my previous experience, I was not sure about the game and after having this game for about a week, I can honestly say my apprehensions about this game were valid but not in the areas I expected.The goodCampaign mode is much improved this time around. While it seemed like it would end up just being a non-stop action fest during the first few missions, things really started getting good after getting to the Vietnam missions. The story is written better and is easier to follow for the most part, but the flashbacks can be a little distracting. But I can say for a fact that I really got addicted to the single player mode.Online play has many improvements; first of all many of the lame and cheap perks from MW2 are GONE! This means no more commando/lightweight users, no excessive noob tube damage, and no impossible kills from all the way across the screen. In addition there is no more stacking of kill streaks, meaning any kills you get from your kill streak rewards will NOT count towards your kill streak. Because of this you can no longer sit back and let your kill streaks do all the work if you want to get your higher rewards. I was guilty of this in MW2 but I welcome this change in BO and should help to cut down on camping. This also ensures that the more powerful kill streaks rewards (11 is the highest you can get now) will be a rare occurrence which makes for good balance. The spawning system has little improvement but still people will spawn right behind you, but from what I experienced this game is not as bad as MW2. (ummm, scratch this, see my update at the end of this review)New system for weapon upgrades. Instead of having to get 6 million headshots to get a new camo for your gun or attachment, you now have to buy your upgrades with money you earn during your matches. I love this change as in MW2 I became too caught up on completing challenges to get weapon upgrades which in turn forced me to use a particular weapon for all of my matches and it became more of a chore than anything. There are many ways to earn money, but I won't go into them here.Combat training mode is an excellent way for you to practice multiplayer with computer controlled opponents and teammates with customizable game options like time limit and score. You can select the difficulty level and compete in either TDM or FFA on all online maps. In addition you earn upgrades, ranking promotions just like you would online except they don't carry over to online play. I didn't think this mode would be much fun, but it is and is also a good way to try out and practice all the kill streak rewards (if you stay alive long enough) without the pressure or frustration online.The badWith all the improvements in both single player and multiplayer mode the negatives greatly hurt the overall quality of this game.The graphics and sound are a noticeable huge step back from MW2 and even COD4. This does not look like a current gen game, and people who both like and dislike this game all agree the graphics are not up to par with what is currently out on the next gen systems. Many times I have found myself comparing this game's visuals to the graphics of my XBOX (the first one) wondering which one was better. Sound also takes a step back from the previous COD titles, as I have said in many of my comments, all explosive devices sound exactly the same, and the guns themselves just sound a little bit underpowered. While the graphics and sound issues didn't bother me too much on single player they did distract me on online play when it was coupled with the number 1 problem with this game.....ONLINE LAG.While MW2 had MANY problems with online play, LAG was rarely an issue I encountered, this is no longer the cause with BO. Out of all the time I had this game, I only had two or three matches that lag was minimal and this was at 2 in the morning. The rest of my many matches suffered debilitating lag so much that many times I would just quit the game in frustration because it's impossible to kill someone when they are teleporting all over the screen. Even the menu to get to online play is quirky; many times I had to press the "Playstation Network" option on the multiplayer screen multiple times JUST to get into the lobby. Then when I get there the only thing that is guaranteed is a laggy online experience. After the second day of putting up with this, I gave up online play altogether and played Combat training, because I just found online play well....unplayable. All of the great improvements to multiplayer are completely ruined by the lag which is a shame.Single player is much improved but multi-player overall is a huge step back even with the improvements that were implemented. I am glad I rented this game, because multiplayer is what makes games like these worth the cost. But when I can't even play multi-player why would I pay full price for it? I may end up getting this game eventually, but not until the price comes down considerably because unless they find a fix for their online mode, there is no way I'm playing this game online.My suggestion RENT before you buy.

To start off having played through every Call of Duty and watching the franchise grow ill only briefly compare this title to Modern Warfare 2 developed by Infinity Ward and World at War by Treyarch who also made this title, Black Ops. Ill also be writing this from opinion so if you want to details go ahead and read I wont do much to spoil the story except for the beginning sequence but I also have pros and cons at the top for a quick read.UPDATE: Lately 2 days after release the game seems to be getting pretty sensitive to lag. Its not just a personal problem as Ive talked to other players and friends and they've noticed a down hill drop in connection as well. This is coming from Wyoming so it might just be a region issuePros:1.Story has much more depth/longer play time2.No blaring plot holes like MW23.More character involvement4.Like MW2 past characters return from previous Treyarch games5.Personal opinion-Multiplayer is also better than MW2 and WAW6.Much deeper customization than previous titles7.Large amount of in game options and easter eggsCons:1.Noob tubers still present2.Having to unlock gametypes for online play3.Trial and error moments aplenty4.The brick work in laid for it to go down the same route MW2 fell down5.Update: Camping is picking up6.Random placement of claymores is also getting commonSingle Player: I was relatively pleased with Black Ops single player and found the plot more interesting than Modern Warfare 2 or World at War and while there are some who do not agree with that statement its hard to deny the fact that getting a face and voice to the protagonist helps draw players in. You play the majority of the game as Alex Mason who is voiced by none other than Sam Worthington the leading star in James Cameron's Avatar and the revived Clash of the Titans. The story/game starts off with Alex who is strapped to a chair surrounded by TVs and cables. The only other person nearby is a shadowy figure on the other side of a window overlooking the interrogation chamber speaking over an intercom system with his/her voiced masked. Alex is being questioned about past missions and through this you'll play through a series of flashbacks and occasionally taking control of a few other characters. The plot might get confusing (as it was designed to be) to some but in a personal way I was drawn in faster than any other previous Call of Duty game. The squad you work with and get to know over the course of the game are just as easy to get attached to just like Ghost from MW2. A returning character from World at War was welcomed greatly by me and possibly many others if you are familiar with him or that game. On a very positive note the length this game will take can range from 6 to 10 hrs depending on difficulty making this longer than MW2 and WAW. If you are familiar with the occurrences of the Cold War era this game will be greatly welcomed. The one thing I can be disappointed about would be a sense of deja vu experienced through the game as it draws from the two previous entries in the series. Only a minor complaint but this title has much more depth than previous titles story wise so in the end I would recommend a price drop though if you are buying for just sinle player unless you got money to waste.Gameplay: This will be brief but its worth mentioning this title handles just as smooth as the other entries. Just like any Treyarch entry you'll have brief vehicle sections and this time involving helicopters. You'll have a brief motorcycle escape sequence just like MW2's snowmobile chase off the popular cliffhanger level and both handle pretty much the same. Helicopters are a minor pain to handle and to shoot other helicopters first time around but when it comes to strafing moving targets on the ground or even stationary ones you'll be more than likely enjoy it even by a little bit. Weapons handle the same as MW2 but scopes and sights have been tweaked a bit. Quick scoping has been reduced in online play and some will find iron sights better than using the sights like the red dots, acog scopes, and the new reflex sights. I have been noticed that when shooting a target sometimes it doesn't seem to register  but the guns feel just as deadly as ever.The AI in the campaign has a habit of running up to you to beat your face in at the most inopportune moments making for cheap deaths.Multiplayer: This is where i find the greatest improvement in this title is the online multiplayer. Things have been balanced greatly and certain perks are gone such as stopping power which added extra damage to your guns. Killstreaks are more balanced than MW2 making for less first one to get this many kills steals the whole game moments go away. Its still to early on but one of the reasons i despised MW2 towards the end was the glitching, cheating, and the hackers which were more common than what other people try to say or believe. In a short time the same occurrences might happen but hopefully Treyarch has a faster solution than Infinity Ward. The biggest change in multiplayer is the XP system. You'll still level up but gone are unlocking weapons at certain levels or the wait to get one perk. Weapons still become available at certain levels but you now have to spend credits to purchase. Credits are earned like XP through contracts(challenges) and at the end of each game. Contracts work like challenges but need to be bought with credits and only have a limited time to complete the contract. Customization is much more expansive than previous titles where you'll still have to buy attachments as well though. The one complaint I have is the levels to unlock specific game types is rather annoying. There are a multitude of options for this game making it one of the most engaging online games yet.Combat Training: This is now a much welcomed feature that the only other game Ive played that included such a feature was UT3. Combat Training takes place in simulating online play with adjustable difficulties and AI controlled opponents and allies. While  you'll have separate loadouts than what your actual online character is you can easily use combat training to practice, warm up, or test new weapons unlocked and after purchasing. While sadly it doesn't simulate contacts to help earn credits faster it does allow for testing into whether or not you want a certain attachment or weapon. Also if lag is being a bother simply load up some combat training and run through some practice matches on all the maps to learn their layout and in the end this is a valuable addtion to such a game.Theater: This doesn't require much description due to the fact it simply allows you to view past online matches and record or take screen shots.Zombies: The zombies are back and this is without a doubt one of my favorite features in game that just feels well polished and easily done. I wasn't to much of a fan of WAW's Nazi Zombies but with Black Ops the feature is much more refined and well polished than the previous entry. You start the game out with one map but after completing the campaign you get access to a pentagon level featuring Castro and Kennedy and two other American icons as playable survivors.A third level is an overtop camera allowing for an arcade version of zombies that would normally cost around 10 dollars to download. Its easily now one of my much preferred experiences in gaming to date.Overall:ON A SIDE NOTE WAIT FOR THE CREDITS TO END.

Call of Duty: Black Ops for the PS3 is definately a must-buy for gamers. Yet again, when you compare it to the crap Treyarch tried to push down video gamers' throats, I pitty that they tried so hard to make this game look all "badass" and "fun" yet, let's see if that's really the case.GAMEPLAY & CONTENTCampaign & StorylineLet's start with the campaign's gameplay and the storyline which is just techniquelly a joke. A plain old joke. The storyline is nothing more than a conspiracy, where you play as a brainwashed agent who can't remember crap. I like how Sargeant Viktor Reznov and Dimitri Patrenko from World at War makes appearances on Black Ops; certainly suggesting Black Ops to be a sequal and counterpart to World at War. Yes, but what ruined that is the fact that Reznov doesn't even exist half the game, again; simply because that the dude you play as can't remember crap. When you discover this, it's really depressing since he was one of the best characters. Yes we all love how it's all "badass", but that just comes from the fact that the storyline is nothing more than you doing a bunch of stunts and more of just a bunch of guys shooting at each other. There is no tactics in this game, unlike titles like Battlefield: Bad Company 2. The Call of Duty storylines are designed for war, and epic battlefields. Treyarch ruined the whole storylines by turning it all into a conspiracy, and half the missions are a result of a flashback. Well, overall the campaign is fun and worth playing. Seeing John F. Kennedy and Robert McNamara is pretty cool, yet obvious since this is in the Cold War era.Online Play & Game ModesThe fact that there's "new" stuff doesn't really make it funner. But again, let's start with the good stuff. The Wager Matches were a big hit, and those are for the really competetive players. Choosing different outfits were new addition; yet again, very useless. Since it doesn't effect on which team you're on. Now but putting your own emblems on weapons is nice and all. Face paint is pretty bad ass, I have to admit that. The use of COD points is another +1 because buying things is better than unlocking perks and weapons you don't want. The RC-XD Cars are one of my most favorite kill streak rewards. Choosing kills streak rewards is also here, that was from Modern Warfare 2. So now let's get on with the bad stuff, when it comes to Treyarch's games; there's alot of them. That's cool they added split screen online, yet; whatever happened to split screen on campaign? Go back to any former Call of Duty title, like Modern Warfare 2 and you'll find it on there. Treyarch said that Black Ops would be like a combination of all Call of Duty games, apparently with this blunder that's not the case. For the online play, they took out many good perks. Like the perk that allowed you to have 2 primary weapons, and to switch classes at any time. I don't know what happened to those either. Quick-scoping was taken out, because Treyarch apparently found it "stupid". It's here in Black Ops, but it is just that, "stupid" and useless.Zombies & ExtrasI'm impressed by the way Treyarch modified the Zombie mode, and now you can play as Cold War political figures, John F. Kennedy, Fidel Castro, Robert McNamara and Richard Nickson. This is in the "Five" zombies map as you fight zombies in the Pentagon. And I have to admit that being able to unlock this map via cheat codes is a +1. But however, a -1 would be the Kino Der Toten map. It's a good map, bigger than Five. It's great being able to play as World at War characters, but they should have included weapons from World at War as well. They also changed the sound effects of the MP40 German submachine gun, which ruined the authenticity of Black Ops' sequality to World at War. They didn't even include the PPSh-41 Russian submachine gun, which was in the campaign. That too, they also changed the sound. Something similar to spec ops from Infinity Ward's Modern Warfare 2 would have been nice as well. A combinations of spec ops and zombies on the same game would have made Treyarch's claims of a "unity of all titles" game true. But overall the zombies is very fun, and worth playing as well. Yet; again, it could have all been better.GRAPHICS & IMAGESSpeaking graphic and imagewise, Black Ops is crap. The fact that you're playing PS3 (known for good graphics), doesn't make the fact that Black Ops has good graphics. Just to truly admit the graphics suck. They aren't as good and sharp as graphics fromModern Warfare 2. Overall, the game just looks like "crap". Even if it did have good graphics, it still wouldn't look good. In fact, in terms of graphics this is one of the least good graphics games I've seen. I only like how this time, Treyarch doesn't make the playershands look so small and puny like they did in previous titles likeWorld at War, Call of Duty 3 and Big Red One. One EXTREMELY annoying thing is that EVERY SINGLE F***ING time you switch menus, they just GOTTA show these annoying clips from the game over and over again, I guess they do this just to make the game look all "badass", and to truly tell you - they FAIL AT IT. WE GET IT Treyarch. So there you have it, the graphics are just a pure mess.Especially on the Nuketown and Hanoi map. The graphics on there are just horrible.THE REPORT SYSTEMThis report system is a -1. Well some of you may be saying it's a good way to report hackers and cheaters but all I see happening is the abuse of this system. You do not know how many players I knowgot banned by Treyarch from PlayStation Network for no reason. They weren't even hackers or cheaters or anything. Just innocent players. Let's put it this way, the report system is like going on a "witch-hunt" on PlayStation Network. Anybody can accuse and report anybody, and they actually get banned. They don't even tell you why you get banned or deranked. My cousin got deranked first. Then account banned. Then console banned ALL FOR NO REASON. "Offensive language", give me a break. Anybody can sit there and cuss their asses off and it's never gonna stop, it's pretty simple. There's a lovely thing called a "mute". Who cares about their username or emblem? If it was racist or government-threatening that's a whole other story. But truly, the report system is really useless. What's worse is they don't even catch the right people. There is still hackers on PlayStation Network, and Treyarch doesn't even lay a paw on them. How sad. The PS3's security system is NOT that strong as people claim.Call of Duty: Black Ops, I give a 9.2/10 some rating. It's a good game, but it's seriously not as great as Treyarch promised. And it gets really annoying at times.
All I have to say on this one is that it was WAY better than the first two, and the game play was fantastic! Vietnam, and cold war era games MUST BOW DOWN to Black Ops!!!

I was still so hooked on MW2 multiplayer that I really didn't need a new game, but how could I pass up a new Call of Duty? I didn't realize until I bought Black Ops that is was developed by Treyarch vs. Infinity Ward. What a difference. Although significant improvements were made to the campaign mode, Black Ops is a step backward in online multiplayer performance.On the positive side, campaign mode is longer then MW2 with a more interesting story line. There is a good variety of gameplay here. You get to control a number of vehicles and the cut scenes are well done.  In addition to the improved campaign mode, the online multiplayer has some improvements too. The player stats are much deeper, and are represented visually with graphs/charts. Huge improvement over MW2. There is also more customization of your player, with fully customizable player ID (logo), face paint, more gun camo, etc. You can even put your ID or clan tag on the gun. You can also now play split screen online (finally!). These enhancements are all welcome improvements.Unfortunately the spotty performance online makes it frustrating to take advantage of these features. The server performance has been average at best. Connections are often interrupted, games often have to migrate to a new host and sometimes lose connection in the process.  This is very frustrating, especially when it happens right at the end of a match. Although there has been a software update that improved online performance, it is still noticeably worse then MW2. Also, the load times in general are longer then MW2 (main menu loading, connecting to server, etc.).The multiplayer maps are well done. There is a wide variety of locations and sizes. Although I have noticed there aren't as many camper/sniper spots. Most buildings have multiple entry/exit points. This may be a plus though, especially for those who hate campers! Overall graphics are OK, but not as crisp as MW2.Another weakness is in the weapons dept.  I have yet to find a really accurate auto assault rifle, comparable to the ACR in MW2. Most of the auto assault rifles kick back, making them poor for mid-long range shots. There are some cool guns, but overall I think MW2 had a better selection.The bottom line is that Black Ops does some things better then MW2, but it is just the small stuff like stats, campaign mode, etc. The important stuff, like online multiplayer performance, weapon selection, graphics are worse then MW2. And that is a step backwards. If Activision is smart, they will give Infinity Ward the contract for the next Call of Duty game. It will be interesting to see where the franchise goes from here.If you like the COD series, you'll like Black Ops, but just don't expect it to be better then MW2, because it isn't.

reviewText: As some of you may have heard, not a lot of people like the changes. Some people are still stuck on the Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 phase. But, it's time to move on to newer, albeit, similiar things, and Call of Duty: Black Ops is just that! First, instead of going on a malicous rant about the game, remember that Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 was a Infinity Ward production while Call of Duty: Black Ops is a Treyarch production. Therefore, the titles, though they have similiar features in most aspects of gameplay, are, in essence, two different games. Players no longer have the ability to lunge twenty feet forward toward their enemies, nor will the scavenger perk work for you noobers; moreoever, there aren't nukes for you so called nuke-boosters; finally, camping is made difficult due to the circularity of the maps in Call of Duty: Black Ops.But, I cannot deny it. I am and always will be a Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 fanboy.Pros and Cons (Call of Duty: Black Ops):Pros:(1) I ought to start off by saying that the great thing about multiplayer is the ability to jump into a room with a friend without having to wait for an invitation (if it isn't a private match).(2) Gamers can now customize their characters, including the guns and the emblems.(3) Everything has to be purchased, sometimes unlocked before being purchased, for use. This includes killstreaks and perks. This makes the effort of buying new guns with new attachments, in my opinion, better than unlocking them by leveling up (Like in Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2).(4) As I mentioned above, the maps, though linear in direction, are circular in the entirety. Therefore, campers are bound to keep moving to protect themselves, increasing the probability of being killed.(5) The guns are, to say the least, done fairly well and tend to recoil a lot. I put this in the pro section of my multiplayer summary because you have to earn a kill. That means, no more no scoping, quick scoping, no more drop shots, and the like. Gamers no longer have the advantage of quick scoping. Call of Duty: Black Ops did away with it.(6) Theater mode is very entertaining. Being able to see your progress in a previous match is a plus. You can also see another players actions by rotating your camera using the R1 and L1 buttons.(7) Combat mode is perfect for those newbies who are virgins to the Call of Duty franchise. Also, veteran Call of Duty players will find this mode as a way to garner or cultivate their skills.(8) Wager matches are profoundly entertaining! Whether its rotating a cycle of guns, getting a new gun with every new kill, using a pistol, a bullet, and a knife to destroy your enemies, or causing havoc with your crossbrow, its a different, more effective way of earning large sums of money.Cons:(1) The party system needs work. Gamers will find it difficult to connect with a party of three of more to a large deathmatch mode like Ground War or Domination (and other alike). Sometimes, it takes a few minutes to connect, unlike Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 which did it faster, mere seconds. Players tend to get "thrown out" of rooms, sometimes, forcing them to rejoin the party; however, when trying to rejoin, the game goes a little haywire and prompts players back to the multiplayer menu.(2) The sound and graphic quality will remind players of Call of Duty: World At War. Now, that isn't a bad thing. But, if it's a new game living up to "Call of Duty" hype, then it should have a sleeker look.(3) The respawn system is terrible, utterly terrible. Enemies tend to respawn behind players, even after being killed. Sometimes, after killing an enemy, you can actuall witness them respawning directly behind you. This flaw is the downfall of killstreaks.(4) I personally wasn't a big fan of the Commando Perk, the knifing in Call of Duty: Black Ops will cause some players to bark at their televisions yelling "bull!@#$." It feels impossible to knife people at times.(5) The guns are fun, but after some hours of play, tend to feel outdated and useless. And because there aren't many, you're forced to find a favorite gun instead of cycling them from class to class. But this is a minor flaw.(6) The biggest flaw is being booted off of a match either in the beginning, the middle, or at the end. Let me make this clear: sometimes, during the matchmaking process (the screen which acts as the interval between matches), players are thrown out, followed by a sign which says "disconnected" or "your party is no longer available" while your buddies are still in the room. This happens during the match and after the match has finished--especially while making the transition from one game to the next.In conclusion, the game needs a lot of work. But, so did Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 when it first came out. Therefore, give it some time guys, it'll get better with age.

Before I start my review, I want to let u guys know that I own the following games: Killzone 2, BFBC1 & 2, COD4, CODW@W, CODMW2, MAG, and MOH.I notice it's a fashionable thing to bash a mainstream game, but I believe in order to appreciate COD:Black Ops, you have to come from a background playing other FPS games such as COD4 and MOH, and not only from playing MW2. I loved MW2 and I prestiged as well, but you cannot expect a carbon copy of MW2. If you want MW2, then just play MW2 with those $15 map-packs (I bought the stimulus package for myself as well, lol).PERSONAL REVIEW ON THE MULTIPLAYER MODE:I realized many MW2 players are hating on COD:Black ops(BO) because of the graphic. I agree with them somewhat, that is why I wanna give 4.5 out of 5, but it doesn't mean u could give the game only 1 star just cuz it doesn't have more textures than MW2!! If you ever played W@W, you know the graphic and innovation isn't everything for Treyarch; they care more of the gameplay and balance in COD. If you want the innovation in COD, just don't play COD and just pick up a copy of BFBC2. After playing W@W, I knew in terms of graphic, Treyarch is still playing the catch up game with Infinite ward. The heavily modified id Tech graphic engine used in the development of COD4 and MW2 by Infinite Ward is far more superior. That is why many people who ONLY played MW2 with high expectations especially on graphic are disappointed. Anyway, a matter of fact, I was amazed how Treyarch pulled off such an amazing graphic in BO, which is almost close to MW2 consider W@W's graphic was really bad compared to COD4.Well, I believe those MW2 players who gave lower rating simply cuz BO got rid of the following:1)Noob-tubing: scavenger + Danger close perk do not exist anymore for those noobtubers; so players who are not good at aiming cannot kill.2)Sniping: it became so much more difficult due to the fact that BO got rid of the quick scoping. If you ever played MOH, you will know how annoying and over powered snipers are. Especially in MW2, many players want to earn their higher kill-streak combo such as Harrier --> AC130 --> Nuke, that the game promotes campers and snipers. I really like how kill-streak do not chained-up as more kills in BO, which further gets rid of campers.3)Camping and dual shoguning: again there were so many campers and dual shotguners in MW2 that their strategies do not work in BO anymore. The implementation of RC-XD w/ ONLY 3 kill-streak (2 kill-streak with hardline perk) is simply to get rid of corner campers. I love that idea.For those of you thought that BO is just an inferior copy of MW2 with just few hours of gameplay, I suggest you to keep on playing. The multi-player mode doesn't grow on some players until you start the CUSTOMIZATION. The personalization of emblem, camo, face-paint, lens color, and lens will have you appreciate and hooked on BO even more. People who are hating on BO is only mentioning the surface of the game (graphic and sound), and have not experienced the real potential of BO. Those who are complaining about the lag, maybe their internet connections aren't good or do not know how to change their setting to LOCALE. You could change your connection setting to LOCALE, where you get to play with local people in your area/region, which personally helps getting the full bar while playing online. The game only came last week, and patches will come to fix those who really experiencing lags. All online games have lag and glitch problems when they first released. If you remember when COD4 first came out, many people including myself simply couldn't play online due to the infinite "DOWNLOADING GAME SETTING SCREEN" freeze. That was MUCH worse than any lag you will experience in BO.NOW, MY REVIEW ON THE SINGLE PLAYER MODE:I finished the campaign in 8 hours and loved every moment of it. The story was intense and creative that it reminded me of the movie, "Shutter Island." Treyarch did a great job. I loved how Reznov and Dimitri from W@W came back in the story, and how you actually get to be in Hong kong, and even in German to get rid of SS soldiers like the good old W@W. For me, I thought the story was much much better than other FPS out there.OVERALL:Call of Duty:Black Ops is the closest thing to COD4!!! which for me was the most balanced multi-player experience. In BO, players actually have to run and circulate around the map in Team Deathmatch, which reminded me much of COD4 and I really enjoy that. However, I know there are many people do not appreciate how balanced BO's gameplay is and judging the game by just the surface appearance. Simply, for me, the gameplay of BO is amazing, fun, and addictive.

I was one of the people that couldn't wait for this game to come out and got it when it first came out. I was disappointed with the single player campaign, but I loved the multiplayer. The story mode can get very boring and repetitive. (Spoiler) There is a twist in the story towards the end of the game, but it isn't as good as the twists in games like BioShock. The story mode isn't very long and if you are really good at it, you can finish it pretty fast. The game is mostly shooting people like most fps are. There are some moments in the game where they change things up, but it doesn't last for long. One thing I didn't like about the game was that the weapons sound silly. They aren't loud like they should be. The graphics for the game aren't that great either. For a game that makes a ton of money, I wish they would have spent some of it to help make the single player better. Now on to multiplayer. Multiplayer is a very fun and a little of the same from the previous games and some new stuff. Now you have so many customization options. You can design your own player card, customize your class (which now has a ton of options), choose your killstreaks (there are a bunch of new ones), and more. You can now play online by yourself (in combat training mode) or online. In both of those, you can play with a friend with split screen. The only thing is that your friend can't sign into their own profile and will have to use whatever weapons you have unlocked. There are a bunch of maps to play on and there are 4 more on the DLC pack and 4 more coming soon in the next pack. Zombies is also brought back and is better than World At War's zombie mode. The only problem I had with this is that there aren't many maps for it. Only two. With 1 more from the DLC pack and another coming with the next pack. The two maps that it does come with are very good though. They made sure to make the maps big and with their own unique twists to the zombie mode. You can play it on your own, with a friend or online. Overall, the story mode was disappointing, but it makes up for it with multiplayer and zombie mode. If you like to play by yourself, then you should wait until the price goes down or not get it at all. If you love multiplayer games, then get it asap!

reviewText: Call of Duty Black Ops is a game that I have only held off buying due to the fact that all I hear is "Stay away!" or, ""This game is broken!", etc. and so forth. Truth be told, I have yet to experience any of the connection issues, system crashes, or whatever else people are complaining about. Quite frankly, I experience fewer host migrations on Black Ops than I did on MW2. In MW2, I had times where there would be 4+ host migrations in one game. But such doesn't seem to be the case with Black Ops. And for complaints about graphics, graphics don't make a game. If that were the case, I would only be playing Killzone 2 right now... but I'm not.One huge perk that I never knew about is the ability to bring a guest online with you. I remember how much fun it was to go to my friend's house in the early days of Halo and split-screen online. It adds a lot of value to the game. I just tried this out last night, and its pretty cool. It beats doing local split screen matches, where screen peaking runs rampant. So this is a nice, fair way to play a FPS with a friend at your house.Now I will list a few of the other cool things I have noticed about the game. Combat Training mode allows you to play online, but with bots. Those bots use the PSN names of your friends. This gives you a good opportunity to get a feel for the maps and guns. This will for sure save you from getting absolutely destroyed in your earlier matches. Guns seem to be a lot more balanced this time around. No more longshots with SMGs, or shotguns. Those only work in CQC, as they are supposed to. You no longer have to unlock every single attachment to get extended mags if you want them on a gun. You simply purchase the attachment with Call of Duty points (the entire game revolves around these.). This means you can have any desired attachment the first time you use a gun. Kills from killstreaks no longer contribute to more killstreaks. Meaning, if you want the gunship, youre going to have to earn it alllll by yourself.If you still aren't convinced... No more Danger Close Pro. No more ridiculous noob tubing. No more akimbo 1887s. No more quick scoping. No more Commando.Campaign seems to be typical of the CoD series. Short, and exciting. The replay value lies in beating it on higher difficulty levels and finding intel. The Zombies mode is pretty boss. Don't try to play it by yourself though. Bring a few friends to avoid pointless frustration. Lastly, contracts and wager matches add a new level of fun to the online multiplayer. These involve gambling your CoD points in an attempt to win big payouts. Try "One in the Chamber," I think it is a pretty fun game.In closing: this game is really fun, not broken, and currently around 40 bucks here on Amazon with a trade in value of 33 bucks. At this point, if you don't like it, trade it back, and it will be the price of a rental. What do you really have to lose?
summary: Still on the Fence? Just Buy it Now!

reviewText: ***UPDATE*** After having spent substantial time with Black Ops, I stand by my initial impressions. The overall balancing has proven to be exceptional as there is no single "money" class to exploit or be forced to use in tough games. The maps are fun, weapons and upgrade system a blast and all of the customization available makes the game really enjoyable.There is a big negative. As mentioned in my original review - connection is a serious issue. Lag, framerate drops, freezes...pretty much any connection problem you can think of applies. Patch 1.04 is on the way from Treyarch to address some of these issues, but connection certainly mars what is an otherwise great online experience.***END UPDATE***I'm about 42 hours into the game. I would consider myself a hardcore-console gamer (if there is such thing). I logged 25+ days on MW2 and have spent time with BFBC2, Killzone2 and pretty much every other game that involves shooting other people in the face - online. The review is aimed at people who may have been turned off after MW2.Campaign mode - I wouldn't know cause I don't play it. I hear it takes 6 hours, so probably just a rental if that's all you're interested in.Online* The fixes - noob toobing, commando, stoping power, one man army, boosting, tactical insertions, stacking killstreaks, explosive radius nerfed - ALL GONE. If that means anything to you, then you already love this game.*The Mechanics - best in the console market. Period. The guns are NOT all the same. No more UMP45 across the map kills. It also requires more hits to get a kill. This is good and bad - see connections below.*Graphics/Sound - The maps look phenominal, but the player models are mediocre. The music ambient sound effects are great, but I'm not impressed with the sounds of the guns.*The Maps - my first impression is that they are amazing...BUT... and this is one big but - they are not sniper friendly. I'm not a sniper, so I don't care, but I have some friends that already hate the game becuase the wide open lanes in MW2 are non-existant. There are varied levels, tunnels, etc. - but camping just seems much more difficult.*Connection - still P2P, no dedicated servers, and that sucks. Ultimately, regardless of skill level, connection will be the deciding factor in your enjoyment of the online game (also why I give it four stars)*Wager Games - also known as online crack. Being able to wager your money (which is required to purchase the items you've unlocked and their attachements - it's not automatic anymore) is like playing poker online. There are multiple game types, all very new and add a whole seperate dimesnion to online shooters. Definately the best innovation for FPS's in a long time.*Split Screen - for all online modes is awesome. I have 2 PS3's in the house and can accomodate 4 players with them in an online match. It's about time that option was available.Overall, this is a must buy if you are a COD fan. If you were turned off by MW2 - which many were, and rightfully so, at least give it a try. The Zombie mode, Training mode and wager matches are a blast and give everyone a shot at having a good time - not just experts and 12yr old, foul mouthed racists.

reviewText: Judging by the title I gave this review, it is easy to see that most will feel a lot of deja vu while playing this game.  The gameplay has become a bit dated while the graphics look just about the same as in COD4.  For the three console owners who have not experienced COD before, this game will blow them away.  For the other millions of people, it may look a lot like COD4, a game that came out about 4 years ago.  Treyarch did a lot of good things with Black Ops, but lip stick can't make this old game look new.Pros--For players who have not played Call of Duty before, the graphics will seem great, the gameplay will be intense and innovative, the single player campaign over-the-top drama, and multiplayer will keep them busy late into the night.  Let me emphasize that this is for players who have not played COD before.-Game balance on multiplayer is greatly improved from Modern Warfare 2.  Seldom do you see people running around with knives, noob-tubing, or instant ducking/shooting.-Split screen multiplayer makes it a bit more social of a gameCons--No matter whether you play the single player or the multiplayer, you will feel like you've done this all before.-The single player will seem to drag quite a bit and not seem very satisfying.  It is probably as good as COD4, COD5, or COD6's single player story, but by now, they all seem a bit tired.-Multiplayer, while improved, again seems a bit old.  Sure it is not as frustrating now, but it sure seems a bit tired.--Update--I've noticed a lot of disc reading noise coming out of the PS3 lately when playing this game.  It happens a lot during multiplayer games.  It is annoying and I have no idea how much damage it is doing to the hardware.  Google Black Ops PS3 noise and you will see a lot of people complaining about this issue.  Definitely avoid getting this game at least for the PS3.  I can't believe Activision can't release a 4 year old game without bugs.

Black Ops is a good game. I doubt that a lot of people would argue against that assertion. It's a game that has everything that made Modern Warfare and Modern Warfare 2 great: Incredible scripted events, tense moments, an intriguing story and awesome weaponry. All that said, Call of Duty: Black Ops suffers from something that few other games are lucky enough to suffer from, it has the problem of having to outdo its own previous iterations. In my opinion it does this and does it quite well.Story:The game this time around takes place during the Vietnam war but you're not on that particular battlefield for very long. The story takes you into the shoes of several different soldiers and as that disembodied camera that posses different soldiers you're globetrotter that goes from Cuba to Vietnam, Washington DC to Russia and quite a few places between that. This is both a blessing a curse. Of course it's very cool to see a wide variety of environments and have the opportunity to snipe from a snowy mountain one minute and take out a camp in the swamps in another, but at the same time, switching from one character to another in different places kind of kills the flow of the story to the point where sometimes it's difficult to understand (or care) what's going on.Weapons:Given the time period weapons are very similar to the ones found in Moder Warfare. the most notable new weapons are the Crossbow and the flamethrower, both are pretty fun to use in single player, though the flamethrower has a pretty short range and enemies tend to attack in packs. In multiplayer they are usually not the best weapons to utilize unless you're one of those guys who is very good at getting accustomed to weapons quickly and can strategize their use effectively. Personally I find the Crossbow to be too slow to reload and the flamethrower too limited in range.Multiplayer:A lot of people by Call of duty and Halo games just for the multiplayer, I'm not one of those people so my opinion on this is kind of slanted. I'm not awful at multiplayer but I'm not consistant by any stretch of the imagination. I've gone from one game having a 21/5 (Kill/death ratio) to having a 6/19 (k/d ratio.) The maps are pretty varied and there are of course the usual camping spots that people generally overuse but there is often a way to get around them without too much trouble. spawning can be problematic at times since the game isn't beyond having you respawn next to an enemy in the next room but, at least in my experience, does not happen all that often.The newest thing to be implemented into multiplayer is that you no longer need to level all the way up to have everything. with every kill, win or contract fulfilled you get money. With that money you can by guns, upgrades, layers to make emblems (which you can put on your guns,) etc. This is a pretty neat addition as now when you can presumably make your best combinations earlier on. The whole customization aspect of the new multiplayer is a welcome change that shows that the franchise is moving int he right direction. Hopefully the next CoD will expand on this even more.Verdict:Call of Duty: Black Ops is a good game. What keeps it from being a fantastic game is weak character development leading to little intrest in the characters themselves and at times a confusing plot in single player. Multiplayer is multiplayer, it's as good as we've come to expect from the franchise (zombies included) with some welcome customization options that add a whole new element to the hectic battleground.

One thing Treyarch does well is stats, though... this has all the stats that MW2 should have had.  Oh, and zombies are always fun.

There is no way not to compare Call of Duty Black Ops to the excellent Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2. The later has become the game that all current FPS are judged by, more so member of the Call of Duty family. I had spent an unhealthy amount of time playing Modern Warfare 2 and so comparing the two as I played through Black Ops was second nature. I will admit I was less than thrilled to hear that Treyarch was developing Black Ops, since the last two CoD games they made (CoD3 and World at War) were my least favorite of the series. For the most part all that worry has been set aside, Black Ops is a great FPS and a great new addition to the Call of Duty line of games.The game plays very much like all post Call of Duty games, good tight controls and fast paced shooting with some story to tie it together. If anything the one thing that dissappointed me the most was the rather odd and somewhat boring story of the game. The mission levels and settings a varied to an amazing degree, Vietnam, Russia, Cuba, etc and span several decades of the Cold War. Yet the story that ties it together seems something out of a cheap spy thriller. While most people will not be bother by this I expect all games at this stage of video game history to have a decent story and a certain amount of polish. The CoD formula is a very linear game with set piece scenes and so the story and presentation are what really makes you feel like going on to the end. The story wasn't bad, but I think they could have told it much better. The interation they have implemented is very nice though. During many scenes you will still have buttons to press and things to do, from starting the engine of your SR71 spy plane to rappelling down mountains, I think that was a nice touch.As I mentioned before the missions are extremely varied in setting, from jungle to snow and everywhere in between. The voice acting is all very good and the graphics are amazing. I remember just looking at the reflection in the canopy of a helicopter you pilot and thinking 'wow nice touch'. The weapon, an important element in all shooters, are varied and interesting. They did a good job of putting lots of gun in the game, while helping them to feel unique and different from each other. The realism isn't great, many of the weapons were not around during the time frame the missions were based on. There are other small details like the Troy folding sights on the weapons facing the wrong direction and the like which bothered me, but its something most people wouldn't pick up on and doesn't really take away from the game.The campaign is rather short but not terribly so and its worth a couple play through. And while the story is somewhat short Treyarch did a wonderful thing by adding a zombie game as well. That was a major hit with their WaW game and I was glad to see it not just returned in Black Ops, but improved as well. It also adds a lot of value and replay to the game. Multiplayer is good and the ability to outfit your kit and weapons again is good.Multiplayer is very good. The maps are well laid out and fun, they seem somewhat camping resistant as well. The weapons are different and the mods are nice. Their are a number of types of online games to play and the option to play split screen or LAN as well. You can set up multiple custom classes so you can switch on the fly. There is also the option to play alone again AI enemies, which allows you to practice. The AI is quite good and on all settings they seem to be fantastic shots.I was worried about picking this game up on launch day since I felt burned bu CoD3 and WaW before, but after reading some good reviews decided to give it a try. And I am glad I did, Treyarch has done a great job on this game and have vastly improved from their last couple attempts. Black Ops is not just a good Treyarch game, but a great Call of Duty game when considered with the fit of the entire series. I am glad I p
summary: A great addition to the franchise

Same with Ninja, you have to plant bombs to unlock pro, what if you don't like S&D; or Demolition?I do like that the MP is balanced, there are no more overpowered killstreaks. The dogs are kind of overpowered, but still not as bad as an AC130 or chopper gunner.The one thing I really really about this game is the sound. The sound is absolutely terrible in MP. For instance, the footsteps... you can't hear them. I have an expensive set of surround sound headphones and they are useless since you can't hear the footsteps. The Ninja perk is not even necessary since the enemy is moving in dead silence by default. Even after you unlock Ninja Pro, it just sound like random footsteps, there is no sense of direction.Overall this is a subpar game that was overhyped to be this great game that was going to change the future of FPS. Treyarch must have some seriously talentless developers, because they supposedly spent two full years exclusively to develop this game. Just another fail product from Treyarch studios. reviewText: I love the COD franchise and this game lives up to the hype! The single player campaign is fun, although it's short but the real action is the online play! I am not going to go to in debt with this review, but chances are if you bought this game or plan on buying it, you know what to expect. A short 6 hour single player campaign, some fun or unbalanced multiplayer (depending on which of the Call of Duty games you have played), and some fun zombies co-op. You know what you are getting from the package, but the question is this: is it better than Modern Warfare 2? Is it the best Call of Duty game since COD4? Well it depends on who you are talking to, but I would say yes, it is. The singleplayer is easily one of the best in the series, with awesome set pieces and a great story, with balanced and engaging multiplayer, and spiced up zombies, Black Ops is the definitive Call of Duty game.However, despite the fact that all of these components work, the Call of Duty series is simply stale at this point. Ever since Call of Duty 4 (or World at War if you include Zombies), each game has basically been the same, in terms of the campaign and the multiplayer design. There are a few customization options in multiplayer this time around, but they aren't really game changing even though they are cool. The campaign is also as short as you would expect from a Call of Duty game, and with the lack of co-op campaign unlike World at War, there was some wasted potential.So yeah it has its flaws, mostly because of its staleness, but if you can look past some of these flaws and you still find Call of Duty fresh, then you will be in for quite a fun ride! It is the best Call of Duty game since 4 because of a great singleplayer and the best multiplayer since that game's release. The zombies is also fun still with new additions and some awesome weapons. Overall Black Ops is a fun game and is worth your money, let's just hope that next time around we get some more fresh content to water our waiting mouths.
summary: Call of Duty needs some spice, but it is better than MW2.

reviewText: Call of Duty: Black Ops is a fantastic game in every aspect and has brought a great amount of enjoyment. The creators put forth a great deal of work and made many improvements from previous installments. The game feels like an entirely different game . I am extremely pleased so far.

To begin this review, I feel I should establish a few important points. 1) I am not a big fan of the series...yes I have played previous installments, and mostly enjoyed them.  And it is absolutely true these games, as a rule, do create the quintessential on-line multiplayer experience.  All others are imitators where this is concerned.  However, I actually got this copy for free (its previous owner apparently did not place much value on it). 2) I am not here to laud the merits of Battefield 3.  I have in fact not played it, and I would have no expectation for loving that game much more than this one if I did play it.  So, given these admissions, on to the review.I will concede good marks for the multiplayer (hence the 3 stars on the fun factor)...however, this game is a glorified (and overpriced) expansion pack disguised as the full package.  The single player experience is just okay at best, lots of style but very little substance.  It is pretty much a nice lengthy tutorial for the multiplayer, which is more appropriately designated as an MW3 expansion pack.  Honestly, I see no innovation or upgrade that would warrant a purchase price over about 20 bucks.  What is most disturbing, IMHO, is the trend this game and others like it reinforce...the radical decrease in quality, depth and length of an excellent single player experience in favor of multiplayer mayhem.  For my 60 dollars I would like a truly complete game that delivers on all aspects, Black Ops is simply not that game.  I truly hope someday more gamers will use their purchase power to demand more from developers, until then I suspect we will continue to be inundated with the hollow tripe of this game and its imitators.
summary: The death knell of quality single player experience?

reviewText: I don't want to sound like a MW2 fanboy but I'm a prestige multiplayer gamer for this fantastic game so it's normal for me to compare them both.Black ops servers seem to be having lots of problems, you get disconnected all the time, and finding a good game seems like an impossible task atsome point. Let me get the good points out of the way first:Story mode is ok, challenging, a little different and has a surprise twist to it.  But that just about does it.  Its nothing we haven't seen with Call Of Duty before, run gun and shoot em up.  There are a few new twists, like the explosive crossbow and zip lines, but nothing to get excited about.  Too much filler time between missions as well.Zombies is in a way, an improvement from WaW zombies.  Bigger move involved maps, smoother graphics.  Zombies however, is much harder and the weapon selection and upgrades aren't nearly as good as zombies from WaW.  Too much wacked out crap going on like having to run and link the teleporter then run back to teleport and THEN pack-a-punch.  Zombie crawlers that explode, the "Five" map is just too hard and spastic, to the point where it is nearly unplayable.  Ascension is decent and if you're a hardcore fan of zombies, I'd suggest spending the $15 to get it, it will provide many hours of enjoyment.  New perks, easter eggs, a lot of great stuff going on, but on the same hand, even Ascension is getting to the point of being ridiculously aimless and crazy.Combat training sucks.  Horrible.  The bots are absolutely stupid on the lowest 2 settings so you have to bump them up to hardened to get anything out of it (and then its still kind of stupid)  can't even play on veteran, the bots all run with snipers and auto head shots, just unplayble.  Unfun, doesn't simulate real game play, won't make you better, just make you angry.Now for the online (since thats mainly what COD is about).  If you want good online, DON'T buy this sorry piece of crap.  Buy Homefront, buy Medal of Honor, go back to Modern Warfare, hell go buy Monopoly and play that.  Laggy, sorry host migration, can't keep parties together, sometimes you find lobbies quick, sometimes it takes up to 10 minutes.  All the cheaters, hackers, glitchers, and exploiters have made the transition on to this game.  Aimbots, rapid fire controllers, wall hacks, everything.  I played 10 matches today and couldn't find 1 without a cheater.  The weapons suck, you are forced to run around with the AK74u with rapid fire or else you will get owned.  The Famas has yet to be patched, 1 or 2 shots and it kills you and it has an incredible fire rate.  Pretty much, run with a 203 or rapid fire because you won't stand a chance in a head to head fight.  The weapon's damages are too screwed up to make it fair.  Hit detection....wait, theres hit detection?  Forget ADS, it doesn't matter the bullet will go where it wants to.  I hoped the First Strike map pack would give something new but they don't just more horribly designed maps that are frustrating.  No fix on the spawning issues yet and everyone still runs hardline, gets 2 kills and you have RC XDs live and in effect blowing up everyone.  MW2 went down the drain, but at least it had a solid server, smooth game play, and some fun stuff going on in it.  Everything about Black Ops sucks, perks, weapons, maps, spawning, EVERYTHING.  I suggest go to Vegas with about $15,000 and hit the tables, because thats all this game is, a gamble.  No skill, just randomly picking and choosing who is going to die next.  You may go 20 and 1 then go 2 and 30.  One day the Commando is awesome, the next day you have to run extended mags and MAYBE 45 bullets will kill someone.  It sucks, WaW was the last great COD IMO and I will never waste money on another piece of crap Treyarch makes.  They should be ashamed of this game and hold their heads as low as possible. If you are looking for online, AVOID at all costs!  And the problems are on Xbox as well, not as bad, but still there so don't start PS3 bashing.  Its just one of the worst video games in history.

reviewText: Lets not beat around the bush here, CEO Bobby Kotick of Activision / Blizzard Entertainment doesn't really care what you as a gamer think. He doesn't play video games, and he certainly doesn't care about keeping anyone on his staff who doesn't share his mindset of market domination.  What he does care about is delivering a quality product that sells well, and that is exactly what Black Ops brings to the table.What you can expect:- A 8-10 hour campaign of Michael Bay explosions and "Tyler Durden" plot twists mixed into a diabolical story line- Completely inaccurate portrayal of weapons and technology during the 1960-1970 Cold War- Coop zombie multi-player modes, 2 maps with the regular edition and 4 with the Hardened.- 12 Multi-player maps filled with the quality and level of intensity many fans have come to expect from the Call of Duty franchiseWhat I liked:If you play Call of Duty for competitive online matches, you will probably be dropping Modern Warfare 2 for this one.  Not only is the online game more balanced and regulated than its Infinity Ward predecessor, it has a community of developers who have devoted their attention full-time to making sure the community is listened to. The multi-player is addictive, and leaves much to strive for if you are a long-time player of Black Ops.  Prestige modes now bring you into a higher level of competitive game play.  Wager matches are not for the feint of heart when dropping in-game currency.  The best addition to the series was Combat Training.  This mode allows you to experiment with different perks and kill streaks, without the worry of affecting your precious win-loss or kill-death ratios online.  The recent matches option also lets you look at your past matches, much like in Halo 3s theater mode.  This is a welcome addition for those who want to watch good players which stick out on the leaderboards, and "borrow" their tactics for their own play style.  These are all options which the community wanted for their next Call of Duty game, and like a champ Treyarch provided.What I disliked:It's starting to feel like the campaign for shooters nowadays is simply for game reviewers to gawk at, and for casual players to use as training for the meat of the game: multi-player.  While I did think the campaign was adequate, on veteran difficulty it was downright annoying.  Enemies respawn and storm right back to take the position of the guy you just shot within 5 seconds. So if you don't move up, you die.  Cowering enemies can't be picked off from their foot sticking out, or head slightly shown either.  You must wait until they decide to shoot at you before you can fire back.  The campaign really didn't flesh into its own until the latter half of the game, and even then it just felt like a sequel to Modern Warfare 2.  Perhaps when Black Ops gets a sequel (probably set in the 1970s) and Chuck Norris comes into the fray we will see a campaign more memorable, but for now just expect to follow a very linear story line with little ability to deviate from the main path without getting killed.Like I said before though, you don't buy games like these anymore for the story, you buy it for the competitive aspect.  This game literally has something for everyone from the hardcore to the casual looking to jump on the bandwagon of FPS players.  Shooter fans expect the best from their games, and Treyarch delivered a knockout.  You might as well join the craze now, because Activision is going to milk this franchise every year until gamers get bored of it.
summary: A Great Yet Tired Addition to the Franchise

reviewText: I personally hate comparing games to one and another, I believe if you're a fan of that particular games genre then play it and enjoy it for what it is. However with Call of Duty games it's hard not to compare, there is so much to live up to. I know this isn't Infinity Ward and also not Modern Warfare 3 but they did set the bar very high when it comes to military FPS. So the question is, does Black Ops live up to its predecessors? The answer of course, is yes it does!Come on! Do we really need to review this game, was there really any doubt! If you are a fan of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 1 and 2 then you'll really enjoy this game. Honestly I enjoyed Black Ops just as much and in some cases more.In a nutshell, the graphics are beautiful, the action amazing and the story is entertaining to say the least. Controls are great and very fluid and if you've ever played any other FPS you'll feel right at home, and if you haven't its very easy to pick up from the start. Multiplayer has been revamped, includes everything that made Modern Warfare great plus fixes some of the things that didn't. My only complaint would be the match making, I wish it would match people more by their skill level and not randomly.It's worth the price and (not to sound like a commercial LOL) if you only buy one game this year, this should be it.Now stop reading reviews and go pick up the game so you can start blowing things up! By the way, if you see me online follow me around because I'm an easy kill. I suck really bad, so right now let me say; you're welcome for the kill streak!MikePSN & Xbox Live gamer tag is MikeJMele
