reviewText: disclosure: i was a HUGE COD fanboy until march of this year. what happenend, you ask? battlefield bad company 2.  it took 1 BFBC multiplayer match to convert me.  since that moment i've barely played a handful of COD MW, MW2 and WAW matches and left each with a sour taste in my mouth.however, i am a fan of shooters and not a COD hater [but getting awfully close], so i was marginally excited for black ops. the premise seemed interesting me and i like the idea of globetrotting and exploring the so-called 'black ops' missions. i also liked the idea of a richer customization experience in multiplayer.  all signs pointed to a solid release.sadly, i was so wrong.as many have already commented, the graphics aren't even passable for a game released in 2010. they look extremele dated.  the skies still look someone took a picture of a sky and threw on top of the map.  it's very one-dimensional.  to me only the explosions and burning embers looked OK, and even those were just OK.  having said that, however, the script/story was at least somewhat compelling and step in the right direction compared to MW2, which was incoherent at best.  the voice actors, for their part, do a fine job with the material they're given.  the single player campaign was decent, and it was nice to see reznov again, but i can't imagine picking it up again for another go around.i've played about 2-3 hours of multiplayer and it's just terrible. terrible.  the guns sound like cheap mexican firecrackers - all treble, no bass. you may as well be playing with BB guns [play 10 seconds of BFBC2 and you'll see what *amazing* sound design can do to enhance your gaming experience].  the maps are all essentially medium-sized squares in which people run around in circles or go prone at the end of a hallway and wait for someone to run by for the easy kill. you've won't see any new map style/design in BO that you've haven't seen in previous COD games - industrial park, rubbled city, and well, that's pretty much it. every map is a variation of another map, probably even reskinned from another map.  the only thing the MP gets right, in my opinion, is the option to choose what to buy with the COD money you earn.  i think that's a great innovation and i hope it spreads to other games.all these issues, not to mention the atrocious lag and hit detection, simply don't warrant a $60 purchase. sure those things may be fixed in the future, by why aren't they fixed the day of release? shame on you, activision.  i hope bobby kotick got a nice lap dance with my $60.i'm really a bit mystified by the COD mystique and why so many people get suckered into it.  yes, i was one, but i saw the light and moved on. based on all the flaming and disappointed COD fan boys, i can only many of them will be open to playing BFBC2, which in my opinion is a superior game in every single way.it's OK to admit you were wrong, COD fanboy.  i was. remember, the truth shall set you free.one last thought about the so-called 'journalists/critics' heaping praise on this game - if you were flown to LA, the choppered to some exclusive spa in ojai, given the royal treatment, and essentially paid off with gift bags full of COD goodies, would YOU give it a negative review? think about it.did someone say payola?

Bullet Points...#1  MARKETING CAMPAIGN:  The COD Black Ops marketing campaign was the best I've ever seen for a video game.  Eminem trailer played during the MLB playoffs, NFL Sundays, and Primetime?!  WOW this is a big game release,and a big deal to Activision.#2  THE BAD:  The graphics are noticeably below average, I was dissapointed immediately.  Some report that the game looks better on the 360 than it does on the PS3.  Sure they do look darker and clearer on the 360, but trust me it's not enough to make that much of a difference in the overall appearance of the game.  As well, I played close to 50 games and there wasn't one game that didn't glitch, have a framerate issue at least twice a game, both of these concerns speak volumes.  This game wasn't polished.  I think the majority of us felt the Treyarch team was playing hacky sack for about a year because they felt the game was done and brilliant long ago.  I wasn't crazy about the gun games and wager matches other than the one in the chamber game I love that idea, because your playing these games with these horrible graphics that feature the guns and your hands and wrists all look undetailed.  The RC car is too easy to get and it unerves everyone and takes away from the focus of the game as you can hear it all over the map; and all it will likely kill is one player.#3  THE GOOD:  The player and gun/gear customization is a brilliant move.  The menus are excellent.  The maps are all so different and creative.  One in the chamber game sounds fun I couldn't find it, likely an unlock.  You can set and move your claymore, very cool. Co-op zombie mode a fun diversion.  Combat mode with bots another great idea.  Hidden games.  The game is chock full of content.#4  However, to me the game lacks heart.  It's just missing the drama and intensity of a war themed FPS, it feels more like an arcade game.  As players run by with the horrible graphics... ping! I shot the rabbit, here ducky... ping! with the cartoon-like undetailed graphics.#5  Fun Arcadey FPS lacking the intensity of its three predecesors, but not lacking on the fun meter, as well as chock full of talent.  Normally I'd give a game like this a 7/10, but with all the content smashed into this game and the cool custmization I'll give it a solid 8, more of a fun game than a great game.#6  I sold my copy for $50 this morning and will be going back to MW2 this evening.  The tough part is all your boys are going to be playing Black Ops, but there are plenty of people still playing MW2.
summary: Black Ops:  A FUN Arcade FPS Lacking Heart

reviewText: This is just my opinion and I did love MW1 & 2.  I borrowed this game from a friend who got it the day they released it.  He played the campaign for about an hour and then played the on-line multiplayer for a couple hours.  He said he didn't like it and loaned it to me the next day.  And, well, hate to say I didn't care for it either.Now I hardly play on-line.  If you do, this review probably doesn't have much to offer you in regards to this game.  I only played the campaign.  And, quite honestly, I now have zero interest in playing this title on-line after the disappointment of the campaign.Why?  Well...It was just plain cheesy.They tried to cram too many things into it.  Meaning, you fly a chopper, an SR22, operate several vehicle-mounted guns, different carry guns and I can't even remember all what else, but the problem is the way they only have you do each of those for a very short time.  Hardly enough to catch on to it before they switch you to something else.  I don't know, maybe they are catering to people's A.D.D.  I found it annoying.  Not much of what you get to do is really all that fun and even when it is (flying the choppers) it doesn't last long at all.The best graphics / action / scenes are the cut scenes.  Pretty much what you saw in the ads.  Forget about repelling like they showed i the ad and like you do in Rainbow Six.  Yea, you do that once or twice here.It was a very short campaign. reviewText: It seems interesting how much Call of Duty has grown from the original, yet at the same time, some of the mechanics that had made the series so popular are still alive in their latest release from Treyarch, Call of Duty: Black Ops. I'm moreso of a casual gamer, and since I'm certain most of the reviews are by outright gamers whom always get the latest FPS (first person shooter) games, I hope I can provide a different perspective.First, I can say I've played most of the Call of Duty series, but wasn't really "hooked" until Modern Warfare came out. I loved the current yet slightly futuristic gameplay of it; the storyline was, for a FPS, amazing. The game mechanics were great. But, I can say I didn't really try out the multiplayer aspect of the series until Modern Warfare 2, which I purchased for the PS3 on release. MW2 was notably geared towards its multiplayer, offering a decent but incredibly short single-player, so I decided to suck it up and play multiplayer, and let me say, I was hooked. There were so many failed aspects to MW2 multiplayer, yet for me, it didn't compete with the absolute wins of multiplayer. It was fun, and it was visually amazing. That being said, its biggest setbacks for me were lag/glitching (peer-to-peer gaming I still don't think is the way to go for FPS), and cheap hacks that never fixed (so, the biggest setback was the lack of support by Infinity Ward).Developer Treyarch seems to have listened to the gaming community, and has made an excellent effort to bring an excellent gaming experience. Here's my personal veiwpoints:*Graphics: Overall, the graphics are still a stunning next-gen presentation, but as many have noted, they lack slightly compared to the polish of MW2. Namely, there is jaggedness in much of the visuals, although I think the scenery settings are more robust than MW2, which was purposely scarce of scenery objects overall. Online is also slightly worse, but after playing for a few hours, its not really even noticeable. Not knowing the specifics, the engine seems to be far more similar to BFBC2 than MW2, I actually think a lot of Black Ops is really an in-between of those two games (saying this will probably get me flak from both communities, but it's just my opinion).*Sound: I thought the sound was overall very good in Black Ops, I love that it asks for your sound setup type. I thought MW2 had "better" sound, but it was more theatrical. The reality is, most of the SMGs sound like firecrackers in the game, but its also somewhat more realistic than the roaring "boom boom boom" every gun would make in MW2.*Single-player: I don't believe the storyline to be as great as MW, but it's certainly an interesting take, and I applaud them for the effort. The gameplay is good, but you'll find the AI to be lacking, particularly on the enemy side, making it slightly less-than-believable.*Zombies: A welcome addition; essentially worth it on its own, and for being included in the game makes it a great bonus.*Multiplayer: The meat of the game resides here in multiplayer. First thing to note is the small-scale of the maps. Teryarch seemed to want less of a "campers" paradise, although there are plenty of spots to take cover in, you won't be running for a minute only to be sniped and have to do it all over again. I think the many places for cover are well suited, and even without hardened perk, bullets can go through much of cover, an aspect I enjoy for being more realistic. I would say people are a little too difficult to kill sometimes, but as usual the "hardcore" mode provides a much more realistic representation.Some of my favorite aspects have been the removal of commando and danger close perks, the "weakening" of quick-scoping (sniper rifles can still be used quite successfully, even in close combat, but requires more skill in Black Ops), and fun maps (although it'd be great to see more, and some larger maps would be great additions as well).There are several issues I will point out about the game. First and most importantly, while there was much hype about the end of glitches and lag, it still runs rampant in the game (in my experience, the first two days were great, and has gone downhill since). This means its anybody's guess if you will actually hit the person you're shooting at, providing random advantages to different users; some games I can easily skate to a 20+/2 K/D ratio, many of my kills even I'll admit were less than fair, while others I'll be unable to kill anyone, despite shooting point-blank. I haven't had too many issues with disconnections/host migration, but I'd say it's close to as frequent as MW2. Knifing is currently somewhat of a guess/luck as well, as many times I'll see others or myself go flying by the person they're knifing, essentially knifing the air even though the guy hasn't moved, only to wind up being knifed yourself. While there is no "commando" in the game, having the ballistic knife out significantly improves the speed and ability to melee somebody.The largest thing I can do is have a "wait and see" attitude; I've heard Treyarch is more responsive to the community and patching, so hopefully they will improve gameplay (I don't expect perfect, but sometimes it can be ridiculous how off it is).*Multiplayer Training/Practice: Wow, I wish MW2 had this! Seriously, to me this is such a welcome addition, I just wish I had been able to use something like it in the past. When I first made the multiplayer leap in MW2, I went with trepidation that I would be slaughtered, and screamed at for being a n00b. Well, all those things happened. Multiplayer, for the first time you try it, is very different from an idiotic AI in single-player campaign modes (don't get me wrong, there's still plenty of idiots). The goals are very different, and thus playing is ultimately very different. Well, if you were hesitant to make that jump into multiplayer, Black Ops provides the ability to practice against AI of varying difficulty, some of which I found to be even better AI than in campaign mode (still stupid, but it does the trick, starting off very stupid at beginner difficulty, great for learning).*Overall: The game is excellent, albeit with its shortcomings. I hope they patch the flaws, that will really prove to the lifespan of the game for me. If you are on the fence, new to Call of Duty or online gameplay, this one is truly the one to get, since it has most of the best aspects of the series, and many improvements.I really would give this something along the lines of 4.4/5.0 or 8.9/10 if I could.Feel free to ask me questions in the comments section, I will try to check back, and even update if patches resolve the issues. I purchased this pre-order here on Amazon, and it was, as usual, a great experience.
summary: Another great release, some setbacks, but worth getting

reviewText: Despite mixed reviews, I took a lead-of-faith and got this game anyways. Being a long-time fan of COD series, I thoroughly-enjoyed MW and MW2 and felt confident about this game from a single-player perspective. I am glad to say I was NOT disappointed.Being primarily a fan of single-player/campaign games, I found this game to be very well-crafted and well-paced. There is a good mixture of varying gaming elements such as vehicles, turrets, and the typical on-foot FPS action. Controls are slick and smooth as you would expect from a COD title. The plot was actually a pleasant surprise in that it is much more cohesive than MW or MW2; I found it to be much easier to follow despite several twists and turns. Clocking in at around 8 hours, I found it to be just right in terms of overall length; you will find no fillers here, as each mission/stage is designed extremely well.Now for multiplayer -- Having invested many many hours into MW, MW2, WaW, and BFBC2 online, I consider myself not a great but decent, experienced player who is familiar with the variety of games that's been offered out there. After a few hours of playing online, I found multiplayer in BO to be disappointing. Fans of the series are likely to see it as a very slightly-modified MW2. There are some minor enhancements but the overall gameplay is flawed in certain aspects. One example is match-making; when starting out at Level 1, you are required to endure many hours of humiliation by those who have nothing better to do but skip school and play this game all day long and talk trash. Yes I'm talking about the Level 40+ folks. In 10 or so matches within a span of 1 hour, I was matched up against less than 5 players (total in all matches) who were ranked less than 10; this means 90% of the players are far more superior in their perks and weaponry than me, and I stood no chance whatsoever. This is a significant flaw that I cannot understand; developers should know how to match similarly-ranked players together by now. I would rather be kicked to the lobby if there are no players with a rank that is somewhat close to mine (which would be hard to believe given there are always thousands of players online), than to be destroyed by players who make it their life's mission to humiliate others. In my opinion, this match-making flaw is inexcusable, and coupled with lack of depth and variety such as the "Rush" mode in BFBC2, I sadly cannot find any entertainment value here.In my opinion, this game is worthwhile for its single-player but definitely NOT for multiplayer. Try at your own risk!
summary: Single player - short but sweet (4-stars), multiplayer - flawed (2-stars)

reviewText: I play all kinds of games but spend a majority of my time playing first-person shooters online and since November of last year, that has been almost exclusively Black Ops.  I have logged 425 hours of online play on Black Ops and after seeing the 3 star-rating on here when games that suck are getting 4 stars or better, I thought I'd put in my 2 cents.  Most of the negative reviews revolve around minor issues that haven't been a problem for a long time or they have been written by Dice fanboys.Like I said, online is where I spend my time but I have run through the campaign a couple of times.  It's short but it's fun.  I like the story and you don't get bogged down with long cutscenes.The online play for me is unsurpassed.  I typically load out with an SMG or AR anyway so the fact that the best selection of weapons are in these two classes fits perfect.  Almost all perks have a counter-perk, if you will.  No one perk has a significant advantage over the other.  For the most part, no one gun is vastly superior to other guns.  It's the most balanced FPS I have played.  The fact that you can't quick-scope in this game is worth the price-tag alone.The COD cash system to purchase attachments and perks is ideal.  On MW2, for example, you had to go out and kill 25 guys with a silencer to get the motion sensor.  I don't run silencer but I wouldn't mind running motion sensor.  I like the freedom of being able to choose my load out rather than having to accomplish tasks with attachments I don't care about.  Same goes for perks.  Maps are just the right size and well-laid out for each type of playerAnyway, this isn't a very well-thought-out or well-written review but I feel like this game is waaaay underrated on here so I wanted to state my opinion.  Take it for what it's worth.  I don't even know why I'm bothering considering it's already the best-selling video game of all time.

I'll admit that I had no plans on buying or even playing Call of Duty: Black Ops. I only own the game because it was given to me as a Christmas present. The series has it's fans and it's detractors and seems to incite so much heated debate between the two groups. Personally my main reason for avoiding Black Ops was that I felt the series had grown stagnant and offered very little new experiences from game to game. To some extent the same can be said here. If you're reading this review and have never played a Call of Duty game, you'll be amazed by Black Ops. If you have played CoD before then be prepared to take a familiar journey, albeit still a quality one.Single-player Experience:Expect the single player campaign to last you about 7-10 hours depending on the skill of the player and the difficulty level. The storyline is all Call of Duty - a continent hoping affair that takes you from the jungles of Vietnam to the frozen tundra of Russia. The story places you in the roles of several characters but mainly as Alex Mason. The game is set during the Cold War/Vietnam War era of the 1960s. When you start the game Mason is strapped to a chair and is being interrogated by parties unknown. Each level in Black Ops is really a flashback that Mason is reliving.Personally I found the story to be a bit confusing. It's almost like the movie Inception at times - very complex and if you don't pay attention for a moment you'll miss out on a tidbit of important information. The confusion is enhanced with the chaotic graphical presentation of the cut-scenes. All that said the missions are generally very enjoyable and offer a fair bit of variety. True to form, Treyarch vary things up by including vehicle segments that are on a scale not seen before in a Call of Duty game. These are very fun segments that are a nice break from the standard run-and-gun gameplay.The graphics are a mixed bag. I had the chance to play Black Ops on a friends PC using nearly maxed settings and it's a sight to behold. Not Crysis but very, very crisp graphics. On the PS3 the graphics aren't so polished but still generally good. There are occasions where the game has some muddy/blurry graphics. Textures on vehicles for example are generally poor. We all know that given the right developer the PS3 can do much better. But this is a multi-platform game and it does show in comparison to some PS3 exclusives.Multi-player Experience:Let's face it, multi-player is why people buy Call of Duty games. It seems that each new iteration of CoD features the same 5-10 hour single player campaign and loads of attention to the multi-player. The same can be said here. New maps, new Perks, new Kill-streak rewards and new modifications. This time around the name of the game is customization. As you progress through the multi-player portion of Black Ops you'll unlock more and more ways to customize your character. Only instead of solely relying on rank based rewards, Black Ops uses and in-game currency to allow you to modify your character and weapons. It's a fantastic system that streamlines the gameplay greatly.So say for example you reach level 24 (Lieutenant) and finally unlock the AUG you've had you're eye on. In CoD's past you would have needed to unlock the weapons attachments by racking up kills. So if you wanted that ACOG scope you knew you needed to get a set number of kills. That system has been replaced. Now, once you unlock a weapon you have instant access to all of it's attachments as long as you can pay for them. A red-dot sight you say - $1000 credits and it's yours. No fussing with iron sights or any other attachments that you don't care for. The same system is in place that allows you to customize the camouflage pattern of your gun and even create your own emblems that are displayed prominently. It's a fun, efficient and addictive system.Sadly I haven't noticed any new online game modes besides the tried and true CoD favorites. Maps are thankfully very good and offer a nice variety of environments.Online Issues:Before I ever popped CoD into my PS3 my plans were almost derailed by the amount of complaints regarding the online stability of Black Ops. I'm happy to say that thus far I've found these reports to be greatly exaggerated. That's not to say that I don't believe what some folks are saying - just that I've experienced very few problems online myself with Black Ops. There are occasional disconnects and games where the host cannot be migrated but that has been a small percentage of the many, many rounds I've played online.One of my major complaints with the CoD series is the balancing issues that continue to plague the series. There are rounds where teams are simply not accurately balanced thus leading to very one-sided victories. It seems that given the stat tracking already built into the game it would be easy to implement a load balancing algorithm to more evenly split teams up.All in all, Black Ops is another quality entry in the dominant FPS genre. While the game doesn't offer much innovation it does offer very approachable gameplay, competent graphics and an addictive online mode. Good but certainly not great. Black Ops is worth checking out.
summary: Better Than Expected - Online Issues Severely Over-hyped

reviewText: Great information found on COD Wikipedia.Call of Duty: Black Ops is a first-person shooter video game developed by Treyarch, published by Activision and released on November 9, 2010. Officially announced on April 30, 2010, the game is the seventh installment of the Call of Duty series and the third game in the series to be developed by Treyarch. It is a sequel to the developer's previous title in the series, Call of Duty: World at War. It is the first Call of Duty title set during the Cold War era.Multiplayer:The online multiplayer mode of Black Ops keeps experience points and unlockable reward system that has been kept since Call of Duty 4. The game's multiplayer "Create-a-Class 2.0" allows enhanced personalization with appearance items as well as upgradable perks weapons will be customizable with clan tag writing, emblems, attachments and camouflage painting. There is more than one style for an attachment, which allows for a lot more personalized weaponry; for example, the player can choose between a Red Dot Sight or a Reflex Sight, both of which share the same traits only visually look different. Character models will depend on the first tier perk instead of the weapon's type. Furthermore, face paints can be unlocked.A currency system has been implemented so you can buy weapons, accessories and clothes. You can gamble with their "COD Points" in a free-for-all based playlist called "Wager Match", which is composed of four game modes. Time limited objectives known as "Contracts" can be purchased to gain more currency and experience points. New custom killstreak rewards include RC explosive cars, guided missiles and controllable attack helicopters. For the first time in the series, clips from online gameplay can be recorded so expect to flood youtube. Players will be able to play alone or with friends against AI opponents in "Combat Training" with a separate progression system.Story Mode:You take the role of various characters during the single-player campaign. The playable characters are special forces operatives conducting black operations behind enemy lines. All the missions features a series of objectives that are displayed on the heads-up display, which marks the direction and distance towards and from such objectives. The player is accompanied by friendly troops who cannot be issued orders.Although primarily a first-person shooter, the player will get to pilot a Hind helicopter and guide friendly troops from an SR-71 Blackbird reconnaissance aircraft. The cinematic moments are great and remind me of the quality of the Uncharted cinematics.The game is simply amazing...

This game has WAY too much hype. Sorry for you fanboys. I preordered this, thinking this would be a new revolution of Call of Duty. Like all the other Call of Dutys... same game, different guns. They made MINOR adjustments by adding the "currency" system, which I'd prefer, but it's nothing to go nuts over. Yeah, you get a bit more customization, but the gameplay... exact same. Although, I must admit, it is MUCH more balanced than Modern Warfare 2. However, I found myself extremely bored after my first prestige. It's the same thing over and over... kill, kill, die, kill, die, die, kill, kill, etc. It just needs some.. variety, and Treyarch AND Activision seem to not understand that... but what does it matter? They're making a fortune off of your money. Eventually, people will come to their senses, but here's my ratings for the game.Campaign: 8.5/10- Like many people have said, it's a GREAT campaign, if not the best. There's a great story and interesting characters and those great Call of Duty action moments. However, some parts seemed sort of thrown together and it tends to get pretty predictive. The voice acting was not very intense, unlike previous ones.Fun: 8/10- At first, it feels like a totally new Call of Duty. You'll be excited to unlock everything and show off your tag to other people and what not, but trust me, it dulls out eventually.Multiplayer: 6/10- Everyone buys these games for the multiplayer. They don't want to constantly be interrupted by host connections failures. New players don't want to face a team full of level 8 prestiges, while their team consists of non-prestiged players (terrible matchmaking). The game is rated M. It's not meant to be swarmed with little children talking smack over a microphone. The only reason this rating isn't a 3/10 is because they've got TONS of multiplayer modes, and if you're lucky enough to get a mature group to play with, it can be loads of fun, but that won't happen too often.Graphics: 7/10- Yeah, everyone always says gameplay is more important than than graphics, which is true, but when you have repetitive, boring gameplay, paired with PS2 graphics, it doesn't really help... C'mon Treyarch it's 2010 (when released), those are surely not 1080p graphics like you claim.Zombies: 10/10- I mean c'mon... it's zombies..Overall, this is an OKAY game. Wait for it to drop to at most $30, it's not worth anything more. As for the "Vietnam" theme it's based off of, if you truly want a good Vietnam feel for an FPS, I highly recommend Bad Company 2's Vietnam expansion. Hope this helps SOMEONE make up their mind.

There really isn't much teamwork in COD, you can try to hold down an area together, but a well placed grenade could remedy that, you can revive fallen players, but that's the extent of the teamwork.

I'll start off by saying I think the last couple of Treyarch games have been far superior to the Modern Warfare games (although I love the original COD:MW). This game takes all the strengths of previous games and capitalizes on them while making a few great-yet-minor tweaks to improve the overall gameplay experience. The single player campaign is awesome, if somewhat confusing at times. Chewing up the Vietnamese coast in a PT boat while "Sympathy for the Devil" plays in the background? It doesn't get any more awesome than that. MP is awesome as always, I love the in-game economy for upgrading weapons and systems. Lets you get what you want and ignore what you don't. Overall the game isn't innovative, but frankly it doesn't set out to be. It's a continuation of what we know and love with minor improvements, making it overall the best COD game to date. People are too hard on it just because the improvements, at this point, are only incremental. There is NO way this is a 3-star game, as current reviews suggest. This game is getting poor reviews only because of where it is in the franchise's evolutionary progress (the tail end--following nearly perfected predecessors), which is a shame.

reviewText: Little intro: I'm relatively new to multiplayer FPS and my kid talked me into getting BBC2 about 3 mos ago...I, of course sucked at it at first and immediately hated it. I was getting killed/sniped/knifed every 10 sec or so until she gave me a few pointers (don't be Rambo, don't run around in the open, work with your team, etc..) to which I eventually became better and ending up loving the game.So Black Ops comes out and I figure, hey I should like this too, right? WRONG. Of course, I immediately sucked at it too and hated it in the beginning because I was getting killed/sniped/knifed (this time every 5 sec) but figured I just needed to learn the mechanics of this game before writing it off like I was about to do with BBC2. Well, I gave it a couple weeks but I found myself popping in BBC2 more often than Black Ops so I ended up trading it back in yesterday.Things I Liked: I did like the character/weapon customization aspects of the multiplayer game and the single player campaign was pretty good but very short and very linear. I think I liked and played the zombie mini-game the most come to think of it.Things I did not like: Connectivity issues-I can't be certain that it was the game's servers or my connection but I had a hell of a time getting & staying connected..very frustrating. What really killed it for me was the multiplayer maps..they are WAY TOO SMALL for that many players!! You cannot turn around without bumping into someone and subsequently getting knifed. The 'Nuke Town' map comes to  mind. Also the action seems way too fast which makes it very 'arcade-ish' and ends up taking away from the realism for me at least (not that there aren't issues like that in BBC2 mind you).Anyway, hope you read all these reviews with a grain of salt...no way is this game either a 1-star turd or 5-star Holy grail, its somewhere safely in the middle. You could definately do worse but for me, I'm hoping the new BBC2 Vietnam DLC (which is awesome btw and well worth $10) will tide me over until HomeFront comes out in March :)

When MW2 came out, I lived on that game! My friends and I got online together and played every for hours...like...30 days of non stop gaming lol. It was highly addictive, even with the faults. With Black Ops, the whole feel is just cartoony and can only be played one way.With MW2, you could run and gun, camp, play with the shield, snipe, etc...In Black Ops, it has completely taken out sniping. Asides from 1 map, every map has the same close feel to it. It's great for running and gunning sloppy action, but me and my friends definitely enjoy the option to sit back and snipe and relax some. The maps are poorly designed in my opinion.Also, every gun is the same pretty much. It's nice working your way up the levels to get better and better weapons. With BO's...the guns are so evenly balances, it takes all the fun out of leveling up. And since you can't snipe...there goes the drive to get new classes by prestiging.Oh, and let's not forget about the perks and the rediculous challenges to get Pro versions of them. Lots of people don't want to play the different game modes...but we have to if we want to complete the challenges to unlock the pro perk. It's just silly and annoying. Why would anyone want to keep doing that when they prestige?I just purchased World at War, and it's amazing how great the maps and graphics are in that. It's light years better than black ops. reviewText: First of all ANYONE who says they hate black ops please go back to the arcadish, Noobtubing, Cheesykilling ways of MW2.  I love MW2 as well as any MMO games but with competitive games comes lazy people who want to look better than they are and they exploit the game to appear godly.  In black ops grenades dont kill you as often,  Noobtubing is almost a nonissue.  You occasionally see someone running around with the grenade launcher attachment but its alot easier for them to miss or survive those cheap kills with the appropriate perks.Black ops is for people with skill in shooting, running and hiding.  If you have none of those stay away from this game and go back to MW2.Main story is interesting and a nice little distraction from from the main focus of the game which would be the Multiplayer aspect.Multiplayer is tons better than MW2 mostly because there are 3 types of games you can play in multiplayer.  Basic black ops multiplayer with FFA, Domination, HQs Team Deathmatch etc.  Then two types of Zombie action.  The zombies we all know from World at War is back and just as good and lastly Black ops Arcade which is like a combination of contra and zombies which can be alot of fun if you are tired of the other two.There is a theatre option were you can make movies of recent games you were in and show off your best kills (or your worst deaths lol) and show it off to your friends.For those of you who were godly in MW2 but cant seem to hold your own in multiplayer you can always do the training mode where you pretty much play against bots (the computer) and improve your skills til you are brave enough to take on other people.  But i dont advise this for those of you who are green to the COD series and competitive multiplayer shooters because bots have some serious accuracy and most humans as we all know dont. lolOverall get this game if you love a challenge and want to be interested the entire time you grind through levels.  There is tons of things to do in black ops.  Those who gives this game bad reviews needs to go back to MW2 because they are obviously the type of players who are used to the easy kills of MW2 and cant hack it with a big boy game.

reviewText: Single player mode is fun, but the story is pretty scattered and considering they spent all this money on voice talent, you'd think that some of that would go towards a storyline that was somewhat more thought out and put together. I finished the single player campaign in about 7 hours or so - completely anti-climactic ending. More than once I would be killed over and over again in places where it simply isn't clear what you're supposed to be doing. Do I run and jump? Do I slingshot this flaming ball of fire directly above the target or on the target itself? There definitely should be some more intuitive hints for the player because it puts a serious dent in the action and fluidity of this game.There's also more than a few glitches that I wouldn't expect from a game at this level (and genre maturity). Characters running in and out of walls, load screens that are all white, trophy notifications that show up during a blank load screen and disappearing before you get a chance to read them.Multi-player is more fun, as usual, but not perfect. I have a 20Mb package from Comcast which means a steady 9-10Mbs connection and I still get instances of characters magically moving from a far location to right next to you and shooting you in the face.Overall, however, the gameplay is fun, some interesting locations and you do have some pretty cool weaponry to play with in this version, like remote control cars and control of your own gunship. There's not much different from Modern Warfare 1&2 but then again, there probably doesn't need to be anything different.
summary: Nothing New To the COD/MW Franchise, Good Fun Though.

reviewText: This is a review for the PS3 version.  First off this game has had many bugs in both the campaign and multiplayer games on the PS3.  I don't know if the Xbox had the same problems.  I got the game the day it came out since it released on my birthday.The campaign was just like any other COD game but it was not as fun as MW2.  It probably only took like 5 or 6 hours to complete.  There weren't any sniping missions but I did like the mission with the satellite infrared view while you direct your soldiers.  There were also many times where the game froze loading the campaign also.  I really hope Treyarch does a better job on MW2.Regarding the multiplayer game, my PS3 is one of the few that has a problem loading up the Find Match screen that shows Core, Barebones, Hardcore, or Prestige.  And it is not my PS3 because it has been rock solid for the few years I've owned it.  When the game first loads up, all the choices are greyed out and I cannot choose any of them.  So I have to wait 5 mins before any of them become selectable.  This is VERY annoying.  I'm not sure why it does this, it is not the copy of the game because I even went and exchanged the disc for a new one from Game Stop and it continues to do this.  It is obviously something between my model PS3 and the Treyarch servers.  Every other game that I have for PS3 works perfectly online.  MW2, Killzone 2, Street Fighter, they all work perfect and load up quickly for online multiplayer.  One thing happened however for a couple weeks, after one of the many updates that the PS3 does when you turn on the game. The Find Match screen worked perfect after load up and allowed me to choose Core, Barebones, Hardcore, or Prestige, so you can imagine how happy I was!  Then there was another update a few weeks later, and it went back to being broken again and I could not choose any Core, Barebones, Hardcore, or Prestige and I now have to wait 5 mins again before it becomes selectable.  Unbelievable!!!  And the problem has nothing to do with my internet connection because I have 21mbps on Comcast and like I said all my other games work perfectly online, even MW2 and the other COD games.I don't have to go further and tell you how bad the servers are with "Migrating Host" and countless freezes loading a match.  There are hundreds of other reviews that already mention that.  One night I think I only got through a couple of complete matches because each match kept freezing or migrating host.  This is one of THE WORST games for connecting online.The actual multiplayer game is fun however, and I like the new maps in Black Ops.  But I just don't care for any of the guns except the M16, AK47 and Commando.  I've almost completed my first Prestige so I am pretty familiar with the game.  I just wish you could have a shotgun as your secondary weapon, I really don't like how they changed that part of the game.  Also, I think you should be able to re-supply claymores if you are using the Scavenger perk(like in MW2).  There is a risk using that perk because you are visible on radar and choppers can shoot you.  So why not allow you to re-supply claymores from dead bodies??  Instead of moving forward in the game, it seems that Treyarch made backward progress making this game.  Oh well, nice try Treyarch.  Maybe(hopefully) you'll get it right when you release MW3...

reviewText: I have never been all that in to the Call of Duty series.  I have said it before and I'll say it a bunch more in the future, but FPS games are not typically my preferred game.  That being said.....Black Ops was an absolute blast!  Single player campaign  is full of tense action that never lets go and the built-in soundtrack is fantastic.  The only real issue I have with it is the same issue I have with alot of FPS games: story.  While the story isn't a complete wash, I found it hard to really get in to it.  It is almost as if they were trying too hard to make it great.  While it's got some good moments, I ultimately found it far more interesting to skip the scene(s).Online is an absolute blast.  While I never played MW2, I understand that fundamentally it is the same setup with some tweaks here and there.  However, this is the bulk of the game experience and, for most people who want to own this, the reason they want it.  This is also where my biggest complaints come in.Issue #1:  Playing a match is an exercise in both patience and futility.  It takes SUCH a long time to get in to a match.  If this was the only issue, it probably wouldn't be so bad, but when you wait for (literally) half an hour in some cases to get in to a match only to be booted five minutes in or to have the match lagging so bad that it makes it almost impossible to shoot anything; something is wrong.  This really should have been addressed a while ago, but so far I have seen little improvement.....unless you want to play at 3AM (I am typically a night owl so this isn't necessarily bad for me, but if I want to play during any "normal" time....it's a crap shoot.)Issue #2:  The reason I ultimately jumped on this game was because I wanted some local multiplayer.  Split screen was fun while it lasted.  Notice I said "was".  That is because as soon as I got my patch it began requiring an internet connection to play local multiplayer.  WTF?!  I take my deck over to a friend's house who doesn't have internet.  Basically this makes the game useless to me to play with friends unless I want to hop online at home.  Come on now!  Local multiplay should never REQUIRE a connection.  If anyone knows a work-around on this please let me know in a comment because google searches have been fruitless.  In any case, though, this is a major hassle that may affect only a few of you out there, but it's worth mentioning.  If you plan to locally multiplay this title without internet....make sure you NEVER get the patch for it.Sadly, I consider each of these isues to be "star-dockers".  It hurts me to score this game lowly, but these issues are stupid to have on a game that touts its multiplayer.  I will say this though, I love this game and if these isues ever get fixed; this will be a five-star powerhouse.  Unfortunately, until that time.......

reviewText: This game was a Christmas gift for my son. He absolutely loves it. All of his friends play with him online. He can hardly put it down.

I am writing this review after 5 hours of playing time.  To that end, please realize that this should not be viewed as a comprehensive review.  I will update as I become more familiar with the product, and if you do not find this review helpful, please let me know why in the comments section.  I'll be happy to address the issue ASAP.Original Review begins here:COD: Black Ops is the third COD game I have played but the first I have owned.  I opted for Battlefield Bad Company 2 over MW2 last time around, but I am neither a COD, BF, or MoH fanboy.  I am also a professional software tester, and while that doesn't lend more inherent weight to my opinions, I hope it lets you know where I'm coming from in a review.  For a game to be enjoyable to me, it has to be bug-free, smooth, and without major play imbalances.  Each of these three types of issues have plagued FPS games, so I will begin with this point -- COD:BO does not suffer from any of those issues.It is the smoothest game, particularly multi-player, that I have ever played.  I have read reviews on amazon from other customers who felt exactly the opposite, so I'm tempted to think that's an internet issue.  I have the fastest connection possible, and I can tell you without doubt that it is much, much smoother than anything else I've played in the FPS realm for PS3 (or even PC, for that matter).Graphics: Really, really, really good -- but not perfect.  This doesn't bother me, even a little.Multiplayer:Good gun balance but a bit of a learning curve.  I'm an old-school PC FPS guy, so I still don't have my stick reflexes worked out.  Melee attacks seem to have minimal "suck-in" effect (as opposed to, say, Gears of War) but I do wish the melee attack animations were a little more visually appealing.  I haven't encountered any overpowered weapons yet, which is a huge plus.  This game will *not*, however, work well for folks who like the objective-based squad play of BFBC2.  If you want that out of this game, it isn't there -- at least not within five hours of gameplay.  Maybe one of the unlocked modes will suffice -- I just simply can't say that yet.The unlockable system is great.  It's vastly superior to anything else out there right now.Single Player: Beautiful and engaging from the first moments.  I haven't played very far into it, so I'll leave it at that for now.  Major gaming review sites seemed to think very highly of the story line, though, so I'd recommend checking around for some of those reviews.Training Mode: Honestly, this is a stroke of genius.  Thank you, Treyarch.  Thank you.  You can actually learn the multiplayer maps before you play them now.  This is the most useful tool I've seen included for a gamer because it lessens the learning curve.Critiques: Spawning in multiplayer can be bad.  Sometimes you will spawn in as an enemy runs around the corner and pegs you while you try to figure out which way is up.  The upside here is that camping choke-points off of spawn is virtually impossible (for the 'attacker') due to each map's design.  The maps are smaller than I expected, but larger maps may have been too much to ask for.Overall: I highly recommend this game so far, and I also would submit that anyone experiencing "frame rate issues" in multi is instead suffering from a subpar internet connection.  If you aren't a diehard of any previous shooter, this one will do very nicely for you.  If you love BFBC2 and want something similar, hold off.  If you love MW2, you may still prefer it.  I'm not sure what to say for MoH because the critic reviews have been so negative about it that I didn't put any eggs in that basket at all.I'll be updating this review as we go.  Good luck, and God bless!***First Edit*** This game is just crazy fun in multi.  I haven't spent any time in single player due to how fun multi is.  There are issues -- there's no real reason to play with anything other than an assault rifle (famas or galil, usually) except for novelty.  Certain killstreaks are virtually useless against experienced players (planes should be shot down 5 seconds after they're up if you're playing someone who knows what they're doing).  Spawns are as good as they can be due to map size and game style.  You *will* be spawn killed once in a great while.  That being said, it's like crack.  You won't be able to stop playing.

Call of Duty Black Ops is Treyarch's newest entry into the Call of Duty Franchise. Their last entry gave birth to one of the best mini games in video game history Nazi Zombies. What would this one have to offer? Well plenty of content that's for sure. Let me start out by talking about the campaign.The story is a well written narrative that shows the life of a CIA operative named Alex Mason. You also take over two other soldiers during the campaign, but a majority of the time is spent looking through Mason's eyes. There are twists and turns abound as the story is rather complex for a  Call of Duty game.  It appears that Call of Duty has moved past using historical battles in their games because this one takes a lot of historical privileges to tell it's tale. That's not a bad thing necessarily, but I miss the days of playing historical moments.The level design is rather well done, but the campaign does fail to grab you right away. The narrative has to develop first then it really kicks in gear. It has a lot of intricacies in both story and actual gameplay to be a step above most. The voice acting is excellent, but I do wish there were some more cut scenes to enhance the movie-like feel that they are striving for. The graphics are decent, but they feel like a step down from how good Modern Warfare 2 looked. Your AI brothers in arms are as stupid as they come. They allow enemies to run right by them and kill you while you're reloading. This added to the terrible number of respawing enemies lead to many moments of anger while I tried to beat the campaign in Hardened difficulty. There were times I had to run to the check point because the enemies just kept spawning. I had to lower the difficulty it angered me so much.This game does involve more gore then the previous games as there are many times when your enemies skull is exposed. These moments seem to add some grittiness to the game that really does help the cold war feel. There are many locations to explore in the campaign and it will easily last 6 to 8  hours to complete. There are also some vehicle missions that add some variety. Overall the campaign had a great story, but some technical issues kept it from being spectacular.Zombies is back in this installment as well. You get two maps right on the disc, which is awesome. They both add some new features like the pulse, and freeze gun, along with all the weapons from the campaign. No MG42 in this one but at least the Ray Gun made the cut. These new weapons are powerful enough though so don't worry about killing those Zombies. Also now when you are playing single player you are allowed to buy Quick Revive to revive yourself with four times. It really helps out those people who only play by themselves. These maps are great and I'm going to put a lot of time into them as I know most of you will. They added just enough to keep it fresh while leaving the spirit of the original levels intact.  If you buy the hardened edition you also get the four original maps with the new weapons and updated graphics. The old maps now seem harder so you better buckle down to get to your old high score.Another great add on is Black Ops Arcade. You fight hoards of zombies from an over the top view. It plays like Commandoes on the NES and is a great extra mode that I'm sure they will develop further with the next map pack. Also "Zork" the old text based game is included in full. Assuming you can find it.The multiplayer plays a lot like Modern Warfare 2 but has new ways to get your weapons. When you rank up you don't unlock weapons. You gain the ability to buy them using your XP points. It really makes you think about how you spend your money, or you can bet it all in one match hoping you finish in the top 3. I have never used this betting game mode but I hear it's rather addicting.Call of Duty Black Ops is a great installment especially considering all you get on one disc. The multiplayer is tweaked to add more excitement, the campaign is a conspiracy tale that won't let go, Black Ops Arcade is a great new mini game, and classic zombies is back. Not many games give you this much content on one disc. I'm not usually one who puts Call of Duty in the running for Game of the Year, but this time it's worthy of it.
summary: A Tale of Espionage in the Cold War Era

reviewText: I was cautious upon buying Black Ops, mostly due to my reputation of the original Modern Warfare. I bought the original Modern Warfare a few months ago, and it was decent, but was still a letdown. The campaign was fun, but the competitive multiplayer was terrible, with unbalanced gameplay, and mediocre maps. Since I figured MW2 would be the same (they share titles), I skipped it, and went on to Black Ops. So, was Black Ops another letdown, or was it fun, enjoyable, and balanced?Black Ops is some of the most fun I've had in a video game for a long while, and even that might be an understatement.Not that it's perfect; the campaign leaves much to be desired. While MW1 had terrible multiplayer, the campaign was a blast. The campaign in Black Ops, however, is a boring and bland experience. The story didn't grab me and pull me in like in MW1. After I completed the Vorkuta level, I just gave up on it.None of these problems carry over to the online componet of the game, however. This is some of the most engrossing, action-packed competitive multiplayer on the planet, and it's complemented with a host of features, such as the groundbreaking Wager and Theater modes, fantastic maps, and plenty of unlockable weapons, attachments, camoflouge, face paint, perks, equipment, killstreak rewards... I could go on and on.The variety of game modes at your disposal is staggering. My two personal favorites are Domination (capture three flags. Earn points for holding them) and Sabotage (A neutral bomb is placed in the middle of the map. Grab the bomb, and plant it in the enemy base within the time limit). If these modes don't catch your fancy, you also have game modes such as team deathmatch, free-for-all, demolition, etc.Wager match is another cool feature. After every match, you gain a type of currency called CoD points. You can use these points to buy new weapons and gear, or you can gamble with them in Wager match. There are four game modes in Wager match, and they are all unique twists on free-for-all. One in the Chamber is a mode where you are restricted to a pistol. You start out with a bullet and three lives. You recieve one bullet after each kill. This is by far the most tense of the four, and is as hard as it is fun. Sticks and Stones has you equiped with an explosive crossbow, and knife, and a tomahawk. Tomahawk kills reset an enemies score to zero. This mode is fun, but not quite as appealing as the other three modes.The last two are the best. Gun game (my favorite) has you starting out with a python. With each kill, you get a different gun. Knife kills demote players to their previous weapon. The first person to get a kill with every weapon wins. This is a tense and rewarding mode, and the best of the four. And finally, Sharpshooter startes you out with a weapon. Weapons switch every 45 seconds, and kill streakes earn you perks. Highest scoring player wins. This mode is very similar to Gun game, but is still entertaining.Remember, you're gambling in these modes, so it costs a certain amount of Cod points to play. You can select between low, medium, and high buy-in fees; the higher the amount paid, the bigger the reward.Another feature worth mentioning are contracts. You can pay a certain amount of CoD points to get a contract (it varies depending on the contract). A simple contract might ask you to get two kills from a far distance, while a more expensive one might ask for 11 headshots in a row with a certain sniper rifle. This system is a nice addition, but is ultimately unneseccary.And now we come to Theater mode. This might be the most groundbreaking feature Black Ops has to offer. The game saves every game you play. At any time, you can go back, rewatch a match you played, look for a cool kill, record the kill from either a first-person, third-person, or free camera perspective, save the clip, and upload it to the community to share it with friends. That is incredible. You can also pause time and take screenshots, and view the game from another players perspective.So, I've covered all of Black Ops. Or have I? Yes, there is even more. There is the epic Zombies mode.Zombies mode is exactly like it sounds: survive a horde of zombies. This doesn't exactly fit with the rest of the game, but when it is this fun, who cares? You can buy weapons on the walls with the points you earn for killing the zombies. The zombies grow in both strength and numbers as the rounds pass by, so if you have medical problems when under pressure, be sure to check with your doctor before you play.If it's not the bliss gameplay of the Zombies mode that make it fun, it's the hilarious dialogue that the characters constantly say. The mode is four player co-op, which means there are always four people saying the most hilarious things. Try the zombies mode in the pentagon for example. You have J.F.K, Robert Mcnamara, President Nixon, and Fidel Castro constantly talking. And it is flat out HILARIOUS!!!!!!!I would pay full price just for the zombies mode. I am not kidding. There are three different scenarios to fight zombies in (five, if you count Ascension and Call of the Dead, DLC maps), and each one is massive. Expect a lot of replay value in Zombies.Overall, this is one of the best games I've ever played, and certainly an impressive game. While the campaign is not that great, the multiplayer and Zombies are truly some of the most fun I've ever had. This game is an absolute must-have, whether you like zombies or competitive multiplayer action.PS: You might want to rent it if you are a solo player. This is pretty much an online focused game.
summary: An awesome Zombies mode is backed up by some of the best competitive multiplayer on the planet.

reviewText: Even after the years have passed it by, I still love this game. Not many people play online any more, but I still prefer the gameplay to MW3 and Black Ops 2. Zombies is the ultimate redeeming quality of Blk Ops.  Zombies may seem very difficult at first, since two zombie slapstakes you down, and they can occur in quick succession.  There is alot of difference between the campaign, multiplayerand zombies in terms of gameplay.  The campaign rehashes air strikes, cover techniques, quick-reflex running and gunning,and stealth attacks (which are much more prevalent).  Trearch improved graphics from World at War to be on par with MW2.There's great variety in environments, ranging from indoor, outdoor, under water, under gound and up in the air.The cut scenes are visually apealling, but you can't skip them.  The animators did an amazing job on the Russian, Nicoli,as you can see every wrinkle on his face as he's expressing his war sentiment.  The earlier parts of the story really grabyou, especially while escaping prison.  As the campaign goes on, you may tire of the story, just wanting to get onwith shooting the enemy.  There is an entirely fresh mission.  It involves controlling a stealth bomber for ground support,guiding troops, then zooming down into the troop's shoes, getting the drop on Russians, then killing, killing, killing.There is vehicular combat in the form of pontoon boats and helicopters.  The campaign is playable, and very difficulton hard difficulty.  There is a good variety of new guns, and they have different functions for campaign, multiplayer andzombies.  As always, there are pistols, sub-machine guns, assault rifles, light machine guns, sniper rifles, shotguns andexplosives.  A new addition is the explosive crossbow.  There is plenty of ammunition during the campaign, so that's notan issue.  You have alot less ammo to start with in multiplayer.  I found assault rifles with high fire rate and low recoilto be the best weapons to weild.  The multiplayer maps are pretty good.  I lost alot of stats due to the host quiting.Like any other COD, people hack it like crazy.  The bulk of my knowledge about Blk Ops concerns zombies; it's addictive, fun,frustrating, non-sensical, brutal, time-consuming and repetetive.  The waves of zombies get larger and tougher, unlessyou know a couple secrets about MOON.  You have guns available for purchase, can gamble on the ? box, and can buy perks to aidyour efforts.  The perks include speed reloading, extra health, stamina, explosive immunity, increased fire rate,quick reviving, carry extra weapon, and narrow cross hair/auto aim for heads.  You get points for every time you hit a zombie,and a whopping 130 for a stab kill.  Learning how to play zombies is like learning what not to do in order to stay alive.The game can get pretty nuts while playing online with three others.  When people run all over the place, or mess with yourstuff, it's maddening.  There's alot of etiquite involved while playing zombies.  You should give other players room,because every player needs space to work with.  After learning how the zombies chase after you, they can be predictable,and you can use it to your advantage.  Sometimes, you just have to run around, leading the zombies after you, so youcan do a 180 and polish them off.  Bullets pass through them, and rack up points.  This is important for conserving ammoin later rounds.  Playing zombies makes you paranoid, because you never know when more are going to pop out.  Alwayswatch your back.  Players without spines get in glitches, immune to attack.  People don't hack the game, though.If the host quits, the game's over.  If people quit, the connection usually gets worse.  You can press select to see receptionbars.  Sub-machine guns have a good fire rate and make you quick, but have low ammo.  Light machine guns have more ammo,but slow you down.  Don't bother with shotguns and sniper rifles in zombies.  The ray gun's powerful, but is bad for points,and can hurt you with blowback.  The reason Blk Ops is still popular is zombies.  The multiplayer community was strong untilMW3 came out.  The campaign is worth playing, but not the main ticket.  Thanks for reading.
summary: Train zombies to do your laundry.

reviewText: After reading some of the negative reviews I had to write one in defense of the game. I have not come across a lot of the problems that people claim to have encountered. Some are really absurd such as claiming that the game stops working after such and such time. That is almost impossible. It is possible that the reviewer had a game that had a scratch that made it stop at a certain point. But that is not the fault of the game. Now, I am not a COD fan boy. I am a gamer who enjoy great video games. I have COD, Battlefield and Meddle of Honor and a whole host of military type games. But I always have gone back to COD because they have great multiplayer. No, they are not realistic. Those who think that shooting a gun in COD amounts to shooting a real gun has to have his head checked. Even a ten year old can shoot a bazooka in COD. And being able to play COD does not, I repeat, does not make you a soldier. Playing a video game is one thing. Shooting a real rifle is another. What is so laughable is the comments I hear over and over in multiplayer where players call others the put-down, "camper". I've got news for them. Real soldiers camp. It is part of military strategy. Despite the idiots who "rage" during the game, it is a fun game. The only knock I have for Black Ops is that the graphics for the multiplayer does not stand up to Modern Warfare 3's. Yes, it is an older game but one map in particular looks cartoonish. Some may like the fact that it is small which renders it a run-and-gun map but it could have used more work. If you are sitting on the fence, you should get the game. It is a whole lot of fun. Just be sure you get a headphone that allows you to shut off the in-game chatter as some of the players are men and women who act like children.

reviewText: Many people will agree that Modern Warfare 3 is terrible.  So, like others, I have reverted back to playing Black Ops.  I have to say that I complained about this game when it was first released, but after dealing with the latest abortion Infinity Ward released I have a little more appreciation for this game.  Sure, it has some issues.  For starters, in multiplayer mode the spawn system is probably the worst of any CoD game I have ever played (which is all of them).  People have been spawned behind me while I was camping in a corner and vice versa (so close that I am literally sitting in their lap.) There is also a lag at times, but it is nothing compared to both Modern Warfare 2 and 3.  Because I have maxed out my prestige in multiplayer, I mostly play zombies now.  Zombies is fun and addictive, but it can be a cheap pos at times.  The mystery box will either give you good weapons throughout the game, or it will give you nothing at all.  For me, the latter is what usually happens.  I am good with using the weapons on the wall (because the mystery box usually sucks), but they are not much help in the later rounds.  There are some other problems, but not enough to call this game bad.  If you are new to Call of Duty, I would recommend Black Ops over any other game in the series (especially MW2 or 3).  I give Black Ops 3 1/2 stars because of the added zombie mode and because the multiplayer is superior as a whole compared the rest of the CoD series.

reviewText: MW2 this and MW2 that... which game is this I'm reviewing again? Look i enjoyed MW2 just as much as the next person. It is time someone said it. CoD games have been CLONES ever since MW dropped. New features(border-line gimmicks) from title to title don't negate the fact that the core game-play has remained virtually unchanged since 2007.  Let's cut to the chase;Zombies...My friends and I have spent countless hours on zombie mode in WaW (still did right up until black ops' release)and I could not be more thrilled with the new Zombie mode in Black ops. New maps, *the classic maps return with black ops weapons, The zombies are faster and stronger, new enemies make their debut, Pack-a-Punch and Perka-Colas Return! + new features have also been added to boost your odds of survival(especially when playing Solo!)...OH! and the guns are Awesome! The twist was a little predictable but it's a game not a full-length Block-buster movie. Graphics are sharp and the Action is non-stop. My friends and I finished in about 5-6 Hrs. I had a blast with it.Multi-player:Multi-player is not really my bag but like i said a CoD Game is just exactly  that... and you should know by now exactly how those play; unless you've been living under a rock for the last 3 years and somehow missed out on the juggernaut that is CoD. The new option to get two players online split-screen with one console(also in zombies) is a great idea/improvement. I am playing on a low resolution HD TV(720p) and can't distinguish much of a difference between graphics quality or frame-rate of this title and that of the last.Black Ops' Multi-Player feels a little more balanced in terms of the kill-streaks, perks and weapons available to players.The fast paced Tactical-FPS action we all know and love is still alive and well with Black ops. Get ready for more sleepless nights of fragging online with your friends!Get this title and Happy Hunting!*Hardened Edition only

reviewText: NOTE: When the game first came out, it had a LOT more bugs/problems than it does now. Thankfully, Treyarch have been consistently releasing bug fixing and balancing patches. So the game has progressively improved for the most part.I have 2 main computers that I have tried running Black Ops on:1) My desktop, only a few months old and very powerful.2) My HP Laptop which is about 2.5 years old, but is pretty powerful for a laptop (I can run most new games, albeit at lower graphics)Both are ATI/Intel combinations.On PC #1: The game runs like a charm, very few issues after the patches which fixed some crashing/freezing issues (unacceptable to have this in a released game).On PC #2: Game is actually somewhat choppy, and this is a laptop that has run every single previous version of COD very smoothly including most recently Modern Warfare 2. This is basically the same unreal engine yet it has performance issues on my laptop, I have like a weird delay when playing sometimes. It's playable, but it's not comparable to the game on my Desktop, it's like two different games.PROS:- Very few games come close to how good the CoD multiplayer experience is.- Treyarch opted for dedicated servers, after the disaster hacker infested garbage IWnet of MW2 crashed and burned miserably. This means admins and kick/ban powers, a lot less cheaters on good servers.- Game has everything you'd expect from a COD game, but the maps are a bit smaller than MW2.- Single player is better than Modern Warfare 2, and the storyline makes a lot more sense and is a lot less like a horrible Michael Bay summer blockbuster.CONS:- Optimization sucks on certain PC specs, can ruin your gameplay experience and frustrate you to no end depending how bad it is.- It's more of the same, this is Modern Warfare based in the Cold War era. Bottom line: Buy MW2 or stick with it instead of buying this game.With their default settings, Modern Warfare 2 multiplayer runs much more responsively than Black Ops multiplayer on my PC. Killing background processes and using the lowest graphics settings didn't help.My PC's specs are:AMD Phenom II X4 940 3 GHz processor2 x 2 GB DDR2 800 MHzWindows 7 64-bit2 x NVIDIA 8800GT, SLILAG is ever present in multiplayer and greatly reduces the player's chances of dodging enemy fire, even AFTER managing to get behind cover. Aiming down the sight is slow and isn't practical. Lag makes the knife a less viable weapon because your opponent almost always sees you coming. You learn to cope with the lag but in MW2 there was no perpetual state of having lag and when there was lag it wasn't this bad.I prefer the way human faces and objects like cars are rendered in MW2 than in BO. Human faces in BO look less detailed and seem "cartoony". I was disappointed with the way the game rendered JFK's face. The faces of the North Korean enemy NPCs weren't drawn well and their voices didn't seem real enough unlike the Russian NPCs voices which were good.In BO the player's view of the environment is wider and it feels almost like a third person view with the gun sight placed in the center. I prefer the narrower field of view in MW2. Most metallic objects like guns look too shiny and end up looking like plastic rather than metal.Here are some positive aspects of BO:1. The "Jungle" multiplayer map is impressive. The outdoor environment has dense vegetation, a rope bridge and elevated huts. It's the best jungle environment I've seen in FPS games so far.2. The in-game UI is polished and more intuitive than in MW2.3. You can buy gun camo to "pimp your gun". XP grinding isn't needed to buy guns, perks and attachments. A larger set of guns is available to the player than in MW2.

I guess, for evrey person the experience is different. I have a 3 year old CPU (Intel QX6700), a 2 year old motherboard (XFX 790i), a single GTX 470 and 6GB of RAM running on Windows 7 64-bit.  I installed this game over the weekend and been playing since with max setting and no problems whatsoever.  I guess I'm lucky compared to the droves of people that are having issues.  There are a lot of negative reviews - I would be angry too if it weren't working correctly on my system and I too would give a one-star, but it's working fine and I enjoy it, therefore the positive review (I'm certain my positive review will generate a "no" for being helpful but I can't rightfully ding it if it is working for me as advertised).Onto the game, I am thoroughly enjoying myself with this game.  The single player is ok and entertaining but I'm much more into the multiplayer.  It is definitely fun for me, fast paced and a welcome follow-on to modern warfare 2.  I like the fact that you can buy the perks you want, rather than waiting for each one to unlock as was the case in MW2.  Same thing with attachments.  There seems to be a balance of what you can buy and what you can unlock to keep it interesting and not overwhelming playing against players who are already leveled up significantly.  Another plus is the premade classes that you can use - as a newbie like me, that's great because I got to try out some of the perks without having to buy them and quite enjoyed the "assault" class - got a lot of kills using that Last Stand.A couple of negatives that I think they should fix - first of all, having the option to join a dedicated server or just be auto-assigned to a ranked server is nice but it needs to be fixed.  It's frustrating to be auto-assigned to a ranked server only to wait for it to load and be told "server is full".  Really???  How silly is that, then don't auto-assign me there!  MW2 didn't have that problem...why not use the same auto-assigning engine???  Just strange to me.  Also, when I join up on my friend who is in game, I wish that it would always put us on the same team, or at least give us an option.  When we are playing together, sometimes we are randomly on the same team and sometimes we are not.  Also, why can't I join up on my friend from the Steam interface like other games allow?  In multiplayer, I think the helicopter gunships are way over-powered.  At first people thought that they were hacks when the guy with gunships are getting like 50 kills and dying only a couple of times - that goes to show how dominant that helo is.  Also, when you shoot someone, sometimes you don't even know you killed them.  In MW2, there was no question when you kill someone, here, maybe its the sound effects or whatever but many times I'll waste ammo shooting at a guy to ensure I killed him.  Not sure what it is but it just doesn't feel quite right.  Minor gripes - but overall, like any newly released game, I'm sure the bugs will be ironed out - minus one star for that.Unlike other people, I'm glad that this game is on Steam.  I am on the the Steam bandwagon (at least until I see signs of it sinking) I have a portable eSata hard drive where my steam folder is on and all my Steam games and I'm able plug it into my second PC when the other is being used and visa-versa, plus I never have to worry about patching my games, disc in drive and so on - it's super convenient for me.Anyhow, the reviews on this game are mixed...mostly negative, but with high profile games such as the Call of Duty Franchise, expectations will be high.  It met my expecatations mostly, which is why I'm giving it 4-stars.  Had it exceeded my expectations, I would have given it a 5.
summary: An enjoyable experience for me despite Neg Reviews

This is the 3rd COD game I played. I started with MW2. It's a good game. Then to MW1. Now to black ops.Black Ops is developed by a different developer than the modern warfare series. I'm not really aware of any other major game franchise that pulls off something like this, having two different devs working on the same IP. The differences are subtle. Infinity Ward is more serious and somber while this game is laugh-out-loud funny. IW tends to have lousy briefings but really impressive in-game moments. Treyarch (the devs of this game) seems to place more emphasis on the writing and characters than IW. The level design isn't quite as inventive and the scripted moments are not as awe-inspiring.So, in Black Ops I found myself caring more about the plot and story compared to MW, while I was less impressed with the events that happened in the missions. When you die in MW, you get treated to a quote from a serious world leader or intellectual. In Black Ops, the missions start with this comical blacking out of information, making it literally a "black op."I tend to play games like these as RPG's, in that I pretend that I'm actually in the setting. So it's an interesting tradeoff. I would recommend going in the order I played, since what gets you at first in gaming are the in-game moments. Later on as the game formula becomes apparent, having good characters starts to matter more.This is one of the best story-driven game narratives I've ever played. I'd rank this as better than any Bioware game, even. There's a really cool Forrest Gump feeling you get playing the game, due to the retro setting. The characters are amazingly charismatic. To convince, just let me mention that one of the voice actors is none other than Gary Oldman.Another nice thing about COD games is that you never feel alone while playing the game. You always have an AI friend guiding you through the mission and yelling encouragement.I believe that this game has enough serious literary merit that it will be revisited in years to come like a classic novel.So yes, the SP is pretty incredible. That alone is worth the purchase.Now, as for the sequel, well, skip it. The sequel has some impressive moments, but is missing a lot of the playful spirit of this game.
