I am going to start off this review saying that I have played every CoD game since the original Call of Duty.  I will say that Treyarch did an amazing job trying to catch up, or even surpass the juggernaut MW and MW2.  However this game does come with some of its own problems.  Like many people have said, this game is built for consoles with PC gamers second in mind.  Personally this ticks me off considering that CoD started as a PC franchise and was ported to consoles.  Now it seems like it is a console franchise with a port to PC.  This is totally unacceptable for any studio considering that PC gaming has been around a lot longer than console gaming and in my personal opinion will be the console king for the FPS genre.  Where would the FPS genre be without one of the best original PC FPS games... Doom?With all of that said, this does not mean the game is not fun in any way.  My biggest complaint is that the controls are not as tight as they were in MW and MW2.  It will take a little bit of getting use to but not too long.  I have used a Logitech G9x for MW,MW2, and now Black Ops and I noticed a significant difference in look movement.  The multiplayer is extremely addicted as you would expect from any CoD multiplayer and Wager matches are just too much fun to pass by.  I personally like the system of CoD points as opposed to ranking up for new guns/attachments/perks/killstreaks ect.  All the maps seem to be pretty balanced with 1 or 2 exceptions.If you are a serious FPS comptetive player like myself, you should not hesitate to pick this up IF and ONLY IF you have somewhat of a beefy computer.  I have an i7 960, 12gb RAM, and 2 nVidia GTX 480s in SLI and it runs perfectly.  I know some people have complained that it requires too much in order to play but unfortunately thats the price you pay for wanting a PC game.  New games like this will continue to require bigger and better components to be able to run them. This goes back tot he reason why this is now a PC port.  Most people, especially now, don't have the financial means to build/buy a $4,000 gaming computer just to play games like this when they can buy a $300 X-Box or PS3 and play the same game.Bottom Line:  If you love fast paced FPS games, and you have a beefy gaming computer... do not pass this game up.Note:  If I were to rank the 3 major titles of PC CoD games (MW 1, MW 2, and Black Ops) it would go like this1.  Modern Warfare 12.  Black Ops3.  Modern Warfare 2Why Black Ops over MW2?  1 reason... dedicated servers.

I normally prefer the solo campaign over multiplayer due to the countless cheaters out there who are too lazy to take time and get proficient at games, so they hack their way to being "good".  However, the solo campaign in COD BO is so bug-riddled, I'm just about ready to throw in the towel on completing it.  I've had the game freeze numerous times after I'd passed several checkpoints and nearly completed levels.  It wouldn't be so bad if I could resume at a checkpoint but if the game has to be forcefully ended via task manager (as is the case for just about every freeze), you start over at the beginning of the level (or wherever you left off when you last exited the game properly)!  An "easy" work around is to frequently quit the game manually and restart again after the last checkpoint, but seriously, who wants to exit the game after every stinking checkpoint???  I bought the game eight months after release and this is the nonsense I'm dealing with???  And before anyone starts chirping "Well, you shouldn't play the game on a lousy system", not only is the system way more than sufficient to run the game, I've played through several solo campaigns of Crysis 2 and Battlefield Bad Company 2 without one single crash, ever.  And that's with all the visuals maxed out on both.  If Black Ops works flawlessly for some, I'm glad for them.  Maybe certain drivers or software elements of certain systems get along better with the game, resulting in no crashes, but there is no way I'm buying that this game isn't flawed after playing countless other games that are just as demanding or even more demanding on my system.Now the multiplayer is actually pretty fun.  Not only can you play against human opponents, it also has a training mode that lets you play "multiplayer" against CPU opponents. Granted, as you jack up the difficulty, your team members get dumber while the enemy  gets much smarter.  On the highest levels, the CPU opponents get laughably cheap, camping nonstop (yet if you try it, an enemy will quickly sneak up on you or fire a random sniper shot from some impossible far away angle and pick you off), enemies spawn at your must vulnerable spots, enemies walk right through grenade blasts and dozens of bullets while you fall from a single shot, and while the enemy spends time flanking you constantly and working as a team, your computer teammates run around aimlessly like F-Troop. After a while, you'll start thinking the human cheaters aren't so bad.  I guess that's one way to look at it.
summary: Multiplayer is fun but solo campaign is too bug riddled

This review is for the PC Version of this game -Call of Duty: Black OpsTreyarc brings us the newest Call of Duty: Black Ops which stands definitively as the console release of the year. No doubt, the incumbent has big shoes to fill after Activision's wildly successfulModern Warfare 2. Lets start with the good: dedicated servers are back! No more mid game host migration and peer-hosted 350ms+ ping games. This in an of itself should be enough to win over PC gamers.  Other pluses include a wide range of new weapons and equipment such as ballistic knifes, crossbows, attack dogs, NAPALM strikes, etc... which add some interesting new variety to game play. The multi-player maps are also very fun, my favorite being the firing range.Now for the bad: there are some huge problems with performance and general game play for PC gamers.  First of all, this game is a console game and feels like a console game. The PC port feels forced and, at times, utterly claustrophobic.  The menus don't make much sense and lag terribly. (You have to completely leave the server and the game to modify your custom classes.) The maps, which are deceivingly large, will feel smaller than a cardboard box when you spawn directly on top of the enemy team time and time again. Finally, some performance issues (namely frame rate and stuttering) are practically impossible to eliminate.I feel the graphics in Black Ops are an acquired taste. After playing Modern Warfare 2 for several months, I was immediately disappointed in the "flat" look of the textures. The environment doesn't allow half as much interaction as one would expect and the maps are often closed off and very linear. For example: in headquarters mode, there are sometimes only one or two paths to approach a given objective. Many times, you'll have to run through the streets since most of the buildings lack doorways and are not navigable.All-in-all, despite some of the big game play issues, Black Ops is a fun game which may bring back some of the old LAN party nostalgia. I hope Treyarc continues to release updates and patches which address server stability and performance issues. Overall "B+"

When people talk about Call of Duty, at least the last few installments, they often focus almost solely on the multiplayer.  As a long-time singleplayer FPS gamer on the PC however I still enjoy Call of Duty for its singleplayer content.  The original game was one of the greatest FPS games of all time if you ask me and the original Modern Warfare was another spectacular singleplayer experience.  How does Black Ops measure up based solely on singleplayer?  Poorly.First off Black Ops continues the trend of shorter and shorter singleplayer campaigns.  I would put it at about 5 hours on the harder difficulty, probably 4 or less if you play it on an easier setting.  Some people may take longer if they spend a lot of time looking around or replaying segments but overall it's not a long game.  Worse than this though is the simple fact that you have played this game before, many times, and it's starting to get a little tired.  When Modern Warfare 2 came out I felt a little creak as I started playing; it was already what I would consider an old formula and it was already time for a change.  Black Ops is not that change, Black Ops is exactly the same game with slightly different visuals.  At least World At War was a different looking time period and location with Japan in WW2, but Black Ops, despite being set in the 1960's, looks and plays exactly like Modern Warfare.  It is in essence the third Modern Warfare game in 3 years and that makes you feel every rotting piece of old gameplay with brute force.The graphics are alright, nothing amazing but pretty good on high settings.  It comes on one DVD compared to 2 DVDs for the last game but I didn't notice any drop in texture quality as a result.  Sound is pretty standard, you know what you're getting... the music used in the Vietnam sections is as cliche as possible and comes off kind of silly rather than emotional.  To be honest there isn't really much point in going over anything here because it's all the same... it's Modern Warfare, a third time, with maybe slightly less polish.  Sometimes you will get stuck on things and often times the scripting, like the AI waiting for you to reach a spot before doing something, is much more obvious.  Modern Warfare 1 and 2 hid the game's basic mechanics better is what I guess I am trying to say.  All in all though it's the same exact game, and the cobwebs are showing.PC port is decent.  All the usual control options are there and lean is back, which is nice, though honestly I am so used to "E" being my activate button now I just ignored lean and mapped it that way anyway.  Unlike the last few CoD games Anisotropic Filtering didn't seem to be on by default so I forced it on through my GPU's control panel, which worked fine.  Performance was a little worse than the last few CoD games due mostly to more being put on the CPU, a sign of poor optimization from the console versions.  Patches have supposedly fixed this but I haven't noticed much difference.  The DRM is Steamworks, which requires a one-time online activation at install and ties the game to an account to prohibit lending or selling.  It's lame and pointless on an open platform as the game will be pirated anyway, but what else is new from these clueless publishers.All in all this review is kind of superfluous.  Did you like Modern Warfare 2?  Do you want another game EXACTLY like that, only a bit rougher around the edges?  Then get this game when it hits the dollar amount you think 5 hours of that is worth.  If not, don't.
summary: CoD: Black Ops Singleplayer PC Review

reviewText: Some readers might curse me straight away but the truth is I have never played Call of Duty: Black Ops and I already have an opinion. Ive never done a review like this before but Callof duty:MW2 really stung me back in 2009 and I swore I wouldnt make the same mistake twice (remember no servers issue).I have waited for the general response first... and to me it sounds very bad for the following reasons.To truly understand my plight, you'd have to really understand the history of Call of Duty for the PC.Call Of Duty gained its reputation among hardcore FPS players for its playability and attention to detail. Along the way Call of duty has had its bumps and falls but the core mechanics of the game were still in the hands of people who understood the game.The real success of Call of Duty has come in the way of tight programming. Its accessibility (much like Counter-strike) was its tight coding and strong performance. As long as you had a decent hardware you could count on Call of Duty running very smoothly. Last years computer could still play it comfortably. This made it a multiplayer success because players could concentrate on the technical challenge of fragging each other down. When you're dealing with a mexican stand-off, the last thing you need is a stutter.Power hungry. poorly coded games dont have a long multiplayer life. They always sink.The longest standing FPS multiplayer domains have always existed around games that have been tightly coded. Counter Strike, Unreal, quake etc. These games were smooth and fluid by nature. They were born smooth.. not because it took three kids to run the system (one to spray the graphics card with Nitrous, another to wee on the fans and the third to play it with his toes while he blew ferociously at the CPU)This years Call of duty is a power hungry game which has been poorly programmed. It is simply wasteful. The software is so poorly derived and raw that your hardware needs to work twice as hard to get the same output. Now some kids will cry bloody murder! Insist that it is my responsibility to buy better hardware, but these kids are completely oblivious to the real truth.There is nothing specailly new about Call of Duty: Black Ops. Why should I pay more money for an upgrade because the prgrammers did a lazy inefficent job of mapping out the coding.Which brings me to my second point. Why should I go out and purchase a new $2000 setup for CAll of Duty: Black ops when it wasnt designed for the PC. Originally a game that was made for the PC is now a last minute port conversion. This game wasnt for us.Yes, I realize i have never played the game. I dont know if it is really fun. But at some point you have to make a stand. At some point, the stress and distaste surrounding the game makes it a futile experience.
Don't buy this game for the PC it doesn't run well even after 2 patches and gives you nothing new or exciting in FPS playing.

I am not at all an avid gamer. This was my first first person shooter I have played, so I have never had anything to compare it to. I played it to pass the time in Afghanistan. My first impressions was that there were way too many, and far too lengthy, cut scenes. They made for a decent story, although I didn't much care for having the majority of combat taking place as flashbacks. One chapter even took place as a flashback within a flashback. And I didn't like that I would switch between characters. This was also the first time I have had to reduce graphics for performance. My computer can run almost any new game on full graphics, no problem, but for whatever reason, Black Ops was a bit laggy.All negativity aside, I did enjoy it very much. The graphics, even turned down, are great, I don't know what so many people are complaining about. The voice acting was very realistic, and I instantly recognized Ed Harris. I would say cut back on the swearing, as it is unnecessary, but it actually adds to the realism, since that kind of language exists in the service. What I liked most was the variety. In one mission, you are running down the streets of Cuba, fighting off dozens of soldiers, in another, you are sneaking around in stealth, slicing throats and planting explosives. There is zip lining, skydiving, and sniping, which I loved. And there is no shortages of vehicles to operate: Cars, boats, helicopters, even the radar in the SR-71.Overall, I would recommend the game. I would say it's worth $30. I don't do multiplayer, so that doesn't factor in. Since I bought this, I have played Half Life 2 and its expansions. Despite being 8 years old, it's a much better game, but very different. I also played Sniper: Ghost Warrior, which is decent, but not enough to play again. I have played Black Ops 3 times, and I liked it each time. But it's not great. I might try another Call Of Duty sometime.-UPDATE-After upgrading from 4GB Ram to 8GB, this can run on maximum graphics very smoothly. But I don't use it as much now, since it isn't really all that replayable.

reviewText: I'll start with single player.Pros: It's long enough and has enough unique missions to make it fun. The cut scenes are decent and the story is very detailed. After you beat the game it puts you into a zombie mode that you play as JFK. Some of the levels have great graphics. There is a level in Vietnam that is just incredible. It reminded me so much of Crysis.Cons: Some levels look like they were made five years ago and I have a top of the line gaming machine. I don't understand how one map can look great and the next mission looks like something from 2005. The AI is not very difficult to play against even at the hardest difficulty. The gun selection is terrible but I guess that is what they used in the 1960's. I was just hoping for a lot more when it came to the weapons. In every mission I was having to decide between an AK47 with a scope and an AK47 with an extended clip. The biggest down side to the single player campaign is the cut scenes I enjoyed the first play through. You are forced to watch so many useless cut scenes without the ability to skip a lot of them. It really hurts the replayability of this game because there are so many cut scenes in each mission.Multiplayer - This is why I bought the gamePros - No hackers, lots of servers, ping of less than 20, and several game types to chose from. Also the guns, and kill streaks are much better once you get into multiplayer. One of my favorite things is the ability to customize your character. You get to choose the paint on your gun, paint on your face, different emblems and the list goes on. It's really cool to have a blue camo gun and blue war paint on your face as you run around. There are several dozen options of face paint and gun color. You also get to customize your emblem. The graphics are really good in multiplayer. I would rate the graphics up there with MW2 and other FPS's like Medal of Honor.Cons - servers are 18 on 18. I would have preferred the option to have bigger servers. A lot of the maps are small so I understand the 18 person limit but some bigger maps would have been nice.Some people had bug issues but apparently all those have been resolved. I never had an issue with the game in single player or multiplayer. I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants a good first person shooter and doesn't mind throwing down the $60 to get it.Also, there are 14 prestige's available. You level really fast in this game so doing a prestige is no big deal. It probably takes around five hours played to do an entire prestige.
summary: It's worth the money for multiplayer alone

reviewText: I've owned the 360 version since xmas and I decided to purchase the PC version because of dedicated servers and the keyboard/mouse controls, however, the game fully supports the 360 gamepad.The graphics are definitely better than its 360 counterpart, which is expected. The single player campaign is identical to the 360 version and is much better than the MW2 campaign (imo, of course). Also, playing with dedicated servers removes any host advantage like on the 360's multiplayer component.  The PC version, for me, is just as fun as the 360 version but even with the dedicated servers (which is a huge plus in my book), there are still some issues that really bug me.The method of finding servers (via server browser) feels really basic and antiquated. Of course  you can filter by map types, game types, empty servers, and full servers. However, there's no ability to filter by ping or region. I can overlook those issues, but what really annoys me is when I load COD: BO and click server browser (or even ranked match), COD: BO will have about a 75% chance of freezing and the only way I know how close the game when this happens is to terminate the process using task manager (ctl+alt+del).Still, once the game is loaded and I'm happily fragging away the game will occasionally freeze momentarily (about 1-2 sec) then resume. It's like I suddenly lost connection, but this feels a little different. For you programmer types, it's like the whole client decided to pause and do garbage collection. This usually results in a death unless I'm lucky enough for it to happen when no enemies are around. This freeze sucks and a fix for this should be a top priority for Treyarch, but I will tolerate it unlike the server browser freezing the game.Not to wish that this game was any more of a console port, but there are some things that are in the 360 that I wish were in the PC version:1. being able to update/create a class loadout between matches. Currently, I have to leave the server to update my classes.2. multiplayer lobbies. I'm not saying peer to peer networking like MW2, but it would be nice to have a lobby (imo) between maps. I know it's doable because valve was able to implement both lobbies and dedicated servers with the l4d series.Currently, between maps there's only a 10 second break before the next match starts. It would be nice if there was a 20 second break between maps, while in a lobby, displaying which map is next in the rotation. Additionally, the players could vote to skip the next map if the majority voted for it. Of course, this should be an option that could be set by the admin.Overall, I really enjoy the game, but there's less polish in this PC version over the 360 version. Unfortunately, while I'm sure the developers at Treyarch are a bunch of swell guys, I doubt they will fix the issues or add any features that I described above.When the game works, the multiplayer action is 10x faster and more frantic than the 360 version. It's been stated that the multiplayer population has declined since its release, but there's about 10,000-20,000 on most evenings when I'm playing. That's probably less than a quarter than the amount that's on XBOX LIVE, but it's more than enough to find a match anytime of the day at a location of your choice (provided the server browser doesn't freeze the game). At the very least, there's always Combat Training to simulate the the multiplayer experience via bots.For me, the game play is fun 5/5, but the game itself is only 2/5 due to the lack of polish and missing features that are present in the 360. If the freezing issues were fixed, then this is definitely a 4 star game in my book.

I was a little surprised at how low the ratings are for Black Ops, I've actually liked it better that Modern Warfare 2, and wonder where the venom is coming from.  Last time time it was the multiplayer, this time it seems to be something else.Yes, the game is geared more towards console players, that's the way things are today, but it's still enjoyable on the PC. The single player was much better, while the graphics are still notching up rather than making revolutionary changes.  The story is more like COD4; longer with a convoluted plot but now with a 60's Cold War setting.  As with World at War there's a couple of vehicle levels that are in some way unique from what you've done before, and as with Modern Warfare 2 lots of cool weapons to play with.  In what may be a unique twist for the series two of the characters from World at War appear; one is a major player, the other is in a bit part.  Overall the single player was killer.The Zombies mode is.....different.  If you've ever wondered what it would be like to play JFK in an abandoned Pentagon fighting off hordes of Zombies, this is your chance.And now the multiplayer...Modern Warfare 2 selected the servers for you, and the wailing and gnashing was heard round the world.  How could people form clans? How could they gather together on their favorite servers and cheat, er, play competitively?  How could people make arbitrary nonsense rules about not using rockets or using only sniper rifles?  How can admins who never say they're an admin just decide this round is a knife fight only and the next will just be pistols, and wield the almighty ban stick for logging in and not knowing what's going on?  Or just ban anyone who plays better than them or they decide they don't like?  Well, all that's back.  I actually liked the Modern Warfare 2 system better, just log in and play, only a problem if you cheat; but this is more popular for obvious reasons.While Modern Warfare 2 felt and looked a little cartoon like, Black Ops is pretty much an amped up COD4.  The maps in general have more corridors and alleys, so you have to keep your head on a swivel and watch out for enemies.  There's more variety in weapons (someday they'll run out of cool guns), and the upgrade system to me is more fun.  You still rise through levels too fast, but you earn money to buy upgrades, and there are plenty.  Some perks you gain more skill as you use them, and now you can at last (With the Warlord perk) use two attachments on the same gun.  I really don't understand the hatred about the multiplayer, but have noted most of the negative reviews were from when the game was first released and *duh* lots of people were signing up at once. I haven't had any problems with lag or slow response.My only complaints about the multiplayer is the same I've had on any COD multiplayer: the made up server rules and cheating.  I'll admit I'm just an average player; but when you play enough you know what works, that enemies normally drop with 2-3 hits from an assault rifle.  When someone comes along who is almost untouchable; they always run and never seem to slow down, knife everyone all over the map, get you at ease with endless head shots, and the only way you can drop them is several point blank hits with a light machine gun, something's up.  Heaven forbid you ever try to call one of them on their unlikely prowess, you'll never hear the end of it....It's also one thing to cheat, but if you don't like something the game allows why be so difficult about it?  I've argued for a long time they ought to allow the multiplayer server features to be customized.  You log into a server then whatever they don't like is disabled and no more headaches about so-n-so doesn't want you using Last Stand so you have to create a class without it just to please them.  Really, I play for fun, not to deal with someone's control freak obsession.  The latest thing going around is servers trying to ban people from running.  Yes running.  People are shooting at you and it's supposed to just be a fun action game but don't dare run because then the 25 year old admin living in his mother's basement will ban you for life.  Actually I ask them to do that so I won't have to worry about logging into their server again; at least there's plenty of good servers still out there.
summary: Are we playing the same game?

UPDATE (Sep. 19, 2011): I changed single player from 3/5 to 2/5When I first played the game, I was awed by the story telling, amazed by the updated multiplayer, and most off all, annoyed at how seemingly many could not get this game to run when it ran perfectly fine on my computer (no hiccups at all). If anything, my original review of (4 stars) was inflated a bit to counter act the countless 1 star reviews saying "my game does not work." However, after all this time, I still think the game deserves 2/5 for single player and 5/5 for multiplayer, which gives us and average score of 3.5/5. There has been many improvements through patches, so if you can get game for a decent price (on one of steam's Christmas sales), I would say go for it.Original Review:First of all let me say that this game requires a really good computer. I've been playing this game on a AMD Phenom II X4 955, a 1GB GeForce GTS 250, and 4GB of DDR3 ram. On my system the game runs super smooth from release day, that includes both the multiplayer and single-player. Surprisingly if you have a system that runs this game, this game is actually enjoyable. Please read on to see my thoughts.--Single Player---This game does not reflect the tried and true CoD story format as seen in many of the other games. Unlike CoD 2, CoD4, or MW2, this game pretty much follows the story of one soldier Alex Mason. What makes this unique is that the story in Black Ops, when compared to other CoD games, is actually intriguing. In other CoD games, the story only existed for the gameplay, and you never became attached to the characters your were playing (hell I can't even remember their names). However, in Black Ops you actually care about Alex Mason as you go on this roller coaster ride of his past.The story is great, interesting, and will actually last you about 6-8 hours, when compared to MW2's 3-4 hour campaign. However, the gameplay has taken a step back from MW2. The levels are predictable with the same bad guys in the same place, and your team mates AI still have issues jumping in front of your gun fire. Luckily, your team mates have better AI than the bad guys, because the bad guys are seriously pretty stupid. I cannot tell you how many times one of the bad guys came rushing in lone wolf style into the crossfire of me and my two AI team mates.I'm not saying the gameplay is bad, I'm just saying its a step back from MW2. Now your team mates feel like the ones in CoD4 and the bad guys feel like the bad guys from CoD:WaW (just with updated weapons). Also there are too many points in the game where enemies are infinitely spawning, which can make levels a tedious chore based on luck. I'm sad that Treyarch did not take a page from Infinity Ward when it comes to single player campaigns.Overall, the story is interesting and makes you feel like your inside a movie. So i give the Single Player a 2/5---Multiplayer---Luckily, Treyarch did not take a page from Infinity Ward on how to make a multiplayer game. The multiplayer is vastly improved over MW2. First of all we have semi-dedicated servers (semi because you must use a specific 3rd party to run your server), which is great because now admins have complete control over who and who is not on there server. Therefore, VAC + admin control = less hackers, which is what plagued MW2 to an early grave.Less hackers means fair and competitive gameplay, but Treyarch did not stop there. They also did there best to balance out the super overly unbalanced MW2 multiplayer. While MW2 has some really cool perks, a few of them were so overpowered, especially when used in specific combos. Not to say Black Ops is perfectly balance, because its not, but its good enough to make the game enjoyable.There is also some new features and game play modes. The coolest is that unlike in MW2, you earn money called COD points while you level up. These points can be used to purchased weapons, add-ons, perks, upgrades and aesthetic things such as warpaint. COD points allow the leveling system to be less linear as it was in MW2. Now you can decide what you want to purchase or upgrade, while deciding what things you want to skip.Even with all these features, its still a shoot and not get shot at game. So I give the Multiplayer a 5/5---Overall---This game is pretty good, but i warn you, this game probably wont run on last gen computers. If you have a duo-core, I would probably stay away from this game. Likewise quad-core's and tri-cores do not necessarily guarantee success, especially if your using a quad-core in a crappy mobo (one made for an older cpu). Because of the hardware requirements, this game has gotten crappy reviews, but trust me in saying this game is way better than 1 or 2 stars.If you can play GTA IV on high with a decent FPS, then this game is guaranteed to run on your system.My system:AMD Phenom II X4 9551GB GeForce GTS 2502x2GB DDR3 ramMSI 870A-G54 AM3 MoboNote: I know the game requirements are less than what I say you need, but trust me you'll want a good machine to run this.

I have played many First Person Shooters, but never anything in the Call of Duty series. Steam recently offered a free weekend of play with Black Ops, and I checked it out. The free trial was multi player only, no single player.I had no issues connecting and finding games, and experienced very little lag except when the round would first start. Fortunately, enemies are usually far enough away at the start, so it doesn't hurt you that much. I didn't like the short time between rounds. I could barely read the scoreboard before it would disappear and the next map would be loading.Graphics were not good.  Player animations looked old (as in graphics I saw in games 6 years ago) and clunky. When you see players "sprint", they seem to float and move unrealistically fast. A couple of the maps looked decent, but overall I thought they were lacking detail and you could not interact with the environment much at all.Based on what I was able to "unlock" during the free weekend, the weapons seemed pretty cool, and I liked all the customization options.But here is where the game completely frustrated me. You cannot run and gun. When you are sprinting with a shotgun for example, and come around the corner and see an enemy, and you press the fire button...guess what...your shotgun doesn't fire. Instead your player will stop running and raise his weapon. At that point you can then press fire again and shoot. But you are usually dead by then.  Essentially then game will not allow you to run and shoot at the same time. Beyond that, running in the game is messed up even when you don't want to shoot. You hold the shift key to start running, and you should stop running when you release the key. But nooooo...you have to press some other key or click your mouse to stop running....and then you are dead.  Maybe this is just an issue on the "PC" because I don't see a lot of complaints about this from console users.  But for me, having played a ton of Unreal Tournament and Bad Company 2, not being able to fire off your gun while running is a real bummer.

I was rather disappointed with this chapter in the Call of Duty franchise. Treyarch has shown that they were not prepared to pick up the torch left behind by Infinity Ward - they simply "couldn't see the forest for the trees," so to speak; I applaud the level of detail achieved in the individual characters, achieved via facial mapping, motion tracking, etc., yet they completely neglected more worldly details that detract from the overall experience. Firstly, the general movements of the characters are choppy and sluggish, rather than organic and smooth - character's physical reactions to things such as slippey wurfaces, or bullet hits are repetitive and mechanical. The absence of "the little details," as well as repetitive use of models in level environments make for a bland and unrealistic experience. The audio is atrocious; the sounds of gunfire , explosions, etc. are pathetically weak. Furthermore, it seems to be a rather unstable, inefficient engine - unless you are playing on XBox or Playstation, which are platform-optimized and lacking in quality, you'll need a fairly high-end, new system to run it on to experience it in "all of its glory."But my biggest grievance is the absence of gritty, epic moments found in MW2, which I consider to be the pinnacle of the franchise. Instead, it seems to have regressed to an storyline experience on par with the earliest series' in the franchise.Like them or not, Infinity Ward was innovative - Treyarch simply lifted and copied bits and pieces of what Infinity Ward mastered.Nevertheless, dedicated fans of the franchise will still find the game to be generally enjoyable

reviewText: Never thought I would rate a COD game 3 stars, but there it is. Suprisingly, this game failed in many ways.The single player first: They are telling a story that bounces u all over the place between places and wars. It starts in the early sixties and takes you up to Vietnam. You are being questioned by unkown interigators and then it takes you to a mission you have to complete. Seomtimes, just as you are getting into the mission, it breaks and you are back in the interigation chair. This is repeated several times and gets a little frustrating. The gameplay is typical COD. Very exciting action with little time for taking in the scenery and anything else. you pretty much just keep running an firing just like every other COD game. You would think they could change it up a little, though getting non-stop action is not a bad thing, it just feels the same as all the other games. And the campaign gets shorter and shorter.Now, the MP: Laggy best describes it right now. It has gotten better, but still has rough moments. And the Mp plays like FEAR 2 which is not really a good thing. It looks and plays cheaply. The controls seem clunky and the maps, while not the bad, are not really awesome. Some are good and are wide open giving you less places to camp, but when you spawn in and die from a attack copter without being able to move, you start to hate it, especially when it happens 4 or 5 times in a row. Also, there is very little time between maps, and while I am sure some like this, it doesnt give you time to do things like create a class (which is a good thing when you get a new weapon or perk available) or purchase contracts. You have to leave the game you are playing make the change, and then hope you can get back in. Now, you do get money for kills and winning maps that you can spend to make purchases early, which is kind of cool, but not really all that cool. As for wager matches, I can barely find anyone playing those. Surprise I say as I didnt think that was all that cool. Mp needs more work and right now, Treyarch is working on another patch that is supposed to really fix most of the problems with lag and other issues, but I dont think it will be enough to make this game as good as the others.The graphics seema little better, but not much. Same with the sound. Not much impressed, sadly to say. As for the system requirments, not much has changed except that u need a good processor. I bought a new computer as my 3 year old CPU's processor wasnt good enough (need on anyways). I had dual AMD 64 and it wouldnt play. Call of Duty: Black Ops is an extremely good game. It's not perfect, but when compared to the earlier Treyarch releases it is much better and with luck will keep the series moving in a direction fans love. I have this game for the PC and the XBox 360 and I've not only enjoyed both, I've been impressed with how well the graphics look on my desktop:  the XBox 360 version renders remarkably well but it can't touch the quality of my desktop PC.What I love about the single-player campaign is that the story is intricate and contains some surprising twists to it--and what seals the deal is the history behind it. The story is set during the Vietnam War and also touches on the Cuban Missile Crisis and the Bay of Pigs incident. There are a couple of things depicted in the game that aren't quite accurate, but it's been enjoyable getting details from Vietnam veterans I know (and from the Internet). It's still a very plausible campaign and there is enough variety in each level and its goals that you don't feel like you're being handed a map and a paltry excuse to shoot it up from one end to the other.When it comes to multiplayer, on the PC it can be a huge disappointment.  If you have friends you can group with on a closed map, you're in for a great time--otherwise, my experiences trying random pick-up maps left me worn out by all the cheating.  This isn't a rant about people who move faster; I was running across players who could pull the trigger anywhere on the map and you automatically die of a headshot, over and over, as their stats climb the boards.  On the PC I went to bot-matches and saved multiplayer for the more locked-down XBox 360 platform. I really enjoy the way mutliplayer feels though: it's not just the fact that the technology is fairly accurate to the times, it's that even without Modern Warfare styled gadgets you can get a lot of tactical fun out of running and gunning across the maps. We still have airdropped care packages and we still have the occasional ability to light up the map with a radar sweep that tags enemies with red dots.So the only thing really keeping Black Ops from a 5-star rating are some minor cons. Like with every shooter, you'll have moments where your feet get stuck or you can't move because you can't see the treestump next to your ankle that's blocking you. I've learned to forgive those moments because they happen in any game. With Treyarch's "World at War" there were times that the enemies seemed to be willing to spawn forever if you didn't move to tag the appropriate hotspot on the map. This happens a few times in Black Ops and it can lead to some real Groundhog Day style moments. The other con that I'm hoping goes away in future Call of Duty games is that there will be times a checkpoint triggers at the worst possible moment--and if you die, you respawn into a bad situation that may take you a dozen revives to get past. I only had this happen a couple of times, but it left me thinking, "You have GOT to be kidding me!" Frustrating, and sometimes it causes you to deliberately have to be foolhardy and rush in on a bad situation knowing you'll take a hit or two, because if you don't you'll be back to a bad respawn point. I'd rather push forward acting as if bullets are a bad thing that I can't just brush off by hiding for 10 seconds. It can get silly when some of the enemy AI are foolish enough to step out in front of you or stand next to cover, but at higher difficulties this happens less.Overall, if you like the Call of Duty series, this is a great entry into new territory. It's got an excellent storyline and while multiplayer is difficult without a closed group, both it and single player are loads of fun.TIP:  some people were having huge performance problems with this game (and may be still!)  There is a feature called 'Shader Warming' that will pre-cache shader graphics separately.  I enabled this setting, but some have reported that disabling Shader Warming helps them get better performance and stability.
summary: Breathes New Life into an Old War

reviewText: It's the same thing as Modern Warfare 2.The weapons are basically the same, you call down air strikes, you run through a Russian prison shooting guards, you jump around from country to country shooting Communists, it's the US vs. the USSR only back in the days of the Cold War.  The story is lame as hell, it's all about trying to get Mason to remember something about a sequence of "numbers."  Which I am so sick of as a plot device after seeing Lost for the past 6 years.The game itself is constantly freezing, crashing and is full of bugs.  Not to mention having constant flashbacks in different color filters, slightly out of focus, with the camera tilted slightly to the side gets old really fast, like after 5 minutes of this I was so bored and was actually talking out loud to my computer asking it, "So when can I shoot more stuff?"  What's even worse is that the option to skip these cinematics only works when it wants to.  So 90% of the time you have to watch these lame pointless cut scenes that add NOTHING to the story other than where your next mission is and what Communist you're going after next.  You'll find yourself hitting every button on your keyboard and clicking wildly in the vane hope that you'll be taken to the start of the mission.Also there are some pretty lame achievements, but there is no place in the game itself to look at a list of these achievements or descriptions of them in order to find out what you have to do to get them.  You have look on Steam to find that info.  And forget about Alt+Tabbing out of the game to check what achievements you can still get and then returning to the game cuz the game will crash as soon as you do that.This game shouldn't have been a stand alone game for 60 bucks.  If anything it should have been a $20 expansion pack for MW2.  Not to mention it really sucks that you HAVE to use Steam in order to play this game.  And to top it all off, I finished the game in only 6 hours!!!  That's it!  6 HOURS for 60 BUCKS!!!

I read article after article saying that this game had a full co-op campaign--it doesn't. It has the combat training, which is a nice addition, but they took away the co-op campaign that we were treated too with World at War. Thanks for screwing us like that guys. I can not believe that they would offer it in a past game and take it away. Doesn't every developer know that you can NEVER take away features once they are added. I guess the good developers know that, but these guys don't. They wonder why games like Halo, Gears and Rainbow Six are so successful, its because they give you a lot of options to play. These guys make me sick with their lack of regard for their customers.The other thing is that they continue to ruin zombie mode. What made the original zombie map in World at War so much fun was that you could put your back to a wall and just fight. With every subsequent map after that, they forced you to run around to different rooms to find the boxes. Then they added the very irritating feature of having the boxes dissappear at random and appear somewhere else. They force you to playt he game the way they want you too, instead of giving the user any level of control over some of the options. So with this iteratoin its the same thing, a huge level that you are forced to run all over to find the box, only to die by the time you do because you don't have any money or a good defensible location. I haven't unlocked the other two levels for zombie mode yet, but my hopes are incredibly low at this point.If they would have given us the co-op campaign that they promised, and not continued to downgrade and ruin zombie mode, I'd have scored this much higher. But I'm so irritated that they would take away the campaign's co-op feature. I love multiplayer just like a lot of other people, but NOT at the expense of a co-op campaign. I'm sorry I purchased this game now, and I hope I can save a few of you from doing the same. I'm done with this series.

Im going to write this review to combat some of the negative reviews on here and maybe convince someone to pick this game up and give it a shot.This review is going to mostly focus on the multiplayer since I have only finished about a 3rd of the campaign.This game has taken all of the best elements from all the previous call of duty games, eliminated the things that didn't work, and the result is a nearly flawless online experience. Here are the issues that are fantastic additions/fixes to the series.CAMPINGWhere to start on this one, a combination of things have nearly eliminated this problem entirely.---------Better Map Design, multiple entry points to every location, no rooms with 1 major access point. This forces players to stick and move, get a few kills in an area and then move from that spot or at least readjust his strategy. Maps are smaller overall with no wasted space. There were areas in MW2 maps that people never went.---------No stopping power.Without this perk it is actually possible to survive a few bullets from someone who sees you first but has poor aim, which is usually the case for someone who resorts to sitting in a corner for easy kills. You can react and back out of the room, unlike in MW2, regardless of if you can aim or not most weapons take 2 bullets at most to kill you with stopping power and if you fire first you win 99% of the time.---------Killstreaks dont stack and are less effectiveNo more superoverpowered killstreaks in the air at all times. In MW2 you camp until you get 5 kills for a predator, then you are almost guaranteed to get to 7 for a harrier then 11 for choppergunner/Ac-130, rinse and repeat. You have to actually get kills with your gun, 11 killstreaks are a now more rare and not rewarded to anyone who can hide behind a barrel for 5 kills.--------Nerfing snipers and returning to pistol only secondaries.In Mw2 it was next to impossible to get a sniper out of a good hiding spot, you are no match at long range with any weapon other than a sniper rifle yourself, and at close range nothing was better than a shotgun or even worse akimbo shotguns, there was no tradeoff for a sniper. His weapon combo allowed him to have an advantage in nearly every scenario making the game unbalanced. Now they are relegated to a pistol which is far less effective allowing the advantage to swing for someone that can close the gap.The same applied to any long range weapon.UNBALANCED WEAPONS---MW2, all weapons effective at any range. In Black OPs recoil was added to the weapons, theres a thought, you have to aim when you shoot, or fire in bursts and not spray. Now every weapon has a trade off based on range. A M16 user will have the advantage over someone with and SMG at medium to long range, and if an SMG user gets up close he will have the advantage. Balance.CHEAP TACTICS-----Quickscoping, knife classes, noobtubers, explosive only classes, nuke boosters, akimbo shotguners...all gone----Sleight of hand beniefit removed from sniper rifles, damaged decreases and sway added = no quickcopers and best of all no quickscope lobby messages every 5 mins and will reduce the number worhless Youtube montage makers trying to get internet famous.----Noob tube dmage decreased, no danger close and one man army elimiates the noobtubers and other explosive only users----No commando, and lightweight speed decreased extremely eliminates the teleport knifers. Still could stand to be decreased more, people still occasionaly lunge knife through bullets.----No gaming ending killstreak, this combined with a tactical insertion was the worst idea of all by Infinity Ward. Take it out and no one will boost it.----Shotgun damage decreased and shotguns returned to primary only, can akimbo 1 set of shotguns but there effective range is probably half of what they used to be.OBJECTIVE GAMES ABOUT THE OBJECTIVE AGAINAnother huge but simple improvement is the demphasizing of the kill/death ratio. In previous games you clicked on the leaderboards and you were given a kill/death ratio based on kills through all games including objective games. People would obsess over this number to the point where every objective game in MW2 had 2 or 3 people on each team camping strictly for kills to get that number up and not playing the objective.This overall kill/death ratio number is still there but its buried deep in your combat record. When you click on the leaderboards you have kill/death ratios listed only for games where killing is the objective, Team Deathmatch, FFA etc. In the objective games it only keeps track of your captures, defends plants etc.The result is fun competitve objective games where the objective is the focus and not the kills. Now you cant pad your stats with a number overinflated by not playing the objective, and if you do, it only improves a number buried so far in your combat record that no one will ever bother to check it.ACCESS TO MORE EQUIPMENT/PERKS/ATTACHMENTS/WEAPONS FASTER DUE TO CREDIT SYSTEM--Now you can just buy what you want as you get teh credits. You still have to reach certain levels to be able to buy certain guns but now you can just buy whatever perks, attachments and equipment you like instead of having to wait to reach a certain level, or get so many kills with a certain scope. You can get what you want sooner.MORE CUSTOMIZATION--Endless amount of custom symbols can be created, you can buy the stuff you want and not have to do some ridiculous challenge to get a certain symbol, or boost headshots (eliminated another boosting problem). You can also customize your player model, face paint, reticle and lens type and colors, and put you clan tag and symbol on your gun.TREYARCH BRINGING THE BAN HAMMER---Infinity Ward let the MW2 run wild with more glitches and exploits than I've seen in every other game combined. Prestige glitchers, Private matches that let you gain xp, modded lobbies everything to infinite explosives, to faster running, and higher jumping. Javelin glitch, Infinite Care packages, hiding in rocks, elevators etc etc.Infinity ward patched some of it, others they never bothered, and through it all there was no penalty for any of it. Treyarch has resorted to banning these people and releasing updates to squash glitches as soon as they are discovered, not waiting months if ever to do anything.CONS (Cant get everything right)--I agree with some of the others on here about the sound. It is a lot harder to hear players coming now even with an expensive headset. This was done intentionally by Treyarch to prevent the sound-whoring, which results in camping or players ducking in corners constantly, but in my opinion it was done too much.Treyarch has acknowledged this however and are planning a patch to adjust the sound.--Dive to prone. Ridiculous and nobody really uses it effectively and it usually happens on accident resulting in you getting killed.--Matchmaking sometimes takes a really long time to get into a game with a party, or disbands the party entirely(Also being fixed by Treyarch)--Knife lunge range still a little ridculous (Also being adjusted in a future patch)Overall this is a fantastic game. It goes back to the roots of how FPS should be played. Its about the weapon in your hand again and you shooting better than the other guy. Not the kilstreaks or what cheap tactic you can come up with to get a kill. reviewText: UPDATE (7/21/11)Although my initial review was quite harsh, I do have great praise for theater mode.  I had not used it since the update which added dolly cams to the the mode, and all I can say about that is...WOW.  Theater mode is absolutely amazing.  It is a complete blast to work with and can provide hours of entertainment creating epic movie quality clips.  The only downside is that exporting the videos to a PC for storage (as only 6 slots are provided online) is nearly impossible.  However, I give great credit to Treyarch for this inclusion and I hope it finds its way into MW3.I am also quite glad (even though I predicted it before even the first map pack came out) that Treyarch has decided to cash in by offering the original World at War zombies maps as DLC for players who did not purchase the Hardened or Prestige editions of the game.  I had been planning to pay the price of a NEW GAME to buy the redeem code on eBay, where people were shamelessly selling it for a highly elevated price, but now I can get all of the maps AND a brand new one for a mere $15.I admit it, this is the only FPS that I ever play these days.  I love multiplayer and I love the zombies mode.  I don't love the frequent glitches and sketchy issues with hit detection, stab connection, longshot accuracy, and lag, but I do enjoy the experience as a whole.  However, the single player campaign is still BAD.  Please, Treyarch, fix this in the next installment in which you participate.ORIGINAL REVIEW:My experience with the CoD franchise began with Modern Warfare.  I have neither played nor heavily researched the older titles, so I can't really say what the original "premise" of CoD was.  Regardless, I believe that with new consoles and technology available, game franchises should evolve over time and include new features.  On the one hand, a complete shift in focus is not ideal (to use the example of a racing game, if Need for Speed, an arcade racer, suddenly released a full-blown simulator like Gran Turismo, that would be misguided and ill-received), but development to generate new interest and take advantage of new technologies should be a given.Call of Duty:  Black Ops has made some improvements over its predecessors, but not enough, and has even regressed in a few areas.  Rather than releasing a new game every year, perhaps Activision should "slow their roll," so to speak, and develop a title free of bugs and horrible features that anger people and inspire ranting reviews such as several here at Amazon.com.  In addition, those who say "there was nothing wrong with the original [insert game title here]" can feel free to go play the original title.  Why limit the development of new games just because a dated title for an older console was good when it came out?Now, the game.Treyarch really made some great advances in the area of "sharing the experience."  The biggest thing I can point to right away is the ability to play split-screen online.  My roommate and I enjoyed this opportunity to hit up the multiplayer portion of the game as a team.  Additionally, the new "Combat Training" mode offers either a crazy challenge on "Veteran" or a laughably easy Chuck Norris style massacre on "Recruit," which again can be done split-screen.  Being able to play split-screen in private online matches is additionally a big plus because I can enjoy 2v2 deathmatches with my friend and his wife in another state.  I recently forgot that this was new to Black Ops and suggested we play the tiny MW2 map "Rust" in this fashion, only to realize that we could not.Multiplayer also has some great new features.  I'm a little divided on the "purchase system" which involves buying weapons and attachments with points earned during gameplay, rather than progressively unlocking these items, but I think it is a good working system.  Additions such as "Second Chance Pro," which allows your teammates to revive you when you are downed, unique killstreak rewards (with no more annoying Tactical Nuke), and some enjoyable maps and environments make the experience fun and refreshed from prior installments.However, once you get past these good things, the game starts to fall apart.  First off, multiplayer is riddled with problems.  I won't say a word about the playing style of any gamer, because that is not a game flaw.  One of the biggest problems, though, is a sort of delay that affects one team or the other.  I often get instantly mowed down by someone after they pop out of cover, only to watch a killcam in which they take their sweet time aiming and shooting at me after moving from cover...as though I was offered a 1 second delay on my end of things.  I'm sure the same often happens to my opponents as well, explaining why they fail to shoot at me during games in which I am doing well.Another multiplayer problem is hit detection.  I have, on a number of occasions, unloaded on someone at point blank range, only to see the killcam (after they seem to drop me in one shot) indicating no hits on them.  These are fundamental problems that really need to be addressed by the game developers.Some people may claim that CoD IS multiplayer, and that single player modes are not even necessary.  I disagree.  The storyline in Modern Warfare was amazing, and a true joy to play through.  MW2 was a little less enjoyable, but still a good play.  I don't remember WaW very well because I played the other two again more recently, but it seemed pretty good as I recall.  Black Ops, however, has a terrible campaign.  Cut scenes and voice acting are good, as other reviewers have said, but first off the premise of the campaign is a terrible plot concept (a supposedly highly skilled soldier imagines the perpetual existence of a deceased Russian to the extent that this phantom man actually accomplishes tasks and kills enemies for him?).Second, realism completely failed.  Prior installments of CoD made references to "careful development with soldiers and historians" to ensure an accurate, period-correct experience.  Not the case with BO...about 50% of the available weapons in the game had not even been developed by the year in which the game is set.  A classic example is the SPAS-12 shotgun, which debuted in 1979.  The player is given one to use in the game's 1969.  A 10 year continuity error is not a "minor discrepancy."Third, the AI is complete garbage.  Several other reviews address this issue, but the campaign eventually becomes boring and frustrating because your scripted teammates are worthless, the enemies are unreasonably good, single you out, and spawn infinitely on veteran, and there is really only ONE way to progress through the level, with extensive use of the "trip-wire" effect which basically involves plot advancing or enemies spawning when you reach a certain, invisible "magic spot" on the map.An unexpected boon to the game, however, is the revamped zombies mode.  I loved Nazi Zombies in World at War, and the fact that zombies returned in Black Ops was about 50% of my reason for buying the game (several months after its release, however...I am not THAT obsessed).  The first new map, Kino der Toten, is a brilliant design which, despite the recent DLC, is still the best map in my opinion.  New weapons (including an M1911 that actually sounds like a .45 pistol and not a pea shooter), new dialogue (though still annoyingly repetitive), and features such as useful Quick Revive on solo mode make the new zombies fresh and enjoyable.  However, even this unique game mode is not free of flaws.  Double-hitting zombies, ridiculous zombie strength in higher rounds, and various glitches make the mode sometimes infuriating.  In addition, the new DLC is frustrating and proves even more difficult, while hardly offering any bonuses to compensate for that fact.  Regardless of these annoyances, I still love playing zombies online with my friends, and at the time of this writing I have high hopes for the fourth and final DLC map.In summary, Black Ops debuted some new and enjoyable features but unfortunately was a letdown with a lousy campaign and some glitches that really should be ironed out by now.  I would recommend the game if you are a big fan of the CoD multiplayer experience and/or Zombies game mode, but if you are looking for a great single player storyline, don't even bother.  The weird story, interrupted constantly by dozens of cutscenes and riddled with historical flaws and atrocious AI, is not worth $60.

reviewText: This review addresses multiplayer only. As many of the reviews have said before me, the seventh installment of the COD series introduces gamers to the same tried and true formula everyone has grown to love (or hate) about this popular FPS. Run, gun, kill, die, respawn, repeat. Some absolutely love this type of gameplay, I guess they just get an adrenaline rush from it. So the people I'm talking about will no doubt give this game 5 stars. While I can get into this type of play, many players are already deciding to camp. The killcams prove my adversary was simply sitting near a wall with their weapon aimed for any unfortunate soul to run around the corner. The maps aren't as camp-friendly as MW2, but I see Black Ops turning into something very similar as more players progress and unlock more things. I for one don't want a 60's era MW2. Another aspect of this game I feel has taken a step back are the maps. A couple stand out, but the most frequently played were dull and boring. Also, the weapons sound terrible. They sound like WaW, hollow. I guess it's a Treyarch thing. I see a lot of other reviewers agree with my opinion of this game. They don't want another MW2 and I can't blame them. Why spend $60 on a game that takes many aspects of the former and incorporates them into a different setting. I still get knifed from 10 feet away and there are care-package drops, obviously copied from MW2. Now I understand many people will find this game amazing. That's great, I'm glad you enjoy it. But after playing MW, WaW and MW2, I'm looking for something different. I know GOW3 and Crysis 2 are coming soon. If you agree with what I've said in my review, maybe consider waiting patiently for these games to release.

With great fanfare arrives the next iteration in the Call of Duty franchise.  I will only discuss the multiplayer at this point because realistically, I believe the majority of gamers will be buying this game to play it online.When I first jumped on-line, I was immediately struck with how familiar the game play felt. The phrase "evolution, not revolution" really comes to mind in describing the game play.  I felt like I was playing a re-skinned version of MW2.  The controls are exactly the same, which is good, but nearly everything else about the game play itself just feels a little overly familiar.  Calling in the recon plane, stopping an enemy just short of a kill streak, etc., it all just felt like I was still playing MW2 but on new maps.Ironically, even though this is the next installment of the franchise, the graphics seem a bit drab and generic, at least on some of the maps.  It appears to be a different graphics engine, and it lacks the polish and detail that was present in MW2.  The character animations look pretty generic.  In the end, it is really the game play that matters(and it is very good), but I was surprised the graphics appear inferior to MW2.Leveling up and acquiring new weapons, attachments, and perks has been changed up a bit.  You still generate XP, which moves you up the ladder to different levels, level 1, 2, 3, etc.  What's new is that as you acquire XP, you also accumulate COD points.  As you level up, you will unlock new weapons as before, but rather than having to complete challenges to unlock new weapon attachments, multiple attachments are simultaneously available that you can purchase with your COD points.  Think of it like this:  Your XP is the cover charge into the bar, but you still need money in your pocket to buy the drinks you want.  I like this approach because I don't want to waste time unlocking an ACOG scope that I won't use so I can get to the unlock for a red-dot scope, which I will use. This ability to customize is an improvement on MW2.Aside from straight kills, another way to generate COD points is to purchase contracts, which offer a COD point reward upon completion.  Some are pretty attainable, like killing three enemies in a row without dying.  You pay 25 points to purchase that contract and gain 250 when you complete it.  Another contract involves using your knife to kill a single opponent.  There are contracts that appeal to all play abilities and offer a nice new, personal goal to attain when playing online.  I like this concept because it offers additional goals beyond just trying to have a decent kill/death ratio.  Each contract has a cooling period where you can't repurchase it until a specified period of time has passed.You can also still customize your emblem, although you now get to pay for the privilege with your COD points.  I am not sure how much I like having to pay for this ability, but I must admit the first time I saw my customized emblem adorned on my weapon as a new "gun emblem" I was pretty impressed.  Another nice new feature is the ability to save or upload movies of your matches.  That is pretty welcome.Finally, there is a combat training mode that allows you to play all the maps against bots offline. (although you must be online to play it).  The bots are actually pretty good at simulating a real opponent, and this mode allows you to get familiar with each map without getting slaughtered on-line.  You can also unlock most of the same weapons and attachments, so you can try out new weapons and tactics without sacrificing a few matches to learn whether you like them or not.  A cool feature of the training mode is that the bots are all named from your friends list, rather than generic, computer-generated names.  I was laughing out loud when I was killed by my friends, or vice versa, when they weren't really playing.  I thought it was a nice touch to personalize it this way and it really adds to the immersion that you are playing a real on-line match.  This mode will be excellent to learn all the little hiding spots that snipers will exploit on-line.Speaking of snipers, after putting in a fair amount of gameplay, I should point out that the map design seems improved over MW2.  The variety of maps is excellent, and vary from spread out areas to close quarter battle maps.  The ability to quick scope or camp and snipe are happily gimped.  The weapons balance is also excellent - the weapons you start with in multiplayer allow you to compete against higher ranked players just fine.  So far, I haven't encountered any uber-weapons that seem unbalanced and unfair.The popular zombie mode is also present, which when combined with the training mode, online mode, and single player campaign, really provide a fair amount of content for your gaming dollar.  If you liked MW2 and are ready for a subtle, but not overwhelming change, you should be pleased with Black Ops.  You will immediately feel at home, but it is fresh enough to be a comfortable second home.

I'm going to try and keep this review pretty short because you can read other people's reviews to find out more about the game. I just want to say that it is fun to play overall. Let's start with single player.SINGLE PLAYER:The campaign took me about 7 hours on regular difficulty and it was fun. I just thought there were too many cutscenes, even though I skipped most of them anyway. I wouldn't skip the campaign if you get this game. 8.7/10ZOMBIES:Same as World at War, only with different maps now. I'm not a zombie fan so this held my attention for about 10 minutes. They should have put some spec-ops mode in this game, zombies is just not a good enough replacement because it gets boring fast. Spec ops, on the other hand, was always fun and took about 30 hours to beat the whole thing. 4/10MULTIPLAYER: (I'm going to split this into a few parts)Player match: Same as every other cod game, so this part of the multiplayer portion has gotten quite stale for me. The same recycled CoD formula just doesn't do it. It's either that, or the maps are too dull. But overall you should like this. 7/10Combat Training: This is tons of fun especially if you put the bots on recruit difficulty. It does get boring after a while and after being level 50, there's not much left to do. But if you put it on Veteran it is quite difficult. I'd say hardened is the most balanced difficulty. I would recommend trying this out if you're getting sick of losing on player matches. 8/10Theater Mode: Yes, I'm adding this in because I love it. You can watch old games and edit clips and whatever. Change camera angles, watch it from other player's perspectives, and a bunch of other stuff. I just can't figure out how to make it slow motion when recording. 9.5/10Wager Matches: This is my favorite. I hate sticks and stones because you always get hit with a tomahawk and then you are put in last place. I hate that game mode so much. Sharpshooter is fun because every game has different weapons. I destroyed everyone on my first match then I kept losing after that. Gun game is good, I won probably 10 out of the 50 matches I played in gun game. It's fun until you are in 6th place for like 10 games in a row. And finally, one in the chamber is the best of them all. You get one bullet and three lives, and you get a life for every knife and/or kill with a bullet. I would check that mode out. It's especially fun if you have a friend over and play it split screen so you can work together and screen-cheat when one of you gets out. 9/10Overall, I would buy this game.Wow that review was a lot longer than I thought.

So I am sure there are a few more out there besides myself who decided to make the plunge as an early adopter to the new 3DHDTVs that are currently out. I am working with the Samsung PN50C490 50-Inch 720p Plasma 3D HDTV. For the cost it seemed like a great bargain to test out the new technology so no regrets on this end.One of the main motivators for me to make the plunge was the promise of more 3D gaming and when I found out that COD was making the leap into the fold well for me that was the tipping point of investment.How did it pan out? ****ing awesome!!! It's the best way to play the game IMO and delivers on the promise of a more immersible experience. I am also using the Turtle Beach X41's as my headgear so while I may look silly in my glasses and headset I am being blown away by what I am seeing and hearing in front of me.The 3D is not over bearing where it becomes a distraction but really amps the level of putting you into the game. While I am throughly enjoying the single player mode I can also say safely that this is a slight advantage in multiplayer.There is obviously a graphical drop in frame rate due to the stereoscopic image splitting up the pixels but not enough to take away from the enjoyment of the game or make it unplayable. It's a lot of fun.The tech is only at the start and while there are plenty who are opposed to it please be mindful that eventually all TVs will have a 3D option. Much like the way captions are a part of TVs now. It's going to improve greatly as they expand the technology and I don't foresee it becoming a forced option as much as an additional benefit so no need to bash it since you're not forced to use it.It's obvious that there are those who find it gimmicky and I respect that opinion. And yes it is true in some cases it creates a health issue with it making a person nauseous or possible eye strain which is why anyone considering making the plunge should test one out first.Anyway there you have it.Enjoy!

I really, really, really wanted to love this game.  I had a one year love/hate relationship with MW2 - that game is so addicting, fun, and maddingly frustrating.  It was my first online multiplayer game ever (I've since gone back and played MW1; man, that was a gem!).  However, I was getting very annoyed with all the exploits of certain perks and attachments (you should know the ones I mean).  And the two overpriced and blah map packs further drove me away.But, after two months with Black Ops, I find that I'm being driven back to MW2.  Even as far back as MW1.  Yes, the perks and attachments are more balanced, but just not enough to overcome the game's flaws.  I find the graphics and colors to be dull and unexciting, the sounds underwhelming, and the physics engine/gameplay slow and boring.  And I've discovered that the pro versions of certain perks are those that frustrated me the most in MW2 (unlimited sprint and no damage falls).  Instead of eliminating the throwing knife, we get the tomahawk AND the ballistic knife.  Instead of eliminating the noob tube, we still have it and it's stealthier cousin the exploding crossbow bolts.  The list can go on and on.  Well, they did eventually nerf the panic knifing to bearable levels.  And then the problems with the matchmaking lobby, seemingly endless connection problems, and issues with playing with a party.  Granted, Treyarch is working on that, but couldn't they have released a fully operational product after SOME beta testing rather than sell us a beta product at full MSRP and have us suffer for a month or so?  It got so bad that I could not play BO even if I wanted to.  Another reason for going back to MW2.Bottom line, the formula came to this: BO=MW2a.  It's just an interative change from MW2, but with degraded gameplay, graphics, and sound.  Playing Black Ops seems more of a chore that I have to do to build up my perks (getting those pro versions are a real pain).  I play MW2 for fun.It's going to be a LONG 10 months before the next COD comes out.  If there will be one this year.
