And I actually really like World at War.  This one is nowhere near any of its predecessors (except maybe Call of Duty 3).The Zombies thing is standard affair, and the multiplayer takes a lot from Modern Warfare 2, adds a lot of new things, but overall still feels the same as World at War's multiplayer (which isn't really a bad thing; my biggest problem with WaW's multiplayer was that bolt-action rifles were made virtually pointless against machine guns) including identical menus and perk icon designs.It may definitely be a troublesome task trying to pick between this and MW2 for casual multiplayer gaming.The single player campaign, however, is a total disaster, by the standards set in every Call of Duty game since COD4, or perhaps even COD2.The story:- The story doesn't even begin to come into shape until mid-way through the campaign.  It starts with Generic Loner Badass Alex Mason, the guy with virtually the same name as the guy from Red Faction: Guerrilla, and so badass, John F Kennedy tells him directly he's the best they've got, in a pretty non-Cold War looking room full of television screens, apparently strapped into a chair and being questioned angrily by a distorted voice.  Every mission save for the last are in the form of flashbacks from this location.Alex Mason is painfully unlikeable, with no personality and no real redeeming traits, and the acting done by Sam Worthington with him is so painfully dull, or painfully overacted, it makes his "Avatar" performance look Oscar-worthy.  At no point in the game did I care about what he was doing or what was wrong with him.In fact, I realized he was pretty stupid for a CIA agent and BEST FIGHTER GUY IN THE EVAR, given not only the poor decisions made for the control interface (such as taking twice as long now to throw back grenades, or being unable to pilot a Hind to have it rise up or down, while being able to do everything else in it).  The plot twist at the end involving Reznov was alluded to, which helped in making the preceding scenes not seem stupid in hindsight, came about quite confused and unclear, and Alec Mason's brutish reaction to it is the sort of thing that, given that there is a TIMER RUNNING on the DESTRUCTION OF THE ENTIRE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA AND PERHAPS THE ENTIRE WESTERN HEMISPHERE, makes him cartoonishly buffoonish, especially given that this plot twist has virtually NOTHING TO DO with the very ending in stopping this aforementioned destruction.The story is so convoluted, that I honestly don't even remember what the first five or six missions were, and why.  It just seemed like they were there solely for the action.  Which you'd think would be a given for a video game, but this is not exactly commonplace in the Call of Duty franchise.  Considering the Jason Bourne-style rapidfire incoherence they approach it with, it might be a short stretch to say they were intentionally attempting to fill the game up with confusing early missions filled with nonstop action.When it finally gets to the story itself, it involves the Soviet Union attempting to wipe out the United States using a nerve gas called NOVA-6 that causes quick death, and is planned to be launched on the US mainland in several dozen spots, to pretty much destroy the entire country and its entire population.  Such a direct, apocalyptic action, given the theory of Mutually Assured Destruction, with both the US and USSR posessing over 9000 nuclear weapons each, the sanity, or even basic common sense of such a plan is... pretty nonexistent.  I know the Soviets were villainized harshly by the Americans, but I highly doubt they and their leaders were suicidal, homicidal, genocidal cretinsThe Missions:- The first few missions are a scatter-brained assortment of big set pieces with obscenely copious amounts of gunfire and explosions.  While scenes like the Bay of Pigs are surprisingly accurate with regards to scope, it still feels excessive with the sheer amount of gunfire that gets poured into you, and the enemy, in just the few minutes the level lasts, which amplified over the course of three days, would become excessive; the actual Bay of Pigs had between 100-200 dead, and 500+ wounded (not including civilians); the way it's depicted in the game, this all would possibly fit into the few minutes depicted.Virtually every level is a colossal mess of hundreds of soldiers (endlessly respawning, of course), constant explosions, a cacaphony of nutty weapons that I often question even existed in the 1960s (such as a proto-version of the Thermal Scope in MW2, or gun-mounted flamethrowers that somehow don't melt the gun's barrel after constant use, or high powered assault rifles with five different attachments on it), and gore that gets so copious, it becomes cartoonish; like shooting a soldier in the hand with a pistol, and having his ENTIRE HAND AND WRIST be blown off.  Or worse; shooting once at a soldier on a motorcycle, while also on a motorcycle, and having him literally explode into a vapor of small pieces of gore.- But the single worst, most frustrating thing about the missions is the legendarily thick AI.  I have NEVER seen AI this atrocious in the Call of Duty series since only the last mission of Call of Duty 4 (on Veteran Mode) with Ssgt. Griggs rushing out into the open, standing in front of an enemy, and shooting wildly in random directions.At least 70% or 80% of all missions will be You vs an Army, because your allies rarely, if ever, hit anything, and they ALWAYS take a few seconds before even RECOGNIZING an enemy soldier; I could not count the times a friendly unit would simply RUN PAST an enemy unit, and that enemy unit of course ignoring them and targeting ME exclusively.This sort of stupidity is even scripted, as in one sequence a group of friendlies is ambushed by Vietcong soldiers, and as one of them is shooting a friendly soldier dead, one of your allies rushes up to him, holding his assault rifle near his waist, Hollywood-style, the gun jams, he looks down at it, struggles to fix it, and the Vietcong soldier turns around, LOOKS AT HIS GUN, then uses his own gun to bash the man upside the head.  THIS MAN IS SUPPOSED TO BE AN INSANELY WELL-TRAINED SPECIAL OPS SOLDIER.Another frustrating problem, almost as bad as the horrendous AI, is actually SEEING who is an enemy and who isn't.  Whereas in the WW2 games, people wore uniforms, and even in Modern Warfare 2, you could tell who the OpFor agents were, due to their haphazard attire and occasional turbans, or who Russians were based on their dark red fatigues, here, EVERYONE IS DRESSED EXACTLY THE SAME in the same assortment of pants or jeans, shirts, vests, jackets, masks, headpieces, ALL DARK.  The only people not dressed this way are Vietcong and NVA soldiers (and Nazis in a flashback mission).The horrendous AI doesn't help with this either; there's such a gape in the reaction time for enemy AI, that I've never EVER adapted to turning a corner, seeing someone there, and just waiting for a full second to see if they're a friendly, or if they shoot me, or if I end up shooting at them and they turn out to be an ally.Another incredibly frustrating element is the Hind piloting.  Alex Everyman gets to do BOTH the piloting AND the shooting, and the limitations means that while you can't crash your helicopter into caverns or walls or upside big ships (which is a good thing) you also can't elevate or descend (which is a very very bad thing).  There comes a point in one mission where you have to destroy two opposing Hinds, and you're all alone.  The missiles do NOT lock on in ANY way, and the enemy Hinds CONSTANTLY rise and descend to avoid YOUR incoming fire, whereas YOU can not.  Sometimes, they will even fire DOWN at you, with you unable to hit them unless you turn on your side, strafing wildly and trying to shoot at them while you're moving at high speed.  Add to the frustration for achievement-hunters, there is an achievement for accomplishing this mission WITHOUT using the Hind's cannons, and ONLY using its rockets.  The rockets are infinite, but they reload slowly.  Fatally slow, up against the two Hinds, if you're not a good shot.The Weapons:- Like I mentioned before, I think there's a slight credibility gap with regards to some of the weapons in the game, or weapon upgrades which seem either ridiculous, a bit of a stretch to picture existing in the 1960s, or incredibly goofy.  A gun with a bottom-mounted flamethrower is an awesome thing in game, but I've never seen or heard of this being used before, and it would seem to me that, given where the flame begins, continued use would melt the gun barrel.  There's a neat variety of guns, perhaps more than in Modern Warfare 2.One of the great things is that most of the guns have a more realistic sound than in previous games, more like firecrackers than bombs.The multiplayer has a new system of upgrading in which you do not unlock weapons, perks, or upgrades in a linear way, but you earn "money" in each match, and use it to purchase weapons, perks, upgrades, etcetera.  This is neat, as you can choose to unlock a laser sight ahead of a grenade launcher, or to unlock your favorite Assault rifle before your favorite Shotgun, but this introduces a whole new issue, which would probably not be an issue for many players:It renders certain upgrades useless.  Why bother to buy Laser sight, when you can get a better sight, or a Reflex sight, which is exactly the same, and only different in aesthetics?  Why upgrade something you don't like?  Why buy a perk you never use?  With previous games, you could unlock certain things by kills, and unlock other things by kills using certain upgrades (such as unlocking Holographic sights by getting 60 kills with Laser sights), essentially forcing you to use virtually every upgrade in order to unlock the rest.The Characters:- There are the standard character archetypes here; the Generic Loner Badass protagonist, the Token Black Guy (who obviously dies first), the Sidekick Guy, the Scrappy, the Tough All-Business Veteran Guy, the Nerdy Politician (voiced by Robert Picardo), etcetera.  None of them are particularly interesting.Most of all, Alecks Mason, is called the BEST THEY HAVE and treated like a testosterone-souped Mary Sue, complete with no evidence of why he is the BEST THEY HAVE, no likeable characteristics, a dull tone of voice, total lack of charisma, and either a below average intelligence, or very poor judgement.  I found myself smacking my forehead, calling him such an idiot as, towards the end, he needlessly punches the guy trying to help him, and trying to SAVE THE COUNTRY FROM TOTAL DESTRUCTION just so he can stumble about in a drugged haze, and then get punched in return later on.However, there is the appearance of Viktor Reznov, Sergeant from World at War, boistrously performed by Gary Oldman.  With the dullness of playing as Alex Mason all game wearing me down, a flashback mission from October 1945 with me as Reznov, and also speaking, I was rejuvenated, and found myself actually having fun instead of going through the motions with the game.  We also get to see Dimitri Petrenko from World at War, and him speaking, but it's nothing remarkable.  It's also refreshing to hear music from World at War returning for the flashback mission.Possibly the single biggest problem I have with the characterizations is that they all behave like movie stars in a generic Hollywood action flick.  The military professionalism of the special ops teams and armies in the Modern Warfare series was taut and compelling and COOL.  Here, the actors chomp scenery madly, spouting lines with ridiculous intonation, a total lack of professionalism among them.  There's no dry humor or wisecracks, military-slanged quips, or "Cut the chatter!"s, but tons of "Hell yeah!" and "Kick some ass!" and all other sorts of adolescent trash talk.Playing through the campaign was a dismal, frustrating, boring experience.  The multiplayer is not any MAJOR improvement over Modern Warfare 2, and its true staying power may, as with World at War, lie with its Commie Zombie functions.

One example I have come across, actually let me rephrase that, this has happened to me many many times. Anyway, I have a guy from the opposite team running away from me, I shoot him with the 30 or so bullets in my gun, odd he is not dead yet seeing that I heard the bullets hit through my speakers, I reload to try and shoot this 'terminator' some more, by that time though he realized I had been shooting him, he turns in a blink of an eye does some stupid jump and fires 'one' bullet at me (not a sniper rifle), doesn't hit my head, and kills me instantly. If that is not bad enough, I watch the kill cam and from his view he turned, jumped, and fired two feet from my character's body, yet some how the game thought that the air next to me was part of my body. I think that description is enough to say this game is garbage in the multiplayer department.Okay, This might happen more times than I like but I am not bad at the game either, there are times when I can get 27 kills and 3 deaths, and that is without killstreaks like chopper gunner or dogs. Other times, I have to shoot someone with a whole clip to kill them and they are right in front of me. The whole game is set on the host and the host team. If you are not on the host team I recommend hiding and camping because it is the only way you are going to have a decent kill/death ratio by the time the round ends.Another horrible thing about multiplayer, is when a high ranking character comes into the lobby. The host connection is set to them no matter if his connection is bad or not. I think this is true because of a number of reasons. One, is everyone that had 4 bar connections are now 3 or 2 bars. Second, I will be in a room with a guy that is getting really good kill/death ratios and right as someone that is a better rank than him comes into the room and kicks him to the non-host team, he is trash. I clearly remember giving in to the MODERN WARFARE craze just after MW2 was released. As it loaded, I kept thinking, "There's no way this game is as great as everyone saysohmygosh this is awesome!" The single player campaign completely arrested me until I finished it (good thing it was short, or I would have been sitting there awhile) and the multiplayer was such a breath of fresh air after living in HALO's repetitive shadow for so long.A year later: we have BLACK OPS, from a different studio with the aim of giving us a CoD experience from a yet-to-be-endlessly-exploited era. The Cold War. I kept my expectations pretty low, considering I wasn't the biggest fan of Treyarch's last CoD entry, WORLD AT WAR. Good thing I did; low expectations are easy to meet, especially if you tread on familiar ground.The campaign follows operative Alex Mason, a man who wakes up in an interrogation room just in time to be tortured and drugged into recalling certain memories involving his military service. The purpose of the interrogation isn't entirely clear, though anyone with an interest in Cold War conspiracy theories can probably figure it out sooner rather than later. Mason relives his contributions to the Bay of Pigs, Vietnam, and some rather interesting black ops missions that take place in the background of all of these conflicts.The story itself isn't revolutionary by any means, but it's much easier to follow and much deeper than its predecessor, MODERN WARFARE 2. Let's face it, Treyarch had a win on their hands no matter what they did, but they saw fit to provide a campaign that's exciting and competently channels that Cold War anxiety. Not to mention the enjoyable and expertly-voiced characters (many props to Gary Oldman for making Viktor Reznov so memorable) and beautiful level design.That's not to say it was perfect. I can't really explain it, but as I was playing through the campaign, I just didn't attain that sense of involvement that I felt with MW2. The AI was pretty stupid and there were levels that just felt like your standard "shoot everyone to complete mission" stage. And little things like not being able to control the camera during certain "cutscenes" gave me a sense of disconnect. That said, I can't say that I enjoyed this campaign MORE than MW2's, but I could tell that a lot of effort went into it, bringing it up to a close second place in my book.Basically, if you're buying this game for the campaign just as much as the multiplayer, I don't think you'll be disappointed. I certainly wasn't, though a few of the choices kept it from reaching the level of immersion MW2's campaign provided. But how can you beat personally receiving a mission from President Kennedy?Now, the multiplayer. There's not much I can say that hasn't been said. From my own experience, it's just as addicting and just as fun as MW2's multiplayer. Honestly, not much has been changed up with the formula, save for the changes that come with the Cold War era. But a BIG change that I absolutely adore is the ability to watch, save, and edit replays of any multiplayer match you've played in the last seven days (limited to 100 matches, I think). You can make little montages, take screenshots, and then upload them to the CoD website so you can share them with people. I've had a lot of fun messing around with it so far.In the end, this is another CALL OF DUTY game that doesn't drop the ball. The campaign is entertaining and well-written, and the multiplayer is more of the same (albeit with a different theme), but "the same" is still pretty dang fun.

I only write lengthy reviews on games that I really like, so I'll be keeping this one fairly short. I hold Treyarch to pretty high standards & unfortunately Blops falls short. More specifically in the multiplayer aspect. The single player & zombie modes are the saving grace, both very fun much like WaW's. I'm not going to compare this game to WaW however, because that's just not fair. The multiplayer is in my opinion very poor. First & foremost, the netcode & latency are THE WORST in a CoD to date. Proven in the killcam, you think you turned a corner to safety & when you watch yourself die you can see yourself standing there like a dufus through the eyes of your enemy. The next & just as big of a problem are the weapons, they don't work. They removed stopping power & claimed to have just included it into the weapons themselves. My friends & I think that that is a complete joke, it takes forever to kill someone. And as if that wasn't bad enough, the weapons are innacurate as well. Now I'm all for somewhat of a challange, but they really just handed you a pile of junk & expected us to go along with their "bullet dance", (look it up.) No thanks. The emblem customization is fun & cute n all, the maps are solid & the single player is one of the better ones, but unless you plan to play the multi as a drunk party game with friends, or like me was able to get this game for 20 some bucks....I'd skip it. Treyarch makes a damn good campaign & Infinity Ward has the multiplayer down, now if only they could combine the two. Lastly, WHY ISN'T THERE CO-OP? Any CoD campaign released after WaW that does not have co-op is a step back, period.

Ah, another year, another Call of Duty game. It seems like the annual release of the next installment in the iconic first-person shooter series should be a national holiday, given how many people attend the midnight launches for the game and no doubt skipped work or school the next day (myself included). Having hit the apex of popularity with Modern Warfare 2, the big question is how Black Ops will compare. I don't live and die by COD games as some people do, but I can say that Black Ops is one of the most satisfying and intense shooters I've ever played, with the best campaign out of all the games in the series and a multiplayer aspect that I can finally enjoy.Perhaps I'm the odd one, but I mainly buy these games for the single-player campaign as I am not the best at online shooters. The campaign in Black Ops is easily the best out of the series, with more cohesive storytelling and a more satisfying conclusion than the previous entries. Set in the Cold War era (early to late 1960's), you fight your way through diverse terrain in Russia, Cuba, and Vietnam, among other locations. As with other games in the series, you play as two main characters and you go back and forth between their missions. Without giving too much away, the story is pretty stock, but the manner in which it's told and presented is a big step forward for the COD series, which has lately felt like a batch of multiplayer games with a brief single-player campaign tacked on. Black Ops gives players a better experience in this regard, and despite being brief (7 hours roughly), it doesn't feel too short or seem to end as abruptly as the Modern Warfare games. The difficulty settings are standard for the series, and for achievement/trophy hunters, the biggest rewards come when playing on "Veteran" difficulty.The style of gameplay, the weapons and the linear design is all par for the course, but Treyarch has done a wonderful job at bringing this era and the surroundings to life. The cinematic quality that made Modern Warfare 2 such a hit is still intact here, and the graphics and sound are as amazing as you would expect. What I've always enjoyed about the COD games are the tight controls, and Black Ops will fit like a glove for any FPS fan. The multiplayer, undoubtedly the biggest day of Black Ops, is surprisingly accessible for people like me who typically get owned when going online. The focus is on class creating and experience points, and while I've only played a couple of hours, everything seems to run smoothly and without lag. My only fear is that the usual frustrations, such as campers and rude teenagers acting like idiots, will eventually creep in, but I'll be optimistic and see how things play out.I don't believe in gushing over games and hailing them as the "Best Game EVAR!", so I'll avoid hyperbole and simply say that Black Ops one of the better FPS games that I've played. If I have any negative feedback, it surrounds some of the difficulty spikes and the dumb-as-bricks AI of your teammates (and some enemies), but that was the same case with Modern Warfare 2 and especially World at War. Black Ops is not a perfect game graphically and it doesn't reinvent the wheel for FPS games, but it is a thoroughly enjoyable and satisfying experience that I don't regret investing the time or money into.
summary: The COD gravy train of hype churns on, but I'm glad to be along for the ride

The new COD points which you use to buy weapons, attachments, emblems, and title cards is a nice addition. There is 15 levels of prestige unlike the MW games where there was only 10. If there is any small complaint it is that the maps could be better. I prefer MW2 maps over Black Ops. However with that said I would still buy this game just based on the online part of the game. This game is lots of fun. I will cover the different modes of the game in their respective sections below.Campaign:In my opinion, the campaign of BO is one of the best I have played and is very well written! I won't spoil it for you, but this is the basic story. It is set in the 1970's. You start as Alex Mason, an American soldier being interrogated about information concerning the location of a numbers station. You play through flashbacks of what happened to Mason and other members of his squad during the Cold War and Vietnam War leading up to when he was being interrogated. You play through many different enviornments such as jungles in Vietnam, military outposts in the snowy Ural Mountains, and even in a Soviet cosmodrome. The game loosely follows real history, including dates of events, famous political figures, and battles. It is very entertaining, providing many hours of gameplay. The campaign on Veteran difficulty is not too hard, but brutally hard on some points of the game. There are lots of vehicles to drive or fly, and many cool sequences. There are also intel items to find during the game, and each piece of intel reveals a cool feature in the menu. The game has very talented voice actors, such as Ice Cube, Gary Oldman, and Sam Worthington.Multiplayer/Combat Training:The multiplayer of this game is very fun. There are 50 levels to progress through, and there is a different system of how you unlock different weapons. In Black Ops, you use a currency called Call of Duty Points, and they can be used to purchase Weapons, Attachments, Perks, Emblems, Titles, and Equipment. After every game that you play, you earn a specific number of Call of Duty Points, varying on how well you did or if you completed a Contract (challenges that reward you with XP and CODPoints). I personally like this system better then the ragular system because when I unlock a weapon, I can get whatever Attachment I want for it right away instead of having to use it for a long time before I can. You can also buy Lethal and Tactical Grenades, Equipment, and Perks whenever you want, as long as you have enough money. CODPoints can also be used to buy different symbols for customizable emblems and titles for your online profile. Unfortunately, CODPoints cannot be shared with friends, so if you're low on cash, you'll just have to earn it. Another great feature is Wager Matches, where you gamble CODPoints with other players. There are many game modes, such as the Gun Game, where if you get 1st, 2nd, or 3rd place, you earn some of the winnings from the bets. It is a very fun way to earn CODPoints if you do well. Another feature is called Combat Training, where you fight offline against AI enemies either alone or with friends. It's just like regular multiplayer, except you can play with AI players on your team and on the enemy team. You also rank up in Combat Training, but it's a different rank then in Multiplayer. It's very fun because you can choose what map and what gametype you play. You can even choose the difficulty of the AI, so you can play against terrible Recruits or lethal Veterans. It also very useful for sampling different perks, guns, and attachments so you're not wasting your money in real Multiplayer.Zombies:Zombies mode is back, and it's bigger and better. If you're not familiar, Zombies mode is where you fend off endless waves of zombies, which progressively get harder. Up to 4 people can play via Xbox LIVE or Split-Sceen. You earn points for each Zombie killed and each barricade fixed. You use those points to open doors and buy Perks and Weapons. If a player gets killed by the zombies, his teammates can revive him to get him back up, or if he dies, he respawns the next round. Zombies mode is very addicting and I recommend you get the map packs for Zombie maps.Overview:I would definitely recommend this game to a friend because it has a great Campaign, Multiplayer, and Zombies mode.

reviewText: I'll start by saying that this is *still* a "Call of Duty" game...anyone expecting something entirely new will be disappointed. The base feel of the game hasn't changed in years.Most of what I could say has already been covered, so I'll just summarize my opinion:Pros:-I swear this edition of Call of Duty is less laggy than the last one in multiplayer...I've yet to have a "but I shot him first!" moment, at least not anything near as bad as the ones I had in "Modern Warfare 2".-There seem to be a lot more environmental effects, e.g. heat vapors, better weather, etc. This may have come at a cost (see cons)-The multiplayer weapon upgrade system is much better than in prior editions, in that now you must spend points and choose your upgrades, rather than just have everything handed to you. This seems to result in a lot more in-match weapon variety.-Rocket launchers no longer fire projectiles in a laser-beam straight line, which eliminates a lot of "noobish" behavior online.-From a production standpoint, they capture the atmosphere of the Cold War very well...older gamers will get a kick out of it-So far, the single player storyline is pretty cool. The inclusion and references to real life historical figures is great.-Some new toys to play with unlike anything from the prior CoD games. Plus, flamethrowers make their triumphant return.-We now have a replay mode to playback matches, which is a nice touch.-The online map voting system is FINALLY up to snuff. Players actively vote FOR maps, from multiple options (including a "random" option), and not simply AGAINST playing a single map. If just one player has an opinion, his/her opinion is the one that counts. Small detail, but HUGE improvement.Cons:-Graphics haven't really progressed at all...in fact sometimes they seem to have regressed very slightly in some areas, at least in multiplayer. This may have been a price the developers had to pay to get the additional effects in (see pros). You won't notice it for long though.-Sounds aren't as punchy as they were in Modern Warfare 2.-I wish that multiplayer forced era-based weapon sets. It feels weird to be fighting in a mid-Cold War battle in an Asian jungle with a laser scope that has no right to be there.-I also wish that spy planes (i.e. UAVs in the last game) and the explosive RC cars were harder to obtainAll in all, if you like Call of Duty, absolutely pick this up. The selection of mid-Cold War era weapons (e.g. the original M-16) is a refreshing change from all the WW2 and modern combat games. There are some issues that I had with the past games that they chose not to address, but those are more personal preference items.

As with other video games I have reviewed, the following will be subdivided into categories based on the components of gameplay for Call of Duty: Black Ops. As a disclaimer, this is the first Treyarch Call of Duty I have purchased, and my previous CoD experience has been with Infinity Ward's CoD4 and Modern Warfare 2.Single-Player Campaign:Pros:Story - The Single Player Campaign of Call of Duty Black Ops has a storyline that is, in my opinion, very well written. I will do my best to avoid spoilers, but suffice to say that there is definitely a binding motif to the story that keeps the player mindful of the fact that they are progressing through a series of linked events, not simply some random missions thrown together. The story has a definite beginning and end, and is itself quite intriguing. It combines elements of mystery, excitement, and history that keep the player guessing and involved. As has been mentioned elsewhere, the story is helped in no small part by excellent voice acting from an all-star cast including Ed Harris, Ice Cube, Sam Worthington, and Gary Oldman.Missions - The missions in the single player campaign are diverse and, in most cases, quite exciting. I never at any point in playing the campaign (which at this point I have completed on Hardened difficulty and am just starting on Veteran) felt like I was repeating the same mission with a different weapon or in a different environment. The variety of environments and special features in missions, such as the occasional vehicle piloting/driving, keeps the missions engaging and mixes up the usual CoD mode of "shoot everything until you get to the waypoint".Replay Value - I found a number of the missions in Call of Duty: Black Ops to be extremely fun, and combined with what seem from their description to be some pretty challenging Xbox Achievements, I definitely will be playing the campaign several more times.Challenge - The challenge of the game was about on par with what I have experienced in CoD4 and Modern Warfare 2. As previously mentioned, I have only completed the campaign on hardened so far, but there were several parts even on that where reckless play or inattentiveness would definitely get you killed. I think the challenge level is reasonable - not too easy, not too hard.Cons:Allied AI - As has been mentioned in other reviews, I have found the AI of your allies to be somewhat frustrating at several points of some missions simply for their inability to actually kill enemies coming up behind you and shooting you in the back. Although this was only a problem for me about half a dozen times over the entire campaign, which was about on par with that of Modern Warfare 2 in length and slightly shorter than that of Halo: Reach, those few times produced more than several deaths at each location.Overall Single-Player Campaign Ratings:Story: 5 starsGameplay: 3.5 starsChallenge: 4.5 starsReplay Value: 4 starsOverall: 4.25Online Versus Multiplayer:Pros:Gameplay - The gameplay of online multiplayer for CoD: Black Ops is pretty darn fun. I was an avid player of CoD: Modern Warfare 2 online and Black Ops is somewhat better overall, in my opinion. The new leveling system for how players acquire weapons, attachments, perks, and so on involves a money-earning system that allows players to flesh out the options that make sense for their playstyle and bypass those that they are not interested in. For example, I almost always use assault rifles or submachine guns in multiplayer, and thus I have been able to purchase many of those with their attachments while ignoring the option of purchasing shotguns. The number of available weapons, perks, attachments, and killstreaks is about on par with that of Modern Warfare 2, which I thought was pretty well fleshed-out.Multiplayer Levels - There are a fairly large number of multiplayer maps in Black Ops, only a few of which I habitually find myself disliking. They cover a wide range of sizes and types of environments: day, night, snow, jungle, big, small, everything. There is definitely a map for everyone in this game. Some of my favorites are Firing Range, Cracked, and Grid, but that is just my personal tastes. I think overall the maps in Black Ops are a bit smaller on average than Modern Warfare 2 but perhaps just slightly larger than those in CoD4, to give you some idea.Gametypes - There are all the same classic gametypes in Black Ops as other Call of Duty titles, and even some new lobbies, such as the "Classic" gametypes that put players on an even playing field to start in some capacity, regardless of level.Replay Value - It's multiplayer. It never gets old. 'Nuff said.Cons:Gameplay - Some of the gameplay mechanics definitely need tweaking for Black Ops, in my opinion. In particular, the spawn system sometimes is very frustrating, either spawning players when an enemy is practically looking down their sight at them already or with an enemy claymore three feet away (it's happened to me personally). In addition, I've never been a fan of the insta-kill knife attack in Call of Duty multiplayer, preferring melee attacks to only insta-kill from behind as in Halo or requiring the player to pull out the knife weapon first as in CounterStrike; however, Black Ops has effectively given the multiplayer knife attack even more emphasis, as since the Commando perk from MW2 is gone Treyarch decided to basically give every player the knife range of having Commando. Additionally, the knife attack seems to have the area effect of a frag grenade, as many times killcams show players knifing others without even looking at them.Networking - There are currently consistent network problems with CoD: Black Ops on Xbox Live. It has taken me sometimes upwards of half-an-hour to successfully enter a game lobby with a party of 4 or more players, and occasionally the in-game connections are terrible with no host switch occurring. Hopefully this will improve in the future, though.Overall Online Versus Multiplayer Ratings:Gameplay: 3.5 starsLevels: 5 starsGametypes: 5 starsReplay Value: 5 starsNetworking: 2.5 starsOverall: 4.2 starsDead Ops Arcade (Zombies):Pros:Gameplay - Zombies is just plain fun. Everybody knows it. Whether you're playing solo, two-player split screen, or 4-player co-op over the internet, Zombie mode is both challenging and ridiculous at the same time. It's awesome.Cons: NoneOverall Dead Ops Arcade (Zombies) Ratings:Gameplay: 5 starsOverall: 5 starsTheater Mode:Pros:Presence - It's finally here! Since Halo 3 introduced its theater mode to online multiplayer shooters, I've been waiting for a CoD to do the same, and Black Ops has finally brought it. reviewText: OK.  So here is the deal.  I'm a gamer.  I'm an older gamer that now has kids that like to game.  Yes, we have several family friendly games, and then we have some M rated games like COD.  So I expect violence and a fair share of it when I play it.  What really throws me for a loop is the amount of profanity in the game.  Yes, I know it is disclosed on the box and that way parents can make an "informed" decision.  I'm starting to think now that I would like to see how many times a specific profanity word is used. Parents let me tell you, in this game, the F bomb is used a lot.  Enough to catch my attention and I've used it a fair amount in my earlier days.So bash me all you want about letting my 14 year old see this kind of violence and yet I'm worried about the language.  Actually, I think most kids understand that the violence they see on screen is completely fake and doesn't translate into the real world.  Let's give our kids some credit for that.  Words, however, are a different story.  That language is used by some everyday and not used by others.  However, the constant repetition of the F bomb, over and over is completely over the top and useless in the game.  It adds absolutely nothing to the story.  Zero.From a game standpoint, it is a decent game.  Graphics are good, AI seems to a bit more difficult and you get thrown into a lot of different situations rather than just being boots on the ground.  It was however, a little difficult to follow along with what was actually playing out.So my plea to developers is if you can have an option to tone down the violence (gore, etc), do the same for the language.  It can't be that hard to program in.
summary: Quit using the F bomb already!

Black Ops is the first Call of Duty Game I have owned. Since I bought my xbox earlier this year, I have been playing Battlefield BC 2, which is an incredible game. Black Ops stands up to it in some respects, which I would like to address in this review. First of all, the campaign for Black Ops is just aweome. It's hard to get into specifics without giving anything away, but I would say that the single player for BO tops that of BF BC2 for sure. Great game. Add in the extras that Black Ops offers - Zombie Mode, several Arcade games, etc.. and I certainly think it is worth the $. Now on to Multiplayer.. Black Ops' Multiplayer is a lot of fun, no doubt, but it pales in comparison to that of Battlefield BC2. It's almost like the Black Ops' multiplayer is dumbed-down to some degree. It kind of reminds me of the old Shooters for PC back in the day but with fewer players (i.e. Soldier of Fortune). In the end, the Bad Company 2 Multiplayer is so much more evolved in just about every way. If you are fan of War FPS games, you should absolutely have both of these games in your collection, but just know that the Multiplayer, while really fun, just isn't totally up to par (and if you have both games, you'll be going back to BF BC2 in the long run for your multiplayer fix :)EDIT - I traded this game after having it for a month. After beating the campaign and playing Zombies a few times, I didn't see myself playing it at all in the future. Black Ops is the first game I have ever traded (maybe the only one?), so that says something. I guess this would be a good game to pick up used or as a rental. The graphics are spectacular, but the game tempo is so fast, there's no time to enjoy them.  The game itself dictates WAY too much -- what to do, where to go, when to advance, etc.  "Get to the bunker! Take out those tanks!  Pick up this gun!  Help me open this door!  Get on the roof!  Follow me!  Grab the radio!  Get to cover!  Call in air support!  Get explosives on that wall!..."  And until you do what you are ordered, you will simply waste ammo fighting an endless army of enemies.I like being able to assess the situation around me, then begin dispatching enemies at my discretion before moving toward my objectives at my own pace, and following my own route.  That is NOT Black Ops, where you quickly advance into the enemies' hail of bullets, guns blazing, from objective to objective, in a limited field of play, sometimes under the restraint of a ticking clock.  For this reason alone, I had a hard time enjoying the game.  I actually had more fun hunkering down and picking off perpetually-respawning enemies than I did advancing through my objectives.Another big drawback is that the game seems to focus too much on the movie-like storyline than on the gaming action itself.  The cut scenes are incessant.  Not just between missions, but during missions, too.  Sometimes you cannot skip them, so there were times I'd find myself in the middle of the action, then an unskippable cut scene would come up out of nowhere, and I'd have nothing better to do except go into the kitchen and make a sandwich.  This interruption of play was so annoying, I literally quit playing the game after a few missions.  I don't care about storylines.  Just put me in the battlefield, give me my objectives, and let me do my thing.
summary: Gameplay is too fast-paced and dictatorial.

I was mesmerized and blown away by Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare when it first came. Death from Above and the Ghilli sniper mission easily stand out as the most memorable gaming event for me ever. Easily that game is a 9.5/10 ( or dare I say even a 10/10 ).CoD4:MW2 was excellent but more of the same and I'd say that is a 8.5/10. CoD:WaW is perhaps an 8/10.That brings us to CoD:Black Ops. I had really high expectations from this game. However, after playing this game, its really more of the same with even louder and continuous explosions and high octane stuff thrown in. Its like a Michael Bay movie every minute with lots of explosions, bullets whizzing by and general mayhem and chaos all around you with annoying screen shakes and annoying chaos. The graphics are average ( no where near MW or MW2 quality ), audio is too loud and annoying at times although bullet sounds are great. The gameplay at its core is still the same with auto lock-on and generally quite good. However, the FEEL of the game isn't as powerful or as drawing you in as MW. The story is really the best part of the game. Voice acting is also quite good.Overall, I'm happy with my purchase ( I got it for $20 cheaper through Amazon's excellent promotion ) because for a $40 game its quite good. But for a $60 game its not. This game will sell however. It'll easily cross $500 million by year end or perhaps even hit a billion. Who knows. But Activision is sure milking it - charging $60 for even the PC version (capitalism at its worst) and will probably soon offer like 3 older maps and 2 new ones for like $20 and people will still buy it. It'll make money and leave a mark in gaming history for sure, but the true people behind it - Infinity Ward who rejuvenated the flagging CoD franchise will start to get forgotten. And perhaps in a year or two, this game will go the Madden way where it'll sell but won't remain as good with like 3-4 hour single player campaigns with still premium pricing.I will rate this an 8/10  ( average and good but not excellent ). Definitely buy if you like CoD and perhaps even if you don't because you will be only the loser if you stubbornly hold out in some defiance.

Wow, there seem to be an abnormal amount of haters for this game.  Call of Duty Black Ops (BO) is a good game, I am not sure why people are rating it so low.  After reading many of these reviews, it seems that people have no idea how to logically rate a game, in fact, I would be so bold to say that regardless of the reasons given, it boils down to the fact that many people don't like this simply because it's different and more balanced then MW2.  I personally feel that most of the changes made in BO are for the better.The single player campaign is told in a more cohesive way and the story is pretty good, it doesn't have many of the "wow moments" that MW2 had, but it's still exciting nonetheless and has more of an emotional impact when it comes to your NPC team members.  It's about the length you would expect (5-7 hours) and there is an unlockable zombie mode upon completion.The meat of many COD games is the multiplayer and this is something BO excels at.  Not only do you earn experience points but you also earn COD points which is a form of currency the game utilizes (think Counter Strike).  This allows you to unlock what you want when you want it, it should be noted that some weapons are still only unlocked at certain experience levels, but you still have to buy them with your currency to use them.  It works well, although, I prefer the old system better of just unlocking new weapons as you level up as I find that the currency system lacks the addiction found in MW2 systems.  It's still fun and it leads to the biggest changes of the game which come in the form of `wager matches'.  Not only can you use that currency to buy weapons, sites, camo, killstreaks, etc..., but you can also use it as a down payment to enter a wager match hoping to come out of the match with more money then you had going in.  It's a fun system and something that works well later on in the game when you have currency to spare.  It certainly makes for some tense games when you have money on the line.So far most of the maps are great.  A lot of them have moving parts (train going by, missle launching, etc...) which is a nice touch and adds to the atmosphere.  The layout of all the maps seems to be stellar so far which is surprising because they did not have an open beta test period.  All enemies that I have come across hiding out in a room are vulnerable from some stand point, and no spot on any map really feels "safe".  I haven't really noticed an spawning issues like others have noted, although, on small maps such as Nuke Town, spawning close to the enemy probably can't be avoided from a code/design stand point.But the thing I enjoy most about BO's multiplayer are the small improvements.  Thankfully, the game ending killstreak - calling in a nuke, is gone.  The highest level killstreak you can get is 11, which is actually hard this time around because you can't spawn killstreaks like in MW2, so if you get killstreak 6 and call in a mortar strike and kill 3 enemies, you're killstreak is still 6, not 9, meaning you have to kill 3 more players with your gun to reach killstreak 9.  This is great because it makes it a lot harder to get killstreaks but more importanlty it helps prevent players from camping trying to spawn killstreaks, anything that prevents camping is a good thing.On the camping note, BO is not friendly to snipers, which is another awesome feature, I haven't played a map yet where it wasn't easy to spot snipers and take them out easily.  BO leans more towards a traditional run and gun type of play style which I personally prefer.Statistics!  Stats, and more stats, anything you want to know about how you play is located in the stat section of the muliplayer menu, how shots fired, deaths, kills, captures, etc... and much much more.  Also, at the end of matches you are shown more stats, not just kill/death info.  For example, at the end of a headquarters match you'll see your stats for; kills, deaths, kill/deat ratio, captures, and destroys.  This is a nice feature because it actually shows who on your team is actually trying for the objective,not just running around shooting people.Now the player has 3 spots in there inventory for items so you can have a frag, flashbang, and a claymore if you want.  There is new equipment you can carry now, a sensor which acts like a many personal UAV which you put in the ground and it displays movement near you, an UAV jammer which acts in a similar fashion, a camera that you can set up which replaces your radar with the camera feed.  There are also new special grenades to mess with such as the nova 6 grenade which emits a toxic gas cloud and a decoy grenade which emits gunfire and shows up on the enemy's radar as such implying that a real player is there which is great for causing confusion.Some of the perks have been rearranged too, stopping power has been taken out completely, although you really won't notice because you still die with only a couple of bullets.You can now dive to prone after sprinting which is just cool.Zombies, zombies, zombies, there is one level available to you from the start and you unlock the other one after completing the game.  I'm new to the whole COD zombie scene since this is the first game I've tried form Treyarch, but I find it to be a lot of fun.  It increases in difficulty quickly and you really have to work as a team if you want to make it far which is something that COD players have a hard time understanding and fail at so that adds to the difficulty.  I've made it further by myself then on a team of four!!!  The game style is a lot of fun, although it could be better if they added a simplified leveling system, I just don't feel like I get a lot out of it, some kind of permanent reward system (unlock special camo in multiplayer, or other guns you can use in zombie mode, etc...) would be nice.The graphics are good, they're actually a bit different then MW2 but still good.The game isn't with out it's faults though, but most of them are inherit to the franchise, not just this game.  Lag is still an issue, things like watching the killcam and seeing that you didn't fire at the enemy although you actually fired your gun twice, other players moving in segments, or watching the killcam and the enemy seems to be moving lightning fast, or the players who just drop to prone immediately but when you try it seems to take forever, etc...Also, they introduced a new game type called 'combat training' which is a great idea except it's executed horribly.  You can play by yourself against AI controlled opponents in team deathmatch or free-for-all, up to 10-11 bots I think???, this is great for new players to the franchise, or just for practicing out new techniques.  You level up just as you would in a real multiplayer match (points do not cross over) and it feels surprisingly similar to a real online match.  What doesn't make sense is that they require you to be online to play it???  Whaaaaaaaa, you make a game type specifically made to play offline and you require the player to be hooked up to the internet?  It doesn't make any sense.  I think it's mainly for tracking purposes (company feedback) so they can actually see how many people are playing combat training, but it's an odd design decision.This gameplay style will probably always be around, but it definitely is starting to feel like it needs a major refresher, game changing concepts need to start being introduced to this franchise.That being said, this is a Call of Duty game through and through, don't expect "team play" even if you're on a team, COD is all about lone wolf gameplay, although this is the most balanced COD game to date.  This is a great addition to the franchise and there is no reason you shouldn't pick this game up.Headquarters, here I come....***UPDATE (11/24/10)***Well, I have prestiged once now and have definitely had my fair share of multiplayer combat, both traditional and zombie mode.Here are some additional notes you might find important.  There has been an update which seems to have fixed most of the spawning issues found in the game (although I never really came across many), the downside is, now you spawn on the other side of the map to where the action is so it takes a bit longer to get back into things, which is a little annoying because COD games are all about quick kills, quick deaths scenarios, so starting closer to the action is more beneficial then starting far away.Zombie mode, is a lot of fun!  I"ve made it to level 18 now and it's a good time.  The one major annoyance I have with zombie mode has nothing to do with that actual game play itself but the pre-game lobby that comes with it and how the server handles the host.  Unlike the standard multiplayer lobby where a countdown timer begins when the server has found enough players (requiring no input from players) and if the host leaves the game during the match the server switches to a new host allowing the game to continue, which is a great system, one that zombie mode doesn't use.For some reason, they've done away with that idea with the online zombie mode which requires 3 of the 4 players to be "ready", which is annoying because when you have a system that requires the player to input something before a game starts only half of them do, therefore the game never starts!  The game 'FarCry 2's multiplayer did the same thing for it's main online matches and you had the same thing happen, you would be waiting in the lobby for minutes, not seconds, sometimes 5 minutes, which is just dumb.  It ruined the multiplayer for that game.  So the fact that the zombie mode utilizes this system is baffling.  Once 4 players have been found the match should just start, the players shouldn't have to press the A button to say that they're "ready", it's implied that they're ready by them being in the lobby waiting for the next match!  Why they didn't take the main multiplayer match making system and utilize it in zombie mode is beyond me.Regarding the host issue, if you're playing zombie mode and the a player leaves the match who happens to be the host, the match just ends, doesn't matter if your at level 1 or level 20, the match is over.  No host migration and the game doesn't repopulate the player slot either (if a player leaves who is not the host), which again is a odd design decision and extremely annoying especially if you're far into a zombie match.Hopefully in the future Treyarch will update the zombie mode with unlockables of it's own, which would encourage more players to get into I think as well as reward players who play it well.
summary: An extensive review for Call of Duty Black Ops (focused on Multiplayer)

reviewText: I really did not plan on buying Black Ops...I loved COD 2, but didn't like COD 4 at all.  After hearing numerous previews, and getting a good pre-order deal, I went for it.  This is not a perfect game, but it really is a lot of fun, and that's what I buy games for.I know most reviewers like to measure framerates, graphic comparisons, etc...I'm not big on that level of tech talk, but I can tell you the game looks and plays great.  I played through it once, and spent a lot of time online, and it has never frozen or even stuttered.  I didn't play the last two COD games, so I don't know how evolved it is from the last one, but as a game on it's own merit, it is a very good game.  There is a storyline that runs through all the missions...basically, the missions reflect some top secret missions occurring during the cold war era, in places such as Cuba and Vietnam.  Not revealing too much, the general plotline borrows a bit from the Assassin's Creed series; an unknown group is going through your memories from mission to mission, trying to get to certain information.  Some of the missions get a bit frustrating, but not deal-breakingly so.  There are a couple of levels where your next goal wasn't as obvious as it could have been, and this can be frustrating, but this doesn't make for a bad game, it just takes it from being a great game to being a very good game.  The controls are very smooth, and very easy to pick up.  There are a great deal of different weapons that you will use, which does a lot towards keeping the gameplay fresh.Though I haven't played the last couple of COD games, even I know that the multiplayer experience is really the focus of the COD franchise.  I'm not a fantastic FPS player, but I have spent a long time on that mode, and have really enjoyed it.  There are several different modes of play; you start with team mode, a mercenary team mode (players are randomly assigned teams) and a free-for-all mode.  Playing more and more of the game unlocks other modes, weapons, maps and contracts.  Contracts are basically goals within the game...beat a certain number of people using a certain weapon, for example...which you purchase using COD money earned by playing the game.  Meeting the goal wins you a certain amount of money from the contract; missing it obviously costs you whatever you spent on the contract.  There are wager matches, where you bet on the results of matches. There are special modes like One In The Chamber, where you start with a gun with a single bullet.  If you kill one of the other players, you get their bullets.  Otherwise, you must rely on melee weapons.  The progression of multiplayer really encourages you to play more and more, to unlock all the modes, weapons and other bonuses available.  This is really what brought me to get this game, the variety of gameplay available in multiplayer is huge, and will likely be about the only online FPS I will be playing for quite some time.  I am really not very good, but the matchmaking and gameplay variety have made it a real blast to play.  There is also a training mode for those of us who haven't done a lot of multiplayer games, or just want to familiarize themselves with the game before heading online.  I think this is a great addition to the game; hardcore players may never venture into it, but to others of us, it's a great training ground.Maybe my favorite mode is the Zombie mode.  Basically, you are locked away in a certain area, and must figure out how to accomplish some goals then get yourself out of there.  Zombies are coming at you with gradually increasing vigor, and you must deal with them.  Every time you kill one, you get a certain amount of points.  Points are not just a part of your score, they are used as currency.  It's up to you to decide if you want to spend your points on new weapons, upgraded ammo, or using them to open up a new area.  Do you hang out in a certain room, picking off zombies and running up your score?  If you do, you will hit the harder areas, with tougher, faster, deadlier zombies, so be careful how you spend them.  Make sure you finish the main single player mode at least once to open up a hilarious zombie level!This game has come with a ton of hype, and has already become one of the best-selling games of all time.  Don't let that sway you either way.  I have enjoyed this game a lot, there are tons of things to do, and s.  I would really recommend anyone with an interest in this game give it a try...but it, rent it, whatever.  I don't really have the basis of the last two games to guide my opinion either way, but on it's own merit, I think this is a very good game that is definitely worth playing.
The single player mode is fun, and engaging, but I found the online play a re-hashed release of MW2.  Worth renting, but only buy if you can find it for < $20.

reviewText: Call of Duty Black Ops has been highly anticipated over the past several months. It has broken almost every sales record for first day sales. Unfortunately, the game fails to deliver in many respects.In the single player mode, the plot makes almost zero sense until the last 2 missions. The menu interface (tied into the campaign story) is rather unique and quasi-interactive (there are a few achievements related to this menu system). Unfortunately, many of the weapons used in the game were not developed/used during the years in which the plot takes place. The SPAS-12 and Steyr AUG were not used in the Vietnam era.The game also uses the term "ACOG" in a generic manner to describe a variety of magnified optics. Generally speaking, the ACOG is a Trijicon product to describe its family of Advanced Combat Optical Gunsights. In this game, an ACOG could be a Russian POSP or the built-in optic for the AUG and Enfield L85.Some feel the multiplayer mode is the real gem of the Call of Duty series. Black Ops adds a Combat Training mode where you can play against Bots (Unreal Tournament, anyone) and earn currency for mods so you can try all the equipment/gear before you commit in the normal multiplayer mode. I felt it is more of the same. Once you've played a Call of Duty multiplayer game, you've played them all. The veteran players were already at level 20+ within a few hours of the game being released. I was still trying to get used to the horrible controller interface versus the more effective mouse/keyboard solution for FPS games.The zombie mode is kind of interesting, although you just encounter endless waves of Zombies with up to 3 other players online. Left 4 Dead is much better for zombies.The graphics aren't anything to write home about, and the audio is kind of sub-par compared to Medal of Honor and CoD MW2. I use Turtle Beach X41 Digital Dolby 7.1 surround headphones, and the positional audio in Black Ops is terrible.Overall, the game is moderately enjoyable in the campaign mode and the multiplayer mode is more of the same. It's best to play with friends, otherwise it feels like any other multiplayer gaming experience with random strangers. However, Black Ops was certainly not worth the release date pricing, although Modern Warfare 2 has not dropped much in price even a year after its release.I give it 3/5 stars. CoD MW2 was much better. Black Ops was just overhyped and overmarketed.
summary: Not nearly as good as the Modern Warfare series

I can't believe I'm about to say this about this game-- about ANY game.  This is a phrase I've never used before, but...I don't think children should be playing this game.Please don't interpret this as any right-wing nonsense or ESRB loving BS. When games like Grand Theft Auto and Doom (Doom?  Freaking Doom caused school shootings?  Are you high?) are lambasted for violence and blamed for everything the past two generations have done wrong, I laugh and boot up Gears of War for a while to practice my chainsaw gun skills.  But that's the thing with most of those other games; they exist snuggly in some absurd video game fantasy world.  A chainsaw?  On a machine gun?  Come on now.  We aren't learning a disrespect for life or... anything really.  In fact, I don't think we're learning anything at all, save for hand-eye coordination and basic story telling devices.  The idea that violating pixelated monsters and even human analogs is what's warping my fragile little mind is absurd.  And yet...Here I am, playing Black Ops (Or Modern Warfare, same basic deal), looking down my sites and firing in controlled burst at muzzle flash in the distance that I can only assume is the bad guy and I've got this strange feeling in my gut.  I don't know how to describe it, but it's a little nauseous (just a little) and a little uneasy (just a touch) and it's exactly how I felt while watching Saving Private Ryan (for the first and only time).  I'm engaged, I'm fascinated, I can't look away, but I'm not having 'fun'.  No, what I'm feeling now, I can describe it a lot of ways, a lot of positive ways even, but certainly not as 'fun'.I've never been to war, I've never even played paint-ball.  But there's a part of me that just knows for a fact they've nailed some real-world physics when making this game.  The battle cry of the gaming pacifists has always been that they desensitize us to violence when really all they (usually) do is desensitize us to FANTASY violence or the IDEA of violence, and those are very very very different things from ACTUAL violence.  If anything, I'd say we as Americans are among the biggest sissies on the planet when it comes to ACTUAL violence (think about what goes into a bull-fight or political riot or a freaking public beheading next time you hear someone complain about a damn football game).  But these modern war games are a step (admitted a very small one but the first I've seen since COPS first aired) of injecting real-world, honest-to-goodness, palatable murder into mainstream culture.  Am I saying they're responsible for school shootings and gang wars (do those still happen, or was that a '90's thing?)?  No, of course not.  What I'm saying is...I've no idea what I'm saying.  Maybe parents (especially those with young boys with anger issues) should take the extra step before buying their kids this game and play it themselves?  Maybe... maybe we should just acknowledge the steps we're taking in our entertainment, the level or realism we're demanding and how we've begun to strip away fantasy whilst still labeling as entertainment.  Maybe acknowledging that will be enough?  Maybe none of it will matter in fifteen years when the next bloody spectacle comes  out?  Maybe my guts are just too delicate?But, of course, the reviews are correct and this game is damn near flawless.  Tight visuals and sounds, compelling level design, serviceable story, voice acting that ranges from great (GARY OLDMAN!!!) to ugh-that-guy-from-Terminator-Salvation-again.  It's a good, flowing, extremely playable, top tier game.  And yet...Am I the only one beginning to miss the guilt free days of Nazi sniping?  C'est la guerre fantastique, I suppose.

This review is of the game's multiplayer experience.For those of you who fell in love with Call of Duty 4 and were disappointed by Modern Warfare's emphasis on camping, killstreaks, and spamming explosives, you will absolutely love Black Ops... and this is coming from a guy who detested Treyarch's last foray into the series - World at War.I was sorely disappointed in Modern Warfare 2.  Call of Duty 4 is - scratch that - WAS - my absolute favorite game of all time.  I enjoyed the pace and the strategy.  Modern Warfare 2, however, aimed to up the ante, and it did it at the expense of COD4's core gameplay.  It became all about the killstreaks, and the easiest way to score killstreaks was to camp and spam RPGs and M203s.  It was chaotic and random.  That's not to say MW2 was a bad game, but it wasn't what a lot of us were hoping for in the sequel to Call of Duty 4.Black Ops builds on COD4's pace.  Killstreaks have much less emphasis, so we're actually playing a SHOOTER again.  Gone is the Commando perk and dual-wielding shotguns.  Speaking of the perks, they are perfectly balanced.  Stopping Power is also gone, so you don't feel like you MUST use it.  You're not at a disadvantage for not using one or two "go-to" perks... you're actually free to experiment.Call of Duty 4 was epic in its innovation, but Black Ops is epic in its refine of that innovation.  If you liked Call of Duty 4, this is your game.  Get it.
summary: Solid gold - COD4's pace and gameplay is back

I'm pretty disappointed with this installment of COD.  It feels more like an old Medal of Honor game than a Call of Duty.  The story line is fine and interesting, but it just doesn't work for a Call of Duty game.  What made Call of Duty great and what separated it from Medal of Honor was the fact that it was a no nonsense war based shooter that featured pure combat from beginning to end.  There wasn't any of the bull you got with MOH that featured a bunch of sneaking around and secret missions and other boring stuff you had to wade through to get to the combat.  Now, with Black Ops, it seems COD is aspiring to be MOH and that's a mistake.  In fact, the combat in this game feels a lot like the combat in MOH Airborne.  It feels claustrophobic and extremely tracky, the guns don't seem accurate or feel real powerful.  The enemy doesn't seem real or smart, more like ducks in a shooting gallery.  Once more, for all their considerable gab, the main characters don't seem real either.  The graphics are weak for the most part and the whole thing just has a cheap 2D feel to it, perhaps summed up best by the scene at the end of the last mission where half the ships in the US fleet are jammed into the screen, all sitting about a foot apart.  I felt boxed in and rushed all the time I was playing the campaign mode.  The Zombies part of it was fun and funny for a little while, but it's a game that you can't win, that has no end, so what's the point?  The worst part is that there are no Special Ops with this game which was the best part of MW2.  Overall, despite all the copies sold, I'm forced to give this COD an average rating.  Want a great game?  Buy Red Dead Redemption.  Want average?  Buy this.

reviewText: I still play zombies to this day. The multiplayer may not be anything great, and is definitely out of date by now, but I personally still think it's worth it for zombies mode alone.

Just finished the single player mode and came here to see what people were saying. Surprised to see all the mediocre reviews, as I thought the game was okay. Considering it's a Treyarch game I'm actually impressed. Treyarch usually churns out CoD titles that are fairly standard shooter fare with not much artistry, but here they have aspired to a bit more, and CoD:BO sometimes looks like it was made by Infinity Ward - the same folks who made the original Modern Warfare (which is, in my opinion, the best shooter ever made).Not that there aren't problems. Sam Worthington's voice acting as Mason sometimes betrays his Australian accent. Also, the game tends to lose momentum whenever we get to the interrogation scenes. Also, there's an underwater mission towards the end which seems really tacked-on. We're told that there are 15 minutes left to complete the task, yet in real life it would take at least that long to get the equipment and suit up, especially given that scuba gear wasn't supposed to be a part of the original plan. Then there's the final scene, which takes MW2's over-the-top 'America number 1' jingoism and runs with it. But I guess that's where this series wants to go these days.But in general, this game is a heck of a lot better than MW2. It's mostly realistic - we don't have too much of that set-piece James Bond chase scene nonsense that ruined the previous CoD game, and Black Ops attempts (mostly successfully) to get back to the realism of the original modern warfare.
summary: Not as bad as some here are saying

reviewText: Like many other reviewers, I found this third installment in the modern setting of COD to be incredibly bleak. Let me explain...This game is almost an exact carbon copy of MW2 (which I have played extensively).  The gameplay and strategies for success are identical (run to cover, ADS, shoot bad guys, rinse and repeat).  BO tries to hide this by adding short sections where you fly a chopper or drive a boat, but it is easy to see that the heart of the game is not innovative at all.  New guns and "customizations" don't count: they are topical and do not add to the fun of the game.I always like playing game campaigns if for no other reason than to experience the storyline (Halo Reach comes to mind).  BO campaign is boring and redundant, which would be fine except that the storyline isn't interesting at all and barely even makes sense. I played through it on easy just to expedite the otherwise painful process of uncovering the plot.Multiplayer is equally bland.  If your interest in MW2 multiplayer is waning, then don't expect to be entertained for long by this game's online capacities.  Other than the usual spawn and die COD multiplayer, they added wager matches where you can bet COD points.  Ok, except that wager matches are dumb games like crossbows and gun game (a rip-off from counter strike) that don't reflect in-game skill, so what's the point of being serious about them?  Multiplayer apparently goes up to prestige 15 now. Good luck getting there.  I wanted to gouge my eyes out after 20 levels of presige 0.Zombies mode seems to be a redeeming quality for some players, yet I feel that it is linear and boring; similar to Halo firefight.  Spawn, buy guns, shoot zombies, repair walls, open doors, repeat, repeat, repeat...Overall, the game is just plain boring and is an entirely forgettable entry in the history of FPS.  That's what happens when you produce a game designed exclusively for the prepubescent COD fanboys who've made the previous games so financially successful.  Business is business, eh, Treyarch?
summary: A COD just for the fanboys

There's something strongly addicting about the CoD series.  And that works both ways.  On the pro side, there's a lot of repeat game play value.  That's great because the game is fun when it works.  On the con side, you get people who dedicate large portions of their lives to the game.  It gets insane quickly.  There are some very legitimately GREAT players.  I've seen Youtube videos of people who just have a knack for running through maps killing everything.  There are cheaters who manipulate software exploits, hack their controllers, or even their network wiring for an in-game edge.  There are people who pay for cheating services.  Then there are the boosters who deliberately throw games for their friends in order to help them in their quest for rank, eventually gaining them some special skill or weapon they couldn't otherwise achieve.  Most lately, clans have really taken the game over.  Clan members spend a lot of time coordinating attacks.  One particularly lethal tactic is pining the opposite side down on spawn points.  They kill the other side as soon as players are drawn on the map.  There are other styles of cheating.  A lot of players dashboard, meaning they quit a losing game early in such a way that saves their win/lose statistic.  One annoying oversight of the game, besides encouraging this kind of thing, is putting a new player in the last few seconds of a losing game.I am not a good player.  I think my kill-to-death ratio is a little above 1, which is laughably bad to more dedicated players.  I'm okay with that.  I swear.  As soon as I join a Black Ops multiplayer game and get killed 10 times in a row within a second of spawning, I get irritated rather than competitive.  I'm not going to go join a clan of people I don't know to be "the best around/nothing will ever get you down."  It seems silly.  A beer and a football game is more my style.  But it means I only play Black Ops when it's fun.  And unfortunately, that's an on-off relationship.A par system is the obvious fix here.  It seems trivial to me.  Spawn killing metrics seem easy.  As does pairing clan games.  (Why would any game pair six clan players against six strangers?)  And clamping down on some of the more annoying game aspects like dashboarding and picking up the tail end of a losing game seem really simple too.  All of this stuff seems very easy to fix.  There are thinning gaming profits, sure, and that's a concern.  But I think a par system to make this game universally enjoyable is pretty much the most critical next-step evolution in the series.  Unless "PAR SYSTEM" is a prominent feature of the next game installment, I won't be buying the game.

reviewText: From what I'm reading in the reviews giving this game a 1 star rating, I can only gather that there are a bunch of IW fanboys, with misplaced hate towards Treyarch, posting the reviews.  Now to what I think:Single Player:Easily the best CoD campaign ever.  This includes the steaming pile of fail that was the MW2 campaign.  The characters, locatations and set pieces are interestingly done and well excuted.  The graphics are outstanding in the campaign and the gunplay is smooth and intuitive. The voice acting is absolutely top notch and a strong point of the game.Bottom line is that if you are hating on this campaign, then you must absolutely despise the SP in MW, MW2, WaW, BFBC/2 and any other military FPS.  This campaign is unequivically better than each of those.  Not even close.Multiplayer:I've put in about 6 hours and haven't had serious technical issues.  There has been a few problems when trying to join a game in a group.  And there is some noticable lag, though not much from my end.As for the gameplay, it's what you'd expect.  This is a CoD game and developers didn't overhaul the mechanics or anything like that.  So if you expected this to feel like a "new" game, then you might be disappointed.There are some nice additions to the strategy component of leveling up your character.  Treyarch has implemented a currency system, which allows you to pick and choose what equipment/perks you want to buy.  You acquire cash based on your in-game performance.  You have to plan for the future when you acquire cash, and cannot just buy everything up (at least not at first). This is kind of a polorizing feature, but I like it overall.I think the level design is pretty solid too.  In my 6 hours of on-line play I haven't been noticing a crazy amount of camping.  While there are places to snipe, the levels are designed in a way that once you identify where the shots are coming from, there are plenty routes of ingress to go take out the would-be camper.Also, I think the weapons and gear are really well balanced.  When I'm playing I notice a great variety of weapons being used, which is a good sign, because that means everyone is not flocking to one uber powerful gun.Overall:This is honestly a great game.  Don't listen to the detractors who are going to whine simply because of how commercially successfully this game is going to be.  It's a wonderful package, with plenty of AAA content.  Oh, and I didn't even mention that there are Zombies!!!  Enjoy everyone.

I went straight from MW2 to this and it is pretty disheartening.  The game just doesn't feel as realistic as MW2.  Some of this is because of the graphics, which are not quite as polished as MW2, but I think mostly has to do with the sound.  I play on a giant HD screen with 7.1 surround and a big subwoofer.  With MW2 I could turn up the volume and actually feel like I was immersed in the game, the gunshots would be realistic, the grenades would sound realistic, but with this game it just seems like a muddled mess.  Things that shouldn't be loud are loud (shell casings hitting the floor, footsteps etc), but things that SHOULD be loud are muffled and relatively low volume (such as gunshots and grenades, flashbangs etc).  Also the gun noises seem off.  The are not "crisp" but kind of muddy - kind of heard to describe.  Anyway, It's still an OK game but not as good as MW2 in my opinion.
