I just got black ops and I've been playing around with it for a little over 6 hours now.  As other reviewers have pointed out, black ops is modern warfare 2...set in 1968.  First, I've got to say that the sheer amount of content packed into this game is absolutely staggering, but just content isn't enough to fill some of the game's flaws.  My main criticism is that Treyarch have seemed to just copy-and-paste modern warfare 2 and make some balancing tweaks and add new perks.  Hell, even the graphics are slightly inferior, which is just odd.  The RC car is absolutely overpowered, worse than the predator missile found in modern warfare 2.  A few things I have to applaud treyarch for doing are no nuke, insane customization, and a more balanced game.  I've experienced a few glitches and infinite care package glitches here and there, which is just mind-boggling.  How could that specific glitch make its way back into black ops from modern warfare 2?  If you're just an ordinary call of duty fan that absolutely loved modern warfare 2, you'll either hate it or love it depending on what aspects of modern warfare 2 you liked.  The single-player is the second best I've played in a cod game, second only to infinity ward's excellent and brilliantly paced call of duty 4: modern warfare campaign.  The pacing in black ops is absolutely over-the-top.  There is never a time to catch your breath, the explosions just keep on coming, and bullets keep on firing.  For some people, this may be a good or bad thing.Now, the multi-player is the meat of the game as that's where you'll be spending your hours away.  For the most part, everything seems polished and balanced although the RC car has got to be the worst kill-streak I've ever had to experience.  Unlocked only after 3 kills, this thing freaking kills like a mad-dog.  It's just overpowered.  Other than that, I don't have any gripes at the moment other than that infinite care package glitch that some people are using all the time now.Overall, black ops is an enjoyable experience with tons of replay value packed just like any other call of duty game.I rate it 4.5/7 overall and I suggest you buy it when you can.  Solid game, although it seems too much like a copy-and-paste and refine job to me.  Also, the removal of campaign co-op mode was disappointing.  I don't know why treyarch would take that feature out when they first introduced it in world at war.  The strong familiarity of many aspects of the game along with slightly inferiority in graphics is well made up for with the large amount of content packed into this game including the beloved zombies mode which is an absolute blast to play!
summary: It's a refined MW 2...set in a different time period

This review is going to be divided into 3 different areas: Singleplayer, Multiplayer, and Zombies. I will also give you the basic ratings at the bottom of the review.Singleplayer: Average COD campaign, it was short, intense, and entertaining. Surprisingly though Black Ops adds a bit of a psychological twist to the campaign which was nice to see for once. The story is pretty basic and didn't look like it took much time to think of. Once you've finished the campaign you probably won't go back, as there isn't really a purpose to. Also in campaign there are 40 "intels" located throughout the levels. Collect all of the intels and all you get is achievement points, I felt that they should of rewarded the player more for finding these.Multiplayer: This is where most COD fans spend the most time. Expect everything like perks, camos(which completely fall flat in this game), attachments, challenges, and killstreaks to return. Nothing new to the gameplay is added. The pro perks are a lot harder to get this time around. The camos are horrendous and looked like they were made on the paint accessory by some 6 year old kid. The killstreaks seem more balanced and the Tactical Nuke is gone. There are a lot more challenges which will help you level up faster. They have added a couple new attachments like the Flamethrower, dual mag, infra-red scope, and lower powered scopes. There are also a lot more guns, but lots of them go unused as they don't compare to the better ones. Another thing I really can't stand in this game are the maps. In MW2 I liked almost all of the maps but in BO I don't really like any. They are all to basic and have a boring feel to them. The leaderboards are also back in BO as expected. Except from some strange reason THEY DONT HAVE LEADERBOARDS FOR KILLS/WINS/ and SCORE, instead you have to look at someone's "Combat Record", which shows all their stats. Instead there are just leaderboards for game modes, which vary based on the objectives. Oddly enough, they don't record your amount of wins for each specific game mode, only the score per minute. They do have quite a bit of interesting stats in the Combat Record so its not that bad. Prestige mode is still here too, now its up to 15 levels though. The matchmaking online is also a problem. It can take up to 10 minutes to find a game sometimes. Also you'll be in a game and it will all of the sudden lose connection, which can be frustrating because it occurs all of the time. They have added something called Combat Training, which is multiplayer except with bots that can be adjusted to your liking. Also the game has split-screen online! Nice job Treyarch we've been waiting for this. To sum it up lets say the multiplayer is just like MW2, except with no tactical nuke or constant noob tubes. There are still issues like bad spawning and glitching, but we can't fix that.Zombies: Definitely the best part of the game. This was an instant hit from WaW so there was no doubt they would bring it back. The game starts off with 2 maps, Kino Der Toten and Five. There is also and arcade type zombie mode which is like a top down shooter. Kino Der Toten is a large zombie theatre. It is without a doubt the best zombie map, Treyarch really did well with this. It includes everything that the older zombie maps did plus new stuff, like the turning the power on, the random box, pack a punch, hellhounds, powerups, perks, rayguns and everything else you can think off. They add the new "Thundergun" and these new zombies which are called "Nova crawlers", they faster than regular crawlers and when shot they emit nova gas which distorts the players view. The map Five is not as good. It is smaller and quite difficult. Instead of dogs, the player will come across a scientist who takes your weapons. Five takes place in the Pentagon, and the players are Nixon, Castro, JFK, and the VP whose name I can't think of. Recently released map Ascension is also very fun. It is huge and is a lot harder than Kino and Five. Expect all of the same with new stuff. New perks include StaminUp(Makes you run faster and unlimited sprint) and PhD flopper(No explosive damage and creates explosion when diving). A new powerup is included called Death Machine, which gives whoever grabs it a minigun with unlimited bullets for 30 seconds. Death Machine is quite useful as it kills zombies instantly, also it shows up frequently. Instead of dogs and nova crawlers, you get Space monkeys! These are annoying and will completely wreck your game. The monkeys fly down usually around round 7 or 8. The monkeys go for the perk machines and if they touch them you lose that perk, they will also try to kill you if you're in the way. They aren't too difficult to kill but they can gang up on you which will be troubling. Ascension holds a lot of secrets and easter eggs which I won't spoil here.Graphics- 9/10Sound effects- 8/10Campaign- 7/10Multiplayer- 7/10Zombies- 10/10

There's been a lot of backlash against this game, and I'm not really positive why. Bottom line is if you like Call of Duty games, you'll like this. It's got everything you'd expect: Over the top single player, variety of weapons and levels, and an addictive multiplayer. And zombies.The single player game is maybe not as strong as far as gameplay goes as it's predecessor, Modern Warfare 2, but it's not quite on the same grand scale. However, as far as characters and story go, this is probably the best Call of Duty campaign of the whole series. The game has numerous twists and turns you won't see coming, and it all comes to a satisfying conclusion. I don't want to talk too much about the story as to avoid spoiling it. Also, the varied time periods and player characters keep the game very interesting. The voice acting, featuring Sam Worthington, Ed Harris and Gary Oldman is also very strong.The multiplayer has been overhauled from Modern Warfare 2, and some of the changes are great, others not so much. Instead of completing challenges to upgrade your guns and equipment, there is now an in game currency used for customization. This is great as you can pick and choose what weapons and upgrades you get and in what order, but it's not quite as exciting as the old system. "3 more kills and I get the tactical knife" is much more interesting than "3 more kills and I get a couple of hundred call of duty points." Still, it works, and is very addictive. The addition of wager matches, where you play customized game modes to win points (or lose them) is very exciting and having these modes to play as alternatives to standard modes adds a lot of life to the game.Zombie mode is a lot of fun, if too similar to the mode in World at War. It's a great time with friends, but solo zombies is a little flat. This game really could have used a Special Ops mode like Modern Warfare 2, as that could be a lot of fun alone.Overall I'd recommend it if you like Call of Duty games or other fast paced action shooters. There's nothing revolutionary, but there's lots of fun to be had.
summary: Lots of fun for action fans

reviewText: Call of Duty is a name well known in the video game world.  The game is released every year or two and each release brings with it tremendous sales and an insanely loyal (when they get what they want) online fan base.  Modern Warfare 2 from developer Infinity Ward was a success but didn't receive the critical praise it's predecessor garnered.  With Treyarch's turn to woo the world at hand with a new game, will they succeed or are they forever doomed to be that other development company behind Infinity Ward.I'm probably one of the only people in the world who buys Call of Duty games for the single player experience.  I view the multiplayer as an added bonus that I play, but I'm mainly interested in the single player component first and foremost.  With that said, this review is going to focus primarily on the single player first and then I'll cover the multiplayer.  To date, I've beaten the campaign on normal difficulty and played about 5-6 hours of online multiplayer including zombie mode.  So, how does the game stack up compared to others?  In my opinion, it's the best yet.The single player story begins with your character (Mason) tied up in a room with TV screens all around you.  Someone from an overhead viewing window is yelling at you to remember some set of numbers.  After some introductions between the two characters and Mason realizing he's capture, you begins to flashback to the past at certain points in Mason's life, all circling around the Cold War and all playing a part to tell the story.  The first area you go to is Cuba where you are on a mission to kill Castro during the Bay of Pigs.  When you are finished the mission, you are whisked back to the interrogation room in current time.  The game is played through a sort of flashback segments that work incredibly well to tell the story.  Gone are the days of long hikes in a field to get to the next objective...instead, you are just transported there due to a memory jump.  Think of it sort of like Assassin's Creed but not exactly.During the story, you'll control a couple characters, but Mason is the main one.  I've heard some reviewers say that since you flash to and from a lot that you never get invested in the characters and their story but I didn't find that to be true.  I was definitely invested in the story from the get go and felt for each character.  The story overall though is the best you've ever seen in a Call of Duty game.  I'm a huge story fanatic when it comes to video games and I found myself looking forward to cutscene after cutscene to see what was going to happen next.  The story is great, but you might see the end twist coming a mile away like I did.  Still, it's a great story and it's a welcome addition to the series.The gameplay is the same formula you know and love from the Call of Duty franchise, except with the story set anywhere from 1948 to 1968 in the Cold War, you're going to be using a lot of different guns.  But, since you are an elite Black Ops team member, you'll have access to some weapons that others have never heard of for the times, like a shotgun that has exploding bullets that set targets on fire.  Something else that was more prominent in this game vs. the others was the use of vehicles.  There's some driving sequences but the really fun stuff takes place in the air in helicopters.  There's also a level where you start in a spy plane scouting the ground for a team trying to advance in a snow storm.  They can't see so they need you to guide them.  You have to navigate them around enemies and patrols and if they engage anyone the action zooms into the team and you take over for them.  This was an awesome mission that I really enjoyed, although it was short.  The combat in Black Ops is very similar to the other games so if you liked those, you'll be fine with this one as well.The entire story will last you around 6-8 hours depending on how you play it.  I tend to take my time and explore areas so it lasted longer for me.  Just because the single player game is short though, don't think you won't get your money.  Besides multiplayer (which I'll cover soon) there are other features included on the disc.  For starters, Zombie mode returns with the same winning formula that got it so much attention the first time around.  For those of you who aren't familiar with the mode, you play someone stuck in a building with zombies trying to get in.  You shoot to kill while also bording up windows and unlocking new areas to keep you safe.  Each kill nets you money which can be used to open up said areas or unlock new weapons.  It's great fun and you can even do it with a few other people.  I would have liked to see some more changes to it since it basically is the same game as before, but there is one awesome change they made that you'll see as soon as you beat the campaign.  I won't ruin the surprise.Something else included with the game is a top down shooter that can be unlocked from the main menu.  You need to break out of your restraints on the main menu by rapidly hitting the right and left triggers.  When you stand up, make your way to the computer and interact with it.  You can enter in two codes, DOA and zork.  DOA opens the top down shooter that is co-op enabled and something I would have gladly paid 10 bucks for on the marketplace.  The other is zork, a MUD that you probably won't play ever again after messing with it for a couple seconds.  Both open a new achievement though, so, you're welcome for the codes.The graphics in the game are nice, but nothing spectacular.  It looks like the engine they used in previous games hasn't been tweaked much since the models and explosions look very similar.  This isn't bad, just nothing new.  I did see some screenshot and video comparisons of the 360 version and PS3 and the 360 version is easily discernible as the better graphical version.  The only reason I say this is if you are like me and have both consoles and you want the better looking one, the Xbox 360 is the way to go with this one.  But, if you don't pay for Xbox Live, the choice is already made up for you.  Just something to keep in mind.Ok, on to the multiplayer.  The multiplayer this time around got a pretty big overhaul in terms of Call of Duty changes.  You still level up just like in previous iterations, but the levels come a lot faster.  Instead of unlocking weapons and perks at specific levels, you earn currency in the rounds that you use to buy items.  So, when you hit a certain level a bunch of weapons/perks, etc. become available for purchase all at once.  You then level up and earn money which you can then go and buy the one you want.  Hardcore fans of the multiplayer might be disappointed with the change, but I think it's a welcome addition.  I'm not a huge multiplayer fan because of the time sink involved.  With this new method, I can get to a level, earn some cash, and then buy my favorite weapon instead of having to level up a ton more to get it.  You get what you want, when you want it, in the order you want it.  You'll still have things to look forward to since certain weapons are only available at different levels.  Along with these changes, there is also a theatre mode (like Halo has with it's forge) where you can watch gameplay videos from your games and then change camera angles, save, and upload to the net for others to see.  I haven't played with this yet, but I did view some from other people.  The community is already taking part in it and it looks to be a defining feature of the online game experience.The customization is another aspect of the multiplayer game that has been adjusted.  Your first perk you choose decides what your character will look like.  You actually get to see a ragdoll of your character and you can change the perk to change the look.  You're going to pick the perk you like best and not the look but it's still near to see your character before going into the game.  Before, weapons decided the look, now it's the first perk.Another new feature to the online multiplayer is the wager system.  As I stated before, you earn money from rounds to buy things.  Well, if you are a gambling man, you can bet money to win more money.  There are a couple new modes (which I haven't tried out yet so I'll keep this brief) which allow you to bet money to place in the top 3.  These modes include things like "One in the Chamber" where you get one bullet and a knife to kill everyone.  Kill someone, and get another bullet.  Others involve bow and arrows and incremental guns with each kill.  This is going to be a fan favorite for a lot of people do to the very competitive nature of the games.  But, if you aren't that great at multiplayer but still want to bet a little, you can do the contract system.  With these, you pay to accept a contract and then try to meet it within the time frame.  For instance, the one I took yesterday had me pay 50 bucks to get 10 kills in the next round.  When I did, I won my money back plus some.  It's a neat system that people are going to love.  If you don't, just ignore it since it won't affect you.Call of Duty: Black Ops is a huge game.  So huge, that you would expect all of it's features to come on two discs, but they don't.  Treyarch has gone above and beyond the "call" to make something that is not only a great game, but is their own.  This is the game that sets them apart from Infinity Ward.  World at War was a great game, but there was still a feeling leaving them as the other developer.  That sentiment is now gone with Treyarch's love and affection put into a game that is the pinnacle of the series.  Black Ops is hands down the best Call of Duty to date.
summary: Call of Duty: Black Ops - Review

reviewText: Before all the haters and whatnot give their middle finger to Black Ops, consider first the technical achievement of such a game, the sheer background processing that handles all the stats, graphics and supporting data while keeping the frames running at a more than acceptable rate. It's truly remarkable.Second, Ops delivers so much content. Again - so much content. No arguments here: you get the single player campaign (about 12-14 hrs.), zombies (which has spawned DLC Rezurrection), and multiplayer (brimming with tons of accessories for weapons, callsigns, different game types). On top Treyarch also released DLC for Ops, meaning more maps and more hours of fun.Third, the game looks fantastic, a clear step up from Modern Warfare (yeah, I know it's two different companies producing titles). There are more shadows, realistic environments, and moving objects. There are also contracts you can buy to increase your stats and your money. The end battle report is more detailed and fun to read.I didn't give Ops five stars for technical reasons and for the new money system used to buy weapon add-ons and callsigns. The game lags sometimes and drops the connection more than I expected. I assumed they would've dealt with this problem before. Also, I didn't like having to buy everything, especially weapon add-ons that I unlocked already, and the emblems for weapons, reticle types, camouflage design for weapons, and callsigns. I loved earning callsigns and emblems from MW2. Buying them isn't as enticing.That's it. Black Ops is worth it. Any reviewer who writes using words like "sucks," "worst," "terrible," or any other dysphemism better give a good reason to back up their argument. Otherwise, STFU and play.

I'm simply blown away after playing through Black Ops. This is a review for the gamer who just wants to have a good time. After playing through this game, I had a blast. It's rare for me to be so absorbed into a game and dedicated to beating it on the spot nowadays. Games just seem to have lost their charm. But Treyarch sure outdid themselves with this one.This is coming from a person who HATED World at War. It just wasn't for me. Taking notes from Infinity Ward's COD game last year, Modern Warfare 2, Treyarch took what that team did right and perfected it. This game had me in awe on every level as I played through it. It's so full of action, the budget I'm sure is in the millions.This game really makes you feel a part of it as you play through the levels. It's not just simple run in a room and kill everyone, then move on to the next. It has constant changes to the environment that you must adapt to, such as a bridge you are running on gets a huge hole blown in it, and as you almost fall to your death your teammate helps you up. The A.I. characters aren't just cardboard cut outs like in some games, they actually have a personality to them, and they help you out on your missions. I actually felt for them when they were killed.One thing I like about Black Ops is you are never lost. Thanks to handy indicators, it's always easy to know where to go, or what your next target is. The control is spot on. Aiming is precise, and the weapons handle like the real thing. You are going to blow through hundreds of enemies, yet everybody in the game seems to have their own way of living, the ways that they hide behind cover, shoot at you, scream to their squad you are coming, and the ways they die. It's not the same animations over and over, everything seems new as you come to it.The game always knows when to switch up the flow of the action. There are so many different vehicles and such that you find yourself in, it's always something new. You might be in a boat, shooting missles at everything in sight. You'll find yourself in a tank, raining absolute carnage on anyone and everyone around. This game feels like the most epic action movie of all time, yet it could never be a movie because the budget would be in the billions.It's just so fun to play this. I haven't had as much fun with a game in years, to be honest. I'm not some typical COD fratboy who lives and breathes for this series, I'm just a normal gamer and I came into this game expecting a great time. This game exceeded my expectations, it blew me away. The campaign has a great, detailed story and was also quite long for an FPS title. You travel all over the world, and it's just great to see these environments.The graphics are beautiful, absolutely stunning. I'm sure that this game pushed the 360 to it's hardware potential. It's certainly the best FPS on the console, and probably the best FPS of the last decade.For some reason I was reminded of Goldeneye on N64 as I played through this game. Missile silos, facilities, jungles.. it's all there. Yet as much as I loved that game back in 1997, I don't think I had as much fun with it as I did this game. Black Ops really brought it's story to life, and really drew me into the game. I felt for the characters, I would jump and scream as I stormed through absolute chaos, blasting everything in sight. It was just a great experience, and I haven't had this much fun in a long time.I even see myself replaying this campaign, which again is something I rarely do. I strongly suggest this game to everyone. Whether you like games, wars, or just straight up action, you have got to get this. It's simply awesome.
summary: Get rid of all your other FPS's. This is the only one you need.

reviewText: MW was awesome but too many spam nades and the M16 was overpowered/overused. WAW was great but the MP40 was overpowered/overused. MW2 was a mess. Overpowered/overused noob tubes, sniper rifles, killsteak awards, shotguns (also having shotguns as a secondary weapon), and perks. It was also a major campfest. Black Ops tweaked it nicely. I have a nice 1.8 kdr which the highest I've ever had in a COD. Noob tubes, sniper rifles, and shotguns are nerfed. Shotguns are only used as primary weapons instead of a secondary. Killstreak awards are not overpowered/overused with maybe the exception of the chopper gunner. Perks are balanced now but a few seem worthless. There are some camping but it's not as bad. Me and friends love it as most of the BS is gone. Takes more skill now rather than depending on overpowered stuff in my opinion. New recent patch has a little more stable server and lag. Graphics aren't as shiny as MW2 but still good. Sound and music is nice. Gameplay is great as always.
summary: Best and most balanced COD multiplayer! Love it!

reviewText: Epic single player and story, addictive and well balanced multiplayer with great maps, fun zombies mode.  This is the most value for money in video games.  I will be playing this game for years.
I bought this as a gift for a true gamer, and they really enjoy playing this.  I wouldn't exactly call this a guy game, but I'm sure that most guys would enjoy this.

Overall, this game is not up to the high standard that Modern Warfare 2 (and 1) set. Like it or not, that will be my comparison point.Graphics: Are a mixed bag. Some levels look really good, especially the desert levels or those with lots of orange or tans. The multi-player level with the houses feels like it is something out of 1990's with little detail...REALLY, it's that bad. But other levels look the part of a Call of DutySound: Again a mixed bag, but mostly bad. The footsteps are just AWFUL..I mean wow. Because you here them the whole game they are a huge distraction. I have a subwoofer and holy cow is the bass cranked up too high in the menu screens, I mean I am paranoidMenu screen and functionality: Much clunkier to get around inGameplay: Same smooth gameplay, running at 60 fps, that Call of Duty is known for.While I know the hype for this game is off the charts, it is really running on the fumes of past game success and I can't whole-heartedly recommend it. I would recommend Halo:Reach (a finely polished deep product) or just get Modern Warfare 1 or 2. But if you are a fan of COD, there are things to like here, I'm not saying the game is bad...it's just got too many problems in it to be good.
summary: This is not on MW2's level...

reviewText: I was somewhat reluctant to purchase this game, though I have all the other versions.  The best improvement was the multiplayer options.  One of the portions was called Combat Training- It allows players to pratice with friends and/or AI bots.  This seemed to be a good way to get in a groove before going online.  I like some of the new weapons (though the setting is The Cold War).  The single player version in alright, nothing really amazing.  It was fun to experience the Vietnam setting; driving a boat, flying a chopper, etc., otherwise I didn't see a drastic improvement.  The zombies mode actually seems to be a little less exciting. reviewText: I have heard the most ridiculous flack about this game. Well first off, they are wrong. In the past few years, I have seen some major improvements in the Call of Duty franchise. Most would say(including me) that these improvements are legendary. And Black Ops amps it all the way up!Lets start off with the single player campaign. You are an agent who's identity is wiped out from the records. His name is Alex Mason. This game starts off by you waking up in an electric chair. You are being interrogated to get answers. Now I'm not going to tell any more about the story. So lets jump to the gameplay. If you want an intense single player campaign and gameplay, this is it. This gameplay is fast and energetic. You will be glued for hours. If I must, I will point out one flaw to this game: the graphics have to load up. That's it though. It does not affect the gameplay what so ever. Oh, just to let you know, the levels are flashbacks to get the answers I was previously talking about.Okay, I've gotten through the single player, now lets go to the multiplayer! I have heard major flack about the multiplayer. Treyarch amped up the multiplayer to a whole new level. You get a way bigger variety of multiplayer modes. And the truth is, you get some pretty wacky modes. For example, you get wager matches. I gotta to tell you, that could very well be the best mode. Okay, so the multiplayer maps are pretty good. But you might not want to get this game if you like to snipe in multiplayer. There aren't any advantages for sniping. But if you just want to go to an all out bloody battle, this is an absolute must own. Just to let you know, if you love all out bloody battles, you will absolutely love a multiplayer level called Nuketown.So if you want a CoD with an intense single player campaign and a highly anticipated multiplayer, this is a must own. So if you do want this game, go pick it up at any local game store ana make it a great day!

I feel this game could have been much better. I am not a "hard core" COD fan or a "MW2 fanboy". I actually hated the original Modern warfare game but enjoyed the 2nd (don't ask why, I don't understand either). I also attribute the reason that there's so many bugs and differences in this game compared to others because Treyarch is now the developer of the COD series. The old developer, Inifity Ward, made every COD game until now, and for some reason Activision decided to drop them and pick up Treyarch. Not sure why, but if I did some research I'm sure I could find out. Anywho, the game play is fairly good, and the graphics are nice as well. I don't use an HD tv (20 inch CRT) but everything still looks really good so I can only imagine what it's like in 1080p.Let me get to the Campagin. I haven't finished it yet, but it seems solid. I don't really understand what it is completely about (why he's strapped down and who's talking to him) but I'm sure that will come in time. The AI seems fairly decent, especially since they have killed me numerous times and angered me to the point of having to turn the game off. I haven't experienced many bugs in the campagin which is good. The voice actors are good (Ice T!) and it seems pretty straight forward. I don't expect the game play to take much longer because the Campagin's for COD series are usually relatively short and most of the emphasis is based upon the multiplayer and other lil things you can do in the game (Easter Eggs too!).This brings me to the multiplater...which really needs a massive patch. I have read reviews on here that state players having trouble getting into the games, creating parties, and parties always being dropped. I am right there with you. Treyarch royally screwed up the multiplayer. I think they wanted to push this game out so fast that they didn't test it far enough in the labs. Other bugs include shooting enemies but the shots not registering (and when they kill you, it looks like your just standing there with your thumb up your butt), grenade pins being pulled but the grenade mysteriously disappears when you die (common, isn't this supposed to be "realistic"? If i pull the pin and I die before the grenade is thrown, the grenade should still blow up!), and other various bugs that make the game really hard to continue playing.I do not agree with Activision's choice to drop Inifity Ward and make Treyarch the new COD developer. I think if activision would have kept their agreements with Inifity Ward, this game could have been better. I would honestly have rather waited another month or so for all the bugs to be fixed, then to play a game that jerks and doesn't play right. Maybe I'll update this review when they do patch everything (if that happens) but as of right now, this is why I give the game 3 stars. It is fun to play when it works right, but people don't enjoy playing games that don't work correctly.

Below I have rated and reviewed each of the gameplay modes...SINGLE PLAYER CAMPAIGN (3/5)The campaign is okay. It's short though. It is approximately 4-6 hours of gameplay. It starts pretty slow for the first two hours, takes some unforeseen twists and turns, and then gets pretty interesting. The last two hours are pretty adrenaline-filled. The "Nova 6" gas was a pretty good horror element, creating disturbing scenes and moments of despair.The character development was poor, especially compared to Modern Warfare 2 or even World at War. I didn't care much about the main characters and I had no idea who they were. I just knew I was supposed to follow some rambo guy with no personality.MULTIPLAYER CAMPAIGN (3/5)COD has a distinctive multiplayer. The mechanics simply are "whoever shoots first wins". You have to be ultra aggressive and reckless in multiplayer to even get a few kills. The maps are small, claustrophobic, and are not sniper friendly. There is little room for tactics and strategy. It's a game of reflexes and nothing else. Some people like that, others don't. It's very hard to be stealthy too. An alternative multiplayer game for those who don't like this style is Battlefield: Bad Company 2. The maps are a lot more spacious and its much easier to hide and plan. Anyway, I digress. I heard that on February 1st the first Black Ops DLC pack would be more sniper friendly and have more "vertical" terrain. We'll see what happens.ZOMBIES (5/5)Who doesn't love the zombies mode introduced in World at War? The COD zombies experience is memorable and one of the best zombie games ever made. You and up to three friends have to fight off increasingly difficult waves of Nazi or Commie zombies while upping your game by buying new weapons, opening new areas, and utilizing traps. It's ridiculously addicting and provides a compulsive experience.The map Kino der Toten is really fun. I guess the developers were inspired by the movie Inglorious Basterds to make this map. It's a run down Nazi movie theater with several rooms, an outdoor alley, and a large theater. There's even a camera room you can teleport to that features the pack-a-punch machine and is inaccessible to the zombies. You only have 30 seconds at a time in that haven though."Five" is a tongue-in-cheek trip of hilarity and horror. Players fight as JFK, Nixon, MacNamara, and Castro in the zombie-breached Pentagon. On top of the pack-a-punch, mystery box, and other elements from the past maps... there's elevators that you'll want to camp out in when things get overwhelming, as well as a thief that "steals" your equipped weapon every 7 rounds... unless you gun him down which is hard. It's good clean fun.In the "First Strike" DLC which comes out in February, there will be a new zombie map called "Ascension". I hope they release the classic zombie maps from World at War too.OVERALLBlack Ops is worth getting for zombies alone. Multiplayer may or may not be to your tastes, COD veterans will probably like it... newcomers may have a hard time getting a kill streak going. The campaign is worth playing, but only good for a rental if you're not interested in multiplayer.

reviewText: The overall storyline in CALL OF DUTY: BLACK OPS focus upon Alex Mason, a member of the CIA's Studies and Observation Group (SOG) or Black Ops for short.  The game opens with Mason tied to a medical chair, surrounded with monitors with a non-descriptive disembodied voice asking him questions.  At the same time Mason keeps hearing and seeing a list of numbers.  It's unclear until about halfway through the game whether Mason has been captured and is being interrogated by an unknown enemy or if he is being questioned by a friendly force trying to extract life-saving data from him.  The game progresses through a series of flashbacks that show what Mason has been through and how he came to be in the chair he is in.  The flashbacks take the gamer from Cuba and the Bay of Pigs to Vietnam to a frozen wasteland near Russia and to beneath the ocean. The climax of the game leads up a climatic battle that loosely ties to actual history.The overall graphics in the game are spectacular.  There are many times that you look around and get the impression that you are playing a movie and not a video game.  At certain points in the game, the images are extremely lifelike.  The voice acting is strong and the music does an excellent job of accompanying what is happening during the story.I usually don't play multi-player levels, but BLACK OPS has a special multi-player/co-op mode where you can fight a zombie horde.  The "Zombies" mode is exciting and addictive.  I just wish there was an end point somewhere; the zombie hordes never stop invading.With that said, CALL OF DUTY: BLACK OPS is a disappointment.  The overall storyline is short and the "reveal" at the end is disappointing.  I mean, do we really need another Manchurian Candidate scenario?The way the game operates is frustrating, too.  BLACK OPS has been marketed as though it offers a more expansive and innovative gameplay, but that's just not the case.  You have to complete each objective a certain way, otherwise the game doesn't progress and you are killed.  The A.I. buddies that fight along your side don't do anything during actual combat and the blunt of the enemies attacks are always at your character.  If you try to hide and peak a shoulder or a toe out, you're dead in a few seconds.  There's no thinking outside of the box and if you try, you die.  During battle sequences, if you stay in one spot it doesn't matter how good of a shot you are or how many enemies you kill because they just keep coming and coming and coming.  The men at the Alamo had better odds than you do if you attempt to stay undercover and fight it out without advancing.Beyond that, I was also disappointed by how little you actually get to play in certain environments.  BLACK OPS was marketed as being a Cold War video game.  For example, despite the historical negative connotations of the actual historical war, the prospect of fighting in Vietnam as a secret covert agent is exciting.  You imagine all the possibilities of fighting and surviving in a jungle and think of a video-game version of Rambo. Instead, you are given a few sequences that have to be accomplished in a certain way and only about 25% of the game being spent fighting in Vietnam.  It's like playing a game in the American Civil War only to find out that for over half of the game you're neither going to be a Yank or Reb but will be playing a Native American in a completely different conflict between two warring tribes out in Montana.Overall, the graphics and voice acting are superb, but the storyline is weak and the gameplay is frustrating and non-innovative.  BLACK OPS looks fun from the outside, but when it sees the light of day, it's a disappointment.  The best thing about the game is the Zombie mode.  Kids will probably enjoy it, but those over 16 or anyone who is a more experienced gamer will probably be disappointed by it.

Call of Duty:  Black Ops is an extremely good game.  It's not perfect, but when compared to the earlier Treyarch releases it is much better and with luck will keep the series moving in a direction fans love.  I have this game for the PC and the XBox 360 and I've not only enjoyed both, I've been impressed with how well the graphics look on the XBox, given the huge differences in hardware:  gameplay appears to be a stable and smooth 60fps for me.What I love about the single-player campaign is that the story is intricate and contains some surprising twists to it--and what seals the deal is the history behind it.  The story is set during the Vietnam War and also touches on the Cuban Missile Crisis and the Bay of Pigs incident.  There are a couple of things depicted in the game that aren't quite accurate, but it's been enjoyable getting details from Vietnam veterans I know (and from the Internet).  It's still a very plausible campaign and there is enough variety in each level and its goals that you don't feel like you're being handed a map and a paltry excuse to shoot it up from one end to the other.When it comes to multiplayer, I really enjoy the way it feels:  it's not just the fact that the technology is fairly accurate to the times, it's that even without Modern Warfare styled gadgets you can get a lot of tactical fun out of running and gunning across the maps.  We still have airdropped care packages and we still have the occasional ability to light up the map with a radar sweep that tags enemies with red dots.So the only thing really keeping Black Ops from a 5-star rating are some minor cons.  Like with every shooter, you'll have moments where your feet get stuck or you can't move because you can't see the treestump next to your ankle that's blocking you.  I've learned to forgive those moments because they happen in any game.  With Treyarch's "World at War" there were times that the enemies seemed to be willing to spawn forever if you didn't move to tag the appropriate hotspot on the map.  This happens a few times in Black Ops and it can lead to some real Groundhog Day style moments.  The other con that I'm hoping goes away is that there will be times a checkpoint triggers at the worst possible moment--and if you die, you respawn into a bad situation that may take you a dozen revives to get past.  I only had this happen a couple of times, but it left me thinking, "You have GOT to be kidding me!"  Frustrating, and sometimes it causes you to deliberately have to be foolhardy and rush in on a bad situation knowing you'll take a hit or two.  I'd rather push forward acting as if bullets are a bad thing that I can't just brush off by hiding for 10 seconds.  It can get silly when some of the enemy AI are foolish enough to step out in front of you or stand next to cover, but at higher difficulties this happens less.Overall, if you like the Call of Duty series, this is a great entry into new territory.  It's got an excellent storyline and the multiplayer on the XBox 360 is loads of fun.
summary: New Tales for an Old War

reviewText: This is a really fun game.  It's a building game- basically you have to rebuild a certain number of structures within a given timeframe. The replayability is built right in, as it seems to force you to change your strategy every couple of "towns" to master them with a gold star.Each town seems to take 10-15 minutes to complete, so you can play alot of a little during each session and still make progress in the game.There is also some sort of "easter egg" hidden on the title page I think, by following the butterfly around and clicking on the right "item" to trigger an action, however, I cant figure out when to click what I think is the last item in the sequence.

I'm a game fanatic. Royal Envoy was likeable and enjoyable because it's simply fun. It's fascinating watching the different men at work! There's a cuteness and enjoyability other games don't have. It's concept is quite different. Play it and see.  I'm not one for blood and gore.

In Royal Envoy you are a Royal city planner/designer sent by the King of your nation to help the storm-ravaged people of the neighboring country of Islandshire to rebuild their cities and towns. As a master administrator you must hire workers and tax collectors to repair the homes and reconstitute the economy of each ravaged domain.  The game is broken up into multitudes of scenarios that must be completed in order to advance. What I like about this game is that it's very easy to control. You click on the screen where you want a house or a sawmill or market or whatever to be constructed and workers rush out and start building it.  You click on the bank to send your tax collectors to withdraw assets.  Every house you build earns money, every bank earns money.  You use that money to purchase resources, workers, statues, gardens, street lamps, etc.., in order to meet the goals of each scenario.The animation is wonderful, very fluid, little characters with hammers and saws build the structures, little tax collectors make bargains with market vendors, and the goals for each scenario are different.  For example, in one scenario the goal is to construct three fully upgraded villas and have the "happiness" level at 30. The next scenarios would have different goals. You increase happiness with finishing touches like gardens and lamp posts, and other trimmings.  A nice point is that there is no real time limit to finish each scenario, but there is a "gold star" time limit.  If you finish the scene within the gold star time..., before the timer runs out..., your points are boosted and you earn achievement trophies. but even if you don't finish it before the gold star time runs out you can still continue and finish the scene, and you will still get some points and a score simply for completing it. If you finish a scene but don't get a gold star, you can go back at any time and try it again. To me, a casual game should be casual.  It should be challenging to a degree but not make you work too hard to enjoy it, and this game qualifies in that respect. This game strikes the right balance.The ease of gameplay, the excellent animations, the relaxing music, and the feeling of accomplishment when you have completed each scene makes this a very entertaining game.  The game worked perfectly on my Windows XP system.  The game has low system requirements so I don't expect anyone would encounter trouble running it.

I had doubts through the first few levels -- it seemed to easy to complete the level and get bonus.  Just wait! After completing the levels I am now going back to see if I can earn the Gold Star bonuses on the levels I didn't complete in gold star time.  I highly recommend this game!

I played America's Army for over 10 years but it died when the U.S. Army decided to UPDATE it.  It had a following from ALL over the world. I even joined a clan and we had about 40 members with 10-12 of them from others countries like Belgium, Holland, Italy, etc.  I still play the older version 2.85 and still find 170 servers available for it (Sat. Dec. 4, 2011 there were 165 players playing). The newer version is 3.0 but it is so different it is NOT the same game, in fact it is more like a cheap version of CoD or BF.Some of the game play and even some of the sounds in ArmA II games are very similar to America's Army (referred to as AA, search "AA Army" and you will find downloads for both versions). I think that the developer for ArmA II probably helped develop America's Army. However, America's Army was fun and easy to play, and it was a simulator too but MUCH MORE intuitive than ArmA II is.One thing that made America's Army more realistic is there was NO single player mode, and you had to go to boot camp and COMPLETE IT before you could play. Another thing is that there was no re-spawning like in most games. You could call for help from a medic but if they did not get there quickly you would DIE. Even if they ministered first aid to you it might not be enough, depending on your wounds. Also, being treated by a medic did NOT restore you to 100% health like ArmA II does! You could bleed to death from your wounds (bleeding you could still play until you bled to death, which could be 1 minutes or five minutes. When you died you had to WAIT until the next round started, but you got to spectate your own team while you waited. Which could be very beneficial if you had some good players on your team, you could watch them in action and learn some good tips.As for ArmA II, it seems very similar and has great potential. However, the computer generated Opfor (AI) can see in the DARK, and see through walls, etc.!! Often I am crawling through the tall grass and an Opfor sees me 500-600 yards away and starts shooting at me, and getting a few hits on me too, and I CANNOT EVEN SEE HIM!! I understand it is ALL ABOUT how they setup the program to detect your location but COME ON how real is that? I thought that this was SUPPOSED to be a SIMULATOR? I am ex-military (4 years) and a retired cop, over 20 years on the force and even a swap sniper for 5 years.In the sniper mission, "One Shot One Kill", its dark or dusk and I cannot even get to the target. For one thing I only have 10 minutes and the target is like 2 miles away, it takes me almost 10 minutes to get there, running the whole way, which EXPOSES you to detection to patrol and the troops at the location you are SUPPOSED to sneak up on? I NEVER get to even see the guy I am supposed to shoot "Spider". When I get even CLOSE all of the Opfor see me and start to OPEN UP on me, even the armed vehicles!!IF before I get too close, I try to crawl the last 300 yards TIME RUNS OUT. Also my so-called SPOTTER is stupid! He is always shooting at EVERYONE, alerting the Opfor to our position. I know I can tell him STOP-NO SHOOTING but IF this is a simulator I should not have to. Like I said I WAS A SNIPER FOR FIVE YEARS. If I had a spotter like that, I would have him fired or I would shoot him myself.Another problem with almost ALL fps games is the lack of REAL physics, such as, if you are a sniper looking through your scope it is moving around like you just ran a marathon. Or after you have been running a SHORT distance they have you SLOW down and huffing and puffing after 20-30 seconds!!It is obvious the programers have had NO REAL experience and they are NOT getting good input from someone who does have that experience! A good, experienced sniper will NOT have that kind of scope movement, and IF the guy is a REAL experienced soldier, and especially if he is SPECIAL OPS he will be in TOP SHAPE, able to run long distances, WITHOUT getting tired for 2-3 or more minutes.I AM REALLY LOOKING for a "REAL" SIMULATOR (Spec.Ops and Sniper), that gets it RIGHT. Been playing almost EVERY fps for over 15 years now! Sniper: Ghost Warrior is one of the best for simulating a Sniper but it too needs some improvements.True there are LOTS of controls in ArmA II, IF you like to be a MICRO-MANAGER (control freak), but in REAL LIFE you actually DEPEND on your team having BRAINS enough to do some things WITHOUT you having to be TOLD EVERYTHING, like, "Take cover", "Don't shoot", when we are trying to SNEAK up on people! Or just the opposite "SHOOT" when they are being shot at!!  If I have told them to hold their fire, they won't shoot even when they are shot at. Ha Ha, I believe in FOLLOWING ORDERS but it is COMMON knowledge and practice, "DEFEND YOURSELF" in combat, and "When fired upon RETURN FIRE."When I am offered a new mission I must press the numbers 0 then 8 > 2 > 2 > 1 to communicate that I ACCEPT the mission. I should be much simpler than that, like TWO numbers of like in AA, press a letter "T" and then a menu pops up with a selection of messages. Some lead to another set of messages, etc.TOO many controls, too convoluted, huge learning curve and the graphics that are NOT that impressive. I had to LAUGH at some of the YouTube reviews with titles likes, "THE MOST REALISTIC GRAPHICS"!  They are OK but not that great, and the movements are not very realistic either.AGAIN, I thought that this was supposed to be a SIMULATOR?I would give America's Army ver. 2.85 FOUR-FIVE STARS and America's Army ver. 3.0 TWO STARS. ArmA II THREE STARS but it would get more stars if the AI was not so bad and the graphics are JUST SO-SO! ArmA 3 is LOOKING GOOD though.I have NOT given up on ArmA games yet because I see it has, what appears to be, a large community, it has POTENTIAL, and it IS NOT a RUN n' GUN type of game, which I do play but I get TIRED of these 11 year old kids running amuck, and all of the CHEATERS. Ha let me get a hold of one of them CHEATERS, they would NEVER cheat again, bunch of wimpy little cowards.

reviewText: ARMA2 is a realistic military simulator, probably the most realistic on the market.  It's not just infantry combat, although you can play it that way.  ARMA2 also has cars, trucks, tanks, helicopters, planes, and more.  It even models ballistics and bullet drop, if someone fires at you from 200 meters away you even hear the bullet hit the ground before you hear the rifle.  It's a big sandbox, which is good and bad.The game ships with 2 islands, a large and a small.  Both have forests, hills, roads, towns, fields, mountains, etc.  I'd say you would spend a good 15 minutes driving from one side of the island to the other.  If you can see it you can go there, there are NO invisible walls.  The game locations are fictional, although they are based on real-life topography.  ARMA2 is set in Eastern Europe, Operation Arrowhead is set in the Middle East.  The possibilities on the huge playing areas are almost endless.  You can also download user-created islands, some of which are impressive in both scope and detail.A mission designer is included to make your own missions, along with sophisticated scripting capabilities.  In addition, there are hundreds of user-created mods and missions, everything from a simple "destroy the enemy" mission to new weapons, vehicles, sounds, etc, to new game modes like "capture the island" and a GTA clone.In a way there are almost too many possibilities between official and user-made content, and the quality varies.  The official missions have some neat tricks, although they don't expose you to everything the game has to offer.  Some things work well, others don't.  You'll have to find a way to manage missions/mods and all your time gathering, installing, and playing all the different things.  A launcher like "ARMA II Launcher" helps you manage what mods you want to use.  There is plenty of help on the official Bohemia Interactive forums, although they are picky about posting in the appropriate forums.Although the visuals and presentation are quite good, ARMA2 is quirky and not without bugs and oddities.  Just mapping the controls is an adventure, what's the difference between "Prone" and "Go Prone?"  You'll use practically every key on the keyboard, although remember you can map something like Control-G for landing gear or Control-E to eject.  With a large playing area and so much going on, performance is also an issue, ARMA2 benefits from tweaking and downloading mods to do things like get rid of motion blur and tame the tall grass a bit.There is plenty to do in this game for both single player and multiplayer.  Setting up local, LAN, or Internet games is smooth and easy.  It even remembers the last IP address you manually typed in (I'm looking at you OFP Dragon Rising!)  Co-op missions, deathmatch, capture the flag, and more are all there, and with mission designers being able to do scripting plenty of different game modes are out there.  There are "Warfare" or "capture the island" missions that add strategic and real-time-strategy elements as you build your base, build units and vehicles, and try to take over towns while searching for the enemy base.  You can choose to be a soldier and take orders, command a squad, or be in high command mode and command all the units.  The learning curve on Warfare modes is moderately high and documentation is scarce, but they are very unique and rewarding.If you have the time and patience and like realistic military combat simulators, ARMA2 will delight and amaze you.  If you're a run-and-gun sort of player with a short attention span, this probably isn't your game.  It also helps to be somewhat computer knowledgeable and have good hardware.  I have a 2.4 GHz dual core AMD, 4GB of RAM, Windows XP, and a GTX 250 video card.  With tweaking it runs acceptably on my system, but I wouldn't want to play with much less.  I'm saving my dollars for a solid state drive (SSD), from what I read ARMA2 does a lot of small file reads and greatly benefits from the almost 0 access time of SSDs.
summary: Complex but rewarding military operations simulator

reviewText: A super-realistic modern shooter, "ARMA 2" has a bit of a learning curve, but can provide satisfying, in-depth tactical experiences."ARMA 2" is a first-person shooter developed by Bohemia Interactive. It was developed with many aspects similar to an actual military training program used by armies worldwide. Most notably, ARMA 2 is incredibly realistic with regards to things like ballistics, weapon range, and weapon damage. The usual FPS run-and-gun tactics won't cut it here - teamwork and quick thinking are a must to be successful in ARMA 2. Some relatively simple changes to the usual FPS framework make realistic tactics a necessity. For example, being shot at makes your aim less accurate - as such, the tactic of "suppressing fire" works in ARMA 2 when it does not work in most games. These tactics aren't too hard to learn, but gamers trained in traditional shooters will have to shift their thinking about how to win.ARMA 2 has an extensive single-player mode, featuring campaigns as well as individual scenarios, but the game's best aspects are found in multiplayer (whether cooperative or competitive). Players running around willy-nilly make easy prey for coordinated players who make good use of communication and tactics. The maps are huge to allow for vehicles, which also means that soldiers can engage at realistic ranges (from hundreds of meters away). This prevents the standard spray-and-pray mentality from gaining ground.The game features a robust editor for creating single-player or multiplayer scenarios. Some light scripting is required, but there are plenty of easy references on the internet for it. For the most part, the editor is intuitive and simple - place units, place waypoints, place triggers, and so on and so forth. The game is also fairly easily modded. A variety of expansions and DLC packs provide even more content - "Operation Arrowhead" is the biggest one and provides the most benefits, while the other ones are recommended only for people who are really interested in their niche subjects (like "the Czech army").The game's graphics aren't exactly great, but considering the scale of the game this isn't really surprising. They're certainly "serviceable" - not ugly, but just not up to the par of modern AAA games. The game's sound is a little weak, too, but unlike many games the sound serves a gameplay purpose. There is no "useless" background noise - every gunshot has an actual source on the map, and every spoken word communicates actual information about what allies (or enemies) are doing. Especially notable is the game's disjointed voice system, where characters will give orders and refer to objects or people in an "assembled" manner. For example, an AI commander may give an order to "move" "right" "50 meters", with each fragment being spoken separately. The overall effect sounds weird, but is useful for conveying information "naturally" rather than in a scripted manner.Overall, ARMA 2 is certainly a different experience than most games, and may frustrate gamers looking for a quick pick-up shooter, but the depth of play involved offers an incredibly distinct experience that shooter fans shouldn't easily dismiss.Rating: 9/10.

Definitely get the version of the game with the microphone because it is REQUIRED to play. There are easy, normal, and hard difficulties so anyone can play. A nice feature is that there's singing while you sing so you can keep on track, unlike karaoke, and the singing gets quieter if you sing really well so you're the singer. Also there is playback with some hilarious voice-alterations. Also, while you sing they show clips from the entire movie the song is from, so you get the feeling of watching the movie instead of just the song.RECOMMEND (because it's really fun, and so that they will make a sequel!!!)

reviewText: I'm not much of a singer, but the kids love this game. Seems quite challenging, but they are having a blast.

I bought this because I love Disney, Disney tunes and I love singing. I sent it back. Why? The song selection isn't good. For example, it had three songs from Cars and Toy Story, but only one from Aladdin, Beauty and the Beast, The Little Mermaid, and Mary Poppins? Those four movies alone have great soundtracks with a lot of fun songs to sing, yet they only had one song each? I had no desire to sing songs from Cars or Toy Story and having not seen the Princess and the Frog, I have no idea what those songs were. They did do justice to Cinderella and The Jungle Book, but those were about the only one. Okay, I enjoyed Winnie the Pooh. They didn't even include the theme song from Beauty and the Beast (the song included is Be Our Guest, which is mostly a "speaking" song).The nice thing was there was no unlocking levels and the songs were straight out of the movies. That means, there was a lot of talking in the songs, which I didn't like either. I would have preferred to choose soundtrack or movie to sing with. In other words, I'd rather sing with Elton John, then the movie version of "Can You Feel the Love Tonight."The vocal exercises were extremely easy for an adult, but I suspect they might be useful to a young child, say around 5 years old. The mic was very nice (USB) and very durable with the Disney logo.If you are buying this for a young child, make sure he/she knows a lot of the newer stuff (Cars, Toy Story, Princess and the Frog, etc.) and doesn't really care about the oldies. I would not recommend this for adults.

I'm 20 years old, a HUGE Disney fan and a major karaoke fan! Put it all together and you've got yourself one heck of a time. I purchased this and a second microphone and I absolutely love it. The only downside is the not-so-huge song variety. The difficulty is average, not too hard and not too easy. I love it though. Very fun for everyone. Played it with friends not too long ago.

and what I got did not disappoint. I am a fan of the Dynasty Warrior series though I have not bought every single iteration of them. I got this game for Christmas. The beginning of the game has all these tutorials and if you dont want that simply hit options and disable the tutorials. This was a big issue of frustration for me initially. There are also alot more features with designing the house and with it comes some new buttons to know how to operate which after learning them simply add to the individualizing accuracy of the game. There are still some new features I'm discovering. I really like being able to have and create multiple floors on the houses. The couples or single parent can also have either four or five children by adoption or by "woo-hooing." The kids grow up from infants, to toddlers, children, teenagers and then become young adults. You can choose traits that go with them that they exhibit (example would be excitable which means they are easily excitable). For the adult starting characters they can grow well into graying senior citizens. Initially this caught me off guard and I did not realize you can disable the age feature in the options menu. So in one of my games I now have two gray haired elderly sims and their toddlers. The female sims also become comically pregnant in which they display morning sickness and later grow a belly. They also dramatically arch their backs backwards when walking. The reactions by your other sims when the mother sim gives birth is hilarious! There is now alot more individualizing of the sims character in how they look than there was before. However, one big problem I had was that you cannot not only buy empty lots (which isnt such a problem since you can simply delete the whole house by using the sledgehammer button) but if any of one of your sim characters move the rest all are erased from the game. If you move you can choose who to take with you but for the rest left behind they cannot come with you and are not to be found in the game after that. To me that became a big issue of irritation since when the kids move into young adulthood they cannot leave unless you want them to become deleted. I think they also shouldve added a bigger game booklet with more detail because alot of it I had to look up on the internet. The game seems to have more complex controls than before and a better instruction booklet wouldve been helpful. When I was perusing the online help guides apparently others are also similarly frustrated by the lack of information and detail. Also if youre like me and like to get a feel for the game before you learn all of what the controls do simply hit at the beginning of the game your start button and under options hit disable tutorials. The game tutorials frustrated me initially and they dont go away unless you go through them. You cant simply hit a button and they flash away quickly like the other sims games.
summary: Great new features but one big downer

reviewText: I'm going to admit that I haven't had a ton of face time with this game. Sure, I know the ins and outs of it, how it plays and such, from watching someone else play it for hours on end (I bought it for them), but I've only done rudimentary stuff with it personally. I will say that what I played of the game is better then I remember the original Sims game being way back when, and very very much better then the original Sims port was for the PS2 when I had that. a game that swore me off console ports of Sims games. The fact that EA decided to simply port the entire game to the consoles, instead of just an objectives based half-port, is exciting to me.I'm also fairly surprised that they were able to map the buttons needed to play the game to a controller so well -they're a little convoluted, but they work.But, you might be asking, why don't I play it more then, if it excites you so much? Well, the answer to that is actually where the two stars I've knocked off come in.While watching the game be played one day, the person I bought it for and I decided to get something to eat and come back later. Okay, fair enough, save the game, turn off the console, go eat. Well, later when we came back to it and they loaded in their most current save -something you'd do with any game your playing. But when the save loaded the game became a choppy, corrupted mess. After closing the game and restarting the 360 multiple times, the game save itself was obviously corrupted.Obviously angry, we started a new game and built everything up over the next day or so. Next week, when we had more time to sit with it, the game was --again-- corrupted, pretty much everything lost to a horrible stutter-y mess.Now, we both knew that Sims games do this, its been a series staple to suddenly have your games get funky after so much work is done, usually in spite of your dedication. But you'd sort of figure that if your going to bring a game to the consoles, a game so well known to have bugs like this that its becomes a series wide joke, that a little more care would be taken to weed out the problems.. But, of course, that seemed to be asking a little much from The Sims and EA.Overall, if the game didn't corrupt on a irregular basis, for unknown reasons, I'd be playing it -and I still might on a separate 360 profile, so I don't net unwanted achievements on a game that I'll never be able to finish out. But the problems so bad that the person I bought it for isn't really even wanting to spend time with it any more, which kind of makes it feel like a waste of money. Tread with caution on this one.(Side note: As of writing this I'm pretty much 100% positive that EA's never bothered trying to patch the issue, though they did know about the issue when I spoke to them about it about a year ago)
summary: The fun of The Sims 3 on your 360, if you can stomach the glitches.

reviewText: I had my doubts about this game because of limitations on the console and handheld versions of the sims and sims 2. There are limitations but it does not interfere too much with gameplay.I will list the new features and limitations and gameplay changes of the xbox 360 version of the sims 3.Pros: Since this is being played on a console, there is no need to worry about the usual performance issues that frequently plague pc users, the pc versions performance is iffy and unpredictable, but on the console version, there is no need to worry.Karma powers, challenges and rewards and achievements: One of the best features of this game. Karma powers let you do stuff like raise/lower all your sims needs, make them learn skills at an accelerated rate or make them super lucky for a couple of hours. You earn points at midnight and for completing wishes. As for the challenges, there are many, i think 300 challenges which will have you complete every aspect of the game and will extend your play time for many hours.pros/cons: These are a list of things that can be good or bad depending on how you look at it.Building limit "fire code": I personally am happy with the build limit overall, but there are a few things like how planting seeds take up a good amount of space on the meter, so making the perfect garden at your dream mansion you worked hard for may be hard to do. Also the most expensive pre-built mansion is not really a good choice if you want to customize, i would suggest the second most expensive mansion, there seems to be a less strict building limit and the design of the lot offers more space.Glitches: Though mostly bad, there are some neat glitches in this game, like how the repair man gives you a free $4,000 laptop after he comes to your house, but there are some game stopping glitches how the game thinks that there is a karma power active and does not let you save after 20 sim weeks of progress, or how items from your inventory disappear after moving to a new lot.cons:Right off the bat i will talk about slow fast-forward times. I thought it was slow in the pc version, but it is much worse in the console version. Occasionally the clock may jump forward faster when all sims are sleeping, but it is not much of an improvement and rarely happens. I spent the past 3 hours playing and waiting for my plants to grow. i have been waiting 90% and playing the other 10% of the time. I had time to watch a movie while occasionally unpausing the game or tending to my plants which brings me to my next issue.Almost every event that happens in the game will make your game pause, such as useless opportunities, when sims get job promotions or when those sims ask if they can talk on the phone. So not only does the game take forever to fast forward, you cant just leave the game running because eventually it will pause automatically.Because of the way the game is setup no two created families can interact with eachother, it is one family per save and you cannot modify, delete or add any community or neighborhood locations and you are stuck in one area that may have a park, and a couple of residents, so if you want to travel in another part of town, you must sit through a long loading screen, taking away the freedom to roam you had in the pc version.In conclusion, this game is fun to play to complete challenges and get achievements, but lacks the sandbox style gameplay in the pc version.
summary: Limitations on the console version but the new challenge mode adds many hours of challenging gameplay.

reviewText: Had only played the original Sims on the PC years ago.  Saw that it's out on the XBox360 and thought I'd give it a try.  WOW!  The hours fly by with a "just one more day" mentality.  Game is extremely easy to dive in to, but be warned - while you may be able to customize your Sim, there will definately be unexpected results!  And I mean that in a good way.  A few, minor negatives - everyday (well, most days, depending on your career) your Sim goes to work (the hours vary), and while there the options are limited and you usually sit waiting for those hours to go by.  Same goes for sleeping (unless you don't have a burgler alarm!).  It's also sometimes difficult to decipher the moodlets that often popup - it would be nice if the were listed somewhere in the rather sparse manual that comes with the game.  Also, I can't figure out how romantic relationships work (maybe the game imitates my life?).  You can date someone 500 times and have their like bar max'd out but you'll never be given the option to "go steady" or "propose marriage", yet other times you'll be given those options for those that only like you half as much.  But these are minor quibbles more than anything. I can say I definately recommend this game!
summary: Will eat hours of your time.....

reviewText: I got this game because I got it at a good price and I figured that I would try it.I was disappointed by this game due the large amount of things to do, but no motivation to do them. Your sim can do a lot of stuff, but its mostly boring and mot worth your while. Building and customizing houses is fun, but it is just about the only fun part in the game.

I absolutely LOVE this game. I can't seem to stop playing it! I recommend it to anyone who likes to play games where you can be a thief, writer, businessman, politician, or an artist. There are many goals and achievements that are easy to unlock but there are quite a few challenges that are not so easy to complete, but it's not frustrating at all.

It's been a while since I've been this addicted to a video game.  I played the first Sims and I loved it very much though I felt there were definite limitations to the console version.  Fast forward to the Sims 3, and it's definitely a much more fluid and fun experience than the first game that I played way back in the day.As someone mentioned here, it's fun to play God.  It's even more fun when I have the chance to create real life friends in the virtual world (they even look and act eerily like the real people I know) and see what kind of crazy awkward situations you can put them in (or watch them flourish in specific job situations and/or hobbies/talents).This game is like a black hole that sucks away any sense of time you may have in the real world.  On the first day, I sat through 11 straight hours without even batting an eyelash (other than to grab a quick bite or two and use the restroom).  That's how addictive this game is.  It's incredible that you can have so much control over everyone's lives, as well as how you make friends, interact with NPCs, and learn skills that really define who your Sims are over the course of their lifetimes.  I also like how there is so much attention to detail in terms of how you can design and build the home of your dreams.  You can landscape, paint, wallpaper, roof to your heart's content, and buy all sorts of cool stuff to put in the house.I have heard about the glitch involving people who have game freezes due to possibly too many objects in their inventory or game (I have yet to encounter this problem, fingers crossed) - however, I'm just being very careful about how I manage my stuff in game and am hoping that the problem doesn't affect me.The game controls fabulously.  There is definitely a bit of a learning curve at first when you pick up the game.  But once you figure it out thanks to some helpful tutorials, it will all make sense and feel like second nature to you.  I do notice that there is a slight lag when it comes to load screens in game (and there are a lot of them) but for the most part it didn't distract me that much.  I was too busy in my little sandbox, watching my Sims move up in life (and watching my kid grow up).  Throw in some intrigue (such as one of my housemates bringing her lesbian lover home for some "woo hoo"), a little karma here and there (which is one great addition to the game - it really makes it fun when you can use 'powers' to create dramatic situations) and you have the recipe for an amazing game that will suck the very life out of you.My challenge now is to not ditch my real life friends because their Sim counterparts are just that much more interesting lol!
summary: My real life is over, thanks to this game
