I just wanna add to the already excellent reviews here for AC: Brotherhood. I have been an avid fan of the series since the inception and now on the 3rd game I am totally immersed in the AC world! Nothing could go wrong in this 3rd installment. My anticipation for this game shoots up the roof when it was announced. But then I was asking myself how could ubisoft create another one in the series in such a short period of time? 1 year to be exact between the release of AC2 and AC: B. So I thought to myself that perhaps they have a separate team working on this title while the other team worked on AC2. How thoughtful indeed to keep the masses to continue have an undying interest in AC.So what is the difference between B and AC2 you might ask? The story continues where AC2 left off. The minute the game commenced, you are in the exact same spot where AC2 ends and then the story developed incredibly and expanded in all directions. I have loved AC2 and then B gave me a whole new world and possibilities to toyed around and dived into the life of the protagonist and his journey. I really thought at the time AC2 came out it was an awesome game considering that ubisoft have added so much to AC2 and created a new hero Ezio. I thought to myself what could ubisoft possibly top themselves with this new one? I was amazed and disbelief with all the new addition to the gameplay, story, character development, side quest, the awesome soundtrack and the entire package as a whole. This is something to be thrilled and enthused about.The minute the game starts, you are put in situation where new development take place. The action and the adventure placing you in a world of imagination, bewilderment and awe in the AC universe. I felt myself pulled in to engage in an ancient battle between the good and evil in a world unlike anything I have seen before. I really love playing as Ezio since his introduction in AC2. Now I can continue to play as him and find out more about his journey and adventure. His family, mother, sister, uncle Mario and the rest of his alliances are such an exhilarating experience to discover and and to be part of. And the new addition to the gameplay especially being able to be on the offensive side if you choose to is a great new feature found in B. Ezio is now able to do so much more compared to AC2.The side quests are just enormously exciting and invigorating to take on. And Rome is such a magnificent and vast world to wonder and to explore. The people, the structure, the environment, the location, the time period and the overall representation of Rome is incredibly inviting. I find myself immersed in Rome, wondering about and completing side quests, collecting treasures, flags, feathers, assassinating borgia captains to liberate its town, people from their tyranny. Building the town up from scratch in its different province after liberation is also very additive as the more I build the more money I have in the bank allowing me to upgrade my weapons and armor and to help progress the story and experience the AC world like never before.Another point I want to add is the Romulus quests of treasures in the underworld of Rome. The diversity and the platforming is just unbelievable! The discovery and the exploration is vastly expanded. Compared to AC2, B toppled it easily and in every way. Love the climbing, jumping, shimmering and swinging from one location to the next to discover a world beyond words. It is at times so spooky and intriguing and the other so inspiring to uncover whatever is hidden. There are 6 Romulus treasures to be explored and each is vastly different from the other, giving you a diversified experience and amazement that ubisoft has thought this out incredibly well and the execution of these 6 treasures design is commendable.The thought of building your own clan or brotherhood is greatly added to the mix. I found myself wanting to recruit more assassins to my cause, send them to missions all over europe to better themselves and to allow them to gain experiences as an assassin so that their ranks and levels would increased overtime and enabling them to be a valuable comrade when I need them or when circumstances calls for their aid. This is indeed a new awesome addition to the game and the world of AC at my disposal. I could have never been able to progress without the assistance of my fellow assassins. So it is truly a wonderful experience to have backups and to know that I have other assassins at my side supporting the creed and purpose of our existenceLastly the soundtrack just compliments the game in every way. The universe of AC is greatly enhanced with the emotions and feelings for Ezio and his quests. I find myself experiencing B like never before. The composition, the choir, the orchestration, the soothing female voices and the dark male voices, the suspense and the thrill it creates when in conflict or when engaged in missions, battles or your quests to right the wrong really brought the game to a whole new level. The experience is indeed extremely elevating. As I am writing my reviews, I am on my third play through. I find myself craving for more and wanting to experience Ezio's liberation for Rome and to build my brotherhood and to see the creed of the assassins take center stage. This is indeed a world I have truly come to loved and adored at great length. Will you take the plunge into the world of Assassins? I'm sure and confident that AC3 will toppled AC:B in its own way. Only the extremely talented team at ubisoft can execute such endeavor.

I spent about 30 minutes on the single player just to get the controls down.  I was bored quickly.  There are way too many cinematics.  I would skip one only to go straight into another one and then a third with no gameplay in between.  I have an imagination and the whole point of playing video games is to control the character and create your own story.  I dont know why video games spend so much time on story.  If i wanted to watch a movie, i would go see a movie.  You know the story is going to suck because if the writers had any talent they would be making movies, not video games.  And if a game has a long drawn out story, it is most likely to cover up subpar gameplay.  But on to the multiplayer.I cant stop playing it.  The matchmaking is slow, but once you make it to the game it is a blast.  The game types offer good variety, but i would like to see more.  There is no reason why you couldnt do capture the flag or protection modes.  Mostly, you will be tasked with killing one player while another is trying to kill you.  There will be several npcs that look just like your target and they act like a real player though they dont really run.  That means running is a dead give away, but sometimes you will have to.  You get the most points for patiently walking up to your target and slicing their neck, but you know that at any moment your own neck might be sliced.  This results in many moments of panic when you make a break for it.  You either get a lesser kill or a rooftop chase takes place.The powerups you get for leveling up are also great.  Disguises, smokebombs, flashbangs, a one shot gun, speed boost, or the ability to morph some of the crowd to look like you.  The ways to kill are endless.  Do you walk, hide in some hay, or take to the rooftops?  This multiplayer is not for everyone and I was hesitant because some reviewers obviously do not like it.  But, i had to try it and i am not disappointed at all.  I will take this over call of duty everyday.
summary: No love for the single player, but the multiplayer is awesome.

reviewText: Having played the whole series this game has polished an already fine game to a fine luster. I just got this last week because I have so many other games to play and I had not finished AC2. I have been playing this several hours per day and can see some amazingly good additions to the game. I will be speaking to the improvements I see as there are already some fine reviews giving a whole overview. If you have not played AC1 and AC2 then this might not be as helpful to you. If so, read on.Combat: OverviewRight off the combat system is greatly improved. In the past the taunt was about useless. Now it really does bother the foe enough to get a grab at their weapon or throw them off guard. The kick is easy to pull off and it gets them to drop their guard a bit. How many times have you fought an enemy in AC2 and would just pound and pound on their sword and hope one hit would get passed their defenses. In AC:B there are countless ways to get passed that wall and get a good shot in.Combat: StreaksI love the new streaks. As long as you can be quick enough you sometimes pull off multiple kills effortlessly. There is even achievements for kill streaks in the virtual training room.Horses:Now you can ride and fight from a horse. They also allow horses into the city. That always bugged me in AC1&2 the fact you had to dismount at the gate.Jumping and Climbing:It seems the climbing has been improved. It is still sometimes more difficult to climb areas that really are climbable but you didn't line up right. Jumping from ledge to ledge has been tweaked. It is now easier to make serial jumps.Outfits:I like the new armor. I wont go into a full spoiler but basically you start out with nothing again in the beginning.Online:Very fun to play online against other players. I am not very good 1v1 on these games so I did not enjoy it as much as others would, not the games fault, I just got roflstomped too often.Overall:This game is a perfect addition to the series. It takes what was good and improves it. If you have played the first 2 then you owe it to yourself to continue the journey.Thank you for reading my review.
summary: Sofar a great game! Review of improvements from AC1&AC2.

reviewText: This is such an awesome game...an overall amazing series of games at that!  This and Assassin's Creed II are amazing games!  I have very much enjoyed the awesome gameplay and open worldness of these 2 games.  There is so much to explore, especially as more area opens up as you go along...and there is plenty of little side quests and items to find throughout the environment to keep you plenty busy as you play along.  Plus, like II, after you have beaten the story, you can continue to play to try and find everything you missed and play all the side quests you didn't get around to.  I like the addition of recruiting fighters to build them up as assassins to join the guild.  There is an even greater variety of weapons you can use throughout this game, and a new assortment of fun little gadgets and other stuff to make hunting enemies and exploring more enjoyable.  There are so many great weapons to chose from for melee fighting, but I think my favorite was this one particular mace that you can by later on...I call it Ezio's bashing stick.  There was some pretty brutal counter kills that could be done with that weapon...loved it!  Haha!  I enjoyed the storyline...continuing on with the story of Ezio, and at times I was very immersed in it.  Just ask my wife, haha.My only little gripe about this game was that, like II, it had a tendancy to glitch out just a little bit every now & then.  As an example, sometimes when I would be running along a rooftop chasing someone and trying to catch them, Ezio would occasionally jump a completely different way than I was running or he would not grab ahold of a ledge when prompted.  There are other examples of this, but that is just an example.  However, these little glitches weren't consistent, and I could in no way bring myself to mark this game down any for that because overall it's just simply an amazing game!  I highly recommend this series to any gamer out there who loves a good open world action adventure game like I do...it's simply awesome.  I look forward to getting into Revelations, which is one of the next games in my collection that I have to play!  So awesome!

When I heard Brotherhood was coming out so close to AC2, at first I was over trilled and totally hyped up to get my hands on it... but as many have pointed out, a sequel in less than year is worrisome when it comes to quality.Well, the doubts were completely answered with an amazing, full, and engaging game.Story wise: It is finally being made a LOT more clear that Desmond is the face of Assassin's Creed. He is getting a lot more playtime and the first section you play with him as is nostalgically similar to the Assassin's Tombs in AC2 (only a lot easier and more latches and lifts.)The Shrines of Romulus will be the new "assassin tombs" giving a armor that will give you full synchro with Ezio.On Ezio's side  you will see the return of "flags" that were in AC1 and the "feathers" in AC2, and getting all of them unlocks their own rewards.In conclusion, as to not give any spoilers, the story is what you would expect from this franchise.... awesome. Graphics looks a lot better than what I remember (having played the ps3 version of AC@.)Gameplay:Combat-Assassin's Creed is definitely evolving and I am liking it's progress. AC1 was basically spam the attack button and block... cool at first, right?AC2 expanded on this with counter kill moves, but then we would be stuck waiting for the A.I to attack us for easy kills.Brotherhood ADDS all of that and combines it with a stronger and smarter A.I,  making the enemies attack you back to back (instead of in turns), and offensive gameplay is  now a lot stronger than it was before. So the battles are quick and gory with even larger battles going on compared to previous ACs.Additions to previous features->New Weapons>New Armors (sadly the "armor" gotten for pre-ordering at Amazon is an outfit)>Trade Items furthering the element of a role playing game>Run your own city (in this case Rome) is back on a larger scale> and of course, the ability to make your Brotherhood of assassins (it's the name of the game!)Multiplayer-Assassin's Creed Brotherhood is the first game in series with a multiplayer mode!! We asked for it, and they answered.The animi you see at the beginning of AC2 is the back story of the multiplayer section of the game. Abstergo templars use the animi to gain the skills of assassins with the bleeding effect, and that is us.Each player is assigned a target (some other player), now the player has to assassinate its target without losing their cover, or they will be killed by the person who was assigned to assassinate THEM!I haven't gotten into the story mode that much yet, but apparently the multiplayer characters we will play as are in the main story, so everything is tied in nicely, right?!Uplay points- Assassin's Creed 2 was the first to have these and of course, every new Ubisoft game has them. Brotherhood is no exception to this. If you do not know what this entails, it is basically ubisoft's version of trophies or achievements. They unlock exclusive themes and ingame media (extra bullets skins, multiplayer character, etc). Pretty nice of them.If you have already beaten AC2 as I have you get 20 uplay points at the start of the game.In Closing:As a fan of Assassin's Creed, I can't help but just praise it with a perfect score. If you have seen trailers, demos, gameplay videos... just take a dive and give it a try, it at least deserves a trial run. You wont regret it.
summary: Ubisoft proves a good sequel is possible in a year

reviewText: I've bought this Assassin's Creed title to add it to my collection of "best so far" for this series. I became a fan of the Assassin's Creed series after playing Assassin's Creed 2 which upped the ante on so many levels within the gaming experience from the first title and further tweaked it with Brotherhood. The series captivates with the awesome story line moving from Altair to Ezio Auditore...and the series grew they (Ubisoft) branched out into other assassins expanding the story line...through Desmond Miles who had a link to the assassin's and their lineage through the various historic periods in time.Brotherhood refined a lot of the game play as a single assassin earlier on in the game and as the missions unfold you are introduced to other characters in the game that lend support throughout. It's like having a team player co-op within a single player environment and each of the characters bring their own style of moves and assassination.Apart from Assassin's Creed 2 & Brotherhood I was recently gifted Assassin's Creed 3 (collection growing) which I haven't played as yet since I like to go through the story lines and game play before moving on to the next title and hopefully I complete these  it in time for the new title "Black Flag". Based on these story lines so far I am anticipating "Black Flag" to bring an all new feel to the series...I mean who wouldn't want to be an Assassin/Pirate who participates in high sea battles and plundering across the scenic islands of the Caribbean and the rest of the world...whilst taking on the Templars :)

This is easily better than Assassin's Creed 2, between a very large Rome, a few new weapons, and a multiplayer mode, you get a new and cooler experience with Ezio and his skills. I give this 5 stars easy.

this game is as most expected, nothing new. if you look at all the previous reviewers for this game on amazon, you'll notice they all submitted their reviews right when the game came out. these are not be taken seriously, they are fan boys of the series. i just completed the game and it is disappointing in several areas. first: the game is very repetitive, almost as if they were struggling to find new material for the missions. second: you are basically stuck in rome the entire time and the scenery all has the same look and feel to it throughout. despite what the previous reviews on amazon for this game said, the world is not large in the game by any stretch. in fact, by the end of the game, you will never want to see rome again. third: the multiplayer is fun for the first hour and then gets incredibly boring.most of the time it just dumps you out right in front of your target in the multiplayer. the people who are after you are very easy to spot and for some reason you can't run on rooftops all the time (it just won't let you do it sometimes). there are only about 7 or 8 distinct multiplayer characters, the other 4 or 5 look like other characters with different costumes on. if you look closely you'll notice it like they did in the beta testing. fourth: the fight mechanic is unchanged, enemies still wait for you to slaughter them individually. you can string together a sequence of attacks on multiple enemies but this just makes it even easier than in AC 2. fifth: the cutscene graphics are absolutely beautiful, this is where the game shines, but the in game graphics are not improved at all. they used the same graphics engine as in AC 2, they just put more time and effort into the cutscenes in brotherhood.the overall feel of the game is AC 2.5, they really didn't change anything and the story is almost a complete rehashing of AC 2 through flashbacks and memories. there really aren't any new story elements to this game at all, this aspect was very disappointing 'Assassin's Creed 2' was without a doubt my favorite game of 2009. It had great graphics and sound and a terrific variety of gameplay. While 'Assassin's Creed Brotherhood' may not be a true sequel to the franchise it's a bigger and more polished upgrade to 'Assassin's Creed 2' with even MORE gameplay thrown in!'Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood' picks up right where AC2 left off: Ezio has defeated the pope and got a trippy apocolyptic message and must fight his way out of Rome and into another revenge/conspiracy story involving the Borgia family. Meanwhile Desmond and the gang are also on the run and must explore Ezio's old hideout (now in a modern setting) for the artifact everyone is after. While the story itself is more straight forward than AC2's, it manages to perfectly balance the gameplay between Ezio and Desmond's story. I actually enjoyed exploring modern Italy as Desmond and am now getting more comfortable with his crew as characters. All the voice actors return and give the same knock-out performances as last time, especially Roger Craig Smith who's aging Ezio nicely.The basic gameplay in 'Assasin's Creed Brotherhood' is pretty much the same as AC 2's but is a lot more polished and refined. You can now take the offensive in combat and string together moves and instant kills (much like Batman Arkham Asylum's free-flow combat). Also you can now purchase property in Rome and take control of different 'Guilds' (Thieves, Mercenary's, brothels) and actually explore inside these structures and take part in side-quests and mini-missions. Even shops this time around have side-quests you can complete to get special weapons and armor!Along with the basic gameplay being amped up you can now recruit different people in Rome as assassin's, train them and customize and level them up. It's not a HUGE addition to the game but a fun one that gives you a sense of power over a group of people.One thing I want to make clear again: While 'Assassin's Creed Brotherhood' is a full game (took me around 20 hours doing some side quests) it's very much a EXPANSION of 'Assassin's Creed 2', NOT a sequel. If you didn't like 'Assassin's Creed 2' or did but are looking for the next step-up in gameplay, you should definitly save your money and wait for Assassin's Creed 3.I love 'Assassin's Creed 2' so I love 'Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood'. It features the same excellent gameplay and gives you a chance to spend more time with these characters and setting. 'Assassin's Creed 2' fans: this is a MUST play!

This is a review of the single-player game only.  I didn't touch the multi-player.I like the gameplay in this game quite a lot.  It's fun, but definitely not challenging.  It's downright easy, in fact.  There are plenty of side-missions to keep you busy when you want a change, and I did them all.  The story is pretty convoluted, like the previous game in the series, and the ending didn't make a whole lot of sense.  I guess they're setting up for the next sequel.I took off a star because there are some control issues as well as camera problems.  During one of the ending sequences, my entire fights were obscured by trees in the way of the camera.  How did that possibly get through testing?  I also suffered at least 3 mission-ending glitches.If you liked Assassin's Creed 2, this is pretty much more of the same, which doesn't have to be a bad thing.  Same characters, roughly the same setting, etc.

reviewText: I got the game on Nov 16, so far been playing it for a week now and it's been awesome. List of a few Pros and Cons, hope this helps you out:First,Cons:- Multiplayer is soo much fun, however there's "NOT MUCH" skill involved in it since there's not much control over the moves of your character, but then again this is their first time making it multiplayer for A.C- There's not much of a storyline, it's a bit of a disappointment- VERY few glitches in multiplayer, hardly even noticeable- You ride solo, not much interaction (no voice chat for example) in multiplayerPros:- in Multiplayer it's all the time INTENSE, which I LOVE about this game- The storyline is a disappointment but the graphics and the scenes and the "acting" is amazing- You can customize your fellow assassins which is awesome (story mode)- There's no set story line, you have many assignments, you choose what to do first, so if I'm not in the mood to catch thieves, I can go do something else and then do that later...basically there's Flexibility (story mode)- In multiplayer, the more you play, the more perks you get, like disguise, more sprint.etc. which is AWESOME :)- You can ride your horse in town, which really saves you a headache and time and not to mention it's fun pushing people over with a horse, and it's great for escapingHonestly I can go on and on about how great this game is, I don't regret spending 1 penny on this game.P.S This is my opinion, on what I saw and experienced, I give it 5 stars since for me all the cons I listed I don't really care about even though some people do.HOPE THIS HELPS YOU OUTUPDATE:I've been playing this game for now 15 days, and I don't regret giving this game 5 stars. It's a must-get. One thing I'd like to add is that I'm not a AC fan boy, This is my first game I've played of the AC series and I have to say I love it.

This game has been out for over a year now, so I will be short and sweet with this review.I have played all of the Assassin's Creed games, and this was the best of the series, even over Revelations. I loved Assassin's Creed and Assassin's Creed two, so I was very excited for when this game was announced. When news began to trickle in that it would include multiplayer I was a little disheartened. I anticipated that the developers would focus solely on the multiplayer and do single player as an afterthought; thankfully I was very wrong.New Features:Everything that made Assassin's Creed 2 great is back and better than ever. leaving aside the new weapons like the crossbow, the new Assassins feature is amazing. you can recruit the oppressed people of Rome to join your cause and through sending them out to do tasks they gain experience and level up. Those recruits that aren't on missions abroad can come to your aid wether you're being overwhelmed by the enemy, have a target that's just out of reach or if you want to just see Ezio kill a group of guards just by raising his arm. One would think that gets boring after a while but it just adds another level of awesomeness that you really have to try.Story:The story continues where Assassin's Creed 2 left off. For a game that's supposed to be Assassin's Creed 2.5 there are a lot of developments that definitely move the story along in a whole new direction. It's hard to really get into it without giving much away but be prepared for a lot of "Oh wow!" moments.Pro:- Fresh story fits well with what the franchise has given us so far.- Fighting has been refined and you'll find yourself picking fights with guards just for fun very often.- I can't emphasis enough how great the new assassin recruits are.Con:- If there is one gripe it's that there is the occasional glitch here and there. nothing game breaking though.Verdict:If you're on the fence about this one, get off it. You won't regret your purchase.

reviewText: I am a AC addict.  Since the introduction of AC1 I was hooked.  The amazing details to the architecture, the realism, the fight sequences, the ability to sneak and be stealthy... I really appreciated how the team of historians paid painstaking detail to the construction of Rome.  I enjoyed climbing up and down the Coliseum, the Pantheon, seeing the aqueducts... I enjoyed `restoring' Rome.The game in it's complete entirety was amazing.  Yes, there is always repetition.  They have to find ways to place the `synchronization' towers around the city so that you can `uncover' new locations - these are a staple of the game.  I was actually amused at the different ways they incorporated their syncrho places in the architecture.The game itself has taken on a little bit of a GTA tone.  This game is not as long as the others - if you played it straight through and did very few side missions.  However if you actually allowed yourself to become immersed in the game it could easily take you a good month or two of playing time - just running and jumping and collecting all the fun stuff that there is to collect.The game is brilliant.  The controls stay very similar to the original so that the gamer does not have to slow down and learn a new battle system.  Of course they up grade the weapons and give you some really awesome weapons to use.  I was pleasantly surprised to find some long distance weapons so that I could reach out and touch some one a little easier.My only qualm with the game was that the crowd was not as responsive as it was in games past.  The crowd was almost passive.  In games previous they would interact and they would report your misdeeds, forcing you to blend or be killed by the guards.  I wish the game was a little harder.  A little more complex. Sort of like it was in the first AC.  AC1 was difficult and you really had to `hide' in the crowd.  It took a lot of patience and skill to sneak up on your targets.  In both AC2 and ACB there was never that much of a challenge.  In AC2 there was more of a need to be silent and use stealth.  The crowd was much more aware of your actions.  But ACB looses this some where.As for the multiplayer... it is fun.  I actually enjoy the need to be sneaky and hide.  I like the idea of being trying to show who the better assassin is.  I think that it was a difficult premises to begin with and that the creators of ACB did a alright job with delivering the concept.  I wish that there was a way to fight your adversary and perhaps there is the higher up you get.  But what I saw initially is running around in a small sand box, looking for your target while others look for you.  It would be nice if you could defend yourself.In totality I think that the game delivers a degree of satisfaction that is not seen in the other two.  I truly enjoyed ACB.  I found it to be whole heartedly delightful.I stand by my rating of 10 out of 10 because ACB did what no other game has done this year - I was proud to have bought this game... and even more ecstatic that I was able to `see and explore' Rome...~TMM007 aka: Joshua.(SPOILER ALERT)PS... I CAN't WAIT FOR THE NEXT ASSASSIN'S CREED!!!! THE ENDING OF THIS ONE WAS... INTENSE!!!!
summary: We work in the dark to serve the light... We Are Assassins!!!

reviewText: I am very late to the party on this one.  I wanted to beat ACII before tackling this one, but other games always seemed to take priority.  I finally broke it out and wish I hadn't waited so long.  I haven't even tried the single player game yet because I'm having too much fun with multiplayer.  You'd think that the MP would be barren in a game that's been out as long as this one but I've never had to wait.  Also, all the complaints I'd heard about there being a really long wait time to get into a game has either been exaggerated or it's been fixed.My daughter, who is 11, fights with me to play.  Some may say it's too violent for kids but she understands it's a video game. I'm probably a little lax in letting her as some of the kill scenes are pretty brutal but the gameplay is just superb.  You really have to outsmart both your target and your pursuer, simulataneously.  The perks and abilities you gain as you level up really add to the mix.  While the abilities are incrementally better so that someone playing a long time will have an edge, they aren't so overpowering that new players can't still do well.  I am about level 25 now and still getting owned by players much lower in rank and also owning players that have maxed at 50.  Usually I finish right in the middle but it's pretty rewarding to get a podium bonus (top 3).I'm sure there is a lot of gameplay in the single player game as well, but bang for the buck with mp is amazing.  Five stars.
summary: Best fun I've had in Multiplayer ever

When I preordered this I figured that the single player would just be some tiny tacked on campaign. I was wrong, they certainly put some time into making a full single player experience. From what I understand it's slightly shorter than Assassin's Creed II's campaign. I played the multiplayer beta for the past month, and I was so happy when they made matchmaking faster, and added more game modes. The multiplayer requires stealth, attention to detail, and patience. It gets intense, but the people who run around all the time get annoying. It's like the complete opposite of COD. I like some of the changes they did to the single player. For one thing, you can combine weapons in combat, like you use the sword and gun together during combat. They cut out a lot of the stuff where you have to find codex pages to get your equipment, and instead you start out with everything. The animations are slicker, and there's more moves, as well as more finishing moves. Also, the A.I. has improved significantly; I actually have to run away from the guards once I'm surrounded by 5 or more of them, they're more difficult, and won't stand still while you're doing a finishing move or counter-attack on one of their teammates so you'll have to be a bit more careful. I'm definitely enjoying this game, and I've been a fan of the series since the first game of the series, but I still recommend it to anyone.

I'm new to the Assassin's Creed genre, so I was looking forward to playing this game so I could see what the series was all about.I usually stick to games like Castlevania, Infamous, God of War, Batman, etc. I enjoyed those games because they were very unrealistic with fighting monsters and possessing crazy super powers and weaponry. I wanted to try a game that was more realistic, hence the purchase of Assassin's Creed Brotherhood. It was quite a change of pace not having to slay monsters and riding a horse through the streets of Rome. I really enjoyed the combat in this game, (wish it was more of it) there's nothing like splitting a guard's skull with the bearded axe lol. I have to admit, It took me awhile to get used to having to physically find a Blacksmith shop to purchase upgrades (I'm accustomed to just pressing the start button and getting them). But once I upgraded, I really loved using those weapons! I enjoyed the scenery of Rome, tons of stuff to do and get into, maybe too much at times....There are a few reasons as to why I deducted a couple of stars. Now, this could be due to the fact that I have not played the first two installments, but this game was a bit overwhelming at times. I would be in the middle of a fight, and all of the sudden, a red icon is streaking across my map, I'm like who the heck is this??? I later found out it was a thief, how was I to know that? Or, I could be riding my horse trying to escape guards and all of the sudden a message pops on the screen saying that a deposit failed in the bank. And? Why would I care, I'm trying to escape. It was just a ton of little things like that going on throughout the entire game, just not used to that in an action game. Without all the mindless platforming, (especially as Desmond), this game would have been 8 hours long. It seems that they threw silly things in just to make the game seem "longer". I'm not a fan of the kind of puzzles AC used. The puzzles consisted of: here is a building, now figure out how to climb to the top. That would have been ok if the control scheme was better laid out. I can't count how many times I tried to climb, but ended up doing a wall jump in the other direction....I really wish there was more fighting in this game as opposed to all of the platforming and roaming around Rome (no pun intended). The Desmond stuff alone caused to me to deduct another star. I would have given this game 4 stars if I did not have to endure the Desmond nonsense at the end. All of the endless climbing and jumping really got on my nerves, not needed. I often asked myself, what the heck and I suppose to do now? Where the heck am I suppose to go, no map telling me anything while playing as Desmond. The only thing I'll say about the ending is that Desmond is such a tool...I would have had a blast with this game if there was more fighting and less platforming. For me, it's never good if I'm ready for a game to be over. I don't know if I'll get the next installment of this game, I'll just have to wait and see.
summary: Fun, but a bit overwhelming at times.

reviewText: Assassin's Creed Brotherhood builds very nicely on Assassin's Creed 2.  The platforming is slightly more improved over 2, and all of the systems that made 2 a great game remain in place here.I wasn't honestly expecting much out of the story in this game.  Still, they did a nice job adding to the story of 2, and building on that universe.  It's not quite as refreshing as the story in 2, but I was happy to be in this setting again.Graphically, it's good, but not great.  The PS3 version has a lot of screen tearing, but it's tolerable.  The frame rate, outside of that, is solid.  I didn't experience any game ending glitches.The one thing that was disappointing this time around was the "full sync" system.  Half the time I didn't know what the objectives were for full sync.  What really got me though, was there was no easy way to restart at a checkpoint to do the mission over if you failed a full sync.  Instead you have to start the ENTIRE mission over...which some missions can last an hour.  That system was frustrating and not an improvement.Where they REALLY made things better was the combat.  No longer is it just a game of counters.  Now you have to kick, shove, and counter.  I still found myself countering the majority of the time, but once I learned how to use the kick move, I found it to be a very effective way to do combat, and it made that portion of the game less one dimensional.This game can be had for very cheap now, and I highly recommend it.  The combat is fun, the platforming is great, and exploring the city is fun.
summary: Another great entry in the Assassin's Creed franchise

reviewText: Okay, maybe I exaggerated a bit. This game perhaps isn't to videogames what The Sistine Chapel is to art, but this is one hell of a videogame. And the story even begins inside The Sistine Chapel(!). To me, this is the kind of game where it just doesn't matter if the gameplay is good or not because it is so visually stunning. Mainly because it is set in the most visually stunning place on earth: Rome. Oh, but the gameplay also happens to be good, so there are not many flaws here. If you would like to play a combination of GTA, Prince of Persia and Metal Gear Solid set in The Vatican, this is the game for you.
summary: The Sistine Chapel of videogames, literally

i've only been a gamer for about two years and in that time there have only been a handful of games that have stayed with me long after that final boss battle/mission was complete: COD4, uncharted 2, resistance, red dead redemption, assassin's creed 2 and now assassins's creed: brotherhood.there's so much to respect and admire about AC:B, but i'll touch on a few of the more salient points:1 - there's no better-looking game on the market right now. it's simply beautiful.  not even the mighty red dead redemption can compare with rome's beauty. the color palette and textures are top shelf.  AC:B boasts the best skies i've ever seen in a game. they're virtually photo-realistic.  compare AC:B skies with COD:BO skies.  no contest.2 - the open world gives you tremendous feeling of discovery and excitment.  the missions are nicely varied [the races from AC:2 are gone, thankfully]; the quests largely entertaining and some are very challenging; the characters memorable and likeable.  the platforming exceeds AC:B in almost every respect. destroying leonardo's four war machines was thrilling, and in my opinion, the most engaging part of the game.  the in-game economy, renovations, treasures, borgia flags, feathers, christina memories will provide hours of entertainment, for sure. the 'romulus' missions are great, too.3 - AC:B introduced a few new things - i almost jumped out my chair the first time i called in one of my assassin recruits who performed an air assassination. i felt sad the one and only time one of them died in battle. horses can now be ridden through cities and you even get to parachute from the top of a castle.  the best new weapon, in my opinion, is the crossbow - as if Ezio weren't already a big enough bad-a$$, the crossbow makes it doubly so.4 - AC:B nicely sets up AC:3, although with more than a touch of sadness.  whether or not Ezio de Auditore will be part of future installments remains to be seen [one can only hope], but AC will live on.there were only a few minor quibbles - horses tend not to jump off two inch ledges, shaun and rebecca continue be as annoying as ever, and some of the music, which is by and large fantastic, feels a bit hokey and melodramatic in places [particularly when destroying borgia towers].  but those are just minor issues in an otherwise beautiful and amazing game.ubisoft recently hinted that we may see yearly installments of Assassin's Creed through the year 2020. if so, i'll buy each and every one.if you're on the fence, take the "leap of faith" and join the brotherhood.  you'll be glad you did.

Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood can be best thought of as Assassin's Creed 2.5.  It is a direct continuation of Assassin's Creed II (see my review).  Although this installment has made some substantial improvements over the previous game, it generally feels like an expansion of it, and as a result, just like its predecessor, it is a very good game with some substantial flaws.Let me get some of the negatives out of the way before I talk about how good this game is (and it is quite good).  I was disappointed that the economic system of the game hasn't been improved, that being, at about the half way point through the game, you already have more money than God.  And when you have all the money that you'll ever need so early in the game, it takes away that money-chasing element that is so fun in the first half of the game, such as looting bodies, finding treasure chests, pickpocketing, and questing for money.  Another thing is the combat system.  Yes, I know this game was touted for its improved combat system, and it IS better this time around, with a nice kill streak system that is reminiscent of the Batman Arkham games.  But still, the combat still feels a bit sluggish and stiff overall, and to me, feels several steps behind most current gen games in this aspect.  Lastly, is that the controls still aren't as accurate as they should be.  Considering all the amazing movement you can execute in these games, it's embarrassing that something such as hopping off of a ledge, or making an accurate jump in a particular direction, can be so troublesome.With that said, Brotherhood is an overall better game than Assassin's Creed II.  Lots of the "fluff" of the first game has been cut out, mainly in the side quests, which are fewer and more meaningful and substantial this time around.  A good example of this are the "DaVinci's Machines" missions, which send you to different locations around Italy to destroy the war machines invented by Leonardo DiVinci that are being exploited by the Borgia.  Missions to assassinate Templar agents open up new areas of the map.  Courtesan, thief, and assassination missions are fewer, as opposed to the way they were bombarded upon the player in AC II.  The game's setting also continues to be fantastic.  Although lacking the diversity of the Florence/Venice/Tuscan countryside of the first game, the setting of Rome is stunning in its detail, scope, and feel.  Once again, the teams at Ubisoft have proven themselves the masters at making vibrant, historical worlds that not only look and sound great, but also serve to teach the gamer a thing or two about history.  And although the story of Ezio in this game is entertaining, it's generally more of the same.  It's the story of the main protagonist of the series, Desmond Miles, that steals the show here, and propels the narrative of this series to a new high.I have to mention two features of the game that really stood out as my favorite, and really helped make this game a step up from Assassin's Creed II.  The first are the Romulus Lairs, which replace the Templar Lairs from AC II (which were also very enjoyable in their own right).  Unlike the Templar Lairs, which mainly just required precise platforming to complete, the Romulus Lairs are almost self-encompassing game worlds that Ezio has to penetrate in order to decode a mysterious scroll and retrieve the game's ultimate set of armor.  They are extremely diverse, containing elements of platforming, exploring, combat, and chase sequences that really stand apart from the main game.  At times, they give Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood the feel of a dungeon crawler with secrets around every corner and surprises at every turn.  These were stunningly well done, and always a highlight to play.  The other great feature of the game is the ability to build your secret army of assassins.  This is done through a mini game where you recruit citizens to become soldiers in your secret army, and then send them on missions around Europe where they gain experience points, which in turn lets you upgrade their armor and weapons.  Once they have leveled up enough, they become quite powerful and are able to undergo more difficult missions.  But the best part about having this army of assassins is that they are available to come to your aid in battle at almost any time.  You can have them silently take out guards that are out of your reach, or cause a rainstorm of arrows to instantly eliminate huge crowds of enemies.  Having a strong assassin army at your fingertips is just awesome, and best of all, can save you the trouble of having to get into combat scenarios more than you'd like.  It is a great addition to the game that feels very natural and is extremely fun.Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood continues the tradition of this fine series in a very good way.  There is definitely still room for improvement here, and at the rate Ubisoft is releasing games in the series, the opportunity to phase out the flaws and fine tune the high points is there.  In the meantime, if you enjoyed Assassin's Creed II, Brotherhood is definitely worth the purchase and is a superior game overall.
summary: An expansion to Assassin's Creed II

reviewText: PSN ID GREMDUDE here! This was a hard review to do because parts of this game are just as fantastic and sometimes more so than Assassin's Creed II(one of my favorite games of 2009.) Other parts are annoyingly frustrating, difficult and sometimes just plain stupid. Let's look at the positive first shall we?Graphics on this game are stunning. The only annoyance of Assassin's Creed II was the screen tearing that pretty much occurred whenever you moved the damn camera. I know that the XBox version did not suffer from this as much. That being said when Ubisoft said that they would try to make the PS3 version of ACB as close as the Xbox version as possible, I think they succeeded for the most part. Screen tearing still occurs but mainly in cutscenes(I have seen You Tube videos showing the XBox version and guess what? Screen tearing in the damn cutscenes!) Overall the game looks great. The only time I saw a framerate drop was near the end of the game.Gameplay picks up where AC2 left off--that being said, Awesome. Sword fighting is really fun and easy to be good at. A variety of weapons keeps things interesting as well. The Cross Bow and the Poison dart gun were really cool additions. Climbing and jumping all over Rome is just as fun as it was during AC2. I loved being able to upgrade and buy pretty much all of Rome. Burning the Borgia Towers was also a nice gameplay addition.My favorite parts of this game are where I was just wandering around, giving missions to my Assassins(another awesome addition to the AC game), doing side missions and finding treasure and collectibles. If this was the whole game, I would have loved it.Unfortunately, eventually you have to go back to the main storyline which is to say in a word, AWFUL!!. Near the end I had no clue what was happening or why!! Most of the main storyline missions are either timed(which I HATE), over if you are detected by ANYONE(WHich I loathe as there is no real stealth abilities in the game) or plain old ridiculously difficult(the Bomber mission comes to mind which I finally gave up on due to terrible control of the damn plane!!)Not sure how AC2 could be so fun and this one could be so bad(in terms of story missions) There was a point near the end where I almost gave up but I hung tough and did finish the game(you can check my Trophy list to verify) No game should be like that! Especially one which has so many positive features like this one. Oh well, being I paid $40 for this game and spent close to 40 hrs playing, I guess I shouldn't complain too much. It is worth a buy but just be prepared for some parts where you want to throw your $60 Dualshock against the wall! RIP poor Sixaxis controller :(

WARNING! If you have NOT played Assassin's Creed 2 (AC2), stop reading this and go play AC2 first!!!AC: Brotherhood (ACB) is in all intents and purposes AC2.8 in gameplay and story. The reason I call it AC2.8 instead of AC2.5 is that it is HUGE in terms of content and gameplay, much of which is carried over from AC2.PROS- Open-world gameplay still rocks! Do what you want, when you feel like it! Explore hidden ruins, continue with plot missions, win back control of the city, hunt for hidden treasures, renovate shops...the choice is yours!- The weapons are very similar for the most part with a few minor additions, and the gameplay elements have changed slightly. This is a GOOD thing is you enjoyed AC2 as I did.- The battle system has been improved slightly but creates a significant upgrade to the experience overall. Enemies no longer take turns to attack you one at a time. They try to "sucker-attack" you from behind when you are engaged with another enemy, which makes things a lot more challenging and requires you to make strategic moves. Cool!- Load times are still quite good, Considering the size of the world/map, this is a solid accomplishment.- Your own 'gang' of assassins - the biggest change from AC2 is the addition of the ability ot recruit assassins and send them on missions. You can earn money and XP by successfully completing missions, and upgrade each assassin in terms of a few attributes such as armor, weaponry, and outfit color. This is a nice addition that adds depth to the game. You can send one (or many) assassins to each mission, and decide how much risk to assume; example: as you assign assassins to a mission, you are given a probability of success (up to 100%) so you can send as many or as few people as you wish. The trade-off is not having them available for story missions or side quests. I kind of wished you can get updates for these missions as some of them require up to 15 minutes to complete, and they progress in the background so it's possible for you to lose track of what's going on.CONS- As for the negatives, which are minor, the voice acting for Desmond's cast/group is pretty weak, but passable as long as you don't pay too much attention to it.- There are some minor annoyances such as the visuals not being quite as sharp as you might like it to be, but you can easily overlook this flaw in exchange for smooth, stutter-free frame rate (let's just say it's NOT Fallout: New Vegas by any stretch of the imagination!).- Other weak points are armor upgrades. Instead of being able to purchase upgrades when you have enough money (as in AC2), this game requires you to complete certain "challenges" that consist of gathering various items before you are allowed to make the purchase. This seems to be an artifical way of lengthening the game and making it more challenging, but not a big deal I guess. Since money is relatively easy to earn, I can see how the developer does not want you to amass a huge fortune and upgrade your character to the max in a short time, hence eliminating the difficulty of the game.Just a few notes on multiplayer - I have tried MP a few times but have had trouble getting into matches. They seem to take a long time to process. The few games I have gotten into were fun but nothing to jump up and down about. I see it as a nice 'extra' but probably won't keep your attention very long.In conclusion, this is one of the best games I've played in a very long time. Any fan of AC series should definitely get this, and any fan of open-world adventure games should seriously consider this title!!!EDIT: 12/30/2010Just finished the game; the ending was a bit of a surprise. I was slightly disappointed that not all questions were answered. However, this should still NOT discourage you from playing this great game!
summary: A well-crafted masterpiece worth every penny!!!

reviewText: I won't go into too much detail about the story mode for Brotherhood, if you've played or seen AC2 then you know the drill. It is the same stealth / action gameplay as always, and it's just as fun here as it was in the previous installment. Some minor additions include horse-riding anywhere, improved combat, destroying Borgia towers in order to be able to renovate and develop areas of the city, and a few new mission types. The main new addition is the guild of assassins that you can recruit and manage by sending them off on their own missions or by calling them to your immediate aid. The assassins level up and become stronger as you give them assignments, and you will have a great time remaining stealthy while you summon your elite group of killers to do your dirty work.The real surprise for me with this game was the addition of the multiplayer modes. this is coming from a player who rarely spends any significant time with online multiplayer, and wow, this is the most interesting, addicting, and fun multi i have ever played. There are a selection of different character skins players choose from, then they enter a location that is populated by dozens of clones of all the skins. Each player is assigned a target to kill and has another player targeting them. The goal is of course to kill your target while evading your pursuer. Simply killing is not always the best method though, as major points are awarded for the quality and stealth of your kills, not simply the quantity. You will need to identify which of the identical looking skins is the human player that you need to kill, which is difficult enough, but add in some useful abilities and perks, and the trickery and deception really go through the roof. This definitely feels more like a mind game than a contest of who has the fastest trigger finger.As with other modern multiplayer systems, AC brotherhood's features a leveling system with new abilities unlocking as you progress by gaining exp and completing challenges. In addition to the standard mode i described above (Wanted) there is a 2v2v2 team mode called alliance (works the same way but with 3 teams of two) and a 4v4 mode called manhunt. Manhunt is different in that the teams take turns being the killers and the escapers. The 4 player teams make for some interesting strategies that don't apply to the other modes. All in all, I have found all three modes to be very fun.To sum up, Assassin's Creed Brotherhood is definitely not AC3, but it's not a mere expansion. It is an incredibly robust game with a lot of variety to offer, but also a lot of familiarity. The music is appropriate, the voice acting is decent / good, the graphics are about the best you can hope for in an open world, the controls feel pretty solid most of the time, and the length and depth of content will keep you busy for at least 15 hours through the main game. Two minor gripes are both technical issues, one being that in multiplayer sometimes game-matching seems to hang and you just have to exit and restart, which is frustrating. The other issue has plagued the series before and that is weird glitchiness. It's not as bad here as in previous installments, but i did end up stuck inside a tree and had to reset the system within the first hour of playing...anyway, these small issues do not compromise the game enough to knock even 1 star off this 5 star rating. This is the best Creed yet and should not be missed for its great quantity and quality of gameplay.
summary: Quantity AND Quality - - Great single player, Amazing multiplayer

Assassin's Creed Brotherhood feels like it could almost be chapter 2 of Assassin's Creed 2.  It's a very similar game, only everything has been upgraded, refined and improved.  These improvements are just some new bells and whistles and a shinier coat of paint -- it's a deeper game that incorporates more strategy along with the awesome new ways to kill people.The story in a nutshell: The stakes increase even more as the Borgia family drops the hammer on the Assassins for all the hell Ezio raised in AC2.It's the same world, only localized to a fully realized, enormous Rome.  Hence, you're not having to schlep it from city to city on a horse, which is nice.  Limiting the story to Rome (for the most part) also gives the game more focus.The gameplay is more or less the same, only enhanced with more diverse objectives, more fighting moves, more weapons.  You also begin to build a guild of assassins whom you train, equip and build. Having a team of assassins to do your bidding is not only amusing, but becomes a necessary part of your strategy to complete some missions.ACB is also more focused on the story at hand.  In AC2, there are all sort of side-missions that while mostly fun, have nothing to do with the superobjective of the story.  While I was playing AC2, I'd think, "Why am I collecting these feathers?"  or "Why am I going to beat up a cheating husband while in the meantime I'm supposed to be rescuing my family on the eve of their scheduled execution?"  Obviously video games have lots of conceits, but Brotherhood keeps these to a minimum, so that Ezio's efforts are more or less contributing to defeating the Borgias.An aside: If you haven't played Assassin's Creed 2, I'd recommend starting there.  It begins the story of Ezio, and Brotherhood is a continuation of that story.The bottom line is that this game is FUN.  Nay, SUPER FUN.  I haven't had this big a blast playing a video game since RED DEAD REDEMPTION, UNCHARTED 2 and ASSASSIN'S CREED 2.

The title of my review is not an exaggeration. This is by far the best game in the Assassin's Creed series so far. Ubisoft has learned from the mistakes it's made in previous AC games, and made a sequel that outshines its predecessors by far.For those who have played the first two games, the storyline is familiar already. If not (spoilers!), it's simple and, well, sort of ridiculous. Age-old warring factions -- the insidious, villainous Templars, who ally with the Church and those "in power" vs. the persistent, valiant Assassins, who ally with the thieves, cutthroats, prostitutes, and "underdogs" of society -- continue to fight. You play as two people: Desmond, the modern* day Assassin who lives his ancestor's memories through a machine created by a modern day corporate arm of the Templar; and (in this and ACII) Ezio, one of Desmond's Assassin ancestors from medieval Italy. *At least, we assume Desmond is the present day character, although, theoretically, he could be an ancestor whose memories someone else is living, to see the memories of the ancestors that he is seeing...but that's probably way over thinking things :PAnyhow, continuing with this theme, in Brotherhood (again, spoilers), the Church is evil and villainous because they're a bunch of scheming, power hungry, sexually immoral thieves and cutthroats. Your side is wonderful because you're marvelous scheming thieves, cutthroats, pimps and prostitutes (While churchmen are disgusting for hosting...unusual, shall we say?...parties complete w/near nudity and hookers, Ezio's sister/mother end up running the brothel in Rome, in order to collect information from the Templars who visit "their girls"; etc). While this storyline could well replace Viagra in Keith Olbermann's life, it's really pretty dumb.The voice acting can be less than stellar at times...the "I'm atrying to sound Italiano, but I am astinking at it" moments are certainly there. Again, this is no worse than previous games, however.That said, however, the game is still a blast (I know, it sounds like a contradiction; but hear me out). Ezio (despite his many flaws -- like the fact that his line of work often requires killing men who are just following the law [the guards]) is still the likable character he's always been; his sister Claudia (despite the fact that she works as a pimp...) is a likable character; etc. The voice acting, even in its most awkward moments, is no worse than the storyline; and, if one is willing to accept that silliness (as one has to be, to play), the voice acting seems hardly noteworthy.The best part of this game (singleplayer, anyway) -- what really distinguishes it from the other two -- is that Ubisoft seems to have perfected the balance of doing and planning -- and nixed most of the more annoying Prince of Persia-style stunts in the process. In the first game, the gameplay was a lot of fun -- but quickly got old, as you did the same thing again and again and again with no idea why, except that you were told to do so. In the second game, Ezio was much more a part of the planning process (not just running here and there with no idea why killing people), so the game was far more interesting; however, the designers had introduced just enough timed races/puzzles/traps and whatnot to make the game very annoying (to a non-PoP player like me, at any rate). This game perfected the balance; Ezio is still key to the deliberative process, so the player knows what's going on; the original game play of the first one was merged with the game play of the second (and a few new things, too) to make it just challenging enough without being irksome. A job very well done!I've finished the "story mode" (singe player), and have just started playing the multiplayer (I'm only a level 8 at this point)...but it is a blast too! The two multiplayer modes I've played (I'm not sure if there are more?) were a team based hunt -- one team is hunter, the other hunted; then this role reverses -- and a contract based hunt (where you hunted a single target [another player] and are yourself hunted by other player[s]). These are both a lot of fun -- the latter especially (imho). I was furthermore pleased to note that my somewhat lousy internet connection was not an impediment to play...I've experienced no lag time whatsoever so far as I play.All in all, as someone who has played the series through (and so knew in advance of the silly storyline/less than stellar voice acting, etc.), I give this 4/5 stars. If you liked the earlier games, you'll love this one. Don't go in expecting a "fix" to the storyline...it's not going to happen...but you can look forward to more of Ezio, and improved gameplay. (Oh, and make sure you get out of the Animus here and there to listen to what Desmond's friends have to say...you'll likely be able to predict a portion of the ending of the game, if you do).
summary: Best game in the series so far

While AC1 was a game of originality and innovation, Ubisoft managed to screw up AC2 and turn it into an unenjoyable mess. (Very much like anything else Ubi's touched recently, like Rainbow Six: Vegas).Now, with Brotherhood, many of the things done wrong in AC2 have been improved upon. Not fixed, but merely polished up. So, to sum it up, AC:B is overrated garbage 2.0.___Story___Story telling is slightly better than in AC2, but not as good as AC1. AC2's story was pretty much non-existent, random, and doesn't make ANY sense, unless you read the in-game bio PLUS wikipedia entries, you are not gonna know or care who any of these bald, fat, old European dudes that you are trying to stab are. AC: B's story makes a bit more sense, but it's still pretty lacking. The AC story, so far, could've been Left 4 Dead's story, and no one would be able to tell the difference.The Desmond story is what facilitates all the DNA sequences, the PRESENT DAY story arc is what connects all the dots, and should be what motivates players to keep on playing. In both AC2 and AC: B, there is MINIMAL storytelling for the present. Basically, you get in the animus, and from then on it's "go here, talk to informant, go there, assassinate". The ancient story is drawn out, and 99% of it has ABSOLUTELY NOTHING to do with the main storyline. It seems that Ubisoft could've easily condensed the contents of AC2, AC:B, AND AC: Revelations, into a single game. Instead, they make this unnecessarily elaborated Ezio arc that spans into 3 main titles. It is clear that Ubisoft really doesn't care about making great games, but rather just cashing in on franchises.___Controls___Control is still a mixed bag. On the one hand, Ezio still behaves like a retard sometimes, especially when platforming and when you are trying to act fast. On the other hand, using the hidden blade in large battles is much more fun and satisfying. In fact, I've been using hidden blade for 1 on 8 battles, all game long.Minor tweaks like when you would automatically get into target-lock mode makes gameplay more fluid, but also confusing at times.Really, AC series control scheme is just convoluted and doesn't work. It works somewhat for platforming. But they really should think of a way to simplify and streamline the controls.___Gameplay___People who complain that AC1 was repetitive say that AC2 and AC: B is much better. I'm like, "lolwut". You still have to collect viewpoints, save citizens from guards (who will later help you or join you), ride horses to places, and spam "attack" while holding down "high profile".Sure there are more mini games in AC:B that distracts you, like the "economy" and Assassin Guid, but it's still essentially the old AC1 formula.___After thought____Seriously, every time I play this, I think about how great the series could have been, and how Ubisoft is ruining it. It makes me sad and want to cry. The story is just there for them to release more AC games and make more money. There is about 10 minute worth of story in this entire game. The actions are repetitive and at times non responsive. Recycles characters, etc.However, like I said, it does have slight improvements over AC2, and just more mature than AC1. This makes AC:B the best AC game yet.

Let me start by saying that this is hands down the best video game ever made... I bought it the day it came out which I almost always regret, but this is one title that was worth the full 60$. As a strictly multiplayer gamer I never touched the Assassin's Creed games until I bought this, took it home and inserted the disc, and jumped straight into online competition. What I found was the "Wanted" game mode: an innovative mix of stealth and action gameplay, where the winner is determined by who murders the most players in the least conspicuous fashion. How it works is that you have one player who is your target, along with a rough compass directing you in the general direction of that player. The tricky part is that there are many computer controlled people walking about the town, stopping at shops, etc. who look exactly like your target. If your target is skilled he will act natural in order to blend in with the computer NPC's, making him very difficult to spot until he makes a move to kill his own target. Further complicating matters is the wide array of weapons, magic spells and tricks each player brings to the match, such as smoke bombs, throwing knives, muting and templar vision. As a way to balance all this madness, the developers made it so whoever is in 1st or 2nd place in any match has 2 or 3 people targeting them, while the noob in last place is not on anyone's hit list until he gets back in the game. All of these features culminate into the best gaming experience ever in my opinion and I've been playing since the 8-bit Nintendo, so seriously stop reading this, add it to your cart and checkout.

reviewText: I've heard and read a lot of hype about the Assassin's Creed games.  I guess they're just not my thing.  I popped this in the still-new PS3 and it took 20 minutes just to load--I thought it was broken.  Then the game started and it was like having to watch a movie for 20 more minutes before I could even do anything.  Then the movie scene paused and a prompt popped up telling me to hit one button while holding another, which I did.  Another ten-minute movie scene ensued, followed by "Congratulations, you've won a trophy" and "Checkpoint Reached."  The controller was sitting on the coffee table.  I had pressed 2 buttons in 30 minutes of "game play" and somehow won a trophy and reached a checkpoint. I kept on for another hour or so, but just couldn't get into it. It went back in the box.  I rarely play video games, but when I do, I want a game that I can play, not a game that I can watch play itself. The medieval-meets-sci-fi thing didn't really work for me either.  I consider myself still fairly young, but I guess this game is for the even younger generation--my 16 year old stepson saw it on the table to be sent back and asked to play it.  He tells me this is how a lot of newer games are. He now owns this one.UPDATE: 5/3/2011.  My stepson, who is a huge fan of these games, does say that further into the game there is less movie, more play.  He also says that he "beat it in one night" and "it was okay," but now he's looking for a new game to play.  So my 1-star rating still stands.  My 16-yr-old thought it was mediocre, and $50 is a lot of money for only a few hours' entertainment.  We've gotten weeks and even months of gameplay out of games that cost half as much.

Assassin's Creed Brotherhood picks up exactly where AC: II left off.  Ezio is back for another throat slicing, roof hopping, and horse riding adventure.  This time Ezio explores the ancient and holy city of Rome.  Don't worry about it being too small because it's only one city, it's huge!!  It's easily as big as three Venices from AC: II.  There are many new improvements and additions that give this game a different feel from its predecessor.  The boldest and most interesting addition is the online multiplayer.  AC: Brotherhood will be a game you won't forget.Remember those faces from AC: II?  Well they're back!  Uncle Mario, Leonardo and Claudia are just a few ready to stand behind Ezio.  There are also a few new ones, notably Cesare and Lucrezia Borgia.  Voices and movements are great and the graphics got even better.  I have heard about problems, like glitches but I downloaded an update before I started and I haven't noticed any major ones since.One of Ezio's jobs is to renovate Rome.  You buy landmarks, like the Coliseum, you buy stores, like blacksmith, tailor, and doctor, and you solve more of subject 16's puzzles.  Remember the tombs from AC: II?  Well now they have Lairs belonging to followers of Romulus.  The objective and the way you go about it remain the same.  If you complete all 6 lairs, you get Brutus's armor which is very strong like Altiair's'.  Inside you will do a bunch of free running and climbing, sometimes against the clock, or you might have to fight some Romulus followers.Flags, treasures and feathers are back!  You can purchase maps for them and they will pop up on your mini-map.  They not needed for the story, but if you want to get 100% sync and trophies you'll need them.  Speaking of synchronization, for all missions now there will be a certain objective for you to do.  If you don't do it you only get 50% sync on that mission.  Some of the things they will want you to do are: complete in under 8 minutes, use hidden blade to kill target, don't be detected, or some variation of those.  It can get frustrating at times, but you can always go into you DNA and replay any mission again later.The fighting has changed the most.  Remember in AC: II when you had to wait for your enemy to attack before you could perform a counter kill?  Well now you're rewarded for striking first instead of waiting.  You can perform what's called an execution streak, where you successfully kill a guard and then you can kill all the guards around you in one hit each if you can avoid taking damage.  It is a skill that takes some time to learn, but once you pull it off and kill 10 guards before you can blink, you will become addicted to it.  Travel has also changed; you can ride your horse through the city instead of just the country.  There are also tunnels that you can renovate and then zoom around the city to other tunnel stations for free.  Another new and notable feature is the assassin guild you now command.  What you do is find people who are being attacked by the Borgia and you save them, then they are added to your guild, then you send them on missions to gain experience and make you money or you can call on them in battle.  They will jump out and stab your target or shoot arrows.  Once they reach level 10, they become an assassin where they are sworn in and they become very deadly.  It's a helpful tool, since now you don't have to do all the work yourself.The multiplayer is an interesting addition.  You play as characters from the single player campaign (executioner, doctor, nobleman etc.).  Your job in the multiplayer is to find and kill your target while at the same time avoid being killed yourself.  Essentially you are the hunter and the hunted at the same time.  You get more points for stealthy kills and less for not-so-stealthy ones.  For example, if you killed your target from a hay cart or while blended in a crowd, you would get maybe 500-700 points.  But if you were spotted by your target before you killed him, and had to chase him down and stab him, then you would only get maybe 100 points.  See the difference?  Points are added up after each match and bring you up to the next level.  The higher the level you are the more equipment you have.  For example you can get smoke bombs, the ability to morph into someone else for 15 seconds or a super sprint power.The ending of AC: Brotherhood is very climatic, sort of like the AC: II ending.  I can almost guarantee that they will make another sequel, probably with the good men Ezio and Desmond again.  It will most likely be another extension like AC: Brotherhood was and not a new series.  I wonder what they will do for AC: III??  Over all, if you liked the series, you'll like this."Nothing is true, everything is permitted."

This game is one of my favorites on the PS3.  The the game play is very easy to grasp although I am almost done with teh game and still cant figure out how to chain kills.  The game is pretty fast paced, exciting and fun to play.  Also, the weapons are awesome and are extremely useful.  The one area where I find the game lacking is that certain aspects have made the game a bit on the easy side, but I will get into that.Story: 4/5-Truthfully, the story is ok.  I find the Desmond part of it so dumb and pointless.  Also the part in the beginning where you have to play as Desmond is aggrivatng as hell.  In essence Desmond's story is that he is an ancestor of Enzio and is being chased by the Templar, he has to defeat the templar by using a virtual realty system to overthorw the Borgia in Rome (that is wher eyou play as Enzio).  Enzio's story is really good especially when they start delving into the hidden missions regarding his past via the hidden Christina missions.Gameplay: 5/5-The gameplay is great, smooth and extremely elegant.  There are tons of missions, all of them related to the game and related to your life as an assassin (unlike Prototype where they are tedious side quests).  Most of the missions are not overly difficult and are pretty staight forward though many of them really require to strategize if you want to get a 100% completion for the mission.  Many of the side quests revolve around assassinating Borgia affiliates who are terrorizing the people of Rome.  Additionally, there are 15 Borgia towers where there is heavy enemy influence, you must kill the local captain who is a beefed up guard and burn down his tower in order to remove the influence.  If primary quests are in Borgia influence areas it is in your best interest to destroy the tower first or the missions will be a nightmare.The weapons are great especially the heavy swords.  My favorite weapon is the hidden blades, I find them the most effective.  There are swords, axes, maces, a cross-bow, a gun, poison and blades, all of which are exceptionally useful.  In my opinion the addition of the gun and cross-bow as well as their ease of use have made the game way too easy as I can just stand on a roof and snipe guards from a distance without being seen.Additionally, there is the inclusion of you being able to hire help from 3 distinct classes.  I find the mercenaries make the game too easy as you can take them with you into a mission and have them attack the guards while you do their thing, allowing you not to be detcted at all or allowing you to peform executions whaile the guards are busy fighting.  The inclusion of these mercenaries makes even the most difficult Borgia captain a breeze.Finally, through the game as you take down towers, you are able to rebuild Rome.  As you buy blacksmith's, art shops, banks, and doctors, you make money and you are bale to buy new items.  It is easy to spam this system, which as you buy banks, you make money at a super fast pace and can buy as many bullets or arrows as you want.Graphics/Visiuals: 5/5 - This is easy, the graphics and visuals are gorgeous.  You are running around 1500s Rome.  They producers made the city as close to historically correct as possible.  The game graphics are nearly flawless, smooth and there is minimal glitchyness.  Thank god, the load times are minimal, that drives me nuts!Multiplayer: 5/5-  The multiplayer is a real party.  I love it!  You go around killing other players either by stealth or brute force.  It is addictive.  Although it can get repetitive after a while, you really get addicted to it.Overall, this game is phenominal and a must buy.  Certain aspects make it slightly too easy, but that is rectified by the amount there is to do and the sheer insane number of missions.  Also, blowing through a mission may be easy, but getting full completion can be agrivatingly difficult, that definately makes up for it.Definately buy it!!  I love it, you will too!

I initially skipped this but decided to pick it up in preparation for Revelations. It's a great game but it feels like a dlc add-on... a really, really big dlc add-on.The game's new and only location (Rome) is larger than any city in AC2, but not quite as beautiful or interesting. The cities in AC2 were varied and often romantic, especially when you arrived in Venice. Rome on the other hand is dilapidated and kinda bland.The fighting has improved with new move sets, new weapons (like crossbows and poison darts), and enemies who aren't afraid to attack you while you're engaged with another.Movement and control are less enjoyable for some reason. They're mostly the same as AC2 but a little less accurate, a little less responsive, and a lot more infuriating. This is mostly evident when a situation requires urgency. Ezio bumbles around like a moron, unsure of what you're trying to get him to do, while the enemy attacks him mercilessly.The new feature of recruiting and training assassins is a fun and welcomed addition, as are parachutes, horse ridding while in the city and upgrading shops and buildings for use.The story was relatively interesting, but didn't feel like a significant enough leap in the AC mythos. It feels like AC2 was a little too long and the overlapping segment was cut, stretched out and padded with content to justify a full disc. Regardless, I actually prefer this approach as opposed to repeated dlc releases.I have not yet played Revelations so I cannot say whether Brotherhood is a purchase necessary to understand the overall story. Most of what occurs will undoubtedly be recapped in Revelations but considering the current price ($20>), you may want to pick this up anyway.
