So you're probably thinking, "What's with this guy? He gives it five stars for fun and two stars overall? WTF?" Well, here's the deal. Assassin's Creed is indeed a fun sandbox adventure with all kinds of things to do. You play Desmond in the modern era, who is, in turn, reliving the life of master assassin Ezio in Renaissance Era Rome. As Ezio, you must start a rebellion against cruel oppressors, the Borgia, and you do this by renovating the city (also making sure that the various businesses and vendors kick some money back to you), destroying their fortresses, and breaking up sinister cults. There are also story missions which tend to be a bit more complicated than those other tasks and can be more challenging. It's great fun, whether you're running about and callously battering bystanders aside, stealing from folks, climbing up walls like a crazy man, or slaughtering guards simply because you can.Then it just might all come crashing to a halt. See, the problem is that like me, you may encounter a game-breaking bug or two in your journey. Myself, I got this strange bug where Desmond kept getting bounced out of the Animus (this is the device that allows Desmond to relive his ancestor's past--it's complicated). There was literally nothing I could do. Without the ability to use the Animus, I could not progress any further in the game. And apparently, based on the research I've done, that's not the only game-breaking bug. Supposedly, late in the game, there's a mission where Ezio relives some experiences he had with someone he loved, and if you try to do that mission you're pretty much done for.It's freaking baffling. Ubisoft had a battalion of beta testers working on this thing. How did they miss these bugs? Anyway, the positive reviews are largely right about the game, but I for one cannot forgive the sloppy coding that denied me the chance to finish this game. Ubisoft may patch these issues at some point, but whatever the case may be, it was too late before I just gave up on this thing.Oh, and Ubisoft? Next time, can the political commentary, particularly on health care.
summary: An epic adventure... too bad you might not finish it

reviewText: Best of the series. love 'the truth' sequences even if i disagree with them, their method of obtainment and their ominous presentation is excellent. Rest of the game is on par with what you would expect from Assassins Creed

I do not know where to start, I love this game there is nothing like it new weapons, inventions, Especially the new glyphs or puzzles I really liked it on the second one, There are some problems but that's online when people have crappy connections it rarely happens though this game is fun and it's a must have I have been playing this non-stop.

I really loved this game. I only had a couple issues with it, which I believe to be great considering some of the games that come out these days. Fighting guards is incredibly easy. It seems like it has never really been difficult in these games but there is really no pressure to stay undetected on missions that do not require it. The missions that do require it though, are nice as well. also even though it is not necessary in some missions there is the 100% synch for completeing the mission with a bonus condition. You can either just do the mission and complete it or you can do it perfectly to acquire the 100%. One thing that bothered me only slightly was that at a certain point you get a string of missions you cannot decline which leads to the end of the game. I believe this enter set only took me about an hour or so to complete so it's not like it took a huge chunk of time or anything. Even the conditions of the missions I do not see as that bad, although slightly different. I have seen people say that after this it is impossible to complete a certain quest. I do not know what the quest is because I did not do it, but that is a little bothersome for those that do not want to or do not have the time for a second playthrough. Personally I am not too put off since I believe the game is worth the second playthrough. During the story there seems to be a decent amount of repetitive activites in order to complete certain faction things or collect all the items. I find this to be a little depressing but since there is so many different things to collect or complete in a way it's not as bad, since you can shift from doing one thing to another. I don't know if that makes any sense to anyone else but that's how it feels to me.The factions you could control (to a point) were quite astounding. There are the Assassins, Mercenaries, Courtesans, and Thieves. The quests to complete these along with other collection things were the repetitive things I mentioned earlier. Like I said while repetitive, their was enough to do that it did not feel as numbing. Leveling up the assassins was quite interesting. You could have them execute missions and gain money or even items sometimes. Each place has a chalk board with challenges on it to complete and they all have missions. Doing Leonardos missions were quite fun as well. You got to take control of the inventions he made at some point in the mission and wreack havoc on the enemy. Not to mention he makes a few neat things for you. Especially the last thing you get for completing all his missions, which at first I didn't think I would use much... but I really, really do.The actual story is quite neat as well. They left off with an interesting cliffhanger as I think we should come to expect now from this series. There isn't much I can say that wouldn't really spoil it so I am going to leave it at that, but I am looking forward to the next game in order to see what happens. I enjoyed the multiplayer for the time that I played it. I really wanted to complete the story so I haven't put as much time into it as I liked but my first impressesions are quite good. Unless they add some more game types or some type of diversity I can see it as being great, but not as entangling as some other games out there. I havent found any flaws in the system that I do not like, but I may find some later on. It is a very solid system which I think could hold peoples attention for a decent amount of time. I don't think it will be as popular as some of the first person shooters out there and I would definitly not buy this solely for the multiplayer.Overall I think this is an incredibly well made and solid game. It is an absolutely beautiful world and inside of it I have little complaints, which like I said earlier compared to some other games out now I think is amazing. The little qualms I have do not justify a lower rating as I still had amazing amounts of fun exploring and remodeling every rooftop and alleyway of the world.
I am a fan of the AC series and I thought this one was very fun to play because of all of the action and a good storyline.

reviewText: Game is more-or-less Assassin's Creed 2-2. Mostly the same characters (as you may expect since it's been, like, 5 years of the same characters). More of the same which is a good thing since I liked the previous entries.

I originally rented this game, because I had bought AC 1 & 2, and although I enjoyed both games and the story, I felt they were very similar and ended quickly.  So I reasoned I could save $50 by beating the game as a rental.  I should have bought it when it came out.  Instead I paid for the rental, and even though I beat the game in 5 days, I ended up having to buy it shortly afterwards because it was so addicting.AC3 adding the ability to have a team of assassins to attack guards while you are doing missions and side quests completely changed the game mechanics of the franchise.  Climbing a building on my way to a side mission, I spot an archer...hmmm...what the heck, I command you to die.  Shortly afterwards a couple assassins show up behind him and dispatch him.  Or I am walking through the outskirts of town and see a guard riding on his horse.  Why not, assassins, get him!  so I see one of my assassins running across a house that is parallel to the road, leaps behind the guard, pulls him off his horse, ends him, then rides off on the guy's horse.  I could not get enough of watching my assassins knock people off.  I could spend hours aimlessly walking around the city getting rid of guards.Re-building Rome through purchasing stores, stalls, and stables; as well as rebuilding historic sites versus building a table town with upgrades is another big plus in my book.Another big plus is the challenges they added to sequences and side missions.  If I am to assassinate a major player, I can do it anyway I want, but I can try to do it with an extra challenge of not being seen, not touching water, killing the person while sitting on a bench, or throwing them into a scaffold.  It brought an extra dimension to the hunt whereas AC1 & 2 was mostly hide/blend-in, jump kill, the run like heck.The Leonardo quests were awesome.  Gatling gun on a moving buggy, medieval tank through castles, renaissance flying contraption dropping fire bombs on the bad guys.  AWESOME!!!!Perches to open the map was given an extra level of difficulty by having to assassinate the local Guard Captain.  They completely enhanced the AC franchise to make this a must have game.  Very addicting and very fun to play over and over again.I agree with the negative reviews on the ending.  The ending although somewhat cool was very frustrating.  Platforming on the last sequence also seemed a little buggy in my opinion. I do have to admit that the story is starting to remind me of a Lost episode with a story line that seems to have more questions than answers.  In the end, I have to give 5 stars, because I bought this game for all the things it did right, not because of the poor ending sequences.

Many of these new features will make you stray away from the core main story completely.  But not in a bad way, it's just too addicting not to play around with these features. Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood turned out to be a really cool game.  It builds upon the formula of Assassin's Creed II and is more polished.  There are a few more fighting animations for Ezio and new colors for his outfit.  What makes this game so good is the fact that you can take command of your own squad of Assassins that will help you upon your command during missions, and out in the world.  Leveling them up is a cinch as well, as you can send them on missions all over Europe to gain experience.  I would advise only sending them on missions with a 100 percent success rating.  Keeping them around in Rome is the best way to monitor their progress, and you can choose their colors.Rome is beautiful and very true to its Renaissance inspiration.  It's the only city in the game and it's huge. Players will have fun leaping across the rooftops.  The enemies in the game are very challenging and are a joy to fight. The story is everything you'd expect from the Assassins Creed franchise and is good.The multiplayer is fun and suspenseful, as you must maneuver through the crowds searching for and running from other players.All in all this game gets an 8.5/10 from me, and I recommend it especially before playing Assassin's Creed: Revelations.

I'm confronted by an unusual moment in my history of reviewing video games...On November 28th, 2009, I commented that Assassin's Creed II would have fared much better had it been a bit more like Batman: Arkham Asylum.  I felt that the strategies regarding stealth as well as fluid combat which B:AA deployed so well would have fit excellently in the AC Universe.I swear it's like they freakin' heard me.Enter the Killstreak!  A new flick-the-stick-and-hit-the-button tactic in Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood that lets you wipe out a field-full of baddies in a few seconds flat.  I'll admit getting the hang of it took me considerably longer than I had hoped, but never-the-less, I got it.  Now I can drop on an unsuspecting group of guards and be surrounded by dead bodies in just 10 gloriously satisfying seconds.  It REALLY IS fun - and for that change ALONE I give this game a higher score than it's predecessor.Assassin's Creed also resuses some ideas of it's earlier games - even the first title - with the inclusion of the Borgio towers.  It's very similar to the "Templars" which had to be killed in the first title, but this time there's actually a reason to do so, and you're able to apply more tactics in the process.  No more running up to a guy and trying to kill him before you get your butt kicked - now you can slink across a roof top, watch his motion patterns, weed out his guards, and make the kill.It's hard to comment much else on AC:B because it's still a lot of what we've seen before.  Do missions, unlock weapons, upgrade your character, upgrade the town - there isn't a TON of new content here.  But slowly they're making Assassin's Creed a better game to play, and as long as no major glitches show up, I'll actually finally find myself looking FORWARD to the next title release.And don't listen to your neighborhood Gamestop employee as I did: the guy who told me that AC:B is mostly a multiplayer game and that there isn't much content to the single-player campaign.  I've been playing the main story now for probably close to 20 hours and still have a looooooooong ways to go.I've heard that the multiplayer aspect is complex and rather thrilling, but I haven't gotten there yet, so I won't comment.  I bought the title however with the intent of trying it out with my brother in Nevada, so we'll see how that goes.In the end, I'm satisfied with the direction Assassin's Creed is taking.  Let's hope they keep it up (and that EA doesn't get involved - can I have an AMEN?!)

I really enjoyed certain aspects of Brotherhood - most of which it shared with its predecessors. The new aspects: cruising around performing guild missions, taking out towers and training Assassins was also lots of fun.The problem that I had with the single player campaign was the inordinate amount of 'do not be detected' missions. I remember having fun in AC2 where there was a mission to infiltrate a military compound, kill the chest bearer, steal his clothes and assume his identity. There were some tricks to that mission and it took a number of times to get it right; but, ultimately rewarding and still reasonable on the PITA factor. In AC Brotherhood, take that mission and multiply the PITA factor by 20x. There are dozens of main missions where going undetected turns a fun playground into a tedious exercise in repetitive, buzz killing desyncronizations (not to mention the reload times). It is about as much fun as memorizing random phone numbers. You have to try 20 different things until one of them works, make your way to the next bit of cover and go through it all again. To add insult to injury, is it even feasible that dressed as an Assassin you can go into a Cathedral, crash a closed Mass and hide in plain sight by blending with a bunch of bishops?! Surely they are going to smell that raw sewage that I just swam through.Overall, a nice game but not as engaging or clever as the first two.

reviewText: A game that can be described as "Assassin's Creed 2.5", Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood takes the basic gameplay, graphics, and setting of AC2 and adds a bunch of new features and content for a whole new city.Brotherhood picks up exactly where AC2 left off. Players once again control Ezio, an assassin in Renaissance Italy, as well as Desmond, his modern counterpart who's reliving his life through genetic memory. Most of the game is the same as Assassin's Creed 2 - if you liked it, you'll like Brotherhood. In fact, I'd say a good 90% of the game is recycled. Therefore, it's more important to talk about the new parts of the game.The combat has been retooled slightly. The weapons are the same for the most part, with a few changes. One change is that some weapons are now automatically paired with a ranged weapon - the main weapon connects to Ezio's hidden pistol, while the sub-weapon connects to throwing knives. This allows for smoother combos, and means that you can use a weapon without having to specifically switch to the ranged weapon. Enemies are a bit smarter, too, and will grab at you more frequently (though they still attack one at a time and are easily dispatched by counter-kills).In AC2, the player had the opportunity to invest money into their home villa to make it more profitable and prosperous. AC:B takes place entirely in the city of Rome, and thus the entire city can be renovated and upgraded. This primarily takes two forms: the first is clearing out enemy strongholds, and the second is fixing up shops, banks, and landmarks. One issue I had with the latter aspect was that the only real "benefit" of it was to get you more money (which also happened with the first game), and the only real use of money besides upgrades is to upgrade your property, which gets you more money and so on.One thing I did appreciate is the increased number of missions that are actually about "sneaking" and "assassination", including the previously-mentioned enemy strongholds. There's actually a lot of missions where there's an incentive to remain undetected, find creative ways to approach a situation, and so on. It wasn't perfect, but it was a pretty neat attempt all things considered. A lot of the game's best moments are a result of these missions - almost failing, but then shooting the sentry with a crossbow before he discovers you, and so on.The titular "Brotherhood" refers to the brotherhood of Assassins, who Ezio takes command of roughly halfway through the game. Assassins are recruited from the rank of discontented citizens (the maximum number is based on how much of the city you control), and they serve two purposes. The first is to help you in the game world, either by assassinating a target for you (if you select a target and call for help when not in combat) or helping Ezio fight enemies (if you call for help while in combat). The second is sending them off on missions to get experience and monetary rewards.The upgrade system for the Assassins is unpleasantly simplistic: as Assassins become more experienced, the player can assign points to attack or defense. The problem arises because all assassins end up in the same place (there's 9 levels and only 4 points of attack and defense each). Assassins can be differentiated by their names, facial appearance, and selectable colors; unfortunately, when they hit maximum level their new costume means that they lose those selectable colors, which makes them all basically the same.The Assassins felt sort of unbalanced, too. The combat system is pretty easy, so for the most part calling your allies in felt like overkill. It was neat in some sequences, but it always felt more like "I don't feel like bothering anymore, you guys come take care of this". The only time I had assassins die was early on, when my low-level recruits blundered into a giant group of guards and refused to run away. Still, despite these issues, they still seem pretty cool: it's fun to chase a guy, almost lose him, and then sic one of your apprentices on him at the last second.Brotherhood also has a multiplayer mode, based on blending into a giant crowd of NPCs while trying to assassinate (and avoid being assassinated by) other players. While it's certainly innovative and entertaining, it also seemed a bit oddly-paced. It felt like a deathmatch, but with more gaps between kills. It was kind of fun, but just sort of simplistic. Once you'd figured out the gameplay, it just felt like doing the same thing over and over - there weren't a lot of evolving strategies or clever ploys to carry out.My main problem with this game is that a lot of the content feels sort of overdone. The new stuff is fun, but the thing that actually named the game (the assassin recruits) is really underdeveloped. Most of the content is just stuff from AC2 over again - your new hideout, the new flags to collect, the new feathers to collect, the new secret lairs to explore, etcetera. The new levels and side-missions really make up for it, but a lot of the content just felt like a slog that I didn't want to bother going through again. Still, if you enjoyed AC2, you'll definitely want to give Brotherhood a shot.Rating: 7/10.We purchased this game with our own funds.

reviewText: The first Assassins creed was very good.  The second one was great, a true masterpiece.  This game manages to make enough slight changes to feel new and original, while fitting perfectly into the story with the first 2 games.  The story is amazing, and the variety and fun factor are through the roof.  I got 1000 gamerscore in assassins creed 2, and plan on doing the same in this game.  Keep in mind for this review that I've got around 40 hours into the single player campaign, and there are only 4 single player achievements that I haven't gotten yet.  I haven't even started the multiplayer yet.  It's impressive that they even had time for multtiplayer to be included, with such a well balanced, polished single player experience.

I know the storyline is fictional (you could see it in MANY of it's historical inconsistencies and fantasies) but could this game get any more anti-christian.  It's ironic to see a game made by a french company be so anti-christian in it's story telling. Gameplay is very much the same as SC series which isn't bad. This just struck a nerve with me is all.

No spoilers ahead.I *did* love AC2, and story-wise, it's helpful to play that game before ACB. I didn't play the first AC.There are definite improvements in ACB. As usual, you get a variety of weapons, armor upgrades, and costume variations. Combat and movement seem about the same (though there are times when your character doesn't quite go the way you want, resulting in falling after a difficult ascent, or getting mobbed in combat). Building up factions, esp the Assassin's Guild, is fun and advantageous. The graphics are at least as lush and detailed, and some great views can be had by climbing tall buildings and looking around.Some folks have complained about the lack of locations; almost all of the game play takes place in the city of Rome. No more traveling between cities. Really, though, the presentation of Rome is vast and varied enough to be interesting. There are crowded city streets, large open plazas, rural areas, and some water to cross/swim. The city also has enough shops scattered about to keep you well stocked. There are places to upgrade, and loot to gather. Like AC2, there are special levels to get the special armor, and another bunch of Subject 16 puzzles to solve. I found some of the puzzles to be a little too obtuse.The main problem with ACB is that there's a little too much of it. I admit that sound ridiculous, but the end of the game is a real slog to get through, and falls into that unfortunate trap of feeling like work. One of the final levels, leading to the big confrontation, feels sloppy, rushed, and thrown together. Worse, you can only choose to ACCEPT these missions. It's like the game is trying to force you through this mediocre chapter. There are lots of great missions and chapters, though, and plenty of optional ones related to factions.MULTIPLAYER: The on-line multiplayer is just like a game in highschool or college I've played, called ASSASSIN. Everyone in the game has a contract to "kill" someone, but no one knows who is coming after them, so it's a game of stalk and hide. It's a great idea for a video game. Sadly, it has two major flaws. The first, common in mp games, is there are way too many players who are ranked much higher than you, and have advantages. I understand the idea of leveling up and unlocking items/talents, but it's not fun to be a noob and constantly die. There are supposedly ranked matches, but I've never been able to join one. Secondly, the games are 10 minutes long, and you cannot enter mid-game, so there's a lot of sitting around waiting for a lobby, and there don't seem to be many lobbies. It's too bad, becauase it CAN be really fun.All in all it's a good game, but I think AC2 is better, and I've had enough of Assassin's Creed for a while. I don't think I'll pick up Revelations any time soon.
summary: If you loved Assassin's Creed 2, you'll like Assassin's Creed Brotherhood

reviewText: This series continues to improve. Your still Ezio. It takes place right after the first second title. You go on to stop the Borgia family by recruiting Assassin's and recapturing the piece of Eden. If you play either of the last two titles, the near end gets pretty crazy as well. The game is pretty decent link since a big part of the game is the added multiplayer they put into the game.Before I get to that, the single player game isn't as long but it offers a lot of stuff to do. This time around you don't improve your own place, you improve all of Rome by opening up weapon, medicine, and other shops to use and to add funds that you will receive by opening up banks as well. You do this by taking over the influence of a stronghold held by the Borgia Family. To accomplish this you kill a leader of that area and burn its tower. This starts off as a main objective and becomes somewhat of a side thing to in order to make their influence less threatening to your presence. As you further progress you will gain the ability to recruit Assassins. You can you use them as you fight to call in as a new gameplay element but beforehand you can send them on smaller easier missions to gain experience to be better equipped to fight.The online portion is pretty creative and unique. There are various modes to play in. There is one where you have to be sneaky to attack your target. While your on the prowl someone else is also hunting you. You don't want to give yourself away too easy so gain experience by assassinating quietly and you keep yourself getting noticed. There is also another were you are in groups. You will be the hunted one round and the next round you will be the predator. Its pretty clever. You have perks and abilities you can use throughout as you get more experienced. You start of with a disguise but work your way up to smoke bombs, firecrackers, a gun, and such that aid you as your trying to attack or evade.I highly recommend this game. It is one of the best games I played the does a great job balancing a incredible single-player experience with great multiplayer. Its no way tacted on. When I heard that Assassin's Creed was going multiplayer I knew it would be a huge mistake.  Nothing in the Assassin's Creed series speaks to me as multiplayer, ESPECIALLY a versus multiplayer.  In single player I had endless troubles catching people running all over rooftops and platforming.  I could just imagine how ridiculous it would be with internet lag and intelligent players thrown into the equation.  Honestly, Brotherhood is a very good attempt at making A. Creed multiplayer, but it just doesn't cut it for me.First of all, the multiplayer does not play like Assassin's Creed games at all.  It is only a mini game.  There is no sword fighting (or any tactical combat at all), only assassination and various tools to help you do so.  One of my favorite parts about Assassin's Creed 1 that hooked me was the depth and fluidity of the sword fighting.  It was sorely missed.  It is understandable that they did not allow multiplayer sword fighting, as that would be impossible to keep fluid with internet lag.  However, it is just ridiculous that assassins are hunting you and you can't defend yourself with a sword (which all good assassins should carry, like Altair and Ezio).  Inconsistencies like these damaged the game's immersion, making me feel like I was restricted from the full experience by these arbitrary rules.  Another inconsistency is that, while in most modes you can assassinate others, you can not assassinate the assassins that are hunting you.  You may only "stun" them by knocking them out for a moment so that you may escape.  Really?  I have a blade that I am VERY capable with and I can't kill the number one threat to myself - assassins who are hunting me?  That is... well, I'm sorry, but retarded.  My favorite part about A. Creed 1 was the intense immersion.  This just feels like I'm playing a silly game of tag.A major problem for me was just how much most of the multiplayer modes are dependent on sheer luck or idiotic risks.  In two of the multiplayer modes you are both hunting players and are being hunted by players.  Yea.  Good luck with that.  Inevitably when you go to make your move you will be giving away your position to the assassins hunting you.  It is a complete contradiction.  You want to be stealthy because you are being hunted, but you are forced to break stealth to hunt your target.  Because of this most games are reduced to a mere causal chain of pure chance.  One person kills another, then that killer is killed, and that killer is killed, and so on until everyone is dead except for one lucky remainder.  Rinse and repeat.  Luck of assassin targets and spawn locations are also a big problem.  In Free For All (Wanted) I'm often killed by the same assassin many consecutive times.  Out of pure chance one person keeps getting me as a target AND I keep spawning in his general area.  Fun.  Also, often your target will be snatched before you can reach them, in which case you've probably already given your location away.  This is pure luck depending on the location of your competing assassins and the choices of the target.  For example, if the target is walking away from me and towards a competing assassin, then getting that kill will be doubly difficult - I have to reach the target faster and not compromise my stealth.  This is rather impossible.  And, as it is impossible to know the location of competition, you leave yourself entirely to luck in your pursuit of your target.Aside from all these theoretical problems with Brotherhood, there are very real issues with the multiplayer.  Lag and bugs are serious business in Brotherhood.  It is not rare to see someone "teleporting" and miraculously killing you.  Why, just hours ago my friend claimed someone appeared to teleport through an entire wall and assassinate him.  The same lag-induced oddities have happened to myself.  As for bugs, I have seen players (in Manhunt mode) who cannot be killed by any means or stunned with Smoke Bombs, yet they walk around and "stun" every assassin who approaches them.On top of all these issues, multiplayer is barely explained in a VERY simple tutorial.  This leaves so many parts of the multiplayer unexplained and players must seek the very small third-party information or simply make uninformed assumptions for themselves.  I have often assumed incorrectly about multiplayer game mechanics, due in part to new players being restricted by the "leveling" system.  It makes the mutliplayer infinitely more difficult to learn, as you must reconstruct your strategy as you gain more tools.  Nothing makes sense in the beginning UNTIL you do get your tools.  Then it makes half-sense, but still feels clunky and unresponsive.Oh yes, did I mention that it is insanely difficult to get a game going?  I have waited for games longer than 10 minutes many times, eventually saying screw it around the 15 minute mark.  And don't even try to play with friends.  The wacko system will separate your friends the first chance it gets to fill another game.  There is no integrated support for Xbox Parties to keep your party together.AS FOR THE SINGLE PLAYER...  It is the same quality one could expect from Assassin's Creed 2: thrilling gameplay, decent but iffy story, and annoying platforming exercises.  If you appreciated AC2, I assure you you'll enjoy Brotherhood's single player campaign.  I, myself, am an Assassin's Creed 1 fan.  The open world gave me the feeling of an assassin's freedom, the espionage drove the story with thrilling anticipation, and the realistic characters made Altair's experience infinitely more memorable than the overtly linear story driven Ezio.

reviewText: This game is by far one of the best games I've ever played on the XBOX 360... and I'm not only talking about the Assassin's Creed saga. After ACII was released last year I spent hours and hours playing it last Christmas season until I beat it and believe me I had a lot of fun with it. I also beat the first one when it came out in 2007 (around holidays too) and when I knew that they were going to release another one as a sequel of ACII I was really excited but I never imagine that they would improve what it was already great with ACII. I bought the game last friday and as soon as I got home my nephew and I spent 3 hours and a half playing it (we put it away around midnight) Then, Saturday afternoon after I came from work we p{ayed it for about 5 hours and on Sunday we played it for another 7 hours so, if you add up the hours you'll see that we spent around 16 hours playing it last weekend and you know why? because the game is so addictive in any way you see it. If you are already an AC fan there's no point of telling you what you know but if you want to approach this game for the very first time... don't rent it... BUY IT!!! you won't regret it. The story line continues exactly where ACII finished and the way the creators make you feel involved in the game is so amazing. I must recall the scene when the Village of Mario Auditore is being attacked by cannons (one of the best stages ever in a videogame to play with).The reviewers were right when they said that besides the main story you can do A LOT of things too and what is interesting here is that you never feel that those tasks are not related with the game, I mean, you never feel that the extra activities to do are useless or pointless because you notice that everything is so well related with the whole story in general. The graphics are beautiful and you also learn a little bit about Rome and the places that exist there as well as the people you run into the game (you should know that the Borgia family really existed and that the one that was a pope it turned out to be one of the meanest guys ever). The movements from Ezio are pretty much similar to ACII maybe a little bit faster but that's hard to tell. Buy the game if you want to feel involved in a great story with a fun game from this generation. You will have fun and feel curious (as I did) of exploring every corner of Rome city.

reviewText: This is what happens when you get a great story, great acting, great coding, and the wherewithal to pull it all together. There aren't just great aspects to this game, but truly a great game in general.Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood is the followup to Assassin's Creed II, where you control the secret assassin Ezio Auditore da Firenze. Ezio is part of the secret Brotherhood of Assassin's, which have fought a secret war through the ages against the Templars to ensure that humanity has free will, which the Templars sought to control. The Templars have infiltrated many aspects of power, and thus are intertwined with an oppressive regime bent on ruling Italy (and eventually, the known world).The controls are essentially the same from Assassin's Creed II, and while not perfect (sometimes its overly intuitive where you wind up running up the wrong walls, for example), it adds just enough minor frustration to really make you vested into the game; parts where you are chasing, or timed, you are forced to also slow down and get it right, not just free-run and have everything done for you.The graphics are again, fantastic. Beautiful scenery, high detail without extravagant load times.The storyline is excellent, as far as videogames go, this is one of the most compelling stories told; not just for the main storyline, but the mini story-lines themselves are cheap gimmicks to extend the game, and are themselves incredibly fascinating to experience.If there's any complaint I have of this game, it would be that I miss traveling to different locations like you did in ACII, rather than having it all in one large sand-box area.In summary, this is really a must-play/must-own videogame, with plenty of original content, excellent voice acting, beautiful graphics, and the final polishing which many games lack. This game deserves its very high rating.5/5 stars
summary: AC2 Raised the Bar, Brotherhood follows through

reviewText: For those of you who love the single player franchise you will not be dissapointed.  The story continues to follow Ezio and practically everyone who did not die in assassin's creed 2.  With the addition of things like mounted combat, a personal cadre of trained assasins, plenty of sidequests, aggresive attacks, multiple continuous kills, and an engaging storyline I feel safe to say that Assassin's Creed Brotherhood single player will keep you entertained and immersed for many hours.I bought the game mainly for the online multiplayer.  I am not a fan of shooter games and so I'm not sure that Assassin's Creed Brotherhood will cater to fans of shooters, but if stealth, quick reactions, and good strategy are your thing, or if you just want to escape the already saturated shooters norm, then you have a winner here.How would you feel to be hunting a particular person in a large crowd of people when you know that they know someone is targeting them, while simultaniously being hunted by someone you know wants to stick all sorts of interesting peices of metal in your body?  Would it make you feel better to know that your target can disguise themselves as someone else, have counterattack manuevers, and that you don't know what your pursuer looks like?  He could be anywhere in the crowd right behind you, on the roof above you, or casually walking by your side.  Now imagine that there were two, perhaps three such pursuers out for your blood... Welcome to Assassins Creed Brotherhood multiplayer!The multiplayer features 4 game types (ranked or non-ranked), 10+ characters, several maps, your choice of abilities, and a lot of adrenaline pumping action.  Your objective is to hunt down your contract while being pursued by 0-4 assassins (usually 1-2).  Your contract may also have 1-4 assassins following him (usually 1-2).  Who you are targeting and who targets you as well as how many changes throughout the game.  As you assassinate targets, escape from or stun pursuers you rack up points and are able to level up.  Leveling up allows you to unlock new abilities, equipment, colors, and characters. Points are not based on the quantity of the kills, but the quality of them.  One stealthy kill can easliy earn you the points equivalent to 4-6 noisy, chase-type kills.Like any game, ACB has a few glitches.  The multiplayer seems to take an unreasonable amount of time to actually join a session. Times range from a few minutes to over an hour (the upwards of 15 minutes being less likely).  There are some minor glitches too, such as not recieving a contract target, or not being matched well against other players.  Ubisoft has been contacted and are working to resolve the problems.Despite the minor glitches, ACB delivers in single and multiplayer modes and is a great addition to anyone's entertainment collection.  Also a good chance of future DLC.Update:  I changed my internet provider to Qwest, and I can get into games in seconds now.  Plenty of awesome DLC is now provided.  Still my favorite online multiplayer game!

Assassin's Creed Brotherhood picks up right where Assassin's Creed 2 left off with Ezio in Rome.  You do not need to play AC 2 to enjoy this game, but you will enjoy it more if you do.High Concept: 10/10Take a character like Batman, make him an assassin, drop him into Renaissance Italy, and surround him with corrupt government and church officials that need to be exterminated for the good of mankind!  Allow this character to become a millionaire and renovate Rome while building a guild of Assassins.Story: 10/10Assassin's Creed Brotherhood has a story within a story. On the outside, you play Desmond, the ancestor of Altair and Ezio, who's hooked up to the animus (a virtual reality simulator) in order to uncover clues from the past to stop a diabolical secret organization by recovering a powerful magical artifact known as the "Apple of Eden."In the Virtual World you are Ezio, an aristocrat who gets swept up in the political turmoil of 15th Century Italy.  A change in the government makes you a fugitive, so you use your assassination skills to tip the balance of power and rescue Rome.  You get your weaponry and gear from none other than Leonardo Da Vinci and you form the Brotherhood of Assassins with Niccolo Machiavelli.Ezio is up against a megalomaniac named Cesare Borgia who wants to rule Rome.  Under his influence, Rome begins to crumble.  It's up to Ezio to cleanse Rome of his foul stench. Through the story, you meet many fascinating European historical figures with their own dark pasts. Similar to the Da Vinci Code, the story may have you questioning your beliefs, researching historical figures, or wanting to take a more active role in the world around you. It's rare that a video game story actually makes you want to rethink history.Gameplay: 9/10The combat is similar to Assassin's Creed 2, but the animations and gameplay are more fluid this time around.  You can kill enemies with daggers, swords, hammers, maces, poison darts, crossbow bolts, throwing knives, a pistol, hired thugs, summoned assassins, and stun them with smoke bombs.  The combat is also very easy.  As you kill one enemy, you can insta-kill others by pointing the analog stick at them and pressing the X button.  You can easily kill 12 guys in 20 seconds and you do feel like an assassin while doing it.Although, the free running is good, it's not perfect. At times, Ezio may jump in the wrong direction and fall to his death. This is extremely rare, but when it happens, it sucks.The Open World:  10/10The problem with most Open World Games is that moving through the world to your next objective feels like a waste of time.  You often spend 2-7 minutes just traveling.  Well, Assassin's Creed Brotherhood has created some interesting ways to mitigate this.This time around, it is a lot easier to get from one place to another in Rome.  The overall land mass is a bit smaller than Assassin's Creed 2 and Ezio runs faster.  You can also go about 25% faster by pressing the Y button to summon a horse, or horse-jack someone.  Assassin's Creed Brotherhood also uses underground sewer entrances as "Fast Travel" Spots.  Enter them, pick where you want to go on the map, and you teleport there.Assassin's Creed Brotherhood also rewards you just for playing, so there is NO Downtime between missions.  The main objective of the game is to expunge the Borgia influence from Rome.  You do this by assassinating the magistrates and burning down their watchtowers.  As you destroy the tower, you are free to renovate shops, blacksmiths, and landmarks in the area.  Improving Rome also pays you in dividends.  Every structure that you renovate adds to Ezio's bank account every 20 minutes.  You get paid for playing!Another way to profit from downtime is the use of the Assassin's Guild.  Halfway through the campaign, you get to recruit rebellious townsfolk to your cause.  By using messenger pigeons, you can send your recruits on missions to gain more money for Ezio and XP for the recruit.  It works similar to a Facebook Game.  You scroll through a list of missions with a difficulty rating of 1-5.  You choose which assassin(s) will perform the mission.  The game gives you their % of success and the time it will take to complete the mission.  You press a button to send them on their way.  If they succeed, you get rewarded.  If they fail, they die.  As the recruits gain XP, you can upgrade their weapons and armor.  This makes them more powerful when you summon them in game.  So, as you are running through the world, you get text updates that say:  Mission:  Assassinate a Herald Complete.  When the mission has been completed, you are free to upgrade them and send them on more missions.  This is a really innovative idea with only one drawback.  You have to believe that an assassin can travel from Rome to Constantinople, kill a guy, and return to Rome in 6 minutes.  It's best not to think about it and just count your gold.Missions:  6/10The only flaw in this game that prevents it from being a true masterpiece is a handful of mission designs.  Every Mission in the game has an objective, "Kill the Magistrate" with a condition "Avoid Detection" and an optional condition "Kill him with your hidden blade."  The optional condition makes the game more challenging and gives you a 100% synchronization bonus.  If you were to kill the magistrate with your crossbow, you only get a 50% rating for completing the mission.  The synchronization bonus isn't really used for anything though, it just makes the game more interesting.Some Missions are amazingly great and drive the story, while others are just plain bad.Here are some tips for Mission Designers:- If the Player can Fail a Mission within 1 second of starting it, while they are reading the objective, it is a bad mission.- If you need checkpoints every 10 meters with a paragraph explaining what to do, it's a bad mission.- If there is only 1 way to complete the mission and 142 ways to fail it, it's a bad mission.- If the Player can fail a Mission because an arbitrary clock on the HUD hit zero, but Ezio still has a chance of completing the mission in the world (he's standing right next to the target with no guards around) it breaks game fiction and is a bad mission.- If the Player can fail a Mission because an arbitrary distance counter on the HUD said you were too far from your target, even though you are in a locked room with the guy, it breaks game fiction and it is a bad mission.- If the whole purpose of the game is to upgrade your weapons and gear and you have missions that forbid the player from using their weapons and gear that they have spent 15 hours upgrading it is a bad mission.  (Especially when there are six in a row.)- If the rules of the mission are inconsistent with 99% of the rest of the game, it is a bad mission.Your mission designs should never get in the way of the Player feeling like an assassin.Note:  The game is broken into 9 Sequences.  After you complete Sequence 7, the game becomes a linear string of missions that you cannot decline until you complete the game.  If you want to do optional missions or upgrade your guilds, do this before you finish Sequence 7 or after you complete the main campaign!!!Multiplayer:  6/10Assassin's Creed Brotherhood features an interesting Multiplayer Mode where you are in a room of 200 clones.  6-8 of the people in the room are players.  Some are trying to assassinate you while you are trying to assassinate someone else.  There is no combat, you just press X to kill them for the most part.  You are awarded "Style Points" for your kills.  It is an interesting gameplay mode, but it lacks depth.  As you gain XP, you can upgrade your character and unlock more gear like smoke bombs, disguises, throwing knives, and poison.  The gear is designed to give you a better chance at killing your target or escaping from your pursuers.  If an assassin is about to take you out and you see them coming, a B button icon appears above their head.  If you press B you have a chance at punching them in the face, and stunning them to escape.  There is a problem though.  Pressing the B button doesn't aways work.  I'm not sure if it is a latency issue or what, but it just seems odd that the game tells me to Press B to escape, I press B, and die.  The game should give the player a 1.5 second invulnerability window to press B and escape.  60% of the time that I press B, I die.  Games should never kill the player if they do exactly what they are supposed to do.There are also some team modes where you work in groups to take out another team and they try to take out your team.There are a few major drawbacks to the Multiplayer Modes.  The wait times to actually join a game can be from 1 to 40 minutes long.  To make matters worse, you can't do anything while you are waiting to join.  You can't organize your gear, set your preferences, study the map, research the complex scoring system, choose the map that you want to play on... nothing.  You just stare at a static progress screen.  There are also a few problems with assigning targets.  This is a major problem because the only way to score points is to escape assassins or assassinate other players.  I've had 3 minute stretches of a 10 minute match where I wasn't assigned a target and nobody was sent after me.  I could only wander around the level and watch everyone else outscore me.If you can actually get into a game, the Multiplayer is pretty fun, but you can tell it's very rough.  It's very simple and rewards you for playing, but it lacks the depth needed to keep people hooked for months.Graphics: 10/10One of the best looking open world games of all time, in terms of art direction and quality. The environments, characters, effects, and animations are all phenomenal. The highly detailed buildings, clothing, and props all realistically fit the world. The characters look and animate great right down to their facial expressions. It actually feels like you were transported into 15th Century Italy!!!Sound: 10/10The sound track and sound effects are amazing. The music is appropriate for the setting and gives a sense of action, mystery, and danger. The sound effects put you right into the action or they'll make you want to seek comfort in the shadows as you stealthily plan your next assassination. The soundtrack is also available on itunes!!!Replay Value: 7/10Assassin's Creed II offers 12-24 hours of gameplay, which is especially impressive in this day and age where most action games are 7 hours long. After you finish the game, you have the option to keep everything that you've earned and continue playing to collect items, finish side quests, or unlock achievements. However, there's no reason to start the game over from the beginning. Even with limited replay value, you're still going to get your money's worth.  There is also a multiplayer mode where you assassinate other players and gain XP to upgrade your characters.Overall: 8.5/10When the concept, story, art, and music are all amazing, you have a very immersive world. The criticisms about Assassin's Creed Brotherhood are that it doesn't offer much of a challenge, and 10% of the missions are unfun.Buy it if you liked Assassin's Creed 2 or Prince of Persia.Buy it if you like fun and easy games that constantly reward you.Buy it if you want a thinking man's Action RPG.Rent it if you want to try it out and have about 15 free hours.Avoid it if you like a challenge or hated everything about the original Assassin's Creed.Avoid it if you are EXTREMELY Catholic. The portrayal of the Vatican may upset you.Avoid it if you don't like the idea of being a dude, who's playing a dude, who's playing another dude.And there you have it. If you can't trust a guy whose name is Poisoned Blade and dresses like an assassin (seriously look at my profile pic) then who can you trust?
Good game, better than the previous two in the series. Multiplayer is a lot of fun and there's a ton to do within the campaign.

reviewText: After assassins creed II left with a cliffhanger, i want it to learn more about what happen after the events of ACII. Brotherhood will answer that. Note, this is NOT Assassins Creed III. This is still Assassin's Creed II and it leads up to what happen after AC 2. Now i was really shocked on how addicting and the quality of the game came out to be. This is my honest review on Assassin's Creed Brotherhood.Plot + SettingThe setting takes place in 2012 (playing as Desmond) and 1503 in Roma (playing as Ezio Audtiore). Brotherhood takes place right after Ezio exits out of the vault. After meeting a familiar face, he returns to the villa to relax  but something happens to Ezio once again and after years of fighting for punishing the people who killed his family in AC II, he is force to hunt down his enemies. The game also includes repress memories (Ever wanted to know how Cristina (Ezio ex-love) and Ezio ever met up?)Gameplay + MechanicsThe gameplay has greatly improved. You can now combine attacks to kill your enemy. For instance, Ezio will have his longsword out and have his hidden gun in his other hand. If your a little rusted on your combat skills, Brotherhood has a virtual training game where you can brush up your skills if needed. Also whats a great add on to this game is that you can now relive events that you already did during the story (As the samething occurs in the first assassins creed). During the course of the game, you can have other assassins with you during the game. This is a great add-on and keeps the game going. You can have up to 13 assassins with you. Now whats great about this is that the assassins will come in handy during situations. If your on a mission where you cannot be detected and you see guards all over the place. You can call the assassins to kill the guards for you. You can also send them on missions to level up and get better equipment. Now as for the big update, this game has multiplayer. Great add on and highly addictive. There are three modes. Wanted (Free for all), Manhunt (2 teams. One hides and the other teams hunts. There are two rounds so the opposite team can hide/hunt.), Alliance (three teams.) The great thing about the muliplayer is that when your hunting someone, there's sometimes people one or even four people hunting you. For example, your playing a round of wanted. You have four other players who are trying to find you while you have to kill your target ( There will always be a picture on the top right of your target so you can know what he or she looks like). You see your target and you run up to him and kill him. Little as you know, there's a person waiting for you to kill your target so he/she can kill you. You will always be on your toes when playing this game and it will get very repetitive. Either way, you will have a good time when playing this game. Note: for muliplayer, you cannot splitscreen.One of the best features in the game is that Ubisoft release three DLC's which two of them is free. The two that are free contain new maps and new modes. The last one which is called Da Vinci Disappearance is 800 microsoft points. The overall DLC is about Da Vinci suddenly getting kidnapped by a mysterious cult. It's up to Ezio to find Leorando by searching for clues all over Rome. Including the DLC is an upgrade for the multiplayer which is a nice little treat. The map comes with two new maps, three new characters to play and one new mode. All for 800 points? Sounds great to me!The only downfall of this game is that this felt like a DLC. The single player campaign has 20+ hours into it and it almost didnt feel like a whole game. I felt like Ubisoft should of add-on this to Assassins Creed II.Overall+ Great Storyline! Highly addictitive, rich and detailed.+ Muliplayer+ Recruit Assassins+ Top-notch combat+ In depth characters emotions+ Replay value high- Feels like a DLC.- No splitscreen in Muliplayer

Every time I pick up the controller to play an hour or two I start to formulate an approach to a review. They all test my powers of eloquence, and all the verbal embellishment probably isn't necessary to communicate the simply point that this game is absolutely, staggeringly, phenomenal.All the narratives in my head end up something like this in structure: "First was good, second was great, third is absolutely dazzling, and here's how & why." Instead of writing a novella about spoilers (others have taken care of this) I will instead, simply, relate a few relatively discontinuous thoughts & observations:- It's bigger & better, more detailed and more involved than AC-II, by far. Storyline, open world, texture qualities and effects, cinematics. And as mentioned above, AC-II was already "great" in my book - top-5 game of all time. This one slides in to an easy #1 spot for me.- There are more types of side-missions involving more types of secondary characters.- It has better fighting dynamics, better moves, and generally speaking, superior (and more gleefully enjoyable) @$$-kicking.- The artwork, in terms of realism, detail, variety, and sheer staggering scale, is to my knowledge unprecedented in gaming. This map is so big and so detailed it literally could (and I would argue, SHOULD) provide a virtual world for use in other games - like leasing a hosting platform, they could realistically license this virtual world as a commodity and allow other studios to create new stories, themes, etc, in this world. I would love to see / do more in this world.This game really takes everything that was already great in the second game and makes it even better, more elaborate, and immersive. You definitely don't need to have played the first or second one to enjoy this game; really, it may just make some parts of the story line being continuous and making a little more sense right out of the box. And obviously, playing the earlier games will help you enjoy the 'saga' of the storyline. However, within a couple of minutes, you get the hang of everything anyway, and a couple of minutes after that you're just totally immersed in this game anyway.Buy it. This one's worth having and playing... it's just a spectacular game!
summary: Best game developed in game-world to date, period

I've been a big fan of Assassin's Creed since it was released and enjoyed the improvements Ubisoft has made every step of the way.  AC:B surpassed AC2 in a lot of ways, even with its revisiting the same time frame and characters.-Combat was drastically improved to allow quick kill chains that let Ezio literally decimate mass groups of enemies, with still requiring defensive knowhow to be truly effective in combat.-The transition between animus and real time encounters was done much better, letting you explore both worlds at your convenience.- Achievement hunting improved a lot with all the various maps and map markers that appear as your progression increases through the game and it doesn't feel like a chore, as it did in other AC games.- The tunnel system definitely takes away some of the boring long runs and climbs you have to do between areas to get to objectives, keeping you more focused on the action rather than the grind.- Multiplayer is incredibly fun and addictive.And of course, it sets you up for the big Assassin's Creed 3.

Best Assassins creed game to date and I can't wait for the next installment.Story: continues exactly where ACII left off. You are Desmond trying to escape the modern day Templars. You find a new location to setup the Animous and continue going through Ezio's memories. Ezio starts off where he ended in ACII trying to escape the guards. You take on the Templars and their allies the Borgia. The story continues in Rome.Gameplay: Similar to ACII, you take on missions that advance the plot, and various side missions, such as viewpoints, setting up guilds, finding flags and treasures, rescuing citizens, taking down Borgia towers, etc. The difference in this game is that after you destroy 15 Borgia towers, you can then recruit and train new assassins. You can level them up by sending them on time-based missions throughout Europe. You don't actually see the missions, but you find out the results. The success rate is determined by a percentage you are given based on the number of assassins you send, and the difficulty of the mission. You can reach 100% success if you send enough assassins. Some missions require max level assassins to complete. You can use them in real time by calling on them to assassinate and aid in combat. Like in ACII in the city of Monteriggioni, you can invest in Rome, buying and renovating buildings, shops, adding paintings, etc. and collect the extra amount of income earned from the upgrades at any of the banks around the city. Leonardo is back to help you again with inventions and upgrades. Some of the new weapons include poison darts, a crossbow, and the ability to pick up and use heavy weapons after an upgrade is purchased. You can now ride horses in the city and initiate horse-based assassinations. Stealth still has a role in this game, though not to the extend of AC or ACII. You can still use groups, benches, haystacks, etc. to hide in but unless your wanted level is high, the need to blend in is minimal. The ability to move throughout the city has never been easier with quick access to roof tops using merchandise lifts or using a tunnel system to get from one point of the city to another instantly.Multiplayer: AC:Brotherhood is the first game in the series to feature a multiplayer mode. The players are Templars in training at the Abstergo facility. They use the animi seen at the beginning of ACII to access memories of old Templars and to acquire their skills using the "bleeding effect". Eight game modes total; Wanted, Alliance, Manhunt, Chest Capture, Advanced Wanted, Advanced Alliance, Escort and Assassinate. The different maps include the areas from ACII and brotherhood like Florence, Rome, Castel Gandolfo, Siena and Mont Saint-Michel. Stealth is a major part of multiplayer. You must hunt down targets while being hunted yourself. You earn points by performing assassinations, defending yourself, getting bonuses or completing certain objectives. You can level up in multiplayer which allows you to unlock rewards by earning experience points during the matches and gaining new levels. You can unlock abilities, perks and streaks. Abilities can be used again only after a cool down time, perks can be equipped before the match and they are active all the time, while streaks are bonuses awarded for reaching certain number of successful or failed contracts.Conclusion: Controls are fluid and easier than ever to use. Both the story of Ezio and the story of Desmond advance in this game. I look forward to the conclusion of Ezio's story in next installment, called Revelations. Multiplayer is shockingly good and well thought out. The AC series is one of my favorite and I would recommend this to anyone.
I enjoyed this game. I prefer ACII overall, but this was a nice filler for Ezio's story :) I did wish I could travel to other cities like in ACII but nevertheless, exploring Rome was fun.

Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood is an incredible game.  This game is a great sequel to Assassin's Creed II, as it picks up right where that game ended...and does so without missing a beat!  This time around, you spend your time in Rome, rebuilding the city and undermining the corrupt leadership with a team of assassins at your disposal - assassins that you recruit and oversee yourself.  Much like the previous game, there is tons of gameplay if you take advantage of the many side quests.  As with the past two games in the series, this game makes you feel like no other game does.  Sneaking up on someone and successfully assassinating them is not easy, but you feel like you've accomplished something incredible when you've done it.  The mini in-game cut scenes are great to watch, and don't ever get old.  Running around the city and pouncing on unsuspecting guards is just a blast, and the guild achievement system adds to the fun by encouraging you to employ many different means of assassination, etc...If you haven't played any of these games, do so.  Any of the three would be a fine stand alone game without having played the previous game, but Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood is even better if you've played through the story in the second game.  Choose one of the three and play it, you'll be hooked.

Obviously this game was put out as a way for Ubisoft to make some money.  I don't know that there is enough updates that is required a whole game, but that pretty much goes for all the Assassin's Creed games.  I generally don't pay too much attention to story lines in video games as they get confusing, and this is no different.  I've played all of the released AC games and although there are some new things added to the game, I feel they all could have been sold as downloadable content.With that being said, the game follows the same course ass the prior AC games and you get to buy "businesses" such as doctors, banks, and so on.  It is an open world game, at least after all the areas are collected.  I enjoy being able to run around aimlessly and do what I want, which this game allows.  I'm stupid in I'm a sucker for running around collecting things, and this game has flags like prior games, yet I was finding them in missions in caves, buildings, etc.  So when I was done, I was disappointed to find out I was still 9 flags short and I didn't want to take the time to look up what buildings I would have had to return to to find them.All in all though, the game is fun and if you liked previous AC games, you will enjoy this game as well.

I think the biggest mistake that reviewers can make is to review a game too early. ACII Brotherhood is probably the most amazing example of this, as, had I reviewed it a day before yesterday, I would have been raving about the most amazing game of the year and showering it with praise.Sadly it's not that and there's specific reasons for this which I will get to.Before I do though, I guarantee that my review will get lots of '0 out 100 people find this useful' type votes from folks who simply disagree with my thoughts, or have yet to experience the last two sequences. And well I'm prepared to take it as I feel this game could and should have a been a five star game across the board but it isn't and I think information is key so let me get to it...I reviewed both AC1 and AC2 sometime back and loved them both; AC1 for what a new franchise that brought a lot to the table and AC2 for taking the budding seeds of the first and building a majestic tree out of it. With Brotherhood things start off so well with Ezio continuing where AC2 left off in Rome and yet the game manages to cram a whole bunch of new stuff to find and do. And boy is there a lot of terrain to explore and things to collect - an area many times bigger than the biggest of AC2. Plus, since you can now purchase and upgrade buildings you're literally changing the face of your environment. This is especially true when you begin to repair the aqueducts which in turn will allow you to get to areas that are physically unreachable even though they're in your current 'memory sequence'. There's more though - you have a horse at your disposal which you can call at anytime and, most impressively, you have a crew of trainable assassins ready to aid you in your quests. The upgrade system for both yourself and your cohorts works beautifully; when they're out on missions they're unavailable but when they return they're stronger and more powerful thanks to distribution points you can spend on them. Not only that you can select them to go any missions which will specifically reward you with items which can be traded for treasure maps and so on. But there's even more, shops can but upgraded and fast travel points can be opened, and you can even buy landmarks all of which will increase your income allowing for even heftier purchases. It's all so smooth and simple yet so addictive. If you loved all the stuff you could do in AC2 then you'll be in heaven with AC2:BH.So, I was gutted when I reached sequence 8.I'm not going to spoil the plot for you but I will spoil the game. Once you reach Sequence 8 all logic is thrown out of the window. Everything you have done up to this point was... pointless. For the most part, your only weapon is a silly sci-fi piece of nonsense totally out of keeping with what has happened up to that point and it actually takes away your health to use it. This makes it kind of tricky to do the missions where you can't lose health, by the way. Oh and your health now magically recharges even though it hasn't before in Brotherhood. It gets worse, much worse. Your Assassins, which you may have spent hours getting to Level 10 cannot help you at all for no apparent reason, you cannot use ANY of your weapons or your health vials, your poison, your skills or indeed be able to free roam.I'm not kidding.And then the killer - Sequence 8's missions dictatorially flow from one to the next. There's no option not to take the next mission, just hit (A) to accept. And it goes on and on and on. When playing these sequences I desperately wanted to just be thrown back into Rome so I could complete some of the earlier quests but you don't get that option until you complete the game in what is now a linear frustrating pile of junk. Gone are the wonders of Rome and its amazing free expansive experience, only to be replaced with silly cutscenes and very limited time missions which were very unpleasant to play. It feels rushed, like the devs had run out of time and that's exactly what happened. But you continue to the end just so you can go back and do the missions and collect the items that you missed. But what's the point of doing that when you know it ultimately boils down to the last two god-awful sequences?To add salt into the wound, since you can no longer leave the animus once the game is complete you will miss a vital collection quest in the current time which is not returnable to. So unless you do that optional quest before entering the final phase of the game, you actually would have to start a new game just to get 100% completion and reap the achievement.So with AC2:BH you need to think of it much like the tastiest pie you've eaten, but unfortunately about 80% into it you suddenly realise it was full of bugs and was rushed to bake in a dirty oven. When that happens you don't remember how good the pie was up until then... you think 'urgh that pie was awful and I wouldn't eat it again'.I don't give out 1 stars lightly, especially on a deservedly lauded franchise like AC. Clearly massive amounts of time was spent making the world of AC2:BH amazing to romp around in and enjoy.But I cannot forgive the ending sequences and I doubt you will be able to either.

Active Life Explorer is like no other game I played before because it comes with a mat.  In the game you travel to different missions and have to do things like cross a falling bridge, dive down into the ocean and unlock a porthole, duck under bridges while jumping over holes - there really is a lot to do in this game!  There are 24 themed activities (jungle, western, underwater, snowy, and more) to complete and explore.First you choose your journey and amount of players you want.  My favorite is the Treasure Adventure, which stars you as a treasure hunter who has to accomplish tasks to open up new lands to find treasure on.  You also talk to villagers and learn tips and secrets!  Next there is Free Play, which is where you pick from the 24 games, set the difficulty, number of players and then try to get the highest record in the game!  Free Play is great if you just have a few moments to play and want to release some energy, or want to compete against a friend in a quick match!  Party Mode is the next journey and you can play with up to 8 players in 20 rounds.  You can choose a Quick Game or a longer game - you do obviously have to take turns with 8 players!  The Treasure Room is where you can try on new outfits, check your medals and times, and more.  Finally there is Treasure Trials, which you select your skill on and choose which Trial to conquer.  This journey has different games that you have to complete in a certain order to become a master hunter and unlock new content.The first time I played this game I was so out of breathe and couldn't believe how much of a workout I was getting from a game!  Most of the movements are walking in place, running in place, jumping, and tapping certain arrows with you hit or hands.  Yes you do use your hands!  For example, one of the activities has you running through a island and you have to run, jump, and use your hands to touch the top arrows on the mat to simulate ducking!  Now what is really nice is each activity has a quick description on what buttons you use, how to play, and the difficulty rating.Overall I really like this game and can't wait to play it with more players!  It is also as easy or hard as you want it to be.  For example, I set up the game where you have to run in place and cross the falling bridge and my son and the 4-year-old neighbor had a blast running on the mat.  It really gets you and your family up and moving, and all in some healthy competition!  I also read that you can use the mat with a few other games right now including XX.  If you already have the mat, you can also buy this game separate.  Active Life Explorer is such a fun and different game that is definitely different than just using the Wii Balance Board since you have more movements you can do and that you can have two players on the mat at once!
summary: Very fun and gets you moving!
